title: How might we design an accessible election experience for everyone?

young_people_living_abroad.description: In April I am going to vote for the first time for the election of the next French president.
young_people_living_abroad.creator: cae7f41d64c7a491c186c6ff3512e59e

comments.text: Hi Marie,I also live abroad. Ten years ago I missed a presidential election because I did not register at the consulate in Singapore and realized it even too late to vote by proxy. I felt really bad.Since I've been living in NY I have been more careful. A few days ago I thought of your inspiration as I received an email from the consulate offering me to vote either by mail or electronically for the June "legislative elections"... I can also go to the polls set up by the Consulate. It's the first time I heard we had an electronic option in France. Also I found useful the push from the consulate. Of course, you first need to go and register at the consulate (which I hadn't done in Singapore) but when this is done, they do contact you with reminders. cheers,al

I believe we already have something established for traveling voters.  The first is absentee ballot; you apply for it, then the Registrars Office sends a ballot and you can cast your vote BEFORE the election day.   So long as you sign the return envelope and it's postmarked before the deadline date, then your vote is counted as current on election day, or delayed if it arrives at the Registrars Office after the election day.  If it's too late to apply for an absentee ballot, then you show up an any polling place on election day to enter a "Provisionary ballot."   Your vote is counted last  after they've confirmed you had not entered a vote else where at another polling place.  If you voted twice, your vote is rendered void and doesn't count for that election.  Though its a criminal act to vote twice, I've never heard of anyone being prosecuted for it.

young_people_living_abroad.title: young people living abroad

one_click_online_voting.description: Simply head to vote.gov each election season, log-in with your identify-verified account, and place your vote!
one_click_online_voting.creator: 5e68c6c782a69134b1f3f507f490d3f4

comments.text: Hi, think you are on to something and I like the ideas added by users to incorporate more functions for vote.org. The actual voting situation might need some privacy thinking, how to guarantee free and private votes?

Of course, issues of software security and privacy will have to be addressed before online voting can be implemented.  It took only 36 hours for University of Michigan computer scientists to hack and totally compromise the integrity of a trial online voting system in Washington D.C.  Some good ideas are being discussed in the comments on Stefan Ritter's Concept page: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/opensource-voting/

Jakob and Eric,Thanks for the excellent points. I hadn't heard about the UMichigan trial of the online voting platform. I'm glad this sort of thing is being tested! I like Stefan's points about the strength and speed of open source development as well, I'll add my thoughts there.

Hi Rachel,I like the idea of mixing education and information with easy vote. My first thought when I saw "one-click vote" was but if I make a mistake. I think it's great to facilitate the process but you also want to build in some time for reflection... I know the "one-click" was about the ease of use and access, but I thought I'll share this thought with you. For example, on amazon, I never use the one-click option because I don't want to make a mistake. But I'm only one type of users, and maybe 2 options would be great. This leads me to another point: thinking about the interface and the actual voting experience.I was also trying to figure out how the interface would look like... There might be some interesting built upon other concepts which are focusing more on the interface. thanks,al

Hi Anne-Laure,That's a really good point and example. It was Amazon's one-click purchasing that inspired us in the first place. We definitely need a way for voters to change their vote, in case they've made a mistake or change their minds. One suggestion that came up in our openstorm was allowing the voter to change their vote at any time before the election closed. I think having this flexibility, as you've suggested, would also encourage less decisive voters to cast their vote, knowing that they could change it later.The point about interface is a good one as well. We most thought about the system; but I think the same concept is a great fit with many of the ballot interface designs that have been proposed.Thanks for the feedback!

Daniel and Paul,Thanks for the feedback and suggestions! This is the first I've heard of the Voter Information Project, they have a slew of great tools that should definitely be publicized and promoted by states. I also like the idea of vote.gov being a resource for election officials as well as voters. It only makes sense to centralize all of that communication. I've updated the concept to reflect these great builds.-Rachel(Member of Cornellopenstorm)

I love the focus of this idea on creating a one-stop-shop for voting for users. Government should be more citizen-centric! Since elections are run by the states rather than the federal government in the United States, you may want to think about what it would take to get this started. What might be some steps that can be taken in the short term to create a site like Vote.gov?  (e.g. making it easy to register to vote online, find a sample ballot, and vote absentee) How can it leverage existing tools like the Voter Information Project (http://votinginfoproject.org/) or the Overseas Vote Foundation (https://www.overseasvotefoundation.org/)?
Agreed Daniel - If such a site could be officially established it could be the vehicle for your 'best practice' site too
That's a good idea. Maybe a few different concepts could be rolled up into a vote.gov website.

one_click_online_voting.title: One-click online voting

together_communal_educational_voting.description: Create a system of communal voting discussion "hubs" to relieve anxiety around voting through educated, focused, yet informal dialogue.
together_communal_educational_voting.creator: c0a9a035dc99c5f6b130fab1275b5625

comments.text: Glad to see you've reposted this Matt! I love the story and I do hope you think about prototyping a website or app for people to connect over the issues they care about (potentially even during Concepting so that others can try it out and give you feedback!). I wonder how you could "bake in" accessibility features as well, like being able to use screen readers on the website, or an app that uses touch and vibration to help direct users to their nearest Communal Education Voting event? For inspiration, you might check out Daniel's post http://bit.ly/wh13oG. Can't wait to see how this evolves!

Thanks!  Yes - great connection you've made.  I looked at Daniel's post and it insights my imagination as to how this idea could become truly accessible for everyone!  Exciting!  I will keep thinking about this and keep you posted as it develops....
Nice one Matt. You can update your post with new ideas at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right of your concept.
Excellent!  Will plan to add content as this dialogue progresses!

Can you give some examples of the issues that can be discussed during the debates? I am very optimistic about the concept, but would it be used by people trying to brainwash their friends?It would also be good to try to defend an opponent idea of your own. I remember doing this in high school, and it was so open minding!

Hi Cansu,Thanks for your thoughtful input!  In this concept, the discussions would be framed by local election issues : propositions, candidates, etc.  I hope that people wouldn't be brainwashing their friends!  :)  But you bring up a good point : maybe there could also be a forum on the website that would allow people in the community to post on an issue, and these posts would be rated by users for accuracy, attention to the subject, etc.  This way, well-informed and structured synopses could rise to the top, while more biased responses would carry less weight.Do you have any ideas about how to make this functional and beneficial?

I would motivate people to discuss about a topic that they are involved daily within their neighborhood, such as the frequency of garbage collection, the gardening duties, the new shopping mall nearby etc. I am a bit inspired by a type of Turkish cafes, where old, retired men go and do nothing except playing backgammon, drinking tea and talking about politics (http://bit.ly/wDjdxm). As they think they save the world, they might be ignoring the problems in their own community. You could apply the same concept to schools and encourage young voters to debate on topics within the school, and suggest solutions.Anyway the topic can be defined by the debaters, it is our duty to make it functional. May be it is better to think of a scenario and find out what those people actually have in common. For instance, if they live in the same community, they might be sharing a bus together. In that case, you would 'announce' the event in the bus rather than a website. Do you think of brining people who do not know each other together?

Hi Cansu,These are all great questions / proposals.  In general, I would like the format to be loose enough to be utilized and best applied to any context around the world.  While getting together in my friend's flat with 30 friends may work well in San Francisco, this may not be the best approach in a village in East Africa, or an urban center in India.  Ideally, I think the system can go beyond simply "discussing elections" to actually bringing diverse peoples together in community.  Thus I would hope that people who don't know one another can come together and share their thoughts, opinions, beliefs.  This will allow the process to become both dynamic and transformative for a country, a community, and an individual.  This model could be applied in a school, a community center, a bus, a home... the possibilities are endless.I appreciate your reference to Turkish cafes, and see great potential for people sharing/learning in this context.  Any other platforms for marketing this idea that come to mind for you?Thanks for your input!

together_communal_educational_voting.title: TOGETHER: Communal Educational Voting

comments.text: Hey Ashley - funny, you made me think of the underground here in London and the shops at Piccadilly Circus.On the tube, we sometimes hear an announcement (in the most British fashion!) repeatedly saying "please note that flash photography is not allowed on the underground" specifically directed to a group of tourists. The tourists themselves couldn't be more oblivious to the message, taking as many photographs as they can - simply because they can't understand a word of the very polite Englishman... The shops in Piccadilly are much more efficient at that, announcing in-store deals in Italian and Spanish, the largest populations of tourists in London. It's indeed about being personal, as is also about the right message in the right situation. Thanks for sharing your story

This makes me think of a lot of the conversations I read back in the vibrant cities challenge. Techno wizardry isn't always the best answer... sometimes you just need a person that understands you. Thank you for sharing this!
Thanks Mike!
Great story about the importance of human interaction Ashley. And interesting spin on looking at the challenge from this angle.
Thanks Vincent!

electronic_voting_in_brazil_engaging_the.description: The Electronic voting system in Brazil makes use of visual aids and colour coding to help the country's illiterate voters taking part of the democratic process.
electronic_voting_in_brazil_engaging_the.creator: b17f0e05aacd84d67f5f80334efdd9f0

comments.text: Deleting my comment doesn't change the fact, you're proposal will encourage voter fraud.  The authorities who regulate voting would never allow it.

Tony, I'm sorry you misunderstand the OpenIDEO process.If a concept arises from this inspiration, as I suspect it will, then we will happily discuss any point you would like to raise.During the inspiration phase, as I'm sure you can see, we welcome any ideas that will get us thinking about solutions to the problem set.Having read the comment posted on your OpenIDEO profile I think you could turn that into an inspiration warning against discrimination.Hope you will participate in the rest of the process, perhaps even adding a concept of your own during the next phase.

Wow, seems like this has really simplified the voting process, making it easier for many people (illiterate & literate), though there's room for improvement (i.e. providing features like audio for people with visual impairments).Thanks so much for sharing Luis!BTW, out of curiosity, I'd love to hear your insights on how mandatory voting is run & enforced in Brazil?

Hi Vincent, indeed loads of room for improvement.About mandatory voting and enforcement that's an interesting point. It's not really enforced in a very meaningful way. Justification for not turning up to vote (say if you are travelling abroad or simply busy on the elections day) is fairly easy and can be done in post offices or some other public buildings within a certain period before or right after the elections. Fines for not voting or not justifying within the right period) are also very low (about US $ 5 depending of how many elections you missed). The government also makes it harder for those people to renew expired documents (I couldn't renew my passport before sorting this out after missing a couple of elections while abroad, for example). Not voting and not justifying the reason with the Brazilian electoral body for more than 3 elections could also prevent people to apply for public jobs, benefits and some other bureaucratic issues. Public servants can be prevented to get paid too. I just checked online here and apparently 80% of people able to vote (anyone above 16 years old) turn up to do it.

Hi Luis, I find compulsary voting to be pretty scary as well - if someone wants a vote I feel they need to convince people to vote for them. You seem to have some reservations yourself on that matter? It is interesting though, to look at the major ideological gap between making voting accessible and making voting compulsary, one of which puts the onus on the authorities, and the other on the people.

Compulsory voting in Australia generally works very well (I have included an inspiration about it.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/compulsory-voting-the-ultimate-freedom-of-choice/ ). In fact the mandatory voting process in Australia puts equal onus on people and authorities. Those who can easily cast a vote are expected to do so, and almost everybody accepts this and complies. Those who find it difficult (elderly, those with various impairments or those in nursing homes and hospitals, those in remote communities) are catered for specially - usually by having polling officials visit them. Clearly if you have optional voting then visiting nursing homes may be a fruitless and costly exercise - if voting is compulsory it makes employing someone to visit nursing homes a worthwhile exercise.

It is the question of civic right vs civic duty that I would have difficulty with, as per the views of moral philosophers such as Amartya Sen and particularly Martha Nussbaum, who advocate that people should be made "capable" to achieve certain core rights, rather than have a duty to carry them out.  In the USA, the Amish community do not participate in voting but have no problems with other groups so doing. Perhaps there are no problems with this issue in Australia, but I think a number of younger states with fresh collective memories of some form or oppression (perceived or actual), would react against a compulsary system, so to universalise this approach would be difficult.There do seem to be some questionmarks about how effectively it works in Australia, as the illegality of informal voting is only unenforced beacuse it is "unenforceable" (nobody can see what happens in voting booth - although this would be enforceable under an electronic system which would make informal voting a transparently definitive act).  A group of RMIT researchers including Derek Chong (in an article "It's an evil thing to oblige people to vote") also maintain that such a system crowds out minority parties, such as the Greens. They also point out that the system allows larger parties to target marginal seats because of gauranteed turnout at thier "safe" constituencies.

Thanks for the discussion Eoghan. Do you have a reference to the article?The point about "safe" seats is interesting - given that the former conservative prime minister actually lost his 'safe' seat to the labor party in the 2007 federal election and the same seat swung back in 2009.As for the legality of informal voting - that too is interesting. I haven't spent time researching all the case law but what I have read relates to cases involving those refusing to cast a vote. I would be interested to see legal argument regarding casting informal votes since as you say formal votes are unenforceable There is a strong common sense argument that not marking the ballot paper or ranking every candidate equally is expressing a voters preference for no particular candidate.All of the literature I have so far seen avoids the issue and simply describes what constitutes an informal vote and once established that vote is excluded from the count. The fact that it is termed a 'vote' lends some weight to the argument for its legality.

Eoghan - to your point of compulsory voting, I think there is an important point which may have passed unnoticed. There is a "void" key on the machine and people can simply cancel their vote if they wish to do so. So, simply put, "going to vote" is compulsory. "Voting" is actually optional.

Thanks for this update Luis - I have also found a reference in one of the articles connected to Tim Noonan's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/ - the reference actually says that with telephone voting a voter must be allowed to void the vote (or in Australian terms make it informal). Hence as I mentioned before and as you point out in Brazil: what is 'required' of the citizen is to turn up and cast a ballot - what you choose to do in marking the ballot paper or using the keyboard is entirely free choice.Almost everyone accepts some rules for society, obeying road rules is a common example, compulsory voting need be no more restrictive of freedom than that - it is certainly a long way from coercion to vote in a particular way.
Great global insights here, Luis! And raising the issue of effective promotion and awareness building for new procedures is inspiring too.

Hi Meena, thank you!Indeed the campaign to raise awareness is pretty nice, i couldn't find videos with English subtitles. As TV sets have a high penetration in Brazilian households (even the poorer ones), they become quite effective too.
Hi Luis, One way to add subtitles to a video is with the crowd-sourcing site http://www.universalsubtitles.org
Thanks for the tip Whitney, this is a brilliant website! I guess (hope!) that people can get the point I made even in portuguese as it's all about how visual / engaging the videos were. Many thanks!

I can see why it would be a bit controversial, but it seems like the gains in usability and accessibility far outweigh the loss. I love the simplicity and the visual aids especially confirming your choice by showing a photo of the candidate (or maybe a party logo or some other useful symbol).

Hi Christian, Indeed the visual aids and the simplicity of the voting machine are the interesting things from it. Making it simple also makes it cheap to produce the machines which is also a great thing for the already high logistics cost.

Thanks for that Luis, it was illuminating., and interesting to hear it has been a success in Brazil  There was an e-voting experiment prototyped in Ireland a few years back which failed miserably - the lack of a paper trail and hence a cross-check of the success of the system was considered a major concern, as well as the overall cost.  Also, the excitement of the count, the tallymen(people) staying up all night, the recounts was something that voters and media both saw as a major loss.  It is interesting to see its perceived benefits elsewhere, based on the simplification of the process for the people using it

Hey Eoghan, thanks for the comment. Mind you, 'perceived' success is as far as I'd say it goes. The voting system in Brazil is highly controversial and was much debated at the time of implementation back in 1996. Allegations of corruption permeate the system and until the last elections in 2010 we are told stories of candidates who surely voted for themselves and after the final count have received "0" votes.

comments.text: Have you seen this concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voting-is-about-your-future-teaching-children-also-changes-parenets-behaviour-.../Seems like there is an opportunity to collaborate in some way. Will post something similar over there.

Hey Dan, i also like what u suggesting about involving people with disability as well in the whole process. I have been wondering how difficult it is for people with disability to vote for the first time, this concept would be very helpful at that early stage as well.Thanks
oops , i mean involving them from younger stage !

Nice one Mamta. I like the way you've envisioned alliances between schools and other organisations. Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add the posts from your Virtual Team list to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get email notifications and are likely to come and join the exciting conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)
Hey Meena, thanks, i followed as you mention ! yes i love creative company just like all of us !

Hi Mamta, I think that your concept would right fit into http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voting-is-about-your-future-teaching-children-also-changes-parenets-behaviour-.../Lets leverage and join forces!

This is a great concept and I can imagine some version of it being plugged into other concepts being worked out here. I love the idea of combining aspiring voter education with assisting people with disabilities. Bringing in schools, community centers, and other programs as institutional supports is also important. One possible next step could be to think about how aspiring voters who have disabilities could also be worked into the process. I also wonder if it's worth thinking about how the web could be used to facilitate pre- and post- election connections, training, and preparation for the next election.

Hey Dan, it felt like  a crazy idea to myself, but had to get it out ; ) my only concern was how do we ensure that children are mature enough to handle the responsibility, but then i felt when people face differently-abled citizens, its difficult not to empathize, not matter how careless or lazy a child is ! I think lets trust the adolescents and give them a chance to take up the responsibility and i also think it would create very interesting peer pressures on those youngster who don't vote ! Just wild thinking. Thanks .

I think you're right not to worry about that issue quite yet. And, there may be a way to take advantage of programs that already exist where kids or teenagers are already helping the elderly or people with disabilities (I recall doing that kind of thing with my local Jewish Community Center when I was younger).Also, using already in place institutional structures will help insure quality. If going through a school, it might take a special after school program or some module in high school civics/social science education. But libraries, museums, community centers (e.g. YMCA, Boys and Girls Club) and other after school programs might provide a better venue.

comments.text: Empathy is a must-have tool for a poll worker, that's a nice finding Lucy! I guess, training a completely stranger to build up empathy towards disabled people would take so much time, effort, money.. etc. Wouldn't it be great to take the advantage of people who are already trained to understand and perfectly communicate with blind, deaf, elderly.. groups? People who currently work in rehab centers and so on. In deed, elections happen in 1 day or let's say in our concept in some few days, then using already trained people would require less effort.

Great idea Lucy  and perhaps others here can chime in with other ideas for Empathy tools which might be added to your example. We're anticipating discussions to flourish here and your ideas to evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.
Folks might get further ideas by checking out our Personas post: http://bit.ly/vote_personas Looking forward to hearing what they inspire!

duties_of_a_poll_clerk.description: After seeing inspirations on e-voting, voting by mail, voting from home, a question came up to my mind: 'What are the duties of a polling clerk?'
duties_of_a_poll_clerk.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: No matter how technologically advanced the world becomes, electoral matters just like every other activity will still require manual work. So electoral clerks may reduce in number but will still secure their places in elections no matter what name they may assume in any given geographical location.

You raise a very good point!Having worked as a polling clerk (in Australia) I have seen (but only rarely) family members attempting to influence others votes (principally husbands attempting to influence wives).On these occasions the poll clerk has the job to delicately separate them and point out (quite reasonably) that each persons vote is their own business.In the present system there is the prospect of similar 'interference' when casting postal ballots, but you rightly point out that taking away the relative privacy afforded by the polling booth might increase family or even friendly coercion.Perhaps in America this may be the price to pay for increasing the 'convenience' of the other proposed voting avenues. This may be an inevitable consequence for any society that places too high a value on convenience and instant gratification (my own included).

Thanks for the comment:)  Being a Turkish citizen, I can imagine a bunch of people being pushed to vote for the party that they do not support:S If we are designing for America, can we neglect the fact that people ca try to influence each other? How realistic would it be to ignore, since the concepts will actually become real? I wonder how they deal with this problem in Estonia. Can we create a private environment if we remove the clerks?

Great conversation here guys, and Cansu  thanks for bringing this up. As you'll see in our upcoming Concepting phase, we're going to ask everyone to think about the roll that poll workers play in supporting private and independent voting, as well as what tools we can provide them with to help support them in this endeavor. Stay tuned!
Hi Ashley,i appreciate your active nature in this website and challenges. Please keep it up

duties_of_a_poll_clerk.title: Duties of a Poll Clerk - ensuring privacy

comments.text: Kam - thanks for sending this out. It fired a thought in my head that there are multiple stakeholders that could be used to influence the outcome of the challenge. There has been a lot of focus on posts to date that relate to the stakeholders that are the most central - people with accessibility issues and the organisations responsible for running the voting system. However, there are other sets of stakeholders that we should look at - as you point out, the candidates themselves are key, but there are others as well, such as the media and the various associations that support people with disabilities

Hi Kam  interesting stuff! Perhaps you might add what country you are from in your post? (rather than have folks visit your profile after reading it through) You can do that by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.
Thanks:)

comments.text: Glad you're joining our conversation Drew, thanks for sharing your thoughts. You've uncovered some important questions, some of which we can try to tackle in this challenge. If you haven't already, check out our Guiding Principles for this challenge, particularly the section about Innovating under Constraints http://bit.ly/AiJnLW. Hope to see more of you on OpenIDEO!

Some interesting questions Drew.From the perspective of an outsider the use of the electoral college seems superfluous. at best and unrepresentative at worst.Coming from Australia where we have proportional representation through individual preference voting I personally feel that my representative has been selected by the majority of voters in my electorate.On the issue of numbers of constituents per representative I guess its a matter of balance between the number of constituents per representative and the workable size of congress.

myvote_smartphone_app.description: MyVote is a smartphone application concept designed to enable mobile voting from anywhere in the world.
myvote_smartphone_app.creator: fdc796ef003418e94fbe453634cdcfe8

comments.text: From the 10,000 foot view, how can this product mitigate smart phone access inequality?
Very good idea and simple working flow. My concern is that the data of personal driver's license may be hard to reach event you cooperate with the State or Election office.

This is great for voter registration.  This is terrible for voting, as there is no auditable paper record of the vote. How do you know that the choice you make on your smart phone is the one that will be tallied by the central computer?  It suffers from all the defects of paperless voting.

Here's an interesting development from the New York Times relating to smart-phones and elections. You can't actually vote from this app, but there are a lot of great ideas for the US 2012 Presidential Electionhttp://elections.nytimes.com/2012/mobile/app

Great idea David.  As someone who dreads the long lines associated with voting, this idea completely eliminates that issue.  The app would make voting easier, faster and simply put, a painless process for the voter.  With the current system, people need to leave work or come into work late just in order to vote.  I'm sure this has a negative impact on efficiency and overall work completed.  It also adds stress to the lives of the workers and their bosses who need them in the office completing their various tasks.  This app would allow people to go about their normal lives and still have their voice heard through the voting process.  If this concept comes into fruition, I guarantee a lot more people, especially young people, will vote and vote with pride.

Congratulations David.As one who cannot justify the cost of a smartphone I have largely left commenting to those who are familiar with them. Nevertheless, as Vincent has said I am sure this is a feasible option. I am reminded of the comment, made early in the challenge, that members of the sight-impaired community are keen to embrace the prospect of using smartphones as a means to voting. Taking this into realisation will provide the opportunity to bring your and their expectations to fruition. Hopefully those of us in other parts of the world will be able to follow the realisation of your concept.

Echoing Paul's Congrats. Really impressed with how your visualizations brought the power of mobile voting to life David!Paul, great point on how the assistive capabilities of smartphones have been embraced by various communities.
Thanks guys! This challenge has been an interesting experience, I look forward to seeing the process and eventual results of the Realization phase.Work well ;)
David, Adding my congratulations. The thoughtful detail looking at how something as complicated as registering to vote or marking a ballot could fit onto a tiny screen was very impressive.
I've added a few new screens, looking at the profile area. There are three main sections: personal and contact information, registration information, and voting history.
Nice one, David!
And wohoo  new visualisations to boot  you're on fire!
Thanks Meena! I do what I can ;)

David, the new visualizations/scenarios are really great. Could you do one more thing: use the text from the image as the caption. That way, everyone will be able to follow the story, even if they can't see the great mockups you have done.
Great visualization mockups David! Really brings the potential of mobile voting to life.

Oh, and for what it's worth, here's some more thoughts on benefits of mobile & online voting, and how implementing this is indeed feasible, including in regards to security: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/
Really nice refinements David - great work!
Thanks Ashley! I think this work is a good start for a very complex endeavor. It'll be interesting to see what innovations gain traction for mobile voting in the near future.

I had the same idea... in order to refine it you should check a site related with braille touchpad for smartphones. this will help visual impaired people to vote.... you may found the site on my contribution... good luck =)
Thanks for the advice Christian, if only we had more time! ;)
oh...my bad, im a total newbie here on OpenIDEO...i thought, you can refine your concept anytime you want :S
No worries & welcome, Christian! Yep  time is of the essence  we find it motivates folks to think creatively ahead of the Evaluation phase which starts tomorrow.
I'm not sure you need a Braille touchpad - smartphones have other ways of providing non-visual access through audio and vibration feedback.

well is not mandatory, but using Audio and vibration the usir probably will need some training to use the tool...a braile touch screen may be more natural for voters with visual impairment.in my opnion, the hardware should be adpated for the user special needs and not the oposite.it may sound too expensive, but i`m not thinking in a "general purpose mobile device for visual impaired people", i`m thinking in a special "braile cover" for the touch screen with specific instructions  to show candidates and vote for them, with a sound feedback as you said

Congrats David on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We especially loved the steps you took to outline the interaction a voter would experience when using the app.During this Refinement phase, let's think about how your great mockups might get adapted for different voter needs and abilities. Our Concepting Personas, with examples of different voters, could be a great place to start http://bit.ly/vote_personas. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Great stuff, David! After having many others keen on a mobile voting app, it's great to see someone who has started to tease out the details of how this might work. Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in search terms like "phone",  "mobile" and "app" add that post to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote these various posts will all get email notifications and are likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)
I was wondering how I could tie this effort into the larger conversation, that's rad! I've added a few of the Inspiration posts I referred to while working on these flows. Thanks for the tip Meena!

Also David have a look at the Collaboration Map - you will see the links you have created. If someone builds on your idea their concept will be linked to yours in the same way The focus of the map when you access it is, of course, this concept - the same is true of all the other links in the map so each idea gets equal merit in the network.
Nice, thanks for the tip Paul!

comments.text: Interesting thoughts Tom  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.
Hi Ashley, thanks for the encouragement ... I need to get to grips with the stages of the process so all guidance is appreciated :-)
No problem! It takes time for everyone to learn how our process works  we're glad to have you along for the ride and look forward to your ideas in our upcoming Concepting phase.

Hi Tom, Many states now have "early voting" - with polling centers open for several days or a week leading up to election day. I'm also looking forward to seeing how you might flesh out the concept of voting from "everyday places"

Tom - excellent comments.This makes a lot of sense - especially for the USA.In my personal opinion it would be best of the votes were only counted (or at least no results released) until polls have closed on the west coast. Although having said that early results from Australia's east coast are released a few hours ahead of polls closing on our west coast.Of course even if the time for voting was extended to, say, a week there will still be those who leave it too late but I think, on balance, you would get a better response.If this could be combined with telephone and computer voting then places like public libraries could be included.The basic challenge remains - how to identify voters and recognise that a vote has been cast.

election_day_as_a_national_holiday_.description: An election day holiday = more time, more flexibility + more fun!
election_day_as_a_national_holiday_.creator: 23dac35b99abc54d53b29dd503aae48b

comments.text: Simon Morfit of Pomona?  Fancy seeing you here!  Hope you're doing well.  I'm happy to see so many examples from Brazil in this challenge (I'm a citizen but have never voted there).As you and others have suggested, making voting day a holiday does make the act of voting easier.  This, coupled with other inspirations aimed at simply informing people about existing services for disabled voters could have a huge effect on alleviating the stress and hassle of voting for all people.Does anyone know of examples of voting dress rehearsals to encourage people to know their polling station and what documents to bring?  It would be a tremendous effort and cost but could also help officials learn how to better address the needs of the disabled and, as Jakob and Campbell mentioned below, help celebrate the spirit of democracy.So...two holidays?
Singapore has voting day as a holiday day.That does help on encouraging participation.

Great stuff Simon. It's actually a great point the fact that the elections day - in many countries - is during the week. It really doesn't help people to get to the polling stations! Being a brazilian I always found that quite odd here in the UK and an unnecessary complicating factor for voters. I guess regardless of being a national holiday or simply scheduling elections on a Sunday - when most businesses are closed anyway - it naturally creates this "democracy day" atmosphere that you mentioned. Even in a country where a large part of the population rarely discusses politics like Brazil, the candidates, parties and government proposals become the main topic of the day. Great inspiration!

The other benefit I see of this idea is that voters will get time to talk to friends/family to gather more details on the candidates before casting their vote. Lisa Ball talks about the same. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/information-of-candidate-for-meaningful-voting/

Timing seems important. The holiday approach also highlights its importance, a celebration for democracy!A workaround, not as celebrating: I personally used the possibility to vote in advance in Sweden at a pop-up voting centre on a busy street the upcoming week of the actual voting day.

Interesting post! I would be more than happy to have an election holiday!Timing of the holiday might affect people's motivation to vote as well - If the election holiday is on Monday or Friday, some people may view it as a 3 day getaway. If it's on Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday, people may be more willing to stay and vote.

What a great common sense solution!  Not only does it free up people's time from their job, but it also gives people an opportunity (the time) to volunteer driving a voting truck, shuttling the elderly to voting booths etc.A second benefit of this idea is that children would not have school and would be more exposed to the electoral process.  It helps create a future generation of informed voters. Whether it be through tagging along with mom and dad, or volunteering themselves to help others get to the booth.  The trickle down effect might be really strong when considering future participation.Thirdly, after almost two years of debates and primary elections, (which seem to have a growing negative tone).  A holiday is something to celebrate.  I can see friends having a pre-vote lunch or post-vote cocktail hour.  All in all, i think you are right in that voting should be something worth celebrating with A HOLIDAY!

Campbell, the second benefit really caught my eye! Giving children the opportunity to observe the election process could be more powerful than trying to talk about the importance of election inside the classroom.
Hi Simon also check my post here http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/making-voters-go-away-felony-disfranchisement/

Interesting post about the timing of the elections. It reminded me Jeroen's post on voting in public transports: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-in-public-transport/We also had a conversation in the comments as I was noting that while in France, the elections are on weekends, I have memories of weekends with very low participation because people go away for the weekend. :-)However, I think it does make more sense than during week days and it indeed offer more chances for support for helping others. Thinking about the context of voting as part of the election process is important indeed.

comments.text: Thanks for including some additional and complementary points and links which add weight to a couple of my earlier inspirations.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/compulsory-voting-the-ultimate-freedom-of-choice/andhttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/build-trust-in-the-system-and-achieve-confidence-in-the-outcome/I am convinced that compulsory voting has some distinct advantages and while I am scratching my head to think of ways to get the point across I also realise that this forum has little scope to influence the wider community.One of the strongest arguments for compulsory voting is that it makes supporting disadvantaged voters economic - because the state has as much obligation to provide opportunity as voters have to comply.

early_and_no_excuse_absentee_voting_in_a.description: Flexibility = Great Accessibility. Instead of requiring citizens to physically show up at the polls on one specific day, give people more options - multiple days to vote including the ability to mail in an absentee ballot without needing an excuse.
early_and_no_excuse_absentee_voting_in_a.creator: 3c5a9e3aa2b68d7d01758a4c5a33d584

comments.text: Jim, thank you for sharing this concept. Our research shows that voters with disabilities use convenience voting (absentee and early voting) more than other voters (http://elections.itif.org/wp-content/uploads/Disability-Demographics-6.pdf).As part of your concept, I would encourage you to think hard about the challenges associated with getting these changes made and implemented in all 50 states. You may also think about best practices associated with early voting and absentee voting and what other states can learn from each other.

In looking at this concept and Whitney's concept on a 'best practice' information website template ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/election-web-site-templates-consistent-access-everywhere/ ) I am wondering if there is some way to determine a range of fundamental components to the electoral process, which legislatures (within the US) represent current US 'best practice' in those components and some comparative measure for remaining legislatures.From this a comparative infographic could be prepared (along the lines proposed by  Amanda Drescher in her Infographics to Inspire Change concept from the Vibrancy challengehttp://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/concepting/infographics-to-inspire-change/ ). Such an infographic could be strategically targeted at state level and published generally to encourage multi-lateral discussions of electoral practices specifically.

Hey Paul,i think we can also combine that with Whitney's concept (an his following comments and suggestions) on Ballot Navigator http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ballot-navigator/#c-3c8d022da9f52bf69a1b1759eea75b88 to have this online plateform.I have the impression that there is also a huge opportunity in trying to find solution to ensure that online voting stays anonymous? (we are able to protect sensitive data from companies, i am sure we can dod that for voting)

He would also be neat to begin to pilot online voting with people that don't usually go to vote (that we would have identified with research like the one of Daniel). It would allow to develop an online voting plateform that maximises accessibility for the minority first instead to develop it for the majority of people how design is usually done.When we will extend it to the majority, we will then reach a larger number of voters.

It's also HOW to vote early:  Can you do it online? Just a mailed ballot?Online will eventually be (and already is) the most convenient way to vote.I think the accuracy will be the biggest positive.The thing stopping online voting currently - may be hacking, and/or viruses.  Or for online - does it go to a State or National Data Base?Online voting will help with everyone's flexibility.  You could vote from overseas.  You could vote if you had a language barier.  And you could vote if you had a disability.
Interesting thoughts, Jim. I also thought folks might want to check out this summary of Early Voting from different global locations: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_voting

Thanks for the link Meena - it is, sadly, notable both from this concept and the Wikipedia article that (of those listed) the USA is the most fragmented. As Daniel mentions the challenge (and opportunity) is to assist in bringing all US jurisdictions to a common (preferably 'best practice') standard.

early_and_no_excuse_absentee_voting_in_a.title: Early and No-Excuse Absentee Voting in All States
