johannesburg_blind_voters_left_in_the_da.creator: fa444bfe7b33b1e5d55595291436bd6c

comments.text: Great observations Alice, thanks for sharing this enlightening video!

Almost everybody has access to information and communication technologies such as the internet, mobile phones or television. Every year we can find several new technologies which facilitate human - beings' life. Why don't companies invest in social innovations and social technologies whichelp people with disabilities? We do need a combination of social and technological innovations. Economic and social actors are able to produce new forms of technologies for example 'voting' phones . People with disabilities could use these phones to vote independently from their homes. It would be a new big prooductive area where social and economic organisations cooperate. in the same field!

johannesburg_blind_voters_left_in_the_da.title: Johannesburg: Blind Voters Left In the Dark

voting_a_task_or_an_opportunity.description: While there's an ongoing discussion about how can we facilitate the election process in a smoother / quicker / efficient / user friendly way, the one thing that seems to be a greater challenge is to motivate people to participate / vote.
voting_a_task_or_an_opportunity.creator: 1ca36cc962c17dd262abfabaa734a77c

comments.text: Hi Manjul, this is a great question you've raised. Finding ways to motivate people to exercise their right to vote is an important undertaking. For our purposes here, it's good to keep in mind that we're really focusing more on providing access to elections for people who want to vote, but who are unable to cast a ballot independently due to disability or other limitations. So, while catalyzing communities to participate in an election is related to our challenge topic, we want to be sure to focus our efforts on the question of access. Looking forward to seeing more of you in our challenge!

Hi Ashley,I appreciate the feedback - however, my intention was not to divert the focus but take into consideration the relevance of generating 'user motivation' whilst thinking of ideas to leverage election experience.

It takes even more motivation to overcome barriers, doesn't it. I remember an ad during an election a few years ago that followed a woman using a wheelchair as she got to the polling place. It was a long journey. I found a nice video about the small things that get in the way. I'll post it next.

Its a very important question in those places where voting is optional. By not overcoming the barriers to access the state/country is demotivating electors who are not only eligible but initially interested.According to Wikipedia voter turnout in USA tends to be in the order of 40%, which could be interpreted as USA being less than half a democracy. That's a bit tongue in cheek but it does mean that US politicians have less than 50% approval from the citizens.

It is an important question indeed. In the context of accessibility, lowering all barriers to access might indeed make it easier for people with low motivation. As Whitney noted overcoming barriers requires a lot of energy and motivation, so giving access might also be a way to help increase motivation. Sometimes administrative burdens can already limit access...

I agree, accessibility when created/designed keeping in mind the motivation factor would definitely result in hybrid solutions that will work not just on a facilitation level, but also enhance individual participation at a personal level.
Wow, what great conversation this has sparked! I'm excited to see where this thinking takes us.

This conversation seems to me to be connected with Jakob's inspiraton about universal standards: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/when-the-solutions-for-disabled-becomes-the-new-standard/
Sometimes being forced to do things turns out to be good for us!!

voting_a_task_or_an_opportunity.title: Voting: a task or an opportunity?

see_how_big_stars_asking_people_not_to_v.description: Hollywood big stars made a video to encourage people vote by a interesting way. I've never seen this kind of video before. However, when I saw the video on Youtube, I think is really effective.
see_how_big_stars_asking_people_not_to_v.creator: dd34e49a773017e33be7a9b1d0429754
see_how_big_stars_asking_people_not_to_v.title: See How Big Stars Asking People Not to Vote?!!

primum_non_nocere.description: With fragmentation of national cultural spheres, what does my vote mean outside of  the microcosm of my peers and I? It signifies my preferences and my perceptions; an introverted base for an act that will only deliver if there is consensus.
primum_non_nocere.creator: 0887d47b2d87ec26bd09f25e6b5dfa89

comments.text: Hi Fleur, really interesting thoughts here. What I like most is your point about how we can use elections as an opportunity to connect people and communities, rather than seeing it as another opportunity to point out our divisions and differences. I'm looking forward to seeing how this kind of thinking can inspire our concepts later on.

primum_non_nocere.title: Primum non nocere

voter_friendly_and_interactive_signage.description: This concept is floated to explore the possibilities of making polling place signage  both more friendly to ALL voters and interactive for those voters for whom this would improve accessibility.
voter_friendly_and_interactive_signage.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Hi Paul. Many blind people actually do use GPS to help them find an address. As you probably know, there are a number of low cost GPS apps now available for smart phones. However, not everybody has or can afford a smart phone and when it comes to finding obstacles in our path most blind people depend on a long white cane or guide dog. Both tools provide an efficient (and cheap in the case of the cane) means for detecting obstacles and getting around them. Finally, when I need information that is provided by inaccessible signage and I can't access the information through some othe means, I simply ask a nearby person. It's the cheapest means of all!

Paul, thanks again for doing the hard work of writing all of this up.  As a reference, I also wanted to add a link to the EAC's poll place signage that they make available. Here is a PDF with the images they provide to election officials on request (it is a large file) - http://www.eac.gov/assets/1/workflow_staging/Page/69.PDF

Thanks Daniel when I get time I will look at it.Whitney made a suggestion about near field communication technology apps for smart phones - I wondered if there was a possibility of using this to convey the details of signage and/or obstacles to sight-impaired voters at strategic points on the access route.- I guess if GPS was sufficiently accurate and reliable it could be utilised for the same purpose (my GPS tells me I'm approaching road traffic speed limits and black spots).

NFC-enabled phones (which aren't popular or widely used in the U.S. yet) are for very close proximity (distance measured in centimeters). For example, for mobile payments, it is "tap and pay" so the phone is literally touching the receiver. GPS is probably not accurate or reliable enough right now.

Talking Signs uses infrared to create audio-accessible information for wayfinding. This may not be practical for voting because it requires permanent installation and infrared is typically used on a specialized device, but the concept is interesting. It might be something that could be implemented over Bluetooth (although again, the cost is likely too high).
Here is the link -- http://talkingsigns.com/tksinst.shtml
Thanks for these too Daniel I will try putting my thinking cap on again. I have a small spark but I had better look at talking signs first.

I spoke to my friend Lou Ann Blake who asked around at the National Federation of the Blind for feedback on the talking signs implementation. Some of the problems that have been identified include 1) they are expensive; 2) they require the person who wants to access the information to carry around a receiver; and 3) there is no standardization among systems. The type of transmitter and receiver used varies among the different systems.Some challenges for us to think about...

There are many systems that offer guidance, but (unlike audio loops for enhanced hearing aid) there is no standardization. There have been some research projects on using RFID, but the "last 50 feet" remains a problem in even larger scale navigation. GPS, for example, can get you to an address, but not identify the exact location of the door.

Having visited the Talking Signs site I can understand the limitations of this approach. Again a couple of questions:How do sight-impaired voters navigate access routes now and which aspects are unsatisfactory?Is there technology that gives sight impaired people orientation information - like an audible compass - maybe even an app based on signal strength?My thinking here is a bit "off the planet" but I wonder if such an app could also take your existing GPS position and compare it to the fixed position of building access and compute the path between the two - but again limitations on GPS precision might be too great.Thinking about the information on signs (in general) at the moment there is an assumption that the information is meaningful - for example a sign to assist a sighted person might simply say "Voting Conference in Room 2 on the right". A sight impaired person would need to know if the instructions meant "ahead of the sign on the right, or down the right hand corridor" Besides direction such a sign gives no indication of distance. whether it is up or down etc. - there is an assumption that a sighted person can assess the environment and fill in the detail for themselves.Any audible instructions would need to be far more specific and reviewable. It does demonstrate that friendly human intervention for some things is still probably the most desirable.

Daniel and Whitney - If a ticket dispensing kiosk was located inside the main access door it could both display and announce its purpose.This might allow sight impaired people to approach it to both take a ticket to join the dispersed queue like other voters but once there a message specifically for sight impaired voters could be broadcast.I was thinking that it might have 2 large buttons one embossed with a "T" for ticket and a second embossed with a "?" for additional audio information.This is just preliminary thinking on the run.

If you are thinking about making physical buttons accessible, think about:- Tactile controls that are large enough to press, even with low dexterity or tremor- Spacing between the buttons, so voters don't accidentally press two buttons- Different shapes for each button (round or square and diamond, for example), so they can be differentiated by touch- High contrast (like black on white) labels in 14 pt type- Braille labels that duplicate visual textThat probably sounds like a lot, but it's not really - just making sure that semantic cues are duplicated for every sense.

I wonder if there is more than one solution for different kinds of signage needs. I can think of:- finding the entrance to the polling place- navigating within the polling place- getting set up at a polling station- general instructionsCould floor mats that allow textural discrimination be a way to create a path around the space, for example, from the front door to registration desk? Just a thought.

Good idea Whitney!I didn't see this post until after I was adding comment in the other thread.I had wondered about sight-impaired friendly landmarks of some sort along external access routes perhaps supported by an app based audio file specific to the route but it would involve a lot of work for a temporary building use - unless it could be provided for the regular access to the building for sight impaired people too.

Really nice points Paul  it's amazing how something as seemingly small or unnecessary as signage can make a huge difference (as your example points out)! It made me think of Melanie's inspiration http://bit.ly/zooeuN too. Maybe one possible answer isn't more technology, but a clearer design language, iconography or style? What if signage could include tactile, audio, or other visual cues, to speak to people in a variety of ways?

Thanks for the feedback Ashley - this is all down to Daniel - on this occasion I'm mainly the mouthpiece.Your questions get to the heart of the matter and I will restructure this a little to focus on those three aspects.The biggest challenge here (from my perspective) is how to provide cues to sight-impaired voters that the signs are there in the first place - audible cues would seem sensible but how to make them sufficiently useful and audible to the target audience yet not intrusive or distracting to others.However here in railway stations, airports and the like we have arrival and departure announcements, and aboard trains we have periodic announcements about the next station and appropriate connections - and I guess most of these audible messages are of no interest to the majority yet we accept they are a necessary part of th auditory environment in such places.

Nice job drawing on analogies like train stations, airports etc, where audio cues are the norm. Makes me think of some of our other concepts where the voting space is divided into a quiet section for people who need more focus, time or space and another section that's more auditory or even social.

Good point about quiet spaces too.I have been looking at the ADA Checklist and in particular the diagrams that give me a stylised idea of how convoluted the pathways to actual voting spaces may be.Can anyone tell me please if a school is chosen as a polling place what happens to classes for the day?In other polling places do they co-exist with normal activity?
My guess is that large spaces, like cafeterias or gymnasiums, get used as school-based polling places (as opposed to classrooms that might displace students). But maybe others can weigh in?

Thanks AshleySeems to me that setting up polling places in conjunction with "business as usual" might substantially increase problems with accessibility.I suspect historically it is probably one reason Australia and New Zealand hold elections on Saturdays.

Paul, it varies whether a school is open or closed when it is chosen as the polling place. This decision is often made by the local school district which decides the school year calendar. Some schools are open and Ashley is right that they will typically use a gym. This can present some accessibility issues since the "main" school entrance may be accessible but a side entrance may not be as accessible. Some schools are closed, but of course that presents other problems for parents who now need one day of child care on election day.

voter_friendly_and_interactive_signage.title: Voter Friendly and Interactive Signage

_201c_ease_of_use_201d_.description: While talking to people for my user study on agriculture based projects and Redesign of ATM for illiterates and semi literate users, I got a chance to visit rural India at the time of elections.
_201c_ease_of_use_201d_.creator: 77cfbd410bb1a32c4b63cce4aa4ddbed

comments.text: Thanks Deepak for sharing your observations. It is really useful. I found your point on how most people don't even have access to banking facilities  - and thus the ATM as an analogy might not be the "right" one as suggested in this inspiration:   http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-s-it-like-to-be-blind/Interesting point also about cell phones which are also often assumed to be taken for granted in terms of access and ease of use.The importance of location is also an interesting one: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/where-you-vote-changes-how-you-vote/Mobility might something to be considered: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-in-public-transport/ Indeed as Meena said so much to think! thanks!

Hi Anne,Thanks for your comment, It is very interesting fact that most of the people don't even access to basic banking facility, But we can redesign ATM's and other public accessible mediums accordingly with the people's need.Since it is a notion that people generally fears of new technology , we can also think in this direction as well.I would like to add 1 more point about adoption of new technology.In India adoption of mobile phones among the people took 10 years, very slow. But now its in the reach of common man, and become popular as  a most useful communication medium.Looking forward for others view

Great insights here, Deepak. Lot's to think about here. I was especially interested to note your observation that elections are perceived as being oriented towards urban, educated types. Looking forward to discussion from our community on this notion might be shifted.

_201c_ease_of_use_201d_.title: “Ease of use”

where_you_vote_changes_how_you_vote.description: A Stanford study found that where you vote can influence how you vote. For instance, voting at a school increased support for school funding measures and voting at a church decreased votes for stem cell research.
where_you_vote_changes_how_you_vote.creator: ba1d54060160cefeb885117191c52c30

comments.text: Very clean, simple, and powerful insight Daren.  As someone who studied architecture its easy to see how the space could effect the mood of the person and thus their decisions.  If you want another interesting study on voting behavior, check out this study done by James Fowler.  Its a bit of game theory, but it gives good insight into some other influences (other than space) in voting.http://jhfowler.ucsd.edu/habitual_voting_and_behavioral_turnout.pdf
Thanks for posting your study Campbell. The behavior of habitual voters and casual voters intrigues me. Maybe we could find a way to get the habitual voters to encourage the casual ones.

Very interesting questions you have raised Daren.Far more interesting than the outcome of the Stanford Study.I would be interested to know how important to people are such things as proximity, ease of parking, and size of voting space.Judging by the study Americans are asked to vote on far more issues than Australians. Most of these issues are the subject of parliamentary debate and decision. At election time some of these issues will surface and gain sufficient public debate for candidates to declare their position and gain or lose support accordingly.

It would actually be interesting to know more of how th research was constructed - one inference from the description given is that voters make decisions at the time of voting. Whether this implies a lower level of political engagement in the US than in other places I dont know.
Great points about the influence of location Daren!
Thanks; this is my first post! I'm really energized by all of the great ideas and passion in this community. I've seen a lot of incredible posts from you, including the one featured today.
Welcome to our collaborative community of 20k+ Daren! Hope to be seeing more of you on this challenge and beyond  fab start. (and well spotted  Vincent is an uber-collaborator indeed ;^)

Fascinating piece of research! thanks for sharing! I think you did a great in pointing in important directions to consider:How the location of the polling station might influence the content of the vote? (the school funding and the stem research funding) This is key in terms of thinking of how one can influence the result of the vote.How the location of the polling station might inspire people to vote (or not)? It reminded me the inspiration about voting while commuting: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-in-public-transport/While reading that post I wonder if everyone could have the right focus to think about their vote. That will be an interesting follow up study! :-)Last, about discouraging voting, I guess the environment is partly the location (how easy it is to access? how does it "feel"?) but also other aspects of the environment such as the length of the line that was mentioned in several voting stories. Thanks!
Great questions to keep in mind! Something that I didn't think to consider when voting was the context's influences, but it makes sense.

where_you_vote_changes_how_you_vote.title: Where You Vote Changes How You Vote

your_vote_your_community.description: Election accessibility starts with ensuring citizens have the right information and materials needed to cast their vote. Outreach through community presentations, direct mail, online/tv/print ads, and more ensure a level playing field for all voters.
your_vote_your_community.creator: 9be39b8aa84c91f0f6384fc5dc4540d8

comments.text: @Ginny Redish--I totally agree.

Katie SueYou are absolutely right about everyone needing the right information. And a critical aspect of that "right" is that they be able to understand the information. It must be in plain language -- not just in their language, but also with words they know, short sentences, good layout, and all the other features of clear writing and design.

your_vote_your_community.title: Your Vote, Your Community

a_modern_democracy_is_a_multi_lingual_de.description: The right to vote is a fundamental right guaranteed to all citizens of the United States, regardless of proficient in English as illustrated by Federal law (Sec 203 VRA).  Therefore, any modern voting system must have language access at its heart.
a_modern_democracy_is_a_multi_lingual_de.creator: ec113e80d28e9f953f2858b82fed3ef8

comments.text: A significant issue you've raised here, Carlo  and I came across this link which highlights US Census data indicating where multi-lingual ballots are needed: http://www.fronterasdesk.org/news/2011/oct/13/election-2102-demographic-language-spanish/

Agree with Meena - this is a very significant point, and somewhere in my wanderings to try to understand the US system I came across a similar article to the one Meena has cited.Australia maintains registration and voting information in over 20 languages on its national Australian Electoral Office website as well as 16 telephone interpreter services that are accessible country wide at the cost of a local call. I imagine New Zealand may have similar provisions.It makes me think that there are significant design opportunities here too. Print-on-demand might be a cheaper option for providing information in polling booths or perhaps even using an e-reader (supplied in the booth would be better still). As for ballots in other languages (if they are really necessary) perhaps a re-usable template could be supplied with a normal ballot paper.Lots of possibilities here I think so - thanks for raising such a fundamental point.

Hi Carlos, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

a_modern_democracy_is_a_multi_lingual_de.title: A Modern Democracy is a Multi-lingual Democracy

national_voter_roll_vs_national_voting_i.description:
Some inspirations have proposed changing or eliminating registration/pre-registraion but usually proposed some alternative like an existing National ID Card.
Undoubtedly it is necessary to identify voters and to establish their right to vote.
national_voter_roll_vs_national_voting_i.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: As you consider this option, you may want to reflect on the existing debates in the United States about voter ID (some argue it is needed to prevent fraud, others argue that it disenfranchises voters). You may also want to take a look at this report on the "Identification Divide" that discusses how millions of citizens in the United States do not have a form of ID and the barriers that this creates. http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2008/06/pdf/id_divide.pdf

Thanks Daniel!I shall have a look at your references.As an outsider in an community (Australian) that has rejected a specific ID Card but which has a well organised Electoral Roll I simply thought it appropriate to use the concepting phase to spark debate on this within the challenge. However I find posting comments (blog style) too limiting for the purpose (hence the setting up of the Google document).

The report that Daniel links to above raises a number of issues at the heart of this challenge. How do we create an accessible and inclusive election experience while not sacrificing security or privacy/civil liberties? Especially interesting is the discussion of authentication vs. identification---how necessary is it that we know (and store) who the voter is, vs. simply assuring that each vote is securely and accurately counted?

Thanks for the reply Catherine. As a non-American it is difficult for me to justify expressing some opinions. It is the collision between security and privacy that sets up the tension in the process. The system needs to know who is entitled to vote and that they have voted only once but the individual requires the system respect the privacy of their actual vote. In that regard the current paper ballot based system used in most places works pretty well. - if you can be identified on a list of eligible voters either by giving your name and address (as happens in Australia) or presenting an acceptable form of ID then you are given a blank ballot, practically indistinguishable from every other ,that you can mark (in relative privacy) and place in a sealed container (with relative anonymity). Identification/verification must be linked to avoid multiple voting - I have about 10 polling places within 2 miles (5km) of my house, this is highly desirable from the point of view of accessibility but highly contentious if the system did not record the fact that I (the identifiable individual) have cast a vote and only one vote.As to the separation between recognition of entitlement to vote and the private act of voting current at booth practices achieve this very well, the challenge is to acceptably achieve it in circumstances where voting is moved away from defined and controlled polling places, especially online.While my thinking in drawing up this concept may have been muddled with regard to the variety of American elections I, personally, am still of the opinion that creation of a national voters roll (database), by amalgamating and rationalising the county,state or other voting rolls that already exist would add flexibility and increase accessibility to the voting process.Whether people think a National Voting ID Card is a good idea will depend in part on ideology (including the civil liberties question) and in part on practicality. I, like the majority of Australians, ideologically rejected the Australia Card (National ID Card) but have since realised its practicality compared to the alternatives now in use here. America too seems to have rejected a National ID for the time being but other countries, Morocco, Spain, Sweden, India (to list a few I know of through this challenge), have embraced or are embracing one.To return to my original thinking about this concept I am simply posing the question - would having a national roll or a national id card (for voting purposes) increase voter choice of polling places and therefore improve accessibility for all )including those with disabilities)?

Paul, Excellent analysis of the tension between needing to be able to identify the voter, but keep the vote secret. You are right that there is not a national ID card in the US. That's not something we can change through design, whatever the pros and cons. As I started looking into this, I was very surprised to find out how many people don't have one of the types of ID that are often a stand-in, such as a driver's license. You are also right that a voter registration system that was more centralized would offer more choice of polling place. It requires not only a computerized database, but a way for all polling places to have up-to-date records during the election day (or week). Some of these systems are already online, and more are in progress. The good news is that there is only one registration system for all levels of government, and that voters only have to register once, only updating if their residence changes.  How does Election Day Registration fit into your thinking? In some states, a person can register at the polling place, on election day. And one state - North Dakota - does not require registration at all http://www.nd.gov/sos/electvote/voting/voter-qualifi.html

Well, I can only say that's the actual process in Spain and works very well. A combination of both:  a national ID card and a Electoral Roll. That works but requires voters to make sure they ID card is updated and they appear correctly in the Electoral roll. A easy double check that assures a correct process.

Thanks for this reply Vicen.Can I please ask you a couple of questions about Spain - is voting compulsory? and is where you vote determined by where you live (i.e. do candidates represent particular geographic areas)?

Hi Paul, I'm more than glad to help.In Spain is not mandatory to vote. In fact some ballots have a low participation rate (below 70% and sometimes lower). Regarding geographic distribution. The general election is the same everywhere (the same candidate for all country) but in Spain our representative law is not directly proportional, I mean, depending where you are voting your vote has a different weight ( rural zones have a more representative vote as we apply the "D'Hont" system. Additionally, every region has its own election for regional representatives, these regions are weaker than Estates, but have their own competences (Health or Education among others). I hope it helps, whatever you need don't hesitate to ask :)

Great that you've set up a Google doc as an experiment in extending collaborative discussion Paul. You might find you get more input if you make the link to the doc active. To activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link  Good luck and we're looking forward to seeing how this plays out.

Thanks Meena - I'm struggling with some strange behaviour in publishing concepts that I think must be related to my slow dial-up internet access. The link was structured as active when I published - I will have another go.

Hey Paul, just to jump in  if you're having trouble publishing, would you mind submitting a ticket via the Support tab at the left? We're trying to track down some publishing-related bugs and any details you can share on the errors you're seeing would be helpful. Thanks!
Thanks Ashley - done.

Kudos for highlighting this issue of voter identification Paul!Thinking about the best solution for a national election is complex: national IDs vs. national rolls vs. individual/fragmented documented eligibility proof.It gets even more complicated when you think about the different types of elections (with distinct eligibility criteria): national vs. state vs. local; primaries & caucuses of various political parties.Another way to divide this problem is to attack it in 2 parts: 1) positively identifying an individual, 2) determining whether that individual is qualified/eligible to vote in a particular election.

Thanks for the positive feedback Vincent. The concept is (as you suggest) a vehicle for exploring voter identification and may well morph considerably as the concepting phase progresses. It had its genesis in the relatively stable electoral roll (here in Australia) and the example Sarah gave of using just a national ID in Morroco.Thanks too for the alternative approach to the issue and am considering the possibility of additional concepts.

Hi Paul, I've added some point to your google doc - hope it worked and you can see it. From a user perspective the problem I've always had with the electoral roll in Australia is remembering if I've updated my details on it (I'm from SA, but moved around VIC a lot). I guess the ID card would get around that issue, but if you only use it once every 4 years it would probably get lost at the bottom of my drawer.... Could you combine it with another form of ID that every citizen is issued with? In Australia I could suggest a Medicare card, maybe in the US the social security card?

Thanks Qiu - yes your comments are visible and apt.Your comments here are welcome too - I have usually found here that I have sufficient notice of closing of the roll to be certain I am properly registered, but I can understand regular mobility makes it difficult.Your point about 'too many IDs' is well made - personally I'm not wedded to any sort of ID card but I thought there should be opportunity to discuss it.

national_voter_roll_vs_national_voting_i.title: National Voter Roll vs National Voting ID Card

aggressive_marketing_by_politicians_look.description: When voting is around the corner, one can't help but notice different initiatives that people take in order to conduct a successful voting. Here is my reportage of live-ongoing events covered via SMS's, newspapers, videos, etc.
aggressive_marketing_by_politicians_look.creator: 7f82ce618eb3b2f2d40300a2916de3f0

comments.text: Wow, what a timely real-life inspiration! And great thoughts on what works and what doesn't  definitely all things for us to think about as we head to Concepting.
Thank you Ashley! Infact, this challenge has made me sensitive to the voting initiatives happening in my city, and the timing couldn't be perfect, as India is voting for yet another election.:)

aggressive_marketing_by_politicians_look.title: [ UPDATED ]Following Voting Initiatives in Mumbai, India

blind_person_s_voting_experience.description: A blind person's voting experience tells us how important it is for people with disabilities to use their own tools when they vote.
blind_person_s_voting_experience.creator: b65857c14633e1df40f7cb3c4f8c247d

comments.text: Great inspiration Katsuyoshi! Very important to recognize that people will generally prefer using their own tools which they chose, customized, & are familiar with.For example, I'm sure most people can relate to the fact that they are generally more comfortable with/find it easier to add a new contact # on their own phone, than doing the same on someone else's phone.

Hi Vincent! Thank you for your comment and example.In addition to using your own tools, I think people also feel comfortable when they do something at their familiar place such as home and office. When people need to use new technology for voting, I think we should allow them to try it at their familiar space and to take their time as much as they want. However poll workers are very busy on a voting day, so they can probably offer some kind of pre-training for people on request.

hiii katsuyoshi,you provided useful information!:) and you both are raising a valid point about providing a familiar technology to the people.I had some sort of same idea of an Online/E-Voting system and if we use Braille Keyboards at polling booths with the same system by which blinds can also figure out the keys and can vote themselves, it will be a great help to blind people. Here is the link to the detailed information:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/easy-online-e-voting-system-for-blind-population/For Online Voting System:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/accessible-from-anywhere-anytime/

Katsuyoshi, you make a very interesting point. For a blind person it might be difficult to trust any aiding appliance, or adaptive technology,  since in the mind of the voter its difficult to guarantee that his selection was properly registered. And thats a challenge well need to solve later on.

Terrific local insights  thanks for sharing! Hopefully other folks can weigh in with what it's like in other countries. In the meantime, you might want to check out the video in our 'Understanding the Election Journey' doc http://bit.ly/xd78t5  there's some helpful information there on what accessible voting is like in Los Angeles County.

Hi Ashely,Thank you for your recommendation and sharing the video of Los Angels accesible voting.It is very nice that disabled people can vote without stepping out of their car. Also the audio ballot booth looks really helpful. As a citizen of Japan I think their system is very advanced. I wonder if there's a sufficient number of polling places which support accessible voting as in the video.http://www.lavote.net/Voter/ACCESSIBILITY/Voting_Options.cfmTo install such a system in other places, I think it is very important to make sure disabled people know that there's an accessible polling station and how accessible it is, because they usually have limited access to any kind of information. i.e. How well does this actually work in LA?http://youtu.be/0oYw21juCGYFrom my work experience with several design galleries and museums in Tokyo, I think many venues are accessible but not many people know it. It is pity that even the national art museum of Japan prepared just a brief text-only page to explain how accessible it is:http://www.nact.jp/information/barrierfree.html

blind_person_s_voting_experience.title: Blind person's voting experience

voter_help_hub.description: Voter Help Hub System is a secured network that connects, alerts and coordinates volunteers of areas needing assistance. Information is aggregated from voting survey data indicating disability assistance needs in specific communities to vote.
voter_help_hub.creator: 655112ba0cdb4cc8691b452126aa7f3a

comments.text: Annie, I'm really glad to see this amongst the winning concepts. As I said earlier this can be central to the engagement of people before during and between elections. It has the potential to embrace some of the best elements of other (non-winning) concepts and fit so well with many other winners. Will watch any information coming out of the realisation process with great interest. Well done!

Annie, congratulations! I love the way it engages the entire community in running an election. The power of community volunteers was a strong theme in this challenge and this concept pulls many of those ideas together in an elegant way.

I really like the inclusion of the neighborhood map that enables someone like Leigh to know how her neighborhood's voting numbers stack up to other neighborhoods. I also liked the social media integration, making it easy for Leigh to send out a call to action to her friends! Nice job during Refinement.
americanselect.org does some good work on issues.
Thanks for the link!

Hey T.Annie, i like the way your concept establishes great connections and connectors. I would request you to have a look at my concept - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/national-database-for-rating-voting-system/.I think the voter help hub could take a participatory role in the data collection process and give their feedback in rating different voting systems. Tell me what you think about the concept and how can the database help your vote help hub .Cheers ! Mamta .

Thanks Mamta! Great concept you have as well. I definitely feel the visualizations of information is always helpful. I hope that information from polling centers would collect feedback back into the system in real-time. Incorporating your database and ratings of different voting systems would be useful to know where improvements can be made.

T. Annie, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We loved your focus on tapping into 'people power' to help make elections accessible and inclusive for all.During this Refinement phase, we're eager to hear more about these community volunteers. Perhaps there's even an opportunity to interview some current volunteers (no matter the cause they support) to see if this is something they'd like to be a part of? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Thanks, will do!
Great idea. How will you be sure that the volunteers don't take advantage of the voters that need addition asstance?  Will it require a background check to be considered a volunteer?

At the workshop that developed a similar idea, we thought about a simple self-training program like the training that pollworkers receive. It could include:- Basic training in how to find answers to questions in the election department web site.- Volunteers would be told to look everything up, rather than try to remember details and possibly get them wrong  Use recognition, not recall- They would also learn the boundaries. Their focus is election information, not partisan discussion or advice on how to voter, for example. The training might include role-playing on how to politely deflect a question out of the boundaries.Examples of similar training include Certified Peer-Assistance Counselors for independent living and training on how to work with human subjects in research (such as the online course offered by the National Institutes of Health).There would not be a pass-fail test, but new volunteers would be encouraged to keep trying until they complete enough questions to pass, since the goal is to make sure they have learned what they need to know.
Sending volunteers in pairs will also help with supervision.
Great suggestions to improve upon volunteer training and verification. This will also add upon the reputation of the system too. Thanks!

Cool idea. Like Ubercab for accessibility for elections. This is great for Election Day, but what about before election day? What about early voting? What about helping people get information and connect with election departments in preparation for voting?

I like the volunteerism aspect of getting folks to the polls who need help.  But it would appear the real challenge is changing the actual voter interaction system & this solution doesn't address that.

Great concept! I really like that you've tapped into the power of volunteerism to help connect community members during elections. One sentence caught my eye: "Community members can volunteer and can get rewards from local businesses for volunteering." What kind of rewards might a volunteer get? What kinds of businesses might want to enroll in the rewards program? Funny enough: it makes me think of your winning Vibrant Cities Challenge concept - maybe there's an app component to this that helps volunteers "claim" their rewards? (for anyone who's curious, you can see T. Annie's concept here http://bit.ly/yrf2TR)

It is great to get philanthropic businesses involved in rewarding community members and voluntary individuals who are dedicated to serving the public in any major social event (not just election day alone).  Perhaps, your local Starbucks might help those on duty to be constantly on their toes.  A free caffeine boost is rewarding enough.

Thanks Ashley and Jason! I think a few business may already reward citizens for voting, but making it more formal for those who volunteer can incentivize them to sign up to help. Like you mentioned Ashley, incorporating an app like the buy locally could be a great collaboration to redeem the rewards.

Great visualisations, T Annie. Given it's a very big picture concept you've got going on here  we're expecting lively discussion and questions from the community. Be sure to incorporate developments to your concept using the Update Entry button up there on the right.You might like to start by thinking about how folks who face challenges around language, hearing, speaking and comprehension might contact the hub for assistance. I see that you've currently listed calling in as the option. Would be great to evolve this further to make the system more inclusive and accessible?
Thanks for the suggestions Meena! Hoping to add more to the concept.

And one more thing you might want to check out is our new Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Because great ideas start with people, right?

Hi again T. Annie - I have been meaning to come back here to say what a hugely important and "central" concept this is to the process of helping people to vote.In building on this for one of my concepts I have given your community volunteers some extra complementary tasks. In addition to collecting poll survey data I have given at least some of them the task of collaborating with city government to centralise and map polling place details that can be available online. Together with this, and more importantly, I have suggested they play a part in assessing the suitability of the polling place for access by voters of every need. Finally there may be a role for them, in conjunction with election officials, to monitor and report movements at polling places (queue length, voter throughput etc.) Of course in providing this information generally online it also becomes a resource for the Hub to assist coordinating other activities.As a locally focused group with broader connections each hub is probably ideally placed to implement Mamta Gautam's appointment concept too ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/find-out-book-your-time-slot-/ )

Hi Paul, thanks for coming back to add your feedback. Glad that your concepts tied in more information and responsibilities to the central process as well as for sending me the appointment concept. I definitely think that could be incorporate as well. Thanks! Annie

Hi Annie - one of the things I really like about the Voter Help Hub is that it involves people. That's why I instinctively saw my mapping concept as a component in a broader Information System like Voter Help Hub.

Hi Annie - your hub can be interactively communicated among the various involving parties (or branches) via a Wiki (and preferably using a web-based project management tool like Redmine - see Redmine.org).  Your concept is truly vast as compared to others' crowd-sourcing concept, and having an online Wiki might help facilitate voters to focus and better manage resources.

Very interesting idea. This could be a great complement to some of the community network ideas (Community Clerks, Voting Assistants, Voter Support Network), but adds a really nice dimension around transportation.
Thanks Whitney! There's a lot of great concepts and see opportunities develop them further together.
this is a great innovation; i support it fully
Thanks Rapudo! Please let me know if you have any suggestions on the concept.
Excellent T. Annie!Complementary ideas to Votepools - very comprehensive.

voter_help_hub.title: Voter Help Hub: A Cental System Connecting Voters, Volunteers and Information

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

read_easy.description: Some people find voting to be quite intimidating especially if you have a hard time reading. This often discourages these people from going to the polls, but I have an idea that may alleviate the embarrassment of feeling so lost on election day.
read_easy.creator: 8ae78b3db23dbe9cf7007e3c91b659a2

comments.text: Stephanie, thanks for this great story and for doing these interviews. It can be hard for people who read well to understand the perspectives of those who don't.You are exactly right that people who don't read well can be intimidated -- especially in public with everyone watching.When I've done usability testing of ballots and ballot instructions, I've seen people who do pretty well, until they have to problem solve. Then, they just want to get out of the situation as fast as they can. That's not a good situation to vote in. Having information read in audio form is a great example of a feature that would help many people, for many different reasons. It's one of the advantages of a universal design. If they audio information was "just there" anyone could use it whether they needed help with vision, reading, translation, or just prefer to hear information.

read_easy.title: Read easy

carpooling_to_vote.description: For some, maybe just getting to the voting booth is difficult. But maybe we could create a carpooling system to enable people to come together and share rides to the booth. And better yet, just like the carpool lane, full cars get faster voting.
carpooling_to_vote.creator: 6ca53c38aff4f2024f8442bd320a8ea2

comments.text: Fab thoughts Josh  I'm looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post this again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section of this post as a way to continue building on this with even more inspiration: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire.

No problem! It's easy (and fun!) to jump right to ideas. You'll get the hang of it as you continue to join us on OpenIDEO :)

Hi Jiangxuan, Interesting idea.  It'd be a great way for people to know also if there are any problems with their registration.  If they don't receive an email, it may be a clue to look into their voter registration status before election day.

accessible_public_transportation.description: Buses are now equipped with an motorized platform that allows disabled passengers who are wheelchair-bound to use public transportation. The ramp is usually hidden by stairs for the majority of passengers, until it is needed.
accessible_public_transportation.creator: 3067d61e3de40baca23c6e3503663ac0

comments.text: An excellent suggestion Alvin.We only have a small city (250,000) and I am uncertain if we have any wheelchair friendly buses. My mother-in-law suffered a stroke several years ago so is both wheelchair bound and dependent on assistance for mobility. She lives 400 kilometres away and the only useable transport is wheelchair taxis, when they are available - although her step-daughter did manage to use the horse float (trailer) for two short trips. It would be good to see wheelchair friendly 'long-haul' buses too.I wonder if a fork lift could be used to hoist a special platform to allow entry and exit to high floor buses at terminals. Most terminals will have a small fork lift for associated freight or baggage movement. the front row of seats coulkd be made easily removeable to provide wheelchair space when necessary.

Interesting to note that many global BRTS systems (I covered an Indian one here: http://places.designobserver.com/feature/peoples-way-urban-mobility-in-ahmedabad/12918/) are set up so that everyone boards at level to the bus  eliminating the need for special mechanisms like this. Someone mentioned elsewhere in the challenge  it's great when a solution is so well devised that it benefits most people as well those who might face challenges around accessibility. Something to think about as we move forward...
Oh  and here's an inspiring post I was thinking of on that tip: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/goodgrips-what-s-good-for-arthritics-can-be-good-for-all./

Meena, that BRT system is great! They really thought ahead when designing their public transportation system. I think the major problem for most cities is infrastructure and physical space. I often look at San Francisco's public transport network as an example. I have no idea how the city would ever be able to reconstruct bus stops or dedicate entire lanes for buses/trolleys.

accessible_public_transportation.title: Accessible Public Transportation

demystify_handicap_and_disability_in_soc.description: Many people with a handicap or disability feel excluded from society. A Society that strives to include handicapped or disable people through better services can re-establish a sense of inclusion and increase vote participation.
demystify_handicap_and_disability_in_soc.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: I think this could have a great impact on the general view of society on disability and handicap.  Everyone has a voice and when people feel that their voice is not heard they simply stop voicing it.  This is a situation we never want to be in and helping disabled and handicap people should be a priority and if allocating taxes a little differently solves this issue, I'm all for it.

Hi Yannick, I like your focus on inclusion in this concept. It would be great if you could think about how we can take a manageable piece this idea that we can implement for elections.  For example, what can election officials, with their limited resources, do on or before election day to make sure people with disabilities do not feel excluded?  What can they ask the poll workers to do?  And how can they leverage existing social services?

Hello Daniel,Fully agree with your comment. Election officials help both for COMMUNICATION, and TO SET THE EXAMPLE. For example on the morning of elections, we often see on TV some officials going to vote and reminding people about the importance of this. This can be expanded to people from all type of minorities or impaired of disabled group. For example, why not showing on TV some famous and disabled people going to vote, or HOW they vote (e.g. using all the alternatives to going to the vote bureau). it would have great impact, isn't it?Before the final day, politicians can work with social services to develop communication plans that will insure each group will be fully informed about the different ways they can vote. For those communication campaigns, why not also using some famous people that each community can identify itself to. Pretty sure they would do it for free and temporarily share their image and fame to promote this noble cause, in leaflets, radio or TV campaigns, or simple information throw social networks, GPs, hospitals, etc...Would you like to discuss this further? I m interested in your thoughts. Yannick

voter_accessability_problems_and_potenti.creator: d207020d41a8a21b58c75152ea4dfac1

comments.text: Interesting article that is relatively self explanatory.The main points seem to be:Technology in the form of  the Imagecast Ballot Marking Device exists to help voters with a range of disabilities cast a vote.Training in its set up and use is available for poll workers but access to the training can be frustrated by: - lack of funding; - perceptions of demand for the device; and sadly- attitudes towards the value of disabled voting.

Tejas  would be great if you could summarise the highlights from the article right here in your post. (Hit the Update Entry button up there on the right to make changes) Check out more Inspiration phase tips here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire

Nice one Nathan  and great analogous build on Birdie's post of his personal observations in the Philippines. I'm loving how our global community spark thoughts between each other!

voting_with_autism.description: It can be stressful to go through all the government forms and lines at the poll site, especially for people who experience high anxiety. Making this process simpler and less intimidating might help all of us better exercise our right to vote.
voting_with_autism.creator: 59ce4f71e16c7f4f27abffcca4d3d39c

comments.text: I've found people living with aspergers love games!  Mainly because its a rule-based interaction, it involves repetitive actions and the people they can be certain of the intentions of their fellow players!Perhaps one way to empower voters with autism could be the invention of an educational game... making it very visual (http://www.autism.org.uk/living-with-autism/approaches-therapies-and-interventions/skills-based-interventions/visual-supports.aspx) could help and if they could see it build up into some kind of election results league table I'm pretty sure they would be hooked!

Great inspiration Daniel, thanks for sharing this. And Ali, what a nice build - thinking about how games can be used to explain and share information. I thought the statistic about 90% of the entire voting population not understanding political literature was especially telling. Clearly there's a need to find ways to break down this complicated language into more understandable chunks, for all voters!

I also find it important, that many people with autism or aspergers find contact with strangers and being among many people extremely stressful.Is it maybe possible to create "stress-free"/"people-free" voting experiences? Or maybe cater specifically for individuals who relate badly to crowded places? Could they have a voting place which is as much about peace, quite, tranquility as about voting?

voting_with_autism.title: Voting with Autism

opensource_voting.description: One way to create a safe and secure mobile voting platform - that we can trust  - is through a global open source project. Especially thinking back to Florida, these digital technologies must be absolutely trustworthy.
opensource_voting.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: Stefan, you should check out the Open Voting Consortium http://www.openvotingconsortium.org/ and the Open Source Digital Voting Foundation http://www.osdv.org/ which have similar goals. Maybe there is something there you can build on?

Great tips Daniel! And Stefan thanks for sharing your thoughts. Security for online voting seems like a pretty big and complex topic, yet I wonder if it's possible to start outlining some early ideas for what this open source project might look like? You mentioned governments getting involved - who else might be invited to participate? What if, in addition to online collaboration, there were regional or local hack events where different technologists, programmers and makers got together in person to try to "break into" the security system that the open source project was creating? Let's think creatively about this one and see where it takes us!

It's worth noting that open source is just one way to pursue better security in elections.There are currently many ways election officials work to improve security in elections including state and national certification processes and standards, pre- and post-election security audits, tamper-evident security seals, and in-person security. Some voting systems also add on a level of security that gives end-to-end verifiability and homomorphic encryption (such as the Helios voting system) which allows voters to verify that 1) their ballot was counted and 2) that all ballots were counted correctly.
True Daniel my language was too strong - I changed it to one way. Thanks!

Hi, Stefan, I think the open source idea is great! Daniel I checked the Helios and it seems going good but and I think it has an important security problem when going into serious election, your trackable code might be beaten out of you, or if you discarded it you can not use it to track and verify the result. I think I got a concept going similar to the Helios, that does not have this security problem. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/supercheckup-2013-your-perfectly-private-vote-verification-system.-/

Hi Jakob, with the Helios system even if someone forced you to give your trackable code, the code does not reveal how you voted. It only reveals that you voted (this is public information anyway) and that your vote has not been tampered with. Only the voter knows what is in his or her ballot. Yes, if you discard the trackable code then you cannot audit your ballot. But if enough people audit their ballots then statistically there is little risk of undetectable tampering.

Daniel, that is all good for the privacy! You seems well informed with the Helios, would the tampering also be spotted if the actual voting device was hacked, before it sent/saved the data? Imagine the voting device showing you one thing but sending/saving something else. Or could someone hack the main system including the check-up system, change the result and always tell that everything is fine on the check-up?

Jakob, that is a good question. Helios is designed to prevent undetectable vote tampering. The system is fully auditable so that even if the system itself is hacked, voters can detect this. Since the system is completely open, anyone can write their own software to check the results and independently verify the vote tallies.I don't think I can explain the security protocol better than the creator, so I'll direct you to Ben Adida's paper on this if you want to understand the details ( http://static.usenix.org/events/sec08/tech/full_papers/adida/adida.pdf )

I think this is an extremely important point. The aspect of trust on automation of a system is very crucial in our perception of a system. By realizing who we are designing for - humans - we can see that the most perfect system is useless unless people trust it and want to use it

That's a great perspective Martin. I think the issue of trust extends both ways. It's not just the users that have to trust the technology but the organizers as well. I think there is a somewhat popular line of thought that open source is more vulnerable because everyone knows how it works. In reality, this makes it stronger, because there are more people working to improve it. Along with developing an open source voting platform, we may need to think about the educational process that would be needed for building trust and gaining widespread adoption.

Well put Martin & Rachel. At the end of the day, building trust is absolutely crucial for adoption.That's a key issue for many of the tech-based voting concepts, including my Online/Mobile one: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/With the increasingly popular use of an Open Source Operating System (i.e. Android on phones, tablets, & netbooks), I wonder if the mass tipping point for trust in open source is approaching.

I like this idea. If a platform (hard and soft) were made available people can make amazing things of out that in the same way iPhone and iPad apps are developed. We never know what might comes out  of such a thing ...

Sidi, I think you make an important point. Perhaps it is worth thinking about how to build a voting or elections platform that enables new types of innovations? For example, what if there was a voting system that allowed people with disabilities to use their own devices that they are familiar with (such as an iPhone, iPad or some other assistive technology) to interact with the voting system? Or what if the ballot was available in electronic format and app developers could provide many different accessible formats to display the ballot depending on the user's needs?

opensource_voting.title: Open-source Voting

being_an_election_judge_in_champaign_cou.description: In 2003-2004 I worked as an an election judge in Illinois, fumbling over bulky polling boxes and multiple voting systems in the same precinct (scan tron and punch).
being_an_election_judge_in_champaign_cou.creator: c579c7b1c60dc9cfaacbd463d63b921a

comments.text: Thanks for the comments! I'll look for a good example of the box, Ashley. I couldn't take pictures while in the polling place but I'm sure there are similar box-booths out there!

Hi Maryam, interesting post with great personal insights! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

I sympathise with your experience. It is more than 10 years since I participate as an official. So far the only real changes I have observed are the use of cardboard rather than wood and metal for booths and ballot boxes http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/flat-pack-polling-booths/ and the use of laptop computers for registering voters (marking them off the roll).I shall be interested to see if things still run as smoothly here when paper ballots are replaced - I suspect it will as the Australian Electoral Commission is one of the most efficient government departments.

being_an_election_judge_in_champaign_cou.title: Being An Election Judge in Champaign Country

comments.text: Wow, very informative video, showing the voting experience from the voter point of view. This training actually covers a wide range of disabilities. Thanks for sharing Nymphaea!Looks like your link didn't fully post properly. Have included the full link URL here: http://www.voteseminole.org/en-us/pollworkers/index.php

Wow is right - terrific videos, thanks for so much for posting this Nymphaea. You might also be curious to check out the videos that LA County have made to show what the voting process looks like there http://bit.ly/xd78t5. It's an interesting look at the voting process from a different perpective that might help round out our total understanding of the election experience.
Thanks Vincent for posting the correct URL, I fixed it now.

getting_in_to_vote.description: This is the first in a series of videos that highlights the voting experiences - including barriers encountered - by persons with disabilities.  It discusses the national and local changes underway as a result of the Help American to Vote Act.
getting_in_to_vote.creator: 914da3c8c41d1f207de84e6bd8f010fe

comments.text: Informative video Sharon. Found these 2 quotes, considered in concert, quite thought provoking:"We've made it so you can get to the top of the ramp, but you still can't get in the door.""The right of voting for representatives is the primary right by which other rights are protected." -Thomas Paine
Oops, I mean Sharron. Sorry 'bout that.
