affix_sticker_to_identify_need_for_help.description: Receive sample ballot at home. If you're facing trouble, or if you have any special needs, then affix a sticker to the ballot and bring it to the polling station. Stickers are coded so election workers can identify the need and direct voter to help.
affix_sticker_to_identify_need_for_help.creator: bf65247cb92e7cacb127c0990dcd93df

comments.text: It's great to find ways for voters to ask for help in a discreet way. Although some disabilities are easily visible, not all of them are. Many people with disabilities don't like to have to ask for help. That's one reason why there is so much emphasis on making it easy for everyone to participate in their own way, making their choices on their own. That said, there are times when we all need a little help, even if it's just a chair to sit in while waiting. I wonder what the different stickers might be? Can we make them indicate a functional need, rather than identifying a disability?

I think it's a great idea - to help people get comfortable with voting. Invariably, when I get to the actual voting venue, there is a slight sense of disorientation which could be different for different people. In fact, other ways of simulating the experience, be it virtually or via neighborhood mock-voting-camps could make it possible to discover and talk about any kind of inaccessibility in advance.

@Whiney and @Ramanand - thank you for your points. I quite agree with your points. I think have sought to incorporate the sentiment / ideas in the updated version. Applaud if you like where this is going - other thoughts welcome!...

And one more thing you might want to check out is our new Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Because great ideas start with people, right?

Bring it on MIT  really like where you are going with this. Keep up the conversation and bring on the builds! One analogous insight I can add as an allergy sufferer  I loved it when rather than being scoffed at when asking questions at a local eatery... I was presented with an "I'm Special" menu which featured allergy-friendly options.

affix_sticker_to_identify_need_for_help.title: Affix sticker to identify need for help

community_clerks_let_the_people_already_.description: (Update of Community Clerks)  Underserved communities already have people who know and work with them, and have developed personal relationships.  We should train these people to do voter registration, outreach, and education.
community_clerks_let_the_people_already_.creator: a0be1f5a44bcec8017f016288c16b1e7

comments.text: I think this idea has some great elements but overall would be a little difficult.  My first concern would be the willingness of these teachers, social workers, religious leaders, etc. to take on the role of Community Voter Advocates.  There would have to be an incentive for them to assume this role.  I do believe this would help bring communities even closer together and bring a sense of entitlement and self-worth to their respective inhabitants.  However, another concern of mine would be the influence these Community Voter Advocates could have on the process.  Obviously these people care about those around them, which is apparent through the line of work they participate in, but this power of influence they could feel from advising large segments of their population could potentially be corruptible by nature.  I don't think concern should stop this process from happening but I do think there needs to be certain measures taken, whether it be background checks, interviews, etc. into the people who would be chosen for these Community Voter Advocate positions.  Overall, I like the idea a lot and I think it will bring communities even closer together, but I do fear the power these advocates will possess.

If you have the concern about influence - whether they are "official" advocates or not the opportunity for influence is already there. If anything giving them a 'legal' responsibility to advise impartially about process would actually help. I believe.

Congratulations Darren - as Singaravelan says this concepts strengthens the community from both perspectives. Will be interested to hear of progress with this concept as realisation is achieved.I'm sorry this is the first opportunity I have taken to add comments. As with a few other concepts it is applied common sense - something often overlooked in our fast paced technology enhanced world.

Darren , this idea of creating community voter advocates is not only helping the elections but also help in building community net within the undeserved people, within the volunteer advocates and between underserved and volunteer advocates. This multiple communities creations will have cascading benefits to people and the government like it will give opportunity between communities to help each others and solve problems which are common and build  a resilient society In-terms of training the  voter advocates, flash cards would be one method which is handy and simple on how to teach people. also can have mobile apps that will flash lessons to the voter advocates which they use will training the voters

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist, Darren! We loved your focus on people, relationships and community networks in this concept. During this Refinement phase, let's think about what the training materials and experience might be for these community advocates. How can we get them up to speed so that they can help their community members cast a ballot? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Darren, I like the way you are thinking about how to strengthen existing community networks and connect them to elections. Could this also be an opportunity for people within the communities to be "peer-election-counselors"

Thanks for the support Whitney.  Peer Counselors would provide the same information and support to people as my idea, which would definitely open access to the process of elections.  I also wanted to provide a way to also break out of the precinct model, and also build on trust relationships.  People in disenfranchised communities may feel overwhelmed or distrustful of institutions or people outside their communities, and I wanted to find ways of overcoming that.

Hey Darren, just the first reaction what if these same very advocates  are asked to volunteer to be poll workers and look after the special segment. Such advocates could be identified and  given basic training to be poll workers as well (for perticlar day or be a part of the team) . Just thinking out loud. The same would avoid chances of influencing, one need not know the person ( in person ) .Having dealt with people with special needs already  is a good enough platform to start with.

Interesting way to build upon existing community links. As I was reading your concept, it made me think of another concept http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/bringing-the-experience-to-your-community/which is also focus on mobility and bringing access, although through a specific team rather than already existing relations. There might be connections to develop...

Thanks for bringing their idea to my attention.  Their idea, as well as others I have seen, seek to increase access through breaking down physical barriers.  I think that there is a real opportunity to build on existing social connections that hasn't been much addressed.

I agree that using existing social connections and community network is important. I was wondering if there was a way to combine the two types of ideas, or to have these mobile trucks or vans, providing some support to the community clerks.

I think you're right.  The more I'm working on this idea, the more I realize that the community folks are best for advocacy and encouraging participation, but the actual voting should be in a more structured fashion, such as the voting trucks.
Indeed  great ideas tend to evolve. As your ideas move forward  feel free to update your actual post at any stage by hitting the Update Entry up there on the right.

Hi Darren. I like how your concept builds on & strengthens existing community relationships to increase voting accessibility.One watchout will be concerns about vote influencing, though of course this already happens in elections anyways.

Thanks for the feedback Vincent.  I was also worried about vote influencing.  I was thinking that the Community Clerks would be better vetted than traditional poll workers and would be trained in what they could - and couldn't do.  I'll update the concept to reflect this.

Vincent raises an important point and it might be worth thinking about how to address this issue in your concept. For example, sometimes election officials do things in teams to prevent vote fraud, such as when providing some types of assistance at the poll place or when conducting recounts. So, for example, you might require that community clerks go in teams of 2 or 4, with representatives from different political parties.

Daniel, you make a really important point that this idea does always come down to one person with the ballots of many people, which will have some potential for fraud, no matter how trustworthy that person seems.  We could always propose additional security measures, but I don't think that would every fully eliminate the problem.The problem I see with people being required to be in teams is that I want these to be people who enable voting as part of their regular work with disenfranchised communities.  Adding more complexity might make this unfeasible.I think I might take these points, and those from the other commentaries and refine the idea to be more of an advocate, with less involvement in the actual voting process, to remove some of these sticking points.If you or any other folks can give me some feedback please let me know.

I really like your approach here and I think you are on to something with your advocate approach. As long as the community clerks are not involved in marking the ballot or casting the ballot, there are still many other avenues for them to make an impact and help people vote (e.g. registering to vote, signing up for an absentee ballot, etc.).

I like the idea; yet it would be critical to develop an clear interlink or point of convergence with all possible community clerks so that information content and message conveyed to the masses carry common agenda. Quite a good project for Kenyans to adapt for 2012 elections
Nice use of scenarios to describe you idea, Darren. This really helps folks get a handle on the breadth and scope of what you are suggesting here. Way to go!

community_clerks_let_the_people_already_.title: Community Voter Advocates (Refined): Build on existing social ties to increase election access.

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

voting_cubes.description: What if we filled cubes like the one outside Apple's flagship NYC store with thousands of balls at every voting poll?
voting_cubes.creator: ffdb06bb8d1847add9fac17bcd243648

comments.text: I like this idea too! I think this would generate great symbolism and show that your vote IS "making a change"

Thanks for your response! I totally agree with you that voters need to feel like their vote is making a change. I think this is one of the biggest needs of voters right now. If I can "see" my vote I can see "change!"

I like this idea a lot.  Sometimes you vote and you don't even know if it went through and your vote counted.  Watching a cube fill up, in part due to your one vote, would be interesting and would be a different and more exciting way to view the race then just percentage points.

Exactly! I feel as though the voting process in the U.S. is too secretive and thus leaves it subject to manipulation. The inability to physically see how others and how one's vote plays into that bigger picture is very discouraging.  I appreciate you taking the time to comment!  (I haven't had time to tweak my concept as I've been bogged down with completing my thesis, but will do so shortly.)

Interesting idea Meredith.A sort of upmarket version of Gambia's voting with marbleshttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-using-marbles/ Could be a good way of representing the progress of a count.
Thanks, Paul, for directing me to Abdelrahman's inspiraiton! Yes that's one of the important things this would do is openly monitor the count.

Great thinking, Meredith! One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.
Thanks Meena!  Will do. :)

online_voting.description: An innovation in voting is online voting: already adopted by some, this allows voters the ability to vote on their own time at home or work, using a tool they are already comfortable with & encourages informed decisions via the web for unsure voters.
online_voting.creator: a8e9c11d29e42b83078818fe2e82720b

comments.text: Great resources here. I love how online voting is a solution that makes voting easier for everyone, and will actually increase the number of people voting significantly. With online voting, it will be imperative that the voters have confidence in the security and accuracy of the system, and that  their vote is counted. The current physical (as opposed to online) voting system has more tangible feedback and gives people confidence that their vote will be counted. However, we are reaching a time where more and more people trust their online transactions and would be perfectly comfortable with this. And those who don't feel comfortable online can vote via phone or mail.

Exactly! What a great way to frame it. That options remain is crucial I agree, there should be different methods of transactions that suit different audiences. As a Gen-Y student whose first memory of a voting process was the Bush-Gore debacle, I find it hard to believe that peoples faith in the voting system can actually get worse! (I'm sure that's a generational sentiment though best explored via interviews/ethnographic research) For the younger generations I think an online options would definitely stimulate interest/participation and fight political apathy...more than any p.diddy "rock the vote" campaign!
Great first inspiration Molly! Its' really great how you've given an overview of the global perspective with regards to online voting.
thank you! I was hoping to show *inspire* the group how other countries have accepted online voting as a suitable platform, even though the US hasn't yet.

I recall voting online in a New Zealand election a few years back while I was living in India. This option can be used by citizens living offshore. Although I usually enjoy the social aspect of vote day in New Zealand  like in many countries, getting motivated to visit a polling booth can be a barrier for many and challenging on a physical level for others. I certainly felt that more people would vote when I experienced how easy it was online.

Molly, thanks for this great list of examples of online voting around the world.  My thoughts on this have followed a similar track to Meenas comment.  In a way it is kind of sad to think of losing the in person experience of voting at the polls  the excitement, energy, and feeling like you are part of a community.  But if going to the polls is the barrier that stops someone from voting anyway, that experience is irrelevant to them.  Moreover, it is just so much easier and more physically accessible to vote online, and I bet you are right that more people would vote if we made it as easy as doing it from your computer at work or home.  My question is if we do move to a completely online voting experience, does that mean that we are by default going to lose the social aspect of going to the polls on election day?  Or is there some sort of way to provide that experience, even if online voting becomes the norm?  It seems to me that the benefits of online voting outweigh the challenges, but it is definitely something to scheme about!

Thanks for sharing your insight! I have to confess I've never actually voted before, only heard second hand that its not so exciting and more like a post office visit (i.e. unpleasant) and living in NYC for my first time voting I didn't even know where to go. But enough about my ignorance! I don't advocate a completely online voting experience, I just think its another interface that can be utilized to accommodate different needs. Im really glad to hear how you describe it--I never thought of the experience as a "sense of community" moment... I hope that maybe with online forums and participation we can keep that energy alive! I also think the social-in-person aspect should never be forgotten and for every online establishment there should be a tangible physical and social anchor as well. I think "norms" should be avoided in the process... thats part of what seems unpleasant to begin with because it feels so regulated and unyielding, I think the online platform can detract from this and maybe do more, if you see my second image in addition to the ability to vote online I added the "learn more" section so that people can have a richer resource and feel more confident in their voting. My hope is that a online site that informs--logs you in and you use election after election--could be an engaging resource. But i'm getting ahead of myself, I just wanted to add some inspiration, I agree the benefits of online voting certainly outweigh the challenges in our increasingly present online communities.

You are right that there are many instances of Internet voting. This paper was just released in September 2011 that gives an overview of Internet voting projects over the past decade -- turns out there were quite a few!  http://www.eac.gov/assets/1/Documents/SIV-FINAL.pdf
Wow, great to hear about online voting from around the world!

online_voting.title: Online voting

tap_it_to_configure_it.description: One of the barriers to participation is getting accessible systems set up and then configured for voters in the polling place. Could we use near field communications devices to automate common settings?
tap_it_to_configure_it.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Great read from another NFC advocate. Do you see relevancy to fusion our concepts?
Just another thought could this nfc technology be used at access to buildings to provide sight-impaired voters with details of directions on signage that other people read?

I like this build. The ability to pre-configure functions prior to going to the polling station would make this system more convenient. At the polling place users could also save their settings to the same app if they select new functions or configure new settings.Other concepts could also integrate this concept. I'm thinking of the priority queues, the genius bar, polling station performance tracking platform, and Mapping, Accessibility Rating and Traffic Reports website idea.
This comment above was supposed mis-posted. Any way to delete?
Not sure Graham but you could use the Support button on the left.Now that you have posted where intended we can ignore the original anyway.

Hi Whitney. Love the intuitive ease of use, and greater voter independence provided by this concept!For current voting machines, are a list of common presets available, or do you generally have to manually change each individual setting?

There is a lot of variation in current systems. The earliest designs are often not very flexible...the problem is that it takes a long time to replace a voting system once it's been deployed. But, new systems are developed all the time And, if we think about some of the concepts for using general technology to mark and print a ballot, then it's easier to see how new technology solutions could be implemented more quickly. Using desk or laptops, tablets, or other devices might make it easier to keep up with current technology and accessibility features, while still having a strong system for casting and counting the ballots.
Very interesting concept Whitney - could there be an App available to download to individual smartphones from AEC that voters could pre-configure before attending the polling place?

I like this build. The ability to pre-configure functions prior to going to the polling station would make this system more convenient. At the polling place users could also save their settings to the same app if they select new functions or configure new settings.Other concepts could also integrate this concept. I'm thinking of the priority queues, the genius bar, polling station performance tracking platform, and Mapping, Accessibility Rating and Traffic Reports website idea.

I'm loving that voters could choose their voting option according to the functional support they were looking for, rather than by disability or limitation. It's a nice reframing. Thanks for updating us from the conference Whitney!
Agreed! It is a nice reframing. I also like the simplicity of use.

tap_it_to_configure_it.title: Tap it to configure it

comments.text: Terrific story Anne  cheers for sharing your experience. It's a great reminder that each of us has a voice and we can use it! I wonder how we might connect this inspiration to our focus on accessibility? Are there examples of ways that people previously excluded from voting have vocalized their dreams and opinions? It's certainly something to keep in mind for Concepting.And a quick tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link  :)

disenfranchisement_through_id_laws.description: Several US states have or are proposing new voter id laws to combat "voter fraud".  These laws require forms of id that are difficult for disabled, elderly, young and minorities to get, keeping them from voting.
disenfranchisement_through_id_laws.creator: 7c81f34dd47b91ef5f30f886db309d5c

comments.text: Yes, this is perhaps the most egregious barrier to voting we're currently experiencing in our modern democracy.  I say that because the trend of Voter ID laws, Voter Fraud Prevention Laws, and other laws being passed and adopted by state legislatures in 2011 are specifically designed to disenfranchise a large segment of the population, specifically the low-income, elderly, and communities of color.    In all, 14 states have passed 25 various measures designed to restrict or limit the ballot access for voters of color, threatening to disenfranchise millions of people, a disproportionate number of whom are people of color.  For example, many 'voter ID' laws that seem benign on face value, have undue harm to low income voters who often are not able to take time off of work or burden the extra cost of obtaining a state issued ID.  Moreover, many elderly African Americans who were born in the segregated south do not have access to proper records, such as a birth certificate, because they were born in areas inaccessible to hospitals and other vital services.  It will be crucial for this project to understand the larger context of the election system and all the barriers that prevent people from voting, not just from understanding how to vote, but even being able to enter the polling place.

Virginia, thanks for raising these issues and Carlos, you make a a great point: there are many different kinds of barriers to voting when we look at the whole context. And understanding the big picture is always important when we think about how design can make a positive change. As we get closer to the Concepting phase, let's be sure to think about how we can develop concepts that don't create an even larger barrier. Might this mean thinking carefully about how technology is used, how information is presented, where the concept is deployed, or other aspects of the design?

Ashley, you certainly give us another aspect to think about.  Technology is just a thing.  How it's used makes it a barrier, neutral, or a help.  The same is true for how information is presented. Website owners often don't think about compatibility with screen readers used by the bllind, to take just one example.

Hi Virgina, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

disenfranchisement_through_id_laws.title: Disenfranchisement Through ID Laws

Just one quick note about language: With our global & diverse community, it's important that we all approach our submissions and conversations with respect and understanding. You might want to check out the 'Language Matters' section of our Guiding Principles http://bit.ly/AiJnLW  there are some helpful tips around how to discuss disabilities in a way that's mindful of our different cultures and experiences. Hope to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

ipad_absentee_voting.description: For many individuals, even getting to a polling place is out of the question. This post outlines a concept of an iPad running custom voting software that will allow flexible absentee voting in places such as hospitals.
ipad_absentee_voting.creator: b53e27dc0a9b381d0838cf7b2a3bd517

comments.text: Great idea.  When I read the part about it being used in hospitals it instantly appealed to me.  I think this segment of the population is forgotten in the voting process as it is extremely difficult to transport them all to voting centers and get them through the process.  Great idea.

Andrew and team - great result for this worthwhile concept. Like EZ Vote and MyVote it represents a convenient and effective platform for voting. In particular I see it replacing the need for bulky voting and casting machines, at the same time providing the portability essential for enabling Voting Vans and other means of taking voting to the people. It also represents a great vehicle for implementing things like Online Polling (which I see as a natural winning concept that becomes an integral part of the announced winners) and VApp (as an enabling technology). Hope to see how all the winning concepts fit together in the realisation phase.

Why the need for an ipad? Creating a unique Device could work better, as there would be less need for the graphics, processing power, and memory that apple ipads boast and charge for. Moreover, apps can occasionally crash; and this brings one back to the homescreen, which we are trying to avoid. The tablet app interface is the main point, I suppose, and I definitely agree with the usefulness of that idea.

I agree that the tablet is the main idea. One of the strong aspects of this concept is the way that it uses a commercial tablet (easy to obtain or replace) and adapts it to be used as a voting system. The prototype that Trace Center created years ago used a commercial tablet, but also enclosed it in a case that restricted access to general purpose functions. One thing to consider is the different security requirements for a ballot marking device vs. a device that casts and counts ballots.

Congrtulations Andrew!Agreed Christopher and Whitney - and very important distinction between marking casting and counting. Would still like to see the 'output' from marking embracing your idea of just the voters choices not the full 'menu'.If the application is to grow into achieving all three then it also needs the fourth - the capacity to very voters and mark the roll.

Christopher, you are right in that the tablet app interface is the main point. We are currently utilizing an iPad in development, but by no means does it need to be run on that platform. The application currently in development will be available cross-platform (ideally everything from a smart-phone to a full desktop computer to a custom kiosk). As for the other issues brought up, I am working on some refinements to the idea as have been suggested. Hopefully they should be up by Monday.
Andrew, I'm curious -- are you eliminating the touch-screen input (replacing with tactile controls) or are the tactile controls just an optional form of input?
The tactile controls will be entirely optional. Individuals that are physically able to utilize the touchscreen would be more than welcome to!
Great discussion guys! Andrew  feel free to update your post with any points you feel worth adding from this conversation. Looking forward to how it might evolve!

Andrew, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We were really excited about your idea and appreciated the time you took to sketch out the iPad voting experience.During this Refinement phase, perhaps we can think about how different voters could interact with this system, depending on their unique needs and abilities? Check out our Concepting Personas for some starter examples http://bit.ly/vote_personas. We might also spend time thinking about the initial steps we'd need to take to start testing and prototyping this idea. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
I love the incorporation of current technology into the concept. Practical and doable.

Hi Andrew, Great to see so much thought about how the hardware could be secured and accessible. Could this kiosk be adapted to be portable? I'm thinking about how it could be used with concepts for mobile polling places like:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/vote-van/orhttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voting-vans/orhttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/tablet-toting-door-to-door-voting-volunteers/You also mention the need for a standard format. Have you looked at EML / IEEE P1622http://www.nist.gov/itl/vote/ieee-eml-examples.cfm

Absolutely it could be portable! Because it is currently only intended to be a ballot marking system, it is essentially as portable as a regular iPad. While that is not our initial intention, it is not a large leap to see this being deployed in many ways, such as being mounted directly into a mobile polling place or hand-delivered by "tablet toting door-to-door volunteers".As for EML, I was not familiar with it before you mentioned it, but it does look to be an XML based standard. The problem is not with creating a standard, but getting all of the little municipalities across countries to adopt this standard. Even in the US, as you know, voting is very decentralized and some areas still do not offer anything outside of paper ballots. Having everyone utilize something like EML or any other XML-type markup will make this application and others actually useful, as it can then bring in the necessary data and reformat it into any custom user interface.

Interesting ideas here - would it be possible to upload a ballot already prepared using standardised software from other platforms and stored on removable media making the ipad/kiosk combination like the drug store photo printing kiosks?Also could the printed ballot incorporate Whitney's idea elsewhere for a list of voter choices like a restaurant bill rather than the whole menu ie. just the voters choices rather than the whole field of candidates/issues?Could the ballot also have a machine readable output together with a printed receipt for the voter?

This system would fit very well with an amalgam of Whitney's Ballot Navigator concepthttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ballot-navigator/ and Gabriella's E-Book concepthttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/the-election-ballot-e-book/ to provide a range of guidance options too.

Paul, I think that all of those things that you mentioned are very possible. I am not 100% clear on your idea regarding the ballot prepared by standardized software, but I think that is what we are aiming to do in some ways. We want ballots to be created in a platform independent database format so that when it is pulled into our software, it is reformatted and presented in a clear, concise manner. If this is the case, anyone could potentially make a ballot and, if its in a compatible format, then it should work.

Andrew - sorry to be a bit obscure - my meaning was that if all the proposals for electronic voting software were common standard then preparing a ballot on removable media could be read straight into your system. There has been some comment elsewhere on the need for a physical ballot and a receipt so I thought about a bus ticket sized ballot as output that could then be read into casting machines and be secured for auditing. Hence I built my concept partially on yours -http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/bus-ticket-ballot Reducing the size of everything is, to a point, potentially cost cutting and therefore attractive from the point of view of authorities.A kiosk system which your stand could incorporate would include everything for the Voter Vans (see Whitney's comments), hospitals etc. and even Ting-Hans store kiosks http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/year-round-voting-center-stores-equipped-with-voting-kiosks/

Ahh, I see now! Yes, that would be excellent. I really like the idea of your small ballot though. A mini printer could be included at the kiosk that would zip out the ballot just like a parking receipt. Really really cool.

Thanks for the parking receipt example. I chose a bus ticket partly because I thought it might need to be robust for re-insertion and counting but also because some of them are magnetically encoded (machine readable). However it is more important that it be relatively small compared to the size of traditional paper ballots but still provide an auditable ballot.I know suitable technology already exists for both printing and reading such small ballots and providing encoding/decoding should be no problem at all.I personally have no problem with a completely electronic process but I also understand others concerns about tangible ballots.Paradoxically I am also quite happy with our current relatively simple paper based approach here in Australia.

This is actually a good idea for general voting equipment. Voting equipment is notoriously expensive (I have heard as much as $4000-$5000 per machine) and the tragedy of it is that they only get used once or twice a year. An iPad is a lot cheaper...but here's a question, what can be done with the iPad the rest of the time it is not being used for voting?

This is a good question and I wondered if the app could be developed for the first generation of ipads to five them an extended life as dedicated devices for this purpose to keep costs even lower, particularly in development phase.

This is an interesting element that I have to admit, I had not thought about. Absolutely the iPads and iPad 2s could be utilized to give them extended life now that a newer version has been released. Furthermore, these voting iPads could be used for mobile voter registration before they are needed for the actual election day. Volunteers could carry them and save people from having to fill out the paper registration forms.

Excellent use outside of formal voting periods.I found a comment elsewhere but I don't have the reference at the moment which said "Corporate/public donation: Apple has been collecting and redistributing older model iPads to Teach for America. Perhaps a similar program could be instituted for election season." I will try to find it again.
Exciting developments from Georgia Tech!
It might also help others engage with your concept if you give some simple scenarios for it's use via our Personas post: http://bit.ly/vote_personas
Excellent idea! I'll get on that!

This is an interesting idea. I think it would definitely appeal to countries that have a lot of regular cross-border traffic; since these people are moving around anyways (i.e. paying their own way), the government could facilitate the voting process in a low-cost way.

comments.text: I agree - it is a mutual dependency as I strongly believe that it exists between generations. Both sides benefit.

Hey Jutta, yes your concept would establish all the homework that a old teenager should be aware of. Once they are aware of the process in theory -they would look forward to their chance to be a vote angle. Also, by directly communicating with differently-abled citizens would help them empathize from a very early stage and be more sensitive to such special engines in our society. However i am careful that it should like a mutual dependence and not appear that a teenager is obliging someone with special needs. Make it a mutual dependence equation for both - the vote angle and the navigator.

I like how this concept thinks about how we create engaged citizens from an early age. A few thoughts for how it could build:What about combining civics education with education and awareness about disabilities?How would a program like this evolve through the different grades?There has been a program to get university students involved in elections as poll workers, but what about 16-17 year-old high school students. Could this be organized as part of their community service work (required by many schools these days)?

Great thoughts Whitney! I am aware of some areas where HS students do volunteer as Poll Workers but I believe there are some age restrictions (17-18 /Seniors only). I agree with your comment to explore options for earlier years/ages in school.
Hey Julie, i just posted a concept that talks about the same ! have a  look http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/vote-angel-design-for-mutual-dependence./  cheers..

Here is an intriguing concept that suggests mobilizing "Vote Angels" in the form of aspiring voters (older teenagers) to assist those with disabilities. See:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/vote-angel-design-for-mutual-dependence./It seems that there is room to bring together these concepts in some interesting way. As noted, physically going to the polling place and watching people vote can be a powerful learning experience as it contributes to people's identities as citizens. Playing an active role helping someone else vote could really add to this experience.

Thanks Dan for your comment.I completely agree with it.I am convinced that the more benefits a concepts brings together with more stakeholders involved, the higher is the chance that it will become a sustainable self-driven initiative where people involved take full ownership.Lets connect and join forces for the cause!
I'm just the middle-man, though I'd love to see where this could go. Have you contacted http://www.openideo.com/profiles/mamta12/ about the concept she was exploring?

Good thinking, thanks, just did that.It would need to be added under "Concepts this built upon" - maybe this would even need a function like "Concepts this relates to" - I can imagine that would also really help in the evaluation phase as well.

I echo a great idea to educate early and to encourage family participation. I am aware of some locations where High School students can also volunteer to work as Poll Workers on election day and it is part of their course curriculum (they are guided by their Teacher and report on the experience). I do believe there are age requirements so this may be limited to 17-18 yr old HS students. Perhaps an addition could be a parent/child volunteer effort - create opportunities where parents can volunteer along with bringing their child and learn together. There is "Bring your child to work day" - perhaps there can be a bring your child to volunteer and vote day!
I like the idea of kids getting "I Voted" stickers in class and then accompanying their parents as they earn theirs--great way to show the empowering nature of civic action at an early age.
Thanks Emily, I agree.A way to make visible what is going on always helps to get more attention.

Thank you, Whitney.I think that combining leads to synergies, better use of resources and results involving as many stakeholders as possible. I think that we can learn from organizations that have already been engaging in teaching children how democracy works. I am sure that they have different ages involved in their activities.Again best as I think - involve them and work on this task together.

making_voting_as_easy_as_netflix.description: A democracy where less than half of people vote isn’t good enough. I came across this startup that aims at improving democracy by helping more people vote more often. In their own words, "TurboVote is basically Netflix for elections."

comments.text: http://www.d20.org.mx/Check out Democracy 2.0 in Mexico!
This is even more revolutionary.
Thank you for finding inspiration in our work, Sarah!

I also agree that this project creatively leverages exiting processes for mail-in voting by navigating and streamlining what can often be a painful process---navigating the maze of bureaucracy surrounding registration and remote voting in each state.Im sure Im not the first to raise a concern over increased voter fraud as a result of the service. Kathryn, Im curious how your team addressed this issue.
CatherineCan you please expand on how the provision of this service increases voter fraud?

Paul, Ill reiterate that I applaud the service as an innovative way to provide accessibility within our existing US system, but can also see that critics might identify an opportunity for fraud, given that our current remote voting system can be unreliable and inconsistent across various states. Because the user is responsible for verifying his/her identity per the requirements of the individual states (often by submitting, via mail, a copy of an ID, utility bill or bank statement), an opportunistic person bent on cheating the system might find greater opportunity to exploit the existing loopholes or weak points. Its a question that repeats itself again and again in our analysis of inspiring projects for this challenge---how do we increase accessibility and streamline the election user experience while ensuring the security and validity of election results?
Hey Sarah, this is a really really apt example of how simple, straight forward steps can solve such critical issues. And  cheers to turbo vote for seeing opportunity in the same. Thanks.

Great find Sarah! This supports the view that we don't need disruptive technology and invest billions to make life better. Evolutionary innovation (simple mailers in this case), if properly applied, can solve much of our existing problems.

"Netflix for Voting": who woulda thunk it =PHad no idea what this meant at first, but the creative use of dry erase & permanent markers really brought home how this can make the voting process easier & straight-to-you convenient, even while working within the limits of the current system.Thanks for sharing this gem Sarah!

remote_voting_building_profile.description: profiles can list preferences and keep an updated list of special needs for voting(such as visual impairment, hearing impairment)
remote_voting_building_profile.creator: c5109b6433e41a90db43e344ff50761e

comments.text: This concept is very similar to one developed at one of our workshops. It also was based on the concept of voters creating profiles that would tell election officials their preferences for communication - for example, by printed material in the mail, large print, web, email, or SMS.  You can find a sketch here: http://elections.itif.org/projects/design-workshops/concept-express-voting/Thinking about this idea, it's not just getting your ballot. The voter profile could be used to store preferences for any communication about an election - dates, polling places, information about what is on the ballot. I can see this benefitting all voters, because everyone could choose.  It would also benefit election officials because many voters might choose email or web, instead of receiving information in the mail (which is expensive).

In fact, that was one of the strongest elements as I recall.  That by having an option to express preferences, the voting experience would be facilitated for all voters.  It is not necessary to think of this as an accommodation for voters with disability, but rather a facilitation for "express voting" for everyone.

This is actually one of the ideas that received focus from the January face to face workshop.  It seemed that nearly every concept that emerged could benefit from some aspect of a user-created self profile that would help make the voting process conform to specific voter needs. Some good concept detail is available here http://elections.itif.org/projects/design-workshops/concept-express-voting/

Terrific concept with elements that could be interwoven into other concepts for further building.  Would be great to probe further into how best to merge the profile concept with various options for voting and get into the actual voting system elements...i.e. what is the full scope of options or selections available in the profile, how can that drive the scalability and flexibility of voting options, etc.  Thanks.

political_candidate_matchmaking.description: What are the real issues here and where do the candidates stand? More specifically, what measures and bills do candidates favor or oppose? Most importantly, where do YOU stand on such issues? Matchmaking games to find your like-minded politician rock

comments.text: Interesting inspiration. It reminded me Anna's inspiration about cheat sheet to inform the voters: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/confusion-and-empowerment-/

Dylan,. I think your absolutely right that the key problem is matching the policy approaches of candidates to peoples' own hopes and desires. There is something very appealing about a simple checklist approach.  It would be interesting to explore how specific issues are chosen - whether it is an aggregation of choices from the different candidates, or whether a "representative" committee chosen through an agrees process (maybe jury panel are the right analogy? I'm not sure).  It appears that the debate format in the US tries to address, but certainly, helping people toward making the choice that best represents their values makes the whole  process more representative. I'm interested to see how this would develop.
Eoghan, you bring up a good point about what issues would be considered and how they're to be selected. I would suspect an algorithmic outcome would be favorable over an subjective panel.

comments.text: This is an old NPR story (from October), but here's another example of election officials taking polling places into the community."The trailer is the first mobile voting booth in Iowa. This polling place on wheels was set up by Marshall County Auditor Dawn Williams."http://www.npr.org/2012/10/24/163560324/vote-while-you-shop-pop-up-poll-sites-sweep-iowa
Very interesting! Thank you so much, Whitney!

Hi Chris, this is just awesome! I had been to your site earlier, and it really inspired me! However, i didn't see all the pictures you have there now. So i pretty much took inspiration for your voting mobile and designed one specifically for disabled people. Do you guys tour a lot?
