ballot_box_device_adapt_to_voter_s_indiv.description: Every voter has different needs. Around 85% of disabled Americans have their own personal cell phone device that they are comfortable with using, and adapt to their needs- the voting process can utilize these mobile devices.
ballot_box_device_adapt_to_voter_s_indiv.creator: bea492294642e966c6649e8d925f3566

comments.text: The Exploring Creativity class and the OpenIDEO student chapter at NYU Poly had a prototyping workshop where we refined your concept! You can check it out here:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yHwQogZEH7g
Great video!  I think the role playing really helps make this concept more clear.

Hi Daniel could you please take a quick look at my post here about not being able to watch the video (my dial-up connection makes watching videos difficult - especially on vimeo)?Just would like to know if I have the rough gist of this concept.

Sorry Paul about the video.Thanks Daniel for the comments. In fact, the students involved in prototyping this concept all agree on the usefulness of prototyping and role playing... The class was about prototyping yesterday and we had a great presentation by 2 designers of IDEO NY office for the first part discussing prototyping - what types of prototypes and why. We played with the how. :-)
Thanks for the explanation AL - I can't watch Mei's video either so I thought I would try to describe the concept with my analogy hoping that I had the idea roughly correct.

Paul, I think your analogy makes sense. In fact, students spend a lot of time discussing the process of plugging in and what would happen with the device and the ballot. That made us discuss what is voting: marking the ballot and / or putting it in the ballot box and having it registered. I also wanted to add that a few things that came out from this workshop beyond the importance of prototyping was understanding the interface between the ballot device and the phone, the role of poll workers in this process and how the ballot device would be "set up" and how the vote would be recorded and then the device "cleared" and reused.

Wow thanks for that feedback AL. I dont feel I have done justice to collaboration on this and a few other concepts partly because I am busy updating mine but also because I had been focusing on things I understood early in the concepting phase.

Very Cool! Thanks everyone- it was so exciting seeing my idea being developed and role-played out, it definitely explains things a little more in depth/ gives a good sense of what the interaction experience would be like.

Could not watch the video but I think I understand the concept sufficiently to ask a couple of questions. To use an analogy from the PC world - I can plug a USB stick into my PC and use (say) Excel to create a spreadsheet then store the resulting file on the USB stick then take that USB stick to another machine and upload the file to be read.In this case Excel (a device for manipulating data with which I am familiar) would be my cell phone, the data of my vote (like the excel file) would be transferred to the ballot box device (like the USB stick) which would then be connected to a voting machine (second computer) to record the actual vote.Do I have the analogy approximately correct?If so, once the vote has been recorded would the device be cleared of vote data to be re-used by the next voter (ie. could you recycle the devices within a polling station) ?

thanks for the video! it helped conceptualize the actual solution that you are proposing. I really like the idea of a physical representation of the ballots in the actual use of the devices. I think this is a great idea that keeps the individual and personalized feel of voting and deals with the adaptation to different needs. I wonder if this system could be used in desktop computers as well, to reach those who are not able to leave their house.

I love the concept and you did an amazing video.It provides great independence to the voters... To me it's the other side of the coin of Cansu's let Vapp suggests. Cansu's concept focuses on the poll workers and yours on the voters but the idea is similar: providing options through an "open" device. It made me think of a multiple plugs device. Great job!

wow...no wonder why i`m not in this phase, your concept is awsome!!!perhaps the only adapt  in a mobile device needed is the braille touch screen...but you certainly have a point, the software should adapt to you and not the opposite.i hope you win =)

WOW! Technologically forward concept that is so perfect. I can see exactly why this concept made the short list. My favorite so far. I like that it adapts to the USER - so an individual with a visual issue, auditory issue, information interpretation issue, etc., could adapt accordingly - because there isn't a one-size fits all tool.  Amazing concept. My favorite so far.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Mei! We were very intrigued by your idea and loved the time and effort you put into your video explanation!During this Refinement phase, let's think about what happens once the ballot box device is plugged into someone's smartphone. Does it enable voting via something like the MyVote App that David designed? Or does it help poll workers recognise voter needs, like in Cansu's Let the App Decide concept? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

I was thinking it would be great if the software somehow could emphasize the importance of the vote. There are so many forum polls, and online questionnaires, we click thousands of times every day. How can we differentiate the digital vote from being just yet another click?Maybe we could add a tactile component, working with the vibration features of phones or the camera and face recognition to make the digital voting experience more substantial. The goal would be to give it the feeling of importance and a sense for responsibility and participation similar to the feeling of going to a polling station and making am actual cross on a sheet of paper.

Hello Mei, great concept and video! Since your concept suggests that people can vote with their own devices, do you think people have to come to the polling place in the first place? I also agree with using the existing mobile devices, and possibly using the different sensors of smart phones in the long run. ( http://bit.ly/ytKxA6 ) I eliminate using a new device at all, because you can always download a voting app (may be using a single time password or something). Is the main reason that you have the box to make things fast and controlled, or to make it adapt to the low tech phones?

Hi Cansu, Thanks for the  comments- I was very much inspired by your concept! The reason why I thought that it would be important to have (most) people to go to the polling place in the first place because I read some articles (also on the network) saying that more people are likely to vote, if they are seen being an 'active citizen'- in a public space, voting with their peers. While I do agree that someone could use this program also at home, and send their device through the mail... I feel that the general public should embrace the importance of taking the time to go out of their house to vote. I wanted to try and think of an experience that is a transition between physical paper voting and digital apps... and is more involved and carry more work/significance than our daily cellphone networking apps. I think keeping voting on a reserved day, having voting in a public space, as well as keeping the vote a physical tangible thing- retains its significance in our completely-digital world today.I thought about eliminating the device, and downloading an app, but I assumed that general public or elderly:a) don't have access to download the app via internet (with low tech phones) b) don't really know how to download appsThe other main reason to have the box device (similar to square) is exactly what you said, to make things fast and controlled... I feel that a lot of naysayers to the 'digital voting' in machines is that they don't really understand/believe that their vote is not going to be tampered with. Maybe they aren't accustomed to the digital age yet, but I think it's a valid point. They perceive today's electronic apps/programs as just an invisible cloud of information that may get tampered with if they don't really see the result of their vote ( unlike dropping a paper ballot in a physical box). This is also why I considered using a device platform that is physical- So that people could see these devices being dropped into a box, and it also acknowledges and embraces our country's process to collect votes physically. Thanks again for your comments, I'd love to know what you think!

Great conversation you've triggered here, Mei. If you are keen to incorporate any of the ideas from the collaborative discussion here  feel free to update your post using the Update Entry button up there on the right. Let's bring on the builds & spell out the specifics!

Another thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve.

Hello Mei,Yes I agree that the box would make things much faster in case there is a different app programmed for each device, and those have to be downloaded. I also agree that encouraging people to come to the poll would be the best, however not everyone can. Plus, many handicapped people have stationary devices as well. The strongest points of your idea is to create a voting device from everything, so why not have the poll clerks visit hospitals with the ballot box?

What a terrific idea Mei! Given that more and more consumers are moving towards the smart phones, i really think this opens up a whole new avenue for next gen voting.Building the application wouldn't be hard. Using an interactive text/ voice messaging tool like Twilio, a simple yet secure app can be built, while not worrying about keeping up with different versions of smart phones.http://www.twilio.com

Mei, what a fab concept and video explanation! I think what excites me most is thinking about how it builds on devices that users are already familiar and comfortable with. I'll be eager to see how this develops during Concepting.

Agreed, a great concept & video explanation Mei!Totally aligned with building on devices that users are already familiar & comfortable with. And I find your innovative twist of using a small physical device to store the software/vote quite interesting & appealing.Technical implementation will have challenges to overcome, of course, as I don't think plug & play driver/software installation for hardware devices is currently built into the main phone operating systems (as is the case in some of the major personal computer operating systems). If not, more work may needed in installing the software on user's phones.Also, I posted an online/mobile voting concept that's quite complementary with this one: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/ . Would it be alright with you if I linked to your concept from mine as related/complementary concept, and attached your fabulous explanatory video to help illustrate the potential?Thanks and such a great concept Mei!

The idea of being able to use a wide variety of personal devices - laptops, phones, tablets, (and even paper) - to mark your ballot is really great. WIth so many different devices, how does the ballot get cast?Is there a simple way to do this?  There was an inspiration around boarding passes for airplanes, which can now be printed at a kiosk or sent to a mobile device as a QR code. Could the voting app store all the choices, so they can be easily cast?

Yes, Vincent that would be great if you could link the concepts. Whitney, printing boarding passes is a great idea/ example. Maybe there is a kiosk that downloads the device/voter's information and directly prints the information. The voter could see this kiosk print the vote into a box. I think there is value and security to the voter in having the device store one voter's choices at a time. The voter might worry that their vote would no longer be private, if their vote was stored on a device that had other people's votes on it. Although I think it's time valuable to the poll workers to load multiple votes, do you think it's worth  sacrificing the voter's confidential experience?

Mel, I don't think you want to do anything that will sacrifice privacy. That's really a core concept in US elections. When I think about accessible elections, it seems very clear that there's a lot of benefit to allowing voters to use their own devices because they can use their own assistive technology on a familiar device. The question becomes how do you get their choices from their device to a form in which they can be cast. One idea is some kind of QRcode reader. Another is that they print it to cast a paper ballot. You proposed a small device.  Maybe the key is considering: - getting the actual ballot as cast to be the same for all voters, no matter how they selected their choices- making the way of collecting the information from many different devices be as simple (and inexpensive) as possible.- deciding what the actual "ballot" is - how would the election be audited or recounted. I hope this helps.

I'm wondering how we could trust the client machines to do what they are supposed to do. How can we be sure that the vote they download is actually the vote entered by the voter? How can we be sure that they don't download two votes, or two thousand votes?
Mei - Is the vote to be counted electronically, or manually?

Hmm. I guess this is something I should explain better . I imagine that these 'digital votes' could be downloaded onto a computer and counted electronically- then the devices can be 'reset' and reused

ballot_box_device_adapt_to_voter_s_indiv.title: Ballot Box Device-  Adapt to VOTER'S Individual CELL PHONES

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

living_without_arms.description: The wheelchair is the International symbol for accessibility, but physical disabilities are not limited to the use of wheelchairs. This man is able to travel on an airplane independently, but not without help.
living_without_arms.creator: edaa59d5e115ae6571365e763291c048
living_without_arms.title: Voting Without Arms

relax.description: During the Inspiration phase, I was struck by one thought: voting seems to be stressful for everyone, regardless of your abilities or needs. How can we help people relax on election day?
relax.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Like Concierges:  People who sign them up could be dressed up... or people can approach them in line (dressed up / in uniform) and get there names to check in.  Have volunteers approach people in line, and they can ask them if they'd like to see a menu --- which is the ballot, in a folded menu.(so, it's the asking questions component, they're just offering up information.)You could have vendors / caterers there... Starbucks there while you wait, or Cinnabon.  Anything that's not a full meal...Get donations/sponsors for bigger areas -- so you could have fountain drinks and/or snacks there.  Have music playing in the background.Have TV screens/projection TVs - playing something.
I love the idea of having vendors and caterers! It's like having a mini food fair.

Hey Ashley , i agree and have been thinking of the same. Waiting in long lines and stress is something very common phenomenon and the anxiety/nerveous ness around it as well. While working around same - i have been thinking what if distracts people from the main objective and if it does how can it lead to better experience and people feel that they missed something if they dint go to vote 'socially/culturally'. I personally feel making it a better experience might encourage people to ignore few irritants and enjoy the spirit of democracy . I would like to build on this even though it sounds like a Cindrella tale to begin with  ; ) cheers !

For example -for  a competition i considered places like bus-stands, hospitals, airports etc where one tends to wait. In order to make it fun and distract people from continuous wait/stress -i designed /proposed TALE TILES -basically a reflective surface tile ( modular) in which people can see themselves in different distortions and enjoy and engage/ tease there fellow beings etc and have a good laugh  over themselves ( the competition was under the theme 'ACTION OBJECTS - when you look at an object what action do you do intuitively, the proposed tiles explored the reflection property of steel and we all enjoy a quick glance in the mirror if the time and place permits ; P)
Yes! That makes me think of mirrors near elevators. I remember hearing that buildings install mirrors next to elevators because it makes the wait more bearable. Interesting thoughts Mamta!

Agreed, love how you reframed through this concept Ashley.It'd be great to have elections where you can vote at the pace that's right for you, feel supported by friendly helpers in making your civic contribution, and the before/after-vote period is a time of fun & celebration!

Love the build on so many inspirations to celebrate voting and foster community around the process. The concierge idea is also a great one---possibly playful and fun customer service along the lines of Southwest Air? At a basic level, voting locations could provide refreshments donated by local community businesses. Ideal entertainment would be a celebration of democracy, promoting civic pride in a party and issue-neutral manner, preferably in a graphic or interactive medium. I think of a live feed ticker or image depicting the number of votes cast and where (locally and nationally), or a dynamic flow of voting stories or ideas represented in an engaging way, a la Ink Factory http://inkfactorystudio.com/.
Oooh Catherine I'm loving where you're heading with this! Maybe we'll see some new concepts from you that build upon mine? :)
What about access to iPads, laptops or work stations where one could feel better about stepping out of the office to take the time to vote that way they wont feel so rushed in the first place.

Providing food and refreshments is an excellent way to motivate people to come down to the voting stations. Also, bringing a wholesome festive atmosphere to the voting stations would be amazing- like music, magic shows, etc... Lets CELEBRATE voting!

I like the idea of having the tiles, but what about centering them around national pride. In several governmental offices, there are paintings and art installations that are specifically associated with national pride and the feeling of being a citizen. While this might require work that would be better spent in a more functional way, such as manning the voting booths, I believe that it could work. Make voting day and the days preceding nationalistic in nature. It is the utmost expression of citizenship to be involved in government and unfortunately a lot of people have lost that feeling. If we could reshape the perception of voting from something you need to do to something you want to do, I think this could rapidly change the voter involvement. In the days preceding, student artists from each area could submit art work, poetry, art installations to each voting station to be put on display to entertain and encourage those that are waiting to vote. If the voters see that there are students, most of which can't vote, that think so highly of voting as to visually represent it, they will spend more time weighing their options and being deliberate about their decisions, putting nervousness to the side and truly becoming more involved in the voting experience.
Nothing of substance to add I'm afraid; I just wanted to say I really loved the pic and it made me smile!
Thanks Mark! I like to think that if I can draw something, anyone can :)
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Hello Ashley, although there are possibilities of voting from home, I like that we create concepts bringing people together during such a collaborative event. How about creating a small voting booth for kids as well? It might be beneficial to teach about the democratic process and make everyone feel special.
I suppose you can never start too young! :)

relax.title: Relax!

accessible_from_anywhere_anytime.description: As a result of Communication Revolution, mobile phones and internet have been reached everywhere even in rural areas.The whole election system can be restructured with the use of technology so that elections can be accessible from anywhere anytime.
accessible_from_anywhere_anytime.creator: 0fca0b4519a3a092ae8e54612a875e15

comments.text: Agreed. Since usability of computers have been addressed in many ways it opens up an opportunity for so many more people form the community to take part in the elections. Some elderly would choose not to go out because of their health, and some may have disabilities that makes it hard to vote. With improving technologies like eye tracking system and computer controllers specially designed for specific disabilities, I think this is the way forward. There are hurdles that need to be overcome and potential high cost for the transition but should be feasible.

I like the idea to use the existing communication network/ internet to  use as a basis for the optimization of the voting process. If you are disabled, you have aids that help you to act more or less independently.These aids / device that help e.g. disabled people to take part in the virtual world, in combination with the secure infrastructure of an e-voting platform.True  there ist he possibility of missusing the internet for manipulations. But you can manipulate elections without using the internet, too.When you use applications as e.g. internet banking the security level is high and there is not a malfunction on large scale. In Austria and Germany you can send e.g. your tax return or other official documents to the authorities via internet. In the swiss voting via internet is already in existence.http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internetwahl (sorry I just found it in german)

thanks..sebastian for link, I couldn't read it though as it is in german:):) but I get your point of other large scale services which are securely running through internet. Yes we can use/adopt tight security measures for an Online Voting System also just like internet banking and other online services.

I love this idea.  I recently read an article in Fast Company that stated there are 660 million mobile-phone users in Africa.  The magnitude of people with mobile phone access provides an INCREDIBLE opportunity to utilize personal technology toward accessible, secure voting.  I also agree that the process would have to be heavily guarded, to make certain the election is fair, and not able to be hacked.  Keep up the good work!

hi Matt!even I am very positive about this idea. As we are aware of the fact that mobile phones have become a personal device, most of the population carry it along with them everywhere every time. So, using mobile phones for voting through an Online Voting System will be a great idea. Amount of money, time and other resources involved in organizing an election will be reduced drastically. People's participation of in voting, will increase. And it is already being followed in few places.Lets see what justice we can do with this idea!!:)
got the "General description of Estonian E-Voting System"..the PDF file is attached here!

During my online search I came across this news "Estonia first to allow online voting nationwide"....here is the link:http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9697336/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/t/estonia-first-allow-online-voting-nationwide/#.TybfokKP640

Thanks Ashutosh for sharing your experience, which reveals how migrant & expat workers across the spectrum, are often underrepresented in voting.Agreed that online/mobile voting is a promising way of addressing this and other accessibility issues.

hii vincent..yes..I feel E-election/voting can be one of the best ways to solve many issues..and also during my research I came across few places around the world where It is being implemented successfully. Like Estonia became the first country in the world to hold an election allowing voters nationwide to cast ballots over the Internet. I am posting the link as comment. Kindly have a look.

Thanks for sharing Ashutosh about the voting experience (long lines for registering and for voting which might discourage some people) as well as the difficulty to enact this experience while working away from your voting area. I remember not voting for an important presidential election in France while leaving abroad because I did not register in time at the consulate (I needed to do this even for a mailed ballot) and I felt really bad. I'm looking forward to seeing your ideas developed in the concepting phase.

hii Anne..nice to hear from you. Long queues are severe problem in India as it has huge population. And a big part of population is working away from voting area. Renovation of whole election system while keeping these problems in mind, will solve many problems to large extent (like problems related to casting a vote, it's privacy and security,managing whole public election, huge money which is being spent over it).n yea sure:):) waiting for concepting phase too. I am trying to take out time from my studies:) and hope I will come up with more and more good inspiration/ideas. Cheerssss!!

accessible_from_anywhere_anytime.title: Accessible from anywhere anytime

mobile_numbers_as_unique_id_users.description: Mobiles could solve the 3 central “pains” of the challenge: (1) security, (2) convenience, (3) simplicity; but instead of using mobiles as polling tools, I would think of them as a unique ID user –after a rigorous validation process of course.
mobile_numbers_as_unique_id_users.creator: 8fe69f9420dbc7b9473b4254ca6c8633

comments.text: Hello dear,i like your profile,am miss Anabel Cole,please contact me through my email (anabel.colle@yahoo.in)because i want to share something with you.and also give you my picture,i will be waiting for you in my email box.(anabel.colle@yahoo.in)

Interesting, Hernan! One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.

Hi Hernn, I really like this idea! I've worked in very poor, rural areas in Asia and actually almost everyone can get access to a mobile phone. A few issues I thought of:- Would have to work with mobile companies to ensure the service is free- Include a function where you can review your vote, before sending? (so easy to type a wrong number)- As Paul commented, would work really well for simple 'first past the post' elections. More complicated systems such as Australia's preferential system could maybe be accommodated by a voting app on smartphones - but this would probably restrict coverage in less developed contexts. Looking forward to seeing how this concept progresses!

Great concept with distinct potential, Hernn!You mention a one-to-one correspondence between cell phone number and SSN (presumably Social Security Number).In Australia this SSN would have to become a pin or number of the voters choice since we have no consistent number that applies to everyone.The voting method SMS would be well suited to 'first past the post' elections, and warrants adoption in those circumstances.Do you have any suggestions for referendum type polls or preferential voting?

Thanks for your post Paul !In Peru we have a unique ID for each voter (the DNI number or National Document of Identity); however I guess every country should assign a unique number to each voter before starting to redesign their electoral process.  About your second question, in case of referendum same method would apply: assigning a code for each YES and a code for NO.

mobile_numbers_as_unique_id_users.title: Mobile numbers as unique ID users

eballot_use_technology_to_rethink_the_ba.description: Recreate a "ballot" as a purpose-built digital device that completely redefines every aspect of voting.
eballot_use_technology_to_rethink_the_ba.creator: a0be1f5a44bcec8017f016288c16b1e7

comments.text: I like your idea, it is similar to my own. I think that the use of simple, people friendly technology is the key to making anything more accessible.

If governments made such a device available in the same way they made other things that helped protect people from transmitted diseases, more and more people will vote. If you have a device that is either at home all the time or that comes via the post and be there in your kitchen day and night, you will vote!

eballot_use_technology_to_rethink_the_ba.title: eBallot: Use technology to rethink the ballot, and how and where we vote.

super_election_sunday.description: Super bowl Sunday is a large event in America and even world wide. Use the concept and make elections as large a party as super bowl Sunday. Bring out the snacks, the beers, the betting and make it a day long celebration og democrazy and togetherness
super_election_sunday.creator: fabeacc75ec9dce98ddda9c56ca6043c

comments.text: I applaud the sentiment of making elections a celebration - here in Australia we have small social involvement at some polling places with charity fundraising activities - larger gatherings are usually organised by the major parties for members. For most people the involvement post-voting is on the television coverage from the national or state tally room as the count progresses and outcome gradually emerges. Some people have private parties to watch the progress and it would be a short step to using sports and other venues to celebrate the day (which here is always a Saturday).Having said all that my actual first thought on seeing your inspiration was two questions - Why is Super bowl held on a Sunday but not US elections?Assuming that the reason for having Super bowl on a Sunday is to give fans the best opportunity to watch it, either in person or through the media then the second question becomes -Why is participation in Super bowl more important to Americans than participating in the decision making processes of the country?

Really good and also important questions to raise. I am unfortunately not American myself, so I really cannot answer either. But in Denmark were I am from, election is also on a weekday. I have no idea why. But really it does not make any sense. I come from Denmark and have the same experiences as you explain. Danes have small gatherings in their homes after election or meet up at cafe's or simular. Each parti (we have approx. 7-9 parties) have large celebrations - but only for members of the parti. I think mayor celebrations would be a nice change to this. Why only celebrate with those you share opinion with. Why not celebrate democrazy in generel. And yes, your questions emphasize, that changes in the election setup needs to be made. It has to happen on a satuday or sunday. But why not? Which kind of barrier should there really be? It works for you in Australia - if could work other places as well.
Hopefully some Americans can share some insight...?

Thanks for sharing your experiences too.My family has small connections with Denmark, having hosted an exchange student a few years ago, and my youngest daughter having done exchange nursing training in Denmark 4 years ago. Also the wife of your crown prince comes from our state of Tasmania.I too will be interested to see some comment from American residents to your very sensible suggestion.

Hi Tanja & Paul, just my five cents around this :large parts of population claim to be uninterested in politics. Mostly I believe this is because they don't connect everyday things like extremely important physical things (like schools, hospitals, roads, railroads, unemployment benefits, environment pollution) with what the politicians work with once elected to office and parliament.In my experience it is at least more than 50% of swedes, this strange disinterest in politics, but of course when they are questioned about it, they want a strong social safety net. don't just understand the connecting links. I wouldn't be amazed if you checked regions/areas with large portion of underpriviliged people and the % of disinterested would be closer to 100.I find it very similar to when most people will say they are not interested in culture, and can agree on cutting down budget for all culture : when the definition of culture is how all of us live, design houses, cook and eat food, play or enjoy music, participate or watch sports, how we talk, sing, play, communicate...

Thank you for your point of view Johan. I think that you are absolutely right. Large part of the population do not know/care much about politics. And when that is the case, why should people with disabilities make a large effort to join in? Why should they overcome the barriers to get to vote, when politics are so distanced from "real life"? Politicians obviously do not manage to communicate politics clearly. I believe that if we want to make voting more accesible it is important at the same time to make politics more interesting. No matter how accessible we make the voting process it will still be something that demands some sort of effort. An effort that people (disable or not) will only make if they find it worth the effort.

super_election_sunday.title: super-ELECTION-sunday

pop_up_voting_center.description:
Pop-Up stores are appearing everywhere. From taking use of old empty lots to redesigning shipping containers, these "temporary" spaces are taking many forms.
Why not a Pop-Up informational voting booth or Voting Center?
pop_up_voting_center.creator: ba4a5701a6a9d795566b6fa932549ce6

comments.text: Hello Arjan,You are right, this would be a great collaboration! I always think of Library Mobile Buses or even the inspiration that was posted about the Food trucks. Any additional thoughts?

I think the important thing is to make voting as easy as possible for people. That includes bringing the polling station to where people actually are, but also to make it so that everybody understands and can participate. Maybe with some guidance.

It's a great idea, and there are already some places that do this. Have you seen this inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-in-public-transport/Might be good to link the two :)

Hi, great thinking Camila!In Sweden you see a lot of pop up voting centres where you can cast your vote during the upcoming weeks of the election day. Very convenient! And if you change your mind you can make a new vote and the last one you do will count!
Thanks for this insight Jakob.How is the vote actually cast, and how is the first vote cancelled to allow for the new vote to be counted instead?

I remember it as similar to the standard voting experience. You take a party printed paper with assigned color for the election in question (each election has different colors, you can vote for Government + municipal + county council, + unique topics all in different color) Then you put it in a voting envelope standing behind a screen. You register your vote with ID or passport.The pre vote is not counted immediately; it is sent to your assigned Election Centre and added to the election after the official voting ended if you did not vote there, guess it is marked with your id number or tagged with other identifiable info. If you make more than one pre vote, all your pre votes are invalid since the electing personal cannot choose one for you. Guess a time stamp on the pre vote could make it possible to change these as well. Today the only way to change a pre vote is to go and vote on the election day on your assigned voting centre, this vote is then counted instead since then your pre vote is not added.

This is an awesome idea for more numerous and accessible voting locations, Camila! They could also "pop-up" in popular existing spots like grocery stores, convenience stores, malls etc. to provide an easier (and more routine) destination.
Great inspirational idea Camila. Context aware voting stations would be very appropriate for the design challenge.

Interesting thoughts Camila  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.
Thanks Meena, I am looking forward to grow this inspiration along with others towards a working attainable concept!

Hi all,thank you for the great feedback, I really appreciate it. Keep the thoughts coming and hope this inspire all of us towards new ideas.As Laura and Burgess already mentioned, one of the main ideas of the Pop-Up Voting Center is accessibility. Places like malls, grocery stores, corner of streets, plazas, etc.. can provide an easier alternative to many who have questions or just are looking for a better understanding of the election system.As Laura also mentioned, the Pop-Up Voting Center can be an actual polling station to assist in communities that lack public transportation for voters, or where lines are too large and voting centers are too far away.Another thought, was to use this as a place to assist those in greater need in a specific community. The Pop-Up Voting Center can adapt itself to a certain design that better improves the entire voting experience: whether that is for those with hearing difficulties or first -time voters.Overall, the uses can be endless (we can even recycle the Pop-Up Voting Center to become a temporary meet-up area for community use or as a local retail shop...).
This is also great because having many smaller locations would reduce the lines and wait times for voters, which would overall improve the voting experience for everybody!

pop_up_voting_center.title: Pop-up voting center

accessibility_through_technology.description: Local governments can provide funding for the use of devices which help people with disability and language barriers to vote. By using technology, the election experience can be greatly improved.
accessibility_through_technology.creator: e498db94e743807c8240776d6d7ba22a

comments.text: Hi Ruchik, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

hello, I unfortunately do not have a picture. It was part of my senior design project in university. It was basically a headset that can be wore like headphones, and the system also includes a transmitter, which looks like a cell phone case that you can hook to a belt near the waist.

accessibility_through_technology.title: Accessibility through Technology

microsoft_accessibility_technology_for_e.description: Accessibility enables people of all abilities to realize their full potential. Microsoft creates technology that is accessible to people around the world—of all ages and abilities
microsoft_accessibility_technology_for_e.creator: 0fca0b4519a3a092ae8e54612a875e15
microsoft_accessibility_technology_for_e.title: Microsoft Accessibility Technology for everyone

crowdsource_election_accessibility_best_.description: Create a website to collect and organize election accessibility best practices and encourage continual process improvement.
crowdsource_election_accessibility_best_.creator: 59ce4f71e16c7f4f27abffcca4d3d39c

comments.text: Hey Daniel, while trying to understand the election process, i felt the need for database and a clearer reflection of facts/ground realities. I posted  a concept yesterday which feels similar to what you are proposing here, the link  http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/national-database-for-rating-voting-system/ . As you suggest crowdsource would be the best way to collect precise information ? I like the the way you have shown centralised and decentralised visuals -that is what is the case right -all the information is there but in decentralised manner. I feel this concept would take time(implementation ) but would be effective in building up to a secure and democratic election process .

Hi Mamta,I think there are two separate groups of opinions that need to be looked at. One is for the voters and one is for the election officials. The voters can share their feedback on what systems work best for them and what election practices help them the most. Election officials may have a different perspective than the voter and find that some systems or election processes are cheaper, easier to audit, or require fewer personnel to staff. Both sets of opinions should be taken into account, but we probably need to collect them slightly differently.

Hi Daniel, I had suggested a crowd-collaborative online Wiki for both Annie Nguyen's Voter Help Hub , and Whitney Quesenbery's Ballot Navigator .  However, the collectiveness of the crowd will require constant scrutiny from moderators who are well-versed with the election process and practices, as well as, identifying areas for improvement.  Also, the context needs to be localised within that country, as election process and practices vary from country to country.

Yes, I agree with you that thinking about the institutional framework of this is important. If the information is not well-curated, it will not be a useful resource. I'm thinking this might work best as an editor/journal relationship, where anyone can submit ideas, but the content will be edited and reviewed for quality before posting.

Brilliant idea!  I have a number of close friends who work at  Crowdflower (crowdflower.com) in San Francisco.  I wonder if this idea could be linked with their platform?  Could streamline efficiency and help make this a success with their expertise in the field!  Let me know if you would like some contacts there.  Either way, I am excited to see how this moves forward.  Go for it!

What I really like about this idea is that it humbly acknowledges that there is a lot out there that people have been thinking about and experimenting with when it comes to election accessibility. And, there is a lot of potential to surface disagreements about best practices, which itself could be eye-opening. It might reveal what works differently in different places, under different voting schemes, etc. Looking forward to seeing how this evolves!

Daniel - great idea! In a way you are taking inspiration from the very process we all going through with OPENideo; as you look to develop this there are a number of important design choices to think about (e.g., how to excite and motivate the crowd; how to rate and rank ideas), which I'm sure there is a lot of expertise within the community here (and no doubt the folks at IDEO could give a few pointers as well!).
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Love this idea Daniel.It seems that it would help to empower election officials and help them comply with the legislative constraints under which they work.Once again my lack of personal experience so far as US elections are concerned means I have to keep making some assumptions (or keep asking questions).Looking at the EAC site I thought perfhaps what you are suggesting might already exist in the form of the "Election Official Exchange", however I was disappointed to see that it is simply a network listing.While (to me) a site like EAC would be a logical place to host what you propose, perhaps it needs a touch of dynamism and a Q & A format.

Hi Paul,Yes, the EAC is officially the clearinghouse of all election-related materials in the U.S., but I'm trying to think how we can leverage some of the social network and dynamism of the Internet to make sharing best practices work better.  I love the idea of a Q&A feature.There are other organizations that could also potentially sponsor something like this, including the National Association of Secretary of States (http://www.nass.org/) and the International Association of Clerks, Recorders, Election Officials and Treasurers (IACREOT). Both are organizations for the election officials (state and local, respectively).

Thanks for the explanation Daniel. Between your comments and those of Whitney Quesenbery and Vincent Cheng I am getting a better picture of the US system. From what you and Whitney say about county based controls and the Wikipedia report of the "infamous" Florida butterfly ballot am I correct in assuming that the design and issue of ballots (even in presidential elections) is controlled at the county level? While possibly not directly relevant to accessibility it does go to the issue of best practice which in turn affects efficiency.Applying best practice in the general realm (with attendant efficiencies) does impact the resources available to  develop and apply best practices for the benefit of those with specific accessibility issues.
Yes, counties may often set their own ballot styles (although if they use DRE voting machines it may be somewhat limited by the device).
Great platform for continual + collaborative learning, Daniel!

crowdsource_election_accessibility_best_.title: Crowdsource Election Accessibility Best Practices

ballot_navigator.description: Complex paper ballots can be hard to navigate. Use design to make the clearer and easier to complete, even with the large, multi-contest ballots in the US
ballot_navigator.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Whitney,Let me reiterate my support for this idea! In the midst of some of the loftier ideas presented in this challenge, I think we also need to look at how we can make significant improvements within the current workings of the system. In most places, that means a majority of voters are using paper ballots to vote.I strongly believe that our current paper ballots have a massive amount of room for improvement. Knowing that we'll realistically be using them for quite some time while we work out the kinks of online voting and the like, I think we should take the opportunity to make them them as accessible and usable as they can be!

A simple, wiki approach to your concept might just do the trick.  This will be available in a full web version for a home or portal computer, and a mobile version for a smartphone; which can be freely accessible to all visitors.  Moreover, since it's a wiki, the information can be proactively developed by the crowd (through crowd-sourcing) and constructively refined by the designers and election officials.

Once again Whitney a common sense concept that aims for optimisation/best practice and standardisation.Again another question that I would like to know about - in Australian federal elections we always have two ballot papers to complete (usually being required to indicate multiple preferences), and occasionally a third if there is a referendum question to be resolved - is there any value in dividing complicated ballots into two or three parts - or does this happen anyway?
In the US, there is generally only one ballot per election, although it can occasionally take more, there is a strong incentive to fit it onto one sheet.

I'm still not sure I understand the ballot in the US but based on what I've seen on the brief, and on some inspirations, they indeed do seem complex. My only experience in voting (for French elections) is picking one piece of papers among several (for the first round) and two (for the second round). Therefore, it seems to me that simplifying the process and making it clearer - in paper and then with other media - is a great idea.

I thought to have an online form.  You could pick out who you want at home, print it, then bring it woth you to the polling place.(I posted a Concept on Bar Codes - which I shared some of these ideas.)At the polling station, if there's a computer screen - they should have just the one position on the screen. After you pick the candidates, it then moves to the next screen - which you see the next political position and candidates.Therefore, you won't be overwhelmed with a Ballot that's everywhere.

We could also think to have the form sent directly to the polling place with a system that can recognize you but that also delete the link between your vote(s) and you name once your vote has been taken into account (to insure that your vote is anonymous).People could vote from their home thus increasing accessibility of people who have challenges to travel.It will also increase the level of consultation that government can do toward population.

Daniel and Florian, Both great ideas - perhaps you could develop a concept around those issues. I was thinking specifically about how the form is presented, so that it works well for paper, audio and online presentation. How can we make the ballot itself simpler, especially with the complex ballots in the US.
I love the idea of organising in a linear fashion! I think that's a big part of why so much design now aims to tell stories - since we're cognitively geared to understand linear structure
Isn't it interesting that so much design tries to pack many options and alternatives onto the page or screen, even when it makes the process harder.
Am especially liking the notion of testing in a few states for usability and iteration.

ballot_navigator.title: Ballot Navigator

diaspora_voting.description: Countries often allow citizens living abroad (either permanently or at least abroad for the moment) to vote in their own elections.
diaspora_voting.creator: 68039f05f89fe63864c50905295b54e3

comments.text: This makes me think of the opposite. When living (temporary) in an other country your are most of the time not allowed to vote for the elections in that country. You have to become a citizen to do so. Not everyone wants to give up their nationality in order to vote. But the political decisions also effects them never the less. Especially if temporary means more then 2 years or so.

In Australia it is often but not always possible to hold dual-citizenship.There are even examples of people who live in Australia with Australian citizenship but are actually elected members of other parliaments.

This may be a solution in some cases, but I was thinking more along the lines of when you have are living in a country for more then 2 years you would be able to register as a voter if you want to. The government could turn down your request if they are a really good reason for it.

As a German citizen I can vote through absentee ballots in many cases. You simply send them to Germany by the local mail service. You can vote through absentee ballots whether you live in a different country or you're on holidays. The good thing is that you don't have to be there on a specific date. You can send it anytime, that's handy. Voting through absentee ballots requires the state to know where you live so that you get notified when an election is coming up. But you can also order a ballot via the internet.This system could also make voting much more convenient for people who are physically impaired: someone could simply pick up the ballot at their doorstep.

I voted abroad for my country's referendum last July. It was in the Moroccan embassy in Washington DC. The only issue is, if you're in a city that doesn't have an embassy/consulate/diplomatic representation of your own country, you might not like to drive hours to reach the nearest one to be able to vote...
Yes, this would definitely be an obstacle to consider. Perhaps this is where mail-in voting or better yet, an online interface could come in.

Interesting, Sam. When I was living and working in India a few years back, I was able to vote in the New Zealand elections online. Possibly easier for a little country like New Zealand with low population.
Absolutely! Scale & logistics would have a big role to play in this.

Yes, great provocation Sam! How can we build on practices like absentee/online voting for specific populations like expats. Much to think about in terms of overcoming barriers to broaden this to more people (security/logistics concerns at a large scale, eligibility restrictions, ease of use, etc.).

Hi Sam,interesting question and important one as the number of people leaving abroad increases. In the case of France, absentee ballots I thought (but I'm not an expert) worked only if you were temporary unable to go and vote. For the expatriates, embassies and consulates, at least in the US, organize elections. Yet, the possibility discussed by Meena of doing it online is an interesting one too although as highlighted by Meena the size of a country and population is to take into account.

diaspora_voting.title: Diaspora Voting

mail_boxes_ink_pads.description: Mailboxes/Drop Boxes or something similarly designed can be placed at various locations in rural areas to dispense information about candidates and receive ballots.  An accompanying Ink Pad Station would allow the casting of votes via fingerprints.
mail_boxes_ink_pads.creator: 8482a78370e4b5a84ccf768aedf73d9f

comments.text: Interesting thoughts Sasha  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on this challenge.

Nice idea Sasha,I think this is beneficial for better reach and accessibility. I like the idea of casting of vote via fingerprints, but I have one major concern about the security of  booth (or drop box). Since the places such as India where Booth capturing and tempering to the voting machine is very common, if government does not provide enough security to the voting centers. I hope your concept also fulfill this requirement as well.Best wishesDeepak

Thanks Deepak.  I think the design, foundation, materials used, placement, and location of the boxes can account for part of the security.There might be some other areas of technology and governmental capabilities beyond my knowledge at this time, that might lend to greater security of such Drop Boxes.I'll research further and hope to refine this idea.Thanks for your feedback.

You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know via the Support tab at the left if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

complete_online_polling_station_performa.description: Voter’s Voice is a free online platform to allow voters to rate polling stations, suggest improvements, and connect with election officials to advocate for improvements to polling station accessibility, equipment and the general voting experience.
complete_online_polling_station_performa.creator: 9e7c836b8a00e4f83d6e1d8531aecb41

comments.text: It seems that for this to be effective, there must be some type of mechanism to engage the government/poll workers. Is there any incentive to make this more of a two-sided network rather than just contributions from the voters?

Extremely well organized data and information.  Your idea is great because it helps analyze and improve current voting processes.  It's timeliness is great as it uses much of the information gathered through this challenge to help improve the process.  Great idea Graham.

Graham, fantastic to see this as one of the winning concepts. Well organised feedback is so essential to flexibility and continuous improvement. This platform can incorporate  the best elements from the similar and complementary concepts that emerged during the challenge. I hope we shall b e able to see how this is developed through the realisation phase and will watch with interest for any updates emanating from the challenge partners.
Thanks Paul. And thank you for your contributions and ideas.
Really like the updates you've made during Refinement Graham! I especially like the holistic approach you've taken to map out different elements of the system, from language translation to marketing!
Great update too Graham.
Great idea. But wouldn't a bad rating on a polling station discourage voters completely since they see that voting stations around them aren't positively rated?

Thanks for your feedback. I agree that there is a danger in potentially turning voters away from voting if their polling station has particularly negative ratings or comments. However, only one bad experience at the polling station is enough to turn someone off, so in balance the site will be doing good by allowing users to 1) feel that they have an opportunity to provide feedback about their experience, which could lesson any lasting negative impressions and 2) encourage positive changes that will improve the experience in the future. The key is linking in election officials and getting them to interact with the site and actually use some of the recommendations to make improvements to election experience.

Very true Graham - negative feedback will proliferate through informal networks. Giving voters a chance for both positive and negative feedback that can be accessed for improving the next experience is a great idea. Perhaps voters could be given the option to receive details of changes/enhancements that will be implemented as a result of their feedback. or even enter into a dialogue for improvements.

Thanks Paul. I had envision but did not adequately explain something along the lines of what you added above: a way to follow or track a thread or conversation if you have a particular interest in an issue. Will clarify that in the concept outline. Thanks!

The app could be incorporated as feedback for some of the alternatives to using conventional polling stations too - e.g. Ipad Absentee Voting or Voting Vans, as these, if adopted, would become equivalent to polling stations and require similar critiquing.

Thanks for all the feedback and the great ideas. And sorry for being away! I have been out of internet range for a few days and came back to see the concept is on the shortlist. I will work on building the concept.
Glad to have you back onboard Graham! Refinement lasts for two more days, so be sure to get your edits and updates up before then. We're heading to Evaluation this Wednesday.

Hey Graham, i like the focus of your concept on polling stations. have a look at my concept , where i am proposing to construct a database at national level to rate voting systems with varied parameters.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/national-database-for-rating-voting-system/The  same would help counts to replicate the best practices that suits electoral officials. As suggested by Meena and Paul, your concept could have direct link to my database and one can arrive at various factors that govern the accessibility of polling stations,rate them and then implement them for next elections. Would like to know your thoughts on it. I like the idea of connecting the website to social media networks-would encourage more people to participate. Thanks and Cheers Mamta

Also Graham, i feel we get the best answers when people have just finished the task , like in restaurants -one is likely to give the best feedback right after food.How about asking people to rate the performance right after they voted. Just thinking out loud -Could we ask people to give their feedback in the waitlounge( Paul' s concept -disperse the queue could accommodate this ) right after finishing the job, that would call for a kiosk/screen with website open for people to use. Thanks .Mamta
Cheers for the ideas here. I agree that it will be important to provide an opportunity for voters to provide feedback in the polling place. Will try to integrate this into the concept.

Great link to SeeKlickFix! I built on your concept and integrated a happiness icon to the acceptability map, it could link people to the website you outlined here, so they can find out about what other people thought about a specific polling station.
Thanks for the feedback. I like the build you made on your site and the idea of a simple icon for quick reference.

Hi Graham, love that this provides a real-time feedback loop for improvement.Seems like this would be a perfect Code For America project ( http://codeforamerica.org/ ), which connects technologists with governments to work together on civic innovations.Also, important to find ways to make it easy for voters to learn of & use this. Visible on-site signs/actual feedback systems, such as immediately after voting (i.e. on the way out), would provide the informational nudge at the moment when a voter is most likely to want to give feedback with the experience fresh in their mind.May also want to check out this related concept for some more perspectives: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/easy-button-feedback-for-polling-stations/

Graham, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We really liked that this idea connects voters with their election districts to provide real time feedback.During this Refinement phase, might it be possible to sketch up what this website would look like? Or think about how voters would learn about this new service and get inspired to share their experiences? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Great concept Graham!Welcome to OpenIDEO too.Will build link on this to my somewhat related concept.

Great build, Graham! Here's a couple of tips: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add Lucy's post to your Build Upon feature. That way she'll get an email notification and is likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^) Also: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
Thanks for these tips. OpenIDEO rookie here...

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)

I liked it but preferred others.
