diversity_in_voting_let_the_app_suggest.description: Mobile devices and apps enable different processes of voting using their multiple ways of input and output. But how can a poll clerk decide which method fits who?
diversity_in_voting_let_the_app_suggest.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Cansu! We really loved your idea  and your continued updates throughout Concepting!During this Refinement phase, perhaps we can think about how we might involve voters in the decision around the type of voting method that's best for them? What points in the process might voters be able to work with poll clerks to declare the kind of assistance they'd like, rather than the poll worker making the decision for them? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Hello everyone, here are my update ideas:My first concern has been 'the time spent to learn and select the kind of voting.' Now I am planning to let voters (conscious consumers) select the way they vote through the app or the website a week or two before they go to the polls. This would give them the time to take a look at the possibilities, and save time during elections.My second concern is that a voter might not even be able to use a computer alone. However, in those cases there is usually a family member assisting the person in need. So the profile or voting method can be filled by them, still enabling the voter vote by himself in the end.Finally I thought that this app, running in smart phones, ipads/tablets, in web browsers, or ATMs can be announced and used two weeks before the elections. The app starts by selecting one of these three options1. I am a voter2. I assist a voter3. I am a poll clerk1. If one selects 'I am a voter,' then he can be given several information on voting polls, candidates, that he wants to vote from home, etc.But I will focus on that he can select  either A) the way he wants to vote, such as selecting a different language, a way to input and output B) or he can create his profile by marking, for instance, that his ears do not function C) he can select 'I need a poll clerk to do all this'2. In a scenario where the voter is not able to use this app alone at all, then usually a caretaker or a family member assists the person in need. Again a week or two before, this person selects 'I assist a voter' and the app helps this assistant login the voters details, similar to the first option. The assistant might also know exactly what the voter prefers (such as that her blind son needs an audio guide); and still, the app lets the voter vote alone when the election time comes. The benefit of these first two scenarios is that, when the voter comes to the voting poll, and logins using their national ID card, the profile is already created and the voting method is set. If a voter did not login beforehand, then he is set automatically to 'I need a poll clerk to do all this'3.  'I am a poll clerk' gives a poll clerk all he needs. He can do his poll clerk training, tips on treating handicapped, his work schedule, etc. He logins with his ID, so the system knows he is a poll clerk, gives more options than a regular user.I will focus on that he can fill in voter profile and the app can help him suggest the voter how to vote (just like in the old scenarios). Although the first two options help 'conscious consumers, in this case voters' select their needs, it is not mandatory for a voter to use the app before the elections. The poll clerk should always be ready for a surprise case voter to come to the poll.For instance, two poll clerks can visit a hospital with an Ipad and help particular case voters vote using the app. Imagine that Minjun realizes his eyes do not function at all any more, right the day before the elections and he is in a hospital! A poll clerk can change his voter profile and help him with the most appropriate way of voting.I hope you can give me some feedback so that I update the concept asap:) I do not want to lose focus, so I am not sure if these three options are a bit too broad?In the end the core idea of the concept has been 'to use existing digital devices to create different ways of voting using different ways of input and output' The app is of course the user interface side of all that...

I like your three options. They are really variations in the user interface to customize the presentation for each audience. The support for the poll worker is really important. As many inspirations pointed out, they need tools to help them, too. It was your starting point, so don't lose this! The ability for the voter or voter+assistant to use the app is also great. Maybe this is something they also could do while waiting. This might be a role for the app in Paul's Disperse the Queue.

Hi Whitney, thanks for your quick reply. The voter or the voter+assistant can definitely do this while waiting! Before giving a ticket, the voter can fill in the profile, either by herself, with her assistant, or if she can not, then with one of the clerks working there.I also see that Paul suggest that voters with needs are allocated a prior number, (in some banks, bank users are given priority). In that case, the system has to somehow know that this voter is in need. If the app lets the voter fill in profile/decide on a custom voting, then the system knows that he should be given priority. In that case, should I still let the app be accessed before the election time? Because the app can also be used to get more info such as the locations, candidates. I could keep that part open for further improvement, and still focus on the core idea.

Hi Whitney, I have been doing role playing and I ended up with a conflict:If the voting app is used in the poll, I do not think a voter or a voter+assistant comes in and uses the device alone when there are a number of poll clerks around ready to help them. The app would be more useful if it lets the poll clerk 'ask the right questions to the voter and the assistant step by step' to make a fast judgement and fill in a voter body profile to suggest the voting.There is still room for the voter or voter+assistant to use the app before the elections start. Then, like I mentioned above, they would know exactly what they need and they could save this information beforehand to save time during voting.

Whilst it is true that incorporating the app in ticket issuing kiosks would be possible  it might be both difficult and costly. Additionally it would be counterproductive to the purpose of issuing the ticket, i.e. to allow voters to leave the ticket machine as quickly as possible to await their turn and allow the next voter to take their ticket and so on.On the other hand, once a voter has their ticket which reserves their place in the queue then using another machine on which the app is installed might be a very productive use of waiting time.

Good point! It is much better to separate the two systems to save time. On the other hand, the voter can be guided to the correct booth using his ticket, with the number appearing above that booth:)  Paul, I am also collecting stakeholder feedback in my comment right below this.

Yes if the ticketing system is sophisticated that could happen. I am focusing to some extent on the visually impaired as, for me at least, that is one of the disability groups for which I find imagining solutions most challenging.I will try to find some time to give you the feedback you are seeking.At the moment I need to put together my first update to the Disperse the Queue concept (and its 1 am here).
By the way - your updates incorporating the personas are excellent and very helpful..

Hi Paul, I thought about our conversation and you are right that now there is so little time, we need to focus on our concept details instead of expanding more. I just included an 'Opportunities for further improvement' section, where I will briefly talk about the possibility of a collaboration. I have not written yet (1 am here:)I am happy that you liked the persona updates. You can use the sketches as you wish! Since I made a video, I did not put the images individually here, but I can send them to you if you like.Whitney, I just updated the the concept - the text part for now. I thought about a short yes/no question guide to see if a voter has cognitive disabilities which would effect voting. I also explored ways to use existing resources for executing Vapp (new name:)
Great discussions, guys  and fab updates Cansu  especially including the personas!

Hi Cansu Congrats - just one addition al comment on the personas that arose out of my refinement on queuing - with Amy I decided that it might be practical to simply provide playpens for toddlers within sight of voting stations, then she may be able to put her child down in a safe environment and concentrate on voting. While this is perhaps a trivial example what I am getting at is that there may be another simple solution to some situations and looking for these could be a component of your app as it progresses into realisation. One final point, I don't know if you have already addressed this, as poll clerks find novel ways to assist voters it would be good for them to be able to share these as possible solutions for similar profiles.

Hi Paul, I definitely agree. If you remember, I also had a 'voting fair' kind of a concept where there was a children's corner. Well, I did not want to mix the two concepts by then, but for sure it is more practical for Amy to leave her kid at a safe environment. For the poll clerks, I tried to add a 'quick menu' where he can access 'commonly used profiles'. Also, if the idea comes to realization, then there could be a 'last used profile' since there might be a lot of similar profile voters coming at the same time, for instance a group from a blind school.
Excellent thoughts Cansu and all the best for the realisation phase.

Congratulations Cansu - this concept is easily one of the most innovative technological approaches to the issues raised in the challenge. I'm sorry my connection prevents me from viewing any videos but I have followed the other refinements you have introduced with interest. As this moves into refinement I hope we will be ab le to follow further developments.
It has been so much fun and educating to participate in the challenge. Love my virtual team and this platform!
Vapp is updated with a video explaining the concept. Sorry for my horrible voice and accent:)
Hey Cansu, some how i  likeeeee your accent ; P
haha :) thanks!

Wow Cansu - what great updates you and the community have made to this concept during Refinement! I especially like how you've added the second process by which voters can select their preferred voting method ahead of time. You're right: they're the best ones to know what they need!
Agreed with Ashley. Loved your concept's core idea from the start. And blown away by the thoughtful & extensive updates, and the video/audio presentation that convincingly brings it all to life!
I am glad you liked it:) Thanks to all the comments and feedbacks:)

Hi Cansu - love the concept and organizing the voting process.  One item that could be added would be around privacy.  There are some disabilities that would require voice prompts and others that would require people to speak (i.e. cannot see screen). Might need to consider ways to facilitate the privacy issues in the design of booths or some other such way of providing a barrier to the voice/acknowledgement of actions.
Thanks Erika, you are so right. For now, I am not focusing on that due to lack of time, but for sure a portable booth needs to be designed within the concept.

Guess what? I just stumbled upon a news from NewYork Times that Oregon teamed up with Apple to be the first state to allow disabled people vote with iPads! 'One woman, who has impaired vision, was able to enlarge the print on her ballot so that she could see the names of candidates. A man with arthritis who could not hold a pen was able to touch the screen with his finger and mark his ballot.'http://nyti.ms/uHwNbW

Hi everyone, thank you for all the feedbacks throughout the concepting phase. During the refinement, it is important to record the stakeholder feedback, which might as well be yours! So if you can comment to the following questions with a sentence or two, and include your role in voting + your profession/background below, I can use it to create a stakeholder feedback map. Please also share it with any voter with or without needs/caretakers and relatives/poll clerks/candidates you know!What opportunities would investing in this concept bring, for whom? What might be some challenges and ways to solve them?
A lot updates have been made, a lot to read. You read and and give me feedback to help me create a stakeholder feedback map. And do not worry, a video presentation is under construction!
Sorry for the misspelling, should have been: you can read and give me feedback on the material:)

This is a great idea but why not have the voter fill out his/her own profile rather than leave it to the poll clerk?  To ensure that the voter preferences are clear, accurate and explicitly stated and understood, I suggest incorporating some of the thinking from the January workshop. I am especially thinking of the Remote or Express voter profile mechanisms that came from that work.  http://elections.itif.org/projects/design-workshops/concept-express-voting/

Hello Sharron, wow the concept and the Remote or Express voter profile fit perfectly! I guess you are right that they have the right to chose, but we can only see it if we do some role playing.As far as I understood, the Remote case is when the voter fills in the profile beforehand. This means that all the voters, especially the ones with obstacles, already have access to using internet with/without help. This phase is feasible because there is no need for privacy, and they can be assisted by their family or care takers. In the express voting scenario, choosing among one of the already set up ballots (Large print, Braille, Audio, HTML link, Different language, or Personal Assistant) would definitely make things fast. The problem is when we have look at the personas, we see that people have various obstacles; take a look at Minjun. If we are rethinking voting, and if we digitalize the process, then we have so many possible combinations that will address to there different needs of some special cases. In that poll of combinations of input and output, we need a very easy to use interface not to scare voters and show it like a complicated process. For the express voting there can be a 'quick menu' with commonly used voting processes, such as 'only braille.' It could be the voter or the poll clerk filling in the voter profile, I guess this also depends on the needs and it can be decided later on. Please check our conversation with Whitney Quesenbery below where we discuss about similar issues.

I agree that there is room for both:Some voters will know just what they need, and can indicate this on their own.But poll workers will still benefit from an easy, consistent way to make suggestions to support voters at the polling place. Even better if both were consistent. Two views of the same data, all based on good accessibility practice, and what's available in each jurisdiction.
Hi Whitney and Sharron, can I ask you to check my latest reply to OpenIDEO? I would really appreciate your feedback to do some updates.

You might also want to think about how the app could help with "invisible" disabilities - fatigue, hearing, reading and other cognitive disabilities - that are both not easily apparent, and not easy to identify by pointing to a body part. Could the app also suggest ways to tactfully ask questions, suggesting appropriate and effective ways to communicate?Or have icons for things like a chair indicating someone who can't stand in a line for a long time?

Hi Cansu, I specially like your concept for the adaptability and coverage features. One additional feature could be to record each voters profile once they use the app. The next time a voter attends an election, the app is able to recognize the voters settings from previous elections and suggest the same voting method or similar methods. The voters profile could also allow the app to identify which of the voters conditions are temporary or permanent. For example, Mikkels broken arms will be tagged as temporary and he may not need voice voting for the next election. In order to remedy privacy issues, the data of a voters profile can be disabled for sharing purposes. However, one advantage of sharing this voters profile could be that other civic agencies could also improve their services.

Hi Eduardo, great input with the saving idea. It can immediately pop up in the coming election 'Do you want to load previous election setting?' I do not think that voter's profile is a very valuable information for research and development purposes, and is not very secret when all the insurance companies know it all:) However, I will not go into that at this point.
I agree that this concept could be used with access to a persistent profile, but it's not where you need to focus.
Very well executed concept and I applaud the use of several personas to demonstrate how this system would work amongst a wide range of people. Well done!
Thank you:)
I love the idea. If the voters were able to enter their information before they even go to the voting polls that could save a lot of time.
Thanks Christian, that is exactly what is going to be improved;)
Great concept! I love how well it fits the different personas!
Most of what has been presented can somehow be accomplished  here. Great level of abstraction. Great strategic and generic thinking in my view.

I really like how well the interface adapts to different needs.The only thing I would say this concept is missing though is the fact that it tackles accessibility focusing only in the election day interaction between the system and voter, leaving many other external factors aside (essentially time and trust)I think there's a lot of good ideas in this two other concepts that could help solve those issues1) Extending time: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/polling-day-s-every-day.-vote-when-you-can-when-you-want-during-any-period-of-an-election-term./2) Fostering trust: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/use-your-bank-or-doctors/I think they are both great examples of thinking of other reasons why people are deprived from access to voting. Time may clearly play a huge role (think of isolated people that can't make it to the place of voting in time or who are simply not available on that day). And (dis)trust is an issue that many countries are facing: be it because of corruption, disaffection, etc.Overall, yours is a great contribution to the challenge and it could be a valid winning candidate as it is right now! Congrats for the effort :)

Hello Borja, thanks for the examples. It is true that the concept focuses only on the voting moment, and should be combined with several other concepts. I tried to enhance the overall voting experience in my other concept: http://bit.ly/xVIw29 which turns the voting into a festival, and I did not combine the two ideas because they can also grow up independently. There is also another festival example: http://bit.ly/AjmGH0 which suggests to extend the time! So many of us have similar ideas in mind and I am sure these will merge an become a whole system by the end of the challenge. Fostering trust, I guess focuses more on the poll clerks. In fact, that same concept can also enable the computers in the hospitals and banks to be used for voting. To be honest, above all, the first challenge to solve in this concept is to design the portable ballot which will enable privacy.

I completely agree that portability and adaptability to personal conditions and abilities is the key to improve privacy and independence. Hope to see this challenge evolve among the top finalist soon in the refinement phase!

An intuitive, easy-to-use guide for polling clerks to meet diverse voter needs...brilliant.Loving your concept's core idea Cansu!I'm also thinking there's an opportunity to make an analog form of this as well (whether a visual chart, or a choose-your-own-adventure/identify-this-guide type of flipbook).

Thank you Vincent, when you say 'an analog form' do you mean some kind of a receipt?Btw I saw your Online & Mobile Voting Concept which covers so many common points with the App concept. I really do not know if it is good to focus on high tech solutions, I guess it depends on the country. But for sure a similar app can be adapted to an ATM machine or a basic desktop computer using webcam and headphones.

Hi Cansu. By analog form, I mean your idea may also work well on physical paper in cases where higher tech solutions are not feasible, such as an easy-to-use flip book that guides you through a series of simple questions & visual charts.For example, look at this page from a book used to identify trees: http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v31/kbaumle/Blog%20Phoyos/what%20tree%20is%20that/page45.jpg In terms of high tech vs. low tech solutions, I agree it depends on the situation. In the US at least, where the challenge partner (Los Angeles County Registrar-Recorder/County Clerk) is based, there's certainly possibility for mobile/online solutions like ours ;)

Oh, here's another example of an analog/paper-based form: those classic Choose Your Own Adventure children's books http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_W_4MyIMHk-Y/TCpMXOpciyI/AAAAAAAAAoc/_5sSqG3gdvw/s1600/PyramidX_6-7-small.jpg
Agreed Vincent - as in your book on identifying trees both paper and computer-based expert systems are well suited to this task, as are informal flow-charts.

Ok I see:) For instance, in a low cost solution, instead of having a single app guiding you on how to vote, you would have a paper guide with different kind of paths on how you vote. Could we also include more 'activities,' such as watching a video of all the parties before voting, sticking an 'I voted' sticker' (included in the back of the paper guide), etc. As I see, there is a definite need to create a low-cost version of the idea of 'having a different voting process for people with different needs.'
Makes me think a bit of Tristan's Mother Mati flip book concept from our Maternal Health Challenge! http://bit.ly/lAip66

Wow yea they made a great link between the digital and analogue means of giving information. This is so smart! Ashley, I am also a bit confused, are we also looking into the low-income communities? What is the evaluation criteria?

Good question Cansu - in general, low-income communities are not specifically being considered as a focus for this challenge, but that's not to say that their needs won't match up with many of the other accessibility needs we're designing for (language, literacy, mobility, disability etc). Check out our Guiding Principles for more http://bit.ly/AiJnLW as well as our Concepting Tips http://bit.ly/AdbEH2 for insight into evaluation criteria.

Thank you Ashley. Regarding the comments above, I have been thinking if I should create an analogue version of the 'different voting process for everyone' for low income communities, but I think the digital is a longer term investment and is cost efficient if existing computers and ATM machines are used. Since voting is not an everyday activity, it might not be sustainable to create an analog communication tool. The digital form can be upgraded every election time, without creating waste. I updated the concept continuing with the digital voting method; I guess the analogue can be developed as a new concept.

Great points Cansu. The analog idea is just one suggested direction this concept could take. If you think there's another concept in there, go ahead and upload it  we'd love to see it! But be sure to act fast as Concepting ends after this weekend.

Ashley, I updated the concept again adding a fast way of National ID verification. It can be linked with this concept since it suggests a the use of a mobile app, but it can also be developed separately. Now I do not know if I should add it as a new concept..

Wow Cansu, I'm really excited about the updates you've made! I think it's really your choice if you'd like to separate out the two ideas  you're right: they do work together but they could also exist separately. Either way they're great, so it's your choice. Great job!

Cansu, I love the way you have built out this idea and nice use of the personas to think through the scenarios. The scenario with Angela where she asks for one interface, but the app is able to suggest an alternative she didn't know about is a powerful example.I could also see this being used for poll worker training, building their ability to recognize alternatives. Could the core of this concept also be an online app that voters could use to think about which voting method they prefer?  I could see it connecting to one of the concepts like the Accessibility Map, so voters could check the location and hours of the nearest vote center (for early voting) or polling place (for election day). It could be flexible enough to fit in many places in elections. It would be great to have a consistent way of answering these questions. I also love the way the basic idea could be high tech (tablet or online), low tech (simple PC application) or even non-tech (as in Vincent's suggestion).One other thought: would you be able to either add a voice-over to your video, or put the text into the description so that everyone can read it?

Hi Whitney, thank you for the comments:) The format can definitely be used for poll clerk training. I am sure the complicated training they have to go through can be turned into a much more interactive and easy to use process!Building a public online app is a good idea. It can involve info on the candidates, polling places, asking for a personal assistant beforehand, etc. Keeping the same interface, the app can be developed to be used any internet browser, or be implemented to smart phones. The Accessibility Map is brilliant! Imagine that a voter is looking for the polling place and the app directs him to the nearest location using the GPS system.I am a bit worried about letting voters decide on which method of voting they prefer. The core purpose of the app is to help select the most appropriate way of voting for a particular person in a fast and not troublesome way. Why would the voter bother to learn about all the different voting methods and try to figure out which fits him most? Imagine a person with no obstacles, why would that person spend time on this beforehand? Plus, how many different voting options should be there for people with no obstacles? In case there is an option to chose, then there should be sufficient number of options..Well, now a question with an assumption..in case choosing your own voting method is important, then, how can it be attractive to people, even to the ones who neglect voting in the first place? To chose 'the voting method that fits you', a voter can be given a psychological quiz like in girls magazines: 'Which animal are you?' or 'What celebrity do you match with.' Now it sounds very lame, but the test could be fun and useful; it can analyze if the voter understands more text based information, audial, or visual..However, I still think the voting process should be kept simple. Instead of giving the time and energy on deciding on the best method of voting, a voter can be given more interesting information on the candidates. The app can decide on the voting method if one logs in the necessary information. Also, some things can not be predicted beforehand. May be Amy did not if the environment required her to carry her kid in her arm.I really want to use some post its in our conversation:) We need to suggest this to open IDEO:))Thanks for the final input, the voice over and text description are coming asap.
brilliant idea! by using this, voters really don't have to worry about location or traffic! and a big investment of time and tech...well i think it is worthwhile!
Thanks Jiangxuan (how do you pronounce your name?)I also find it worthwhile to invest in a long term system and temporary solutions.

Hi Cansu, great illustrations, I would actually suggest that the clerks will be able to guide the disabled to the right workstation without this beautiful iPad/paper guide, if such variety of workstation existed. I think a guide/check-list inspired by your thinking could help building voting workstations for the different scenarios when setting up the voting centre though.

Interesting thoughts Jakob. One thing that an app/paper guide would help with would be to support independent voting which is a central focus we've listed on our tips for Concepting: http://bit.ly/vote_tips We welcome all ideas & discussion which suggest ways to do this  including for different scenarios as you suggest. Especially thinking about our recently posted personas: http://bit.ly/vote_personas Looking forward to ongoing conversations and concepts from all of you!
Agree, this guide seems very useful if the voters can access it themselves and see that there is many possibilities for them to vote, and that people do care if they do!

Meena, the personas are just perfect! I am planning to draw a scenario for each persona and see if the system can fit all. It will look fun now that we have names for each character:)Jakob, the reason I left the mobility part open is because the clerks can actually move to the voter as well. The concept focuses on the app, while it is open to be completed with the optimumA. Booth that ensures privacy (working on that)B. Scenario where poll clerks can go to the voter (such as http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/super-clerks/)What you said actually makes a lot of sense for the scenario A. Why would the units be mobile if they are used in a specific voting place, right?

I am wondering if the poll worker will be visiting voters, how will fraud be prevented? How can you make sure only registered voters vote. Maybe it needs to be connected to ID-reader, or other identification system (weather that is credit card of social security number or tax contribution based). It would be cool if it where as easy as Login using Facebook ;)

That is one of the main challenges. Hm, no matter what obstacles a voter has, for sure he/she has a face, so may be taking a photo using the phone cam, and recognizing the person would be the most optimistic and fast scenario. I guess this concept is growing to be high tech, but if we are designing long lasting in the coming years, then it is possible..

Making it as easy as logging in to Facebook is not particularly difficult if the principles of public/private key encryption are employed. However, facial recognition could be employed if sufficiently cost-effective.

Facial recognition was just not good..And linking facebook with a national id might not be something everyone wants.Since the poll clerk is with the voter in the beginning, 'logging in' could be viewed by him as the voter is helped to put his/her national id number in. When the number is put, the name and a photo of the voter can appear, the clerk would know that it is the correct person, and then leave the phone to the voter. Is it actually faster or slower than just showing your id card..?Or, the 'logging in' can be completely separate! A voter can lend his/her id card to the poll clerk to take the phone and vote privately. Meanwhile, the poll clerk can register that this person came and voted, not relating the logging in process to his vote at all. When the voting is complete, the voter can take his is id back and give the phone back to the clerk.
I like itI this solution could be expanded to sign language, other written languages or pictos.
wow I should definitely sketch some scenarios using sign language!
Congrats on this post being today's Featured Concept!
Yes its so exciting:)

I love the idea of providing multiple options for different type of people.  I think it would also be important to allow voters to have a say in the options they are provided.  It can be difficult to asses what a voter needs in a matter of seconds.  Each individual of any ability  is an expert in their own needs.  Maybe there is a way to include the voter's voice in the process like asking the voter what they need and then providing them with options.

Thank you for your comment. This is so true! May be the poll clerk can ask the voter and have the freedom to set the input and output method in the beginning of the app. If he does not know what to do, then he can let the app suggest the most convenient method.

Great start to the concepting phase!This concept highlights that this challenge demand multiple solutions.In order to make solutions as universal as possible we will need solutions that address three levels of participation:High end participation through leading edge technology (e.g.. smartphones, tablets, on-line);Majority participation depending on jurisdiction (e.g. better access to existing facilities, redesign of ballots, using ordinary mobile phones); andMarginalised participation (e.g. marble voting, other creative ways for non-literate voters, educational and language support)..

Thanks Paul. Can this concept address the majority participation as well? The 'app' can be developed in a more primitive version, and can be used with an old computer, a webcam, headphones and a microphone. For instance, instead of 'tapping the screen 3 times,' the voter can be asked to 'click 3 times with the mouse.' In that case, the mobility of the process is restricted, but the cost is lowered down.

We could also use vocal recognition systems to increase people who can use the service as well security (we could use voice to secure voters as an additional way to do it).Then smartphone\computers will propose voting options that are visual and audio.

Exactly! We can create so many different voting methods using all the sensors and possibilities. You can see the second scenario, the final images display one person with two broken arms, voting by voice recognition.
Great use of scenario-thinking and illustration here, Cansu  and we're excited to have OpenIDEATORS joining us from Turkey!
Thanks, I am trying to bring all my friends in!

Cansu, I love how you've incorporated some scenarios to help us visualize how this concept would work! As you get feedback (like Sarah's great points below) be sure to update your entry to incorporate any builds and suggestions you'd like. Ideas evolve throughout the Concepting phase so keep the updates coming!
Thanks for the support! I added one where the poll clerk asks the voter if she has a preference to vote. Hope to get more comments and make more changes:)

You might also want to update and give your thoughts on the optional fields about resources, adaptability, etc. within the Concepting form. This all helps others evaluate your concept against various criteria we are focusing on  especially if you make it through to the Evaluation phase shortlist ;^) You can check out more guidelines here: http://bit.ly/vote_tips

promoting_awareness.creator: a610669548f25670fbed4f6cfcfc288e

comments.text: This post inspires me to highlight what could be done for students in my locality who don't have modern technology facilities in most cases.

bureaucratic_barriers_worst_than_the_arc.description: For years I took for grant the Italian voting system is an easy process and even if it's quite "vintage" can be easy for the "common people" but it's a really frustrating experience for people with disability!
bureaucratic_barriers_worst_than_the_arc.creator: 6ac7203a8c457b1508a4c97c88f1b4c9

comments.text: This is such a cool way of explaining a barrier to voting.  Love the Youtube vid.  Well done  :)
Thanks Judy, I actually did it in the attempt to figure out myself how the process worksif I had wrote it, it would have been a never ending post!
Welcome Alessia  and cheers for sharing your personal experiences to widen our global perspectives on this challenge!
Thanks Meena :)

Dear Alessia I think that in Italy we have another opportunity. When you are sick in hospital or you are permanent or temporary disable the township sholud organize a personal visit with all ballot boxes in hospital or at home. Without doubt we are not good at teaching simplicity regolations or respectful citizen!

Hi Valentina,thanks for the post and yes you're right, in fact when I was researching about the topic I realized that it's possible to vote in the hospitals and in residential care for the elderly and the regulation changes in relation with the size of the place (which is measured in "number of beds", until 100, between 100 - 200, more than 200). To be short (for what I understood) in case of "big places" a special vote section is set up inside the hospital (or elderly residences), in case of "small places" the process has to do with the gathering of the votes. The bad news it's again the bureaucracy cause the voter (which is the patient in this case) has to exhibit the "election card" and a certificate issued by the major of the municipality (election district). The process is kind of similar to the one I described in the short video cause the patient-voter (or a representative) has to find a way to reach the major's office, to ask for the certificate (paper) and to find a way to bring it back to the hospital! There's also a regulation for people that can't move from their house but again the same modalities!!    This is a demanding procedure because it always asks for help which could be fine on the side of the human relations but I'm wondering how it is perceived from the people with disabilities. I'm sure the whole process doesn't push/help them to express their vote!  More info (sorry for the Italian): http://autonomielocali.regione.fvg.it/aall/opencms/AALL/Elezioni/GuidaElezAmm/h/h2/

bureaucratic_barriers_worst_than_the_arc.title: Bureaucratic barriers worst than the architectural ones!

digital_locker_for_election_preferences.description: We all have preferences for how we participate. Do you want information mailed, or e-mailed? To vote in person or remotely? Need help when you arrive? Could a digital locker include a Voter Preference Profile?
digital_locker_for_election_preferences.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: One point inspired from the recommendation is that there should be a reliable and secured manner to authenticate a voter's identity to enable remote online voting. But whether Personal is the right solution is up to discussion. I believe as long as the government has a set of running system, which is capable to achieve the same goal (e.g. Singapore Singpass), on line voting shall be workable. In terms of personal preference, government can also conduct survey via email, or other means. Or it can make both online & offline voting channel accessible, and it's up to the voter's choice on the day.
I would like a clarification here , please. I think that a data locker may not permit election authorities to update or use data as they so wish. What do you think about this please?

Hmm. I'm not sure. Here's what I was thinking: instead of the election officials maintaining a list of personal information and preferences, what if there was a way for each voter to manage this information, but give access to it. The analogy is the way you can use Twitter to sign in to other sites, giving some access, but not control of your data.

Good idea Whitney!I can understand some privacy concerns and fully expect the issue to be raised in my inspiration on a National Voting ID Card for USA. From what I understand of the process at the moment there is already access to some private information when registering to vote. If you apply for a postal ballot they must be informed who to send it to and where.I would see the addition of a preference for if and how you want to receive information as being a natural extension of the registration process. At some point trust has to be involved and here in Australia at least I would trust such details more readily to the bureaucracy (government) than to many private organisations.

digital_locker_for_election_preferences.title: Digital Locker for Election Preferences

preregistration_requirements_could_be_el.description: Current voting requires preregistration. This forethought is more likely for those already inclined to vote. Registration percentages vary widely by state: 41-90%. With secure online voting registration could occur simultaneously with the voting act.
preregistration_requirements_could_be_el.creator: f21f74eace9933753d5f464b744cb6ce

comments.text: Hi Emily, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.
I have tried to update it with an image but never works. Sorry. I did tell the support people. :)

Agreed Emily, especially considering under-registration percentages, and the need for everyone to adapt themselves to voting systems for every election, instead of voting systems being adapted for them!I tried to flesh out secure online voting with registration here: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/ .Would appreciate your thoughts =)

preregistration_requirements_could_be_el.title: Preregistration requirements could be eliminated with secure online voting.

mobile_voting_in_rural_areas.description: It will improve accessibility to voting particularly in rural areas.
mobile_voting_in_rural_areas.creator: 9e29658df6210d6cfbca8bb7f1bdd80b

comments.text: Good start! Building on this idea, I would propose a Mobile Volting Booth. It could used different means of transport like vans, motorbikes, bicycles etc. depending on distance and local resources.It could be a service like 'pizza delivery' when you book in advance to have it delivery/brought to you.
Hi, think the concept is interesting. But you might want to think about the amount of units needed. Would it be possible to extend the voting period so that the same vans can go to various places?

Fab start. We're anticipating discussions to flourish here and your ideas to evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right. Here's an example of how built up ideas can get over the course of a challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/localfood/winners-announced/public-kitchen/ Let's bring on the builds and spell out the specifics!

mapping_from_egypt_to_occupy.description: Over the last year we have seen a dramatic rise in the personal investment in the political process, by harnessing the local and global "personal" and making it political it is possible to mobilize 100's of thousands of people to action.
mapping_from_egypt_to_occupy.creator: 43160183dee0c41d5dbbda3804b27d20

votepools.description:
Organise car/bus-pools to take people from communities to their voting stations.
Additionally, use text messaging or microblogging to help organise these at short notice.
votepools.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7

comments.text: I'm excited about the pdf documents you created to demonstrate how this concept works. I especially loved the use of a hashtag! :) Great job Ramanand.
How do you keep the votepools from becoming partisan? Is there a way of keeping them from becoming partisan?

James, by that do you mean people with partisan agendas could hijack the pools and influence voting? This has been a concern in some elections (in India for instance, political outfits aren't quite allowed to bus in large number of people because voters are often coerced or bribed into following the herd). However, would small ad hoc pools be subject to the same problem? I didn't think so, so I didn't deliberate design to prevent this. I'd love to get your thoughts on this.

I'm not sure if they would be subject to the same problem. There is a large part of me that thinks that it would be likely to occur, because partisans have the most incentive to participate in vote pools (the voter is a captive audience on the way to the polls.) At the very least, that can be unpleasant to the voter and might dissuade them from using the service in the future.I figure you can build in a feedback system. For instance, you mention twitter, so perhaps a voter who was just picked up can tweet in "Votepool driver #575 in Cleveland won't shut up about candidate Cthulhu." It doesn't really matter how the feedback system works (text, email, whatever) just as long as it becomes obvious quickly that that votepool should not avoided.
That's a great idea, James. I'll work that into the concept.

Thanks to everyone who provided suggestions for this concept. I've started paper-prototyping some of the scenarios listed above - they're available in a new attachment to this post. Will be updating this in the next couple of days. Feedback immensely welcome!
Way to go, Ramanand! I suggest you add a line towards the end of your post to remind folks to check out the PDF  just in case they miss it during the Evaluation phase.
I'll do that, Meena - thanks.

I like this idea and it works in a combination of environments. I'm not certain that it is feasible when you have individuals who have more advanced physical disabilities, unless the county or an organization is prepared with van equipped for this type of need.

Thanks - that's a great point. I do agree that this is, in its current form, has no special provisions for those with advanced disabilities, and is geared towards enabling the average voter in accessing his/her voting station. I'll try and address this in my refined version of this idea.

Lots of people have disabilities who would benefit from an easy way to get a ride to a polling place or (farther away) vote center. I like the way this allows impromptu peer-to-peer connections. It might be valuable for people with conditions that cause fatigue or pain, who don't have access to their own transportation, or for vote centers that are not convenient to public transportation (a common problem outside of city centers). Ramanand, you might think about either the concepting personas or others to describe how voters might participate in a vote pool.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Ramanand! We loved the idea of tapping into existing routines and building off personal relationships. During this Refinement phase, let's think about ways to start building this microblogging or text-based service, perhaps even prototyping with sketches or mockups of what it would look like? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Thanks - I'll add some more details and prototypes very soon.

I really like the voter-to-voter nature of this idea. The political parties and other advocacy groups have always organized ways to get their supporters to the polls. (I learned that one reason there are lines at early voting centers is because groups organized vans and bus-pools, so a lot of people can arrive at once..)his could let voters connect on their own. It could take on a social/gaming aspect: will you go with your neighbors, your friends from work, or your sports club (etc). This would make it a nice build on the idea that elections are social, but also be practical and easy to implement.Foursquare and the Voter Information Project joined up to create "I voted" badges. Maybe this could extend that in some way.

Thanks for pointing to the badge project - we could extend this thought to other markers, online (twitter/facebook will add a badge/turn your page's colour from red to green when you've voted) and offline (bumper stickers for the car/badges for all the car-pool-mates are given at the voting venue after you've finished).

In Cities, it may be easier to pick up more people at once... If you have multiple registered voters in one apartment building, you can make just one stop...  You could also have someone in each building see who else needs a ride within the building.  So, people in the building can do some of the legwork.  You could also see ahead of time (weeks in advance) who will need a ride within that building - or closeby... so, you can have a bigger or smaller vehicle ready to pick up as many people as you anticiptate.On picking people up - you could also see if Bus Companies, and/or Van companies would donate vehicles just for Election Day.  This way you could have the bigger vehicles at the ready.  You could have a car with an extra spot or two... but with a van, you could have an extra 5-7 spaces.  And, 20+ extra spots with a bus.----In rural areas, you'll have to be prepared to drive longer, to pick up less people...  -----All votes count equally in the end.

Daniel - thanks. yes, this doesn't necessarily have to be planned on the day of the voting and as you say, can be begun in advance. Anything to remove the mobility obstacle. I'm sure there would be volunteers willing to go out of their way to get people.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks! Have also updated the post to include the many suggestions that have come in.
Like other comments here this is a very good idea.I can imagine a bumper sticker "We Pool Our Vote - join us - Votepools.com"

Nice thought to scale up carpooling for elections Ramanand.In various countries including the US, I think this could be a great partnership/initiative for carpooling/ridesharing organizations like http://www.zimride.com/ : they would promote election day carpooling to allow everyone to vote, and if they usually charge any matching fees, they could waive them for just that day (probably pretty small impact anyways, considering the relatively short distance of these rides).Altogether, this would provide the social benefits of increased voting & carpooling, while also introducing people to these organizations' carpooling matching systems.
Thanks for pointing to zimride.com. It hadn't struck me that an agency like this could also promote carpooling by being associated with such important days, so it's a very useful idea.

Great discussion guys. RJ: if there are any comments that you feel you would like to add & develop into your concept you can do so throughout the challenge using the Update Entry button up there on the right. When it comes to evaluation, it's helpful if all the fab ideas which have been discussed have been incorporated into the concept form. Bring on the builds!

Like others I like the idea of building upon people and self-organizing systems. Vincent's idea of building upon carpooling organizations is a great one as it might make the process easier. Not only it would make easier for people to go, but maybe create a gentle pressure to go... You could image a website where you could search or ask for a car ride based on the location of your poll (assuming that the system of the poll and an assigned poll is our context).Ashley also noted on another concept how the social aspect of your concept could nicely be connected to the idea of elections as a community celebration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/elections-a-community-celebration/
I like the social aspect of this - there's no additional official government/state/electoral structure that's being created. People's support for the people's voice!

Thanks - that's what appeals to me as well :) Self-organising and decentralised systems should make it possible for people to have a feeling of contributing to the democratic process, beyond just voting.

Have a look what happened during Mumbai elections, quiet similar to your concept, :)http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Taxis-autos-have-profitable-run-as-parties-book-them-in-numbers/articleshow/11906690.cms

Jaskeerat :) as you probably know, Indian parties have always been good at mobilising their supporters; hence there are restrictions on taking people in groups. My idea is hopefully to help ordinary people, esp. in other places where political mobilisation isn't as 'sophisticated', and assuming no political bias.The other difference is not paying for this service and getting people to voluntarily offer their help.
Nice thinking to leverage existing resources, Ramanandan.
Ooops! I meant Ramanand  feel free to misspell my name anytime you like ;^)
Thanks Meena. And as for the name, I'm used to it :) Your's is kinder to the keyboard!

votepools.title: #Votepools - Refined

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

voting_for_shut_ins_and_people_with_agor.creator: d02f11d07dc073625590a7ba338ca614

comments.text: Hi Jessica,Thanks for bringing up this point, I've just commented on another post few minutes ago and I was kind of stating that, to me, "being part of something" has a huge value and it's like to compare the experience of being immersed in high-energetic environment (for instance a concert) with a private experience (for instance to listen to the music in your living room). I didn't consider this "shade" that deserves attention as part of the whole. This post taught me something about pushing beyond personal experience and trying to imagine a large range of possibilities (something that isn't always easy)!
Good idea to think about mental health obstacles and not just physical ones.

steve_tells_his_own_story_of_using_an_ey.description: Communication and Control System for people with complex physical disabilities.It enables user to communicate using only the movement of eyes.It is being used to write books,attend school and enhance the quality of life of people with disabilities.

comments.text: Fab inspiration Ashutosh! Makes me think about Dominic's Natural User Interfaces post too http://bit.ly/zy4aFW. Perhaps you want to connect it to your post using the Build Upon feature? This helps us all join the dots between related inspirations and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points! If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you can go in and add that post using the Build Upon feature.
And clearly, after checking out all of your great builds on the right, you're a pro when it comes to connecting your post to others! Keep it up! :)

Thanks for the link Ashley!!:) I was bit confused about how to use "Build Upon" feature. But I got slight idea by seeing other posts and later I tried connecting as many inspirations as possible. I hope, it will be helpful for all of us during different phases of this challenge.:)

Absolutely! As you get the hang of OpenIDEO, you might also want to check out our User Forums https://openideo.zendesk.com/forums  there are some great tips and tricks for how to do things, including building upon other posts http://bit.ly/xrBP2z.

Thank you for your comment professor Anne-Laure but I think they could do it in terms of voting as well where they could have students voting right after their registration process.

compulsory_voting_the_ultimate_freedom_o.description:
Freedom without rules is merely anarchy and ultimately benefits almost nobody.
The essence of democracy is a society that lives by the rules that the society agrees will benefit as many as possible and harm as few as possible.
compulsory_voting_the_ultimate_freedom_o.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Yes, I agree, living in a democracy gives you both some basic rights, but also some important obligations that is important to fulfill.to show leaders that the society cares, and are constantly being updated about their rights and obligations
Thanks for the comment Johan. I would be interested in knowing more about the Swedish system but sadly I suspect language would be a problem for me.

If I show up to vote, and pick a "blank" ballot card to stick in the "urn", it is of much higher value as a message to leaders :"I don't like any of the options you present". (easier to count who is actively protesting against the issue or the system)A real statement.If I just stay at home on the couch, they will be able to ignore me, writing me off as irrelevent, because they can say I just forgot to vote, or came too late or did not bother.That is why I think everyone should at least go to the polling stations! And always include the option for people to select "None of the above" (remember Richard Pryor in the movie "Brewsters Millions"?)If you try to force voters to choose between either cholera and the black plague, they will not play along...

compulsory_voting_the_ultimate_freedom_o.title: Compulsory Voting - the Ultimate Freedom of Choice

vote_compass_for_literacy_and_engagement.description: For the Canadian Federal Election 2011, Canada's national public broadcaster (CBC) launched Vote Compass, an interactive online tool intended to enhance electoral literacy and stimulate voter engagement.
vote_compass_for_literacy_and_engagement.creator: 77a318bafd76867b570d82539f09f2a9

comments.text: Looks interesting! However, how could it work if theres a lot of parties? or more than one candidate in the same party?That tool sound wonderful for young people that dont follow politics so much but feel the citizen right to vote.

Thanks for your comment Camila!If there's a lot of parties, there would be more possible answers per question. But too many choices would become cumbersome. Personally, I would not exceed 6... If there are too many parties or candidates, a similar tool could be designed to help people structure their thinking and consider major issues. It could also be targeted to people with cognitive disabilities and used prior to the vote itself. Then, it would enhance the "expected user experience" (before the interaction, ie. vote).

Hi Gabrielle,I saw this too and thought it was a really interesting tool to engage people, particularly those who don't consider themselves very political.  Multiple parties and candidates could make it a little more complicated than just dealing with the 4 major parties in Canada (5 in Quebec) but I think the compass could be calibrated for multiple platforms with additional questions. I hope the CBC rolls this out again!

Interesting idea and a subtle way of showing how similar many parties are with only a few issues separating them  It would be interesting to be able to see (over a number of years) how the party positions change according to the changing demographic mix. The modal (most common) age in Australia is 26, although the state in which I live has a modal age of 50. This is interesting (to me) because the parties (naturally) try to appeal to as many voters as possible and the interests and priorities of 26 and 50 year olds are likely to be very different.

This is a nice idea.. People disabled wouldn't travel outside often and will be detached from social interactions. This tool help them to given an insight about views of each political parties. This kind of information along with accessible voting system will be a great tool for the  them

vote_compass_for_literacy_and_engagement.title: Vote Compass for Literacy and Engagement

on_peer_pressure_in_voting.description: The voting pressures I experienced at a left-leaning liberal arts college got me thinking about voting dynamics and what drives voting behavior. Is there an opportunity to leverage peer influence in some way as we try to improve access?
on_peer_pressure_in_voting.creator: 6ca53c38aff4f2024f8442bd320a8ea2

comments.text: Josh - could not agree more that the 'soft' side of the solution is very important. While I don't necessarily believe that the use of 'pressure' in peer pressure is the right positioning of the language (as you allude to), the principle has merit. Perhaps 'peer support' or 'peer education' may be more appropriate? There are many solutions that could come from this avenue of enquiry, for example:- What role do the organisations that represent our target constituencies have to spread stories of its members?- What can be done to help the individual that has had a positive experience to spread that amongst her/his peers?- As you mention, how can peer-to-peer networks be built, managed and leveraged appropriately?

on_peer_pressure_in_voting.title: On Peer Pressure in Voting

a_cotton_farmer_confides_on_a_post_it_no.description: The story of how a cotton farmer told me of his losses without saying a word.
a_cotton_farmer_confides_on_a_post_it_no.creator: 7ee7e9a7fb2834f9f52be40680564291

comments.text: Hi Pradeep, thanks for sharing this deeply personal account. It's a great reminder that, at the end of the day, this challenge is talking about people, and providing everyone with the opportunity to have their say in their community and country. I wonder if you could provide a bit more background on this story to help round out some of the details? Where were you? When was this? It sounds like you were helping at a polling station  what was that like? Thanks again for sharing this.

color_coded_ballots.description: By color coding topics on ballots you could provide candidates stances and opinions on key issues in the election.  Currently voters are bombarded with dozens of names but very little information about candidates on ballots requiring prior research.
color_coded_ballots.creator: 4c927c3bb5ebbc5f5870e066d1c6eba7

comments.text: Thanks for your imput guys! Here are my two cents.Regarding colorblindness, putting symbols along with the tags would work for those who are severely color blind.However the direction I was going with this was not so much the idea of color on the ballot, but creating acceptability for voters with no access to media.  By creating easily digestible information along with a clear easy to understand system of tags to identify candidates positions on several key issues, you could allow voters with no access to television or internet to make a somewhat informed decision.And regarding candidates changing their mind on the issues, the goal here is to outline their stances on four or five key issues in the election, not their stances on minor bills or everyday items.  Ideally candidates shouldn't be switching their opinion on a issue that is defining that years election several days before voting.  Finally a series of tags could easily be made to accommodate more than a dichotomous issue.  Really any number of possible stances on an issue could be incorporated into a tag system so there's no reason these would have to be yes and no type issues.

I think this idea is a hint in the right direction. To keep it simple and understandable should be the starting point of a working concept. If you transform different political topics into colors or icons or any scoure system one is able to compare political parties/topics/candidates easier. It mabey only a part of the solution, but an important one.

John - What happens when a candidate changes their mind about an issue close to an election date? What happens for the 10% of Caucasian males who have colour deficient vision, and cannot distinguish some colours? Can you really distill political opinions into simple 'Yes' or 'No' positions?

I am not familiar with the current voting ballots but it seems an improvement to me. A good design can definitively reduce error. I Iknow that good form design is not always a given in the states.One point of attention for color coding, some people don't see color or perceive it differently.Creating block is helpful. And the placement of the blocks also convey some information (if used in a consistent way). In addition you might use a symbol for your red and green sub-blocks, or different line styles. Because red-green deficiency is the most common form of color blindness.

color_coded_ballots.title: Color Coded Ballots
