text_to_braille_concept.creator: ba1d54060160cefeb885117191c52c30

comments.text: Good suggestion in the circumstances you describe.I am absolutely amazed that US states cannot agree and apply best practice in this area. The more I hear about different and inconsistent  approaches the more I understand the need for this challenge, especially as it relates to US.

text_to_braille_concept.title: Text-to-Braille Reader

studying_the_usage_of_the_bangalore_bus_.description:
Ensuring that people with disabilities are able to reach voting centers is key.
This study can serve as a pointer for us to gain empathy into pain points and discover opportunities in improving the accessibility of transport systems.
studying_the_usage_of_the_bangalore_bus_.creator: 86c22340e6c3fb7b0e76dc33f8507892

comments.text: Hi Ishan, interesting research! I shared an inspiration about using public transport during voting. Maybe it will help you to create a concept in the next phase or we could team up to create a concept together. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-in-public-transport/

Could certainly be some learnings for Bangalore (& this challenge) from the internationally award winning BRTS in Ahmedabad http://places.designobserver.com/feature/peoples-way-urban-mobility-in-ahmedabad/12918/ When I was researching this story a few years back, I was heartened at the response from those who previously faced accessibility issues that were now enjoying this system.

studying_the_usage_of_the_bangalore_bus_.title: Studying the Usage of the Bangalore Bus System by the Blind

the_election_poster_wall.description: In Morocco, I grew up around these walls where each candidate gets a numbered space to put up a poster.
the_election_poster_wall.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: Very interesting, Sarah.What I like most about the designated spaces for election posters is that they put all parties on an equal footing, in the eyes of a passer by. There is something to be said about how this kind of structure, as simple as it is, encourages fair representation of parties and candidates. (I've built on these ideas in my own inspiration post.)An equivalent to your poster spots, but in another medium, might be the few minutes of free television air time accorded to each of the national parties by Canada's public broadcaster, during an election. In both examples, more or less money can be spent on the content within the alloted media space, perhaps resulting in a better poster or a video with better production values, but distribution-wise it is on equal footing.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Nice insight and images. I just realized that we have indeed some boards with numbers in France. I went to search for some images: http://archeologue.over-blog.com/article-les-affiches-des-elections-regionales-en-ile-de-france-2-46947457.htmlI never really thought of why, nor of what it could provide for people. I'm curious to know if people "use" these numbers...

I'm not sure they do actually, esp. b/c the numbers differ from a place to another (depending on whether it's a local/national list, and the order in which candidates have registered).  I think the most important thing (at least in Morocco) is just actually "making sense" of the different candidates. I remember my grandma, who was illiterate, she would talk about parties not using their actual name, but their symbol ("so I was thinking of voting for the lamp, but my neighbor said she is voting for the tractor").
I'm not really sure how to explain this correctly...
Thanks Sarah. You explained it very clearly. I guess I was wondering if people in France were "aware" of these numbers and used them, the same way your grandmother used the symbols.

I agree the explanation is clear. The use of numbers, symbols or colours is a good way to allow people to discuss the different candidates. In this way the information about candidates can be shared by word of mouth without everyone having to be able to read or understand specific campaign material.At some point though there has to be a link between the symbols, colours or numbers and the candidates representation on the ballot paper (like Raviraj Pare's Indian example), although it might be a bit different if the ballot is open rather than secret.

Great example of the power/influence of simple branding. When I was in Malawi political candidates would be associated with a primary color - and whole marketing schemes would be developed around this identity - e.g. posters prominently featuring the color yellow, radio songs about the yellow candidate, chitenjes (multi-purpose sarong-like fabric) printed in yellow. It's a really effective way to make the elections accessible to the public - especially to those unfamiliar with the intricacies and nuances of political processes.

Fantastic inspiration! I agree that the use of numbered spaces to help people identify candidates is a fantastic idea.Furthermore, I think this also touches on another issue of accesible elections- making them more accesible to candidates who don't have the funds for huge campaigns. If there are limits to the space where people can publicise themselves, then the amount that candidates with more funding can push out disproportionately large advertising campaigns would be limited.

Hi Sarah,in Italy we have something more similar to the French ones, on "mobile metal boards". If you see posters on a wall it's often unauthorized... which it's actually a big issue because parties are supposed to pay sanctions (for the unauthorized ones) that invariably don't pay. So, as you supposed, at least in Italy, the numbers are related to the attempt to organize the space equally.

I like the idea of thoughtful art in public spaces.Its especially interesting to see art and politics fused together in a non-partisan way.I wonder if there is a way to engage talented artists and support literacy over time, by incrementally raising the bar in a teach and learn exchange...

In Colombia, doesnt exist the wall sample, nevertheless when I was a kid, it used to be just 2 parties, liberals (RED COLOR) and conservative (BLUE COLOR) and if you vote you got a red or a blue finger. The avoid that because the social conflicts of extermists people on the parties. However, I agreed that colors, numbers or even symbols are easier to identify with a party or a candidate to vote. I think that for president is easier address these solutions, but in terms of congress or chambers are more candidates to indentify in that way.
Interesting global insights as always Sarah!
Remember this from your tweet Sarah. Glad you posted it here =).

in India every party/candidate has a symbol and a number. the campaigning is also done with these symbols and numbers. No identifies public place exists for banners. so the louder and prominent candidate gets heard.

the_election_poster_wall.title: The election poster wall

my_first_time_voting.description: Reflection on my first time voting in the 2008 US election
my_first_time_voting.creator: c9ab1eee5269fd3777d652f05817dac7

comments.text: Actually,voting is a good method for participatory decision making. In as much as we are disillusioned with its practices, we should do what e can at our small corners to improve the processes.

Amina, thanks for sharing your story! I agree with you that voting is very much a social activity. As we start thinking about concepts, I hope we can draw on this idea to include those who have been excluded not only the process of voting, but also those social aspects you described as well.

my_first_time_voting.title: My First Time Voting

engage_4_change.description: In California, the Engage4Change.com campaign used Ideavibes’ Crowd Engagement Platform to “tap into the wisdom of the crowd to build better products, engage citizens, and fund the change they want to see.
engage_4_change.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: Anne - I'm a big fan of social-based systems using the crowd like this and in this challenge it would be great to explore how this might work. Some things to consider as we think about it:- We have a large number of different groups we want to touch, many of which will have issues with access to systems (e.g., rural communities)  and/or ability to engage (e.g., difficulty in using current technology). As such we should think carefully about where this would be most applicable.- There is a real opportunity to create a virtuous cycle here. By giving people who have access issues a bigger voice they are likely to get the issues they care about higher up the list of political debate, candidates and parties will be included to take these issues more seriously and the voters will themselves feel more compelled to vote and more likely to choose to overcome any barriers they have to doing so.

engage_4_change.title: Engage 4 Change

the_art_of_choosing.description: The challenge of an accessible election experience begins long before election day. Engaging meaningfully with the process should mean making an *informed* choice - whatever that choice looks like. How can we help people inform themselves?
the_art_of_choosing.creator: 3cecef35c0cd484c61df0b2829a90be4

comments.text: Really nice thinking here Luc  thanks for sharing. I'm looking forward to seeing what our other community members have to say in response to your questions!

Thanks Ashley, I used to volunteer and still have an interest in adult literacy and I actually started thinking about how individuals with literacy challenges could be supported to make an informed choice.  Then I thought "hang on, there were quite a few perfectly literate people who didn't do that!" :)There are lots of reasons for this.  One of those might be a kind of search fatigue.  What I like about StumbleUpon is that I can sit there and browse a whole lot of stuff without having to work very hard at searching, re-searching, selecting, evaluating, backing out, searching again... and I've discovered all sorts of interesting things I would not have deliberately searched for.  So I was thinking that if you could sit down and 'stumble' through a whole lot of political articles, blogs, commentary, party information etc in the weeks ahead of an election, that might engage some people who are too exhausted at the end of a working day to sit down and work (because it *is* work, really) to find information to help them choose.Then there are those who actually have literacy challenges.  Perhaps something similar which channels video content only?I also think that people are afraid to ask questions or say "I don't understand" so a 'place' or medium by which people can ask for advice without being attacked or sold on a particular party/choice could be helpful too.  As an example, I met a lot of people in our last election who didn't understand one of the voting systems we were being asked to evaluate and vote on.  A pretty important thing to understand!  There is probably a social media solution :)

Luc, very interesting and important questions. I agree with you that while some of these issues are critical when people have literacy problems, there are still important for literate people. Technology can help by providing access to some of the information, maybe facilitating the access to information and offering various formats / media (e.g. video as you suggested). Still you have to assume that people have the analytical skills to manage the information (that links some of this conversation to education issues discussed in other inspirations). I am also wondering if providing educational programs or providing access to people, or having people visiting communities to explain the process and the different options could also be complementary options to think of.
Go to the homes of people who can not move, technology can give us the solution, I don't think it's a crazy idea.

the_art_of_choosing.title: The Art of Choosing

copenhagen_bicycle_count.description: One of the most crowed bridges of Copenhagen, Norrebro Bridge, hosts a bicycle counter, which displays the number of bikes passing every day and throughout the year.
copenhagen_bicycle_count.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: Love the idea of real-time counters! I think this can help generate a lot of buzz on the day.
Nice inspiration Cansu  this sounds like a great way to make people feel part of a larger movement/community and to make the process more transparent.

While showing totals for each candidate would be a bad idea (want to avoid gaming of the system)... just showing a total number of votes cast might be an interesting idea to pursue however.  Great inspiration!

copenhagen_bicycle_count.title: Copenhagen Bicycle Counter

improve_voting_by_having_fewer_people_ph.description: Why do people need to vote at all? Statistical models are increasingly accurate and could be used instead of actual voting if we opened up the polls and made it transparent we might improve accuracy of our elections and save money at the same time!
improve_voting_by_having_fewer_people_ph.creator: 92b3cfe4eb4274b7945f4b7ab67166eb

comments.text: Very interesting thoughts, along the lines that I have preciously wondered. I think there are some paradigm-shifting concepts possible to work on in these areas...

I also find this interesting although I have a number of concerns with the suggestion, at least from an Australian perspective, but I can see some possibilities for the US situation.First amongst these from a personal point of view is that I value my chance to vote (and to contribute my information to census too). I would feel disenfranchised if my neighbour was polled and I was not.Nevertheless I applaud your contribution as it gives the opportunity consider such alternatives.

of course I have also some concerns, on how to make it secure and uncorruptable and transparent enough to qualify as democratic.but interested in brainstorming some more along those lines:I was primarily thinking about letting all adults vote, whenever they felt like, once a year or just every fifth year. And you just count the last vote made. (makes it possible to change opinion every month if you want to)And you use some clever algorythms at regular interval checks, to often alter representation in congress or senate according to latest numbers.would this make more "consumer-power" or less? only create confusion or send the message clearer to elected leaders that they will be kicked out instantly if they do something voters don't agree with?I think that the census bureaus (or stock traders) can have some amazing software and expertise about what is needed for this type of process to maybe build upon???

Makes me think of the Iowa Electronic Markets: "The IEM is an online futures market where contract payoffs are based on real-world events such as political outcomes, companies' earnings per share (EPS), and stock price returns." http://tippie.uiowa.edu/iem/Also the work of FiveThirtyEight (that's the number of Electoral College votes needed to win), which analyzes and weights polls to make predictions. http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/

improve_voting_by_having_fewer_people_ph.title: Improve voting by not voting! (use polls instead...)

ease_of_election_experiences_fostered_by.description: During major elections and referendums, politically active on-campus organizations took steps to engage the student body. Additionally, these organizations distributed 3rd party info about the issues and candidates on the ballot.
ease_of_election_experiences_fostered_by.creator: 081cbcaf0242d3572460a9b7635917ba

comments.text: The locations of polling places in the United States are decided according to the needs of local election districts, or precincts. It is my intuition that the creation of this kind of flexible, temporary, and targeted (targeted in this case towards a specific population of students) polling station probably requires the weight of a large institution behind it, but also would depend on the needs of the precinct. The specific locations of polling places are typically decided by local committees and officials.I'm not sure elections are simply viewed as an unnecessary interruption, I think the low voter turnout is a combination of factors. In my experience, low voter turnout has a lot to do with either contentment with the status quo, or a disenchantment with the electoral process. I have been reviewing some literature on the issue, and decreasing voter turnout has been attributed to a number of different causes. One of these causes being, of course, that some people do claim to not have enough free time. There are a number of socio-economic and cultural/hereditary factors,  factors that play a role in election day behavior as well. Voter turnout tends to be higher for presidential elections than it is for state legislative elections. Also, the best predictor of whether or not you will vote in an upcoming election is whether or not you voted in the last one, indicating that voting behavior might be able to be taught/learned as a habitual behavior. This statistic also highlights the need to target and encourage young voters to get out and vote for building strong voter turnout in future elections. If you can get people engaged in the electoral process early, it seems like that behavior generally maintains itself over the course of a citizen's lifetime.

The polling booths were set up as part of a collaborative effort on behalf of the university administration and clubs representing Democrats and Republicans on campus. The booths were on campus, just off of a major pedestrian traffic zone. It was made so that the voting process was practically integrated into the our daily walk to class, at least if you lived on campus.  I am sure a huge number of students voted who might not have taken the time to vote otherwise, thanks largely to the ease of the process and the display of positive energy by student volunteers.

Thanks Matt - so I gather they were extra booths.Does this mean that other organisations could do similar things and set up extra booths?As an Australian (with compulsory voting) I am trying to get a handle on how sites for booths are decided and by whom.In Australia it is totally controlled by the Electoral Commissions who have access to the latest demographic data to decide where booths are best located including providing things like wheelchair access.Although, as I understand it, the usual turnout for US elections is about 40% I suspect there will be clusters of high and low turnout areas.Pardon my assumption but would you say the average American regards voting as an unnecessary interruption to a daily routine?

Very interesting story Matt.Do you know who set up the polling booths?Were they extra booths i.e. places that had not been used before?Given the apparently ad hoc nature of voting in the US this is a really good example of what can be achieved.Were all the booths close to the university?Were students given the day off classes or did they use spare time for this?I have some follow up questions depending on you answers to those above.

ease_of_election_experiences_fostered_by.title: Activism and Ease of Elections

theatre_of_the_oppressed.description: Augusto Boal began using interactive theatre exercises in Brazilian favelas in 1971 with the aim of showing people how to help themselves through democratic institutions.  Now there are hundreds of groups using his philosophy all over the world.
theatre_of_the_oppressed.creator: 54bac105a13dacb597a175650263f4d8

comments.text: This is fascinating - makes me think of how people are always drawn in by street performers and form an instant community as they watch the spectacle together. Harnessing the entertainment power and mobility of street theatre to educate and engage citizens about voting rights and processes is an exciting approach. The "shows" would also present a great opportunity to register voters, distribute election materials, and so on. On a side note, theatre could be a great tool to combat voter apathy in established democracies as well (think "get out the vote" flashmobs). Thanks for sharing Ali.
Hi Ali, This sounds fantastic! I must do a bit of reading into it. Thanks for posting.

theatre_of_the_oppressed.title: Theatre of the Oppressed

google_launches_new_site_with_resources_.description: Information for voters: includes news articles sorted by candidate and issue, links to voter resources such as the political calendar and YouTube politics channel and a search trends dashboard, news mentions and YouTube views for each candidate
google_launches_new_site_with_resources_.creator: 19d366a78e9bc2172eaf549b52b71019

comments.text: Cheers for sharing this with us Ohood! I went to check it out myself and found these two sites: one for the US election http://bit.ly/xLOY8R and one for the Egyptian election http://bit.ly/um3axe. I wonder if this means they'll be providing this kind of trend analysis and info for elections as they happen around the world?
Will be interesting to see how they manage the impartiality.

Nice inspiration Ohood. I had a quick look at the Egyptian mentioned by Ashley. Really interesting and a great resource.Information indeed is an important component and raised by few inspirations such as http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/confusion-and-empowerment- and http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-art-of-choosing/As Paul noted, it is interesting to see how they will manage impartiality as analysis and visualization always involves some interpretation...
I find that is interesting too, the site is up and is more accurate than polls in gathering info. Thanks for the response!

google_launches_new_site_with_resources_.title: Google Launches New Site With Resources for the 2012 Presidential Election

voting_in_public_transport.description: Use the public transport to reach more votes during the election day. Most of the trams and buses in the Netherlands are easy accessible  for the disabled.
voting_in_public_transport.creator: 324905aefb58c08771149a326741025c

comments.text: This is innovative. The problem her is monitoring. How objective will the electoral officer perform his task. It would imply teams would be assigned to all buses or trams.
Thanks for the keen analogy Jeroen! The public transport fleets could also be concentrated on election days or even pilot "Election Routes" encouraging transit and voter participation in one action.
Thank you Michael. It definitely could! It's a strong combination. Maybe we should think this over and create a concept of this in the next phase
Yes Jeroen, I look forward to the collaboration.
Maybe we could already getter some inspirations in this challenge, that we could use for a Election routes concept

Thanks for sharing. First of all, I find it interesting to do the elections during the week. In France, elections take place during the weekend. Yet, it does not always help the process as there are always these stories about people going away for the weekend and not voting, or the rush of the Sunday evening for big elections where people come back from weekend. So it seems that there is no perfect day for organizing elections! :-) Here in the US, there is an election day set by law for the general elections of public officials (the Tuesday after the first Monday in November).  I like the idea of trying to adapt to the context and in this case use commuting time. Also using a bus or a tram (which has to be easily accessible) as a voting space is also a great idea and it is mobile as well.
Thank you Anne-Laure for your comment. Maybe we could spread voting over 2 days. One day during the week and one day in the weekend. Friday and Saturday?

Hi, thought of your post when reading this one about voting day as a holiday: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/election-day-as-a-national-holiday-/Friday and Saturday or a holiday.I think that the mobile aspect is also something to be explored. The use of "spaces" that are already designed for accessibility is also very interesting.

also reading about your experience in the Netherlands, the inspiration in Brazil, and my experience with French elections, it still seems that doing this during the weekend might be a good idea. For example for the last French presidential elections, I was in NY and it took place on a weekend and there were long lines nearby the 2 voting places set up by the French consulates. It is unlikely that so many people would have come during the week.

Australian elections are always held on a Saturday.Polling booths/stations are close enough to each other so each has between 1000-2000 votes. This also means that the staff can count all the paper votes for a booth usually in less than an hour, so preliminary results are available very quickly.

Hi Anne-Laure and Paul,This is a really interesting topic. There doesn't seem one right answer on which should be the best voting day. I think it depends strongly on the culture. In Belgium for example they have compulsory voting. I don't know if that should be the answer of the problem?

Hi Jeroen, It is indeed an interesting topic: culture and voting practices! I was talking with someone from Ecuador the other day and she was telling me how voting is mandatory in Ecuador. As I was asking how "mandatory" it was. She told me that if you don't vote, this will show up on your "profile" if you try to get a loan from the bank...

Interesting idea,I imagine there are more vehicles than platforms/stations. Platforms/stations would be easier for set up than the vehicles but still accessible for the disabled. Nevertheless involving public transport is an excellent suggestion, especially in places where public transport is well used.
In the Netherlands they already created places to vote in railway-stations!

Nice inspiration, Jeroen. I've moved out of the Netherlands a little while back, and have missed developments like this. The picture of the old tram in front of De Grote Kerk, immediately caught my eye, since I'm originally from The Hague. I think the important lesson we can take from how the Dutch approach this, is that they (we) try to bring the voting process to where the people actually are. For us as expats it was a bit different, we had to preregister and then vote by mail, but still.
Thank you for your comment Arjan. There are a lot more initiatives like this in the Netherlands during elections that all focus on bring voting to the people in time and in place.

I agree. Bring the voting to the people versus making the people go to the voting. I live in Los Angeles, and the idea of fighting rush hour traffic to make it to my polling location is enough to make me reconsider whether to vote or not - especially in the minor elections. I can imagine it's even more so for the disabled or poor who do not have ready access to transportation or are holding multiple jobs and just don't have the time.

This reminds me of a system we had at my alma mater that took people on public transit to voting stations. It was a great experience because it gave people an opportunity to discuss the election and create a sort of buzz and excitement around the event. Cool experience.
This is brilliant!
Thank you Sarah
Fantastic Jeroen!!!
thank you Irune!
Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
Thank you Meena for the tip. I updated my inspiration
Voting on the commute? You've got my mind churning Jeroen ;)

voting_in_public_transport.title: Voting in Public Transport

think_a_wheelchair_user_s_daily_struggle.description: This video highlights some of the problems wheelchair users face every day of their lives and how just a little bit of thought can make their lives so much easier.
think_a_wheelchair_user_s_daily_struggle.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Thanks for sharing Whitney. It does indeed take only a little thought but it is hard for people to realize and empathize. I know that each time I'm in the subway and see a woman with a stroller in front of the stairs, I offer to help. They always look surprise but also accept the help with the smile. One of the reasons for my offering is that I remember going up the stairs carrying a stroller with a toddler in it. To your point about the motivation needed: while it takes people designing a system or an environment a little bit more thought, it takes much more motivation to go and vote.

My experience is that in as much as it is good to empathize with disabled, the majority would prefer equal treatment with the able population. Empathy often causes them more pain as we gathered from a survey on "Treatment for Disabled' which we conducted in late 2010.

Thanks for highlighting this point and sharing the results of this survey. I completely understand and agree on the importance of providing equal treatment. Yet, to provide equal treatment might mean allowing people with disabilities to have access. Empathy in my mind does not mean to feel bad about people, but just as the video suggested to "think".To go back to my analogy: when I help a mother with a stroller in the subway, I don't think I give them the feeling that they are unequal but I just make sure that they can go up the stairs nearly as easily as I can. Does this make sense?I also thought of empathy in the design of the environment and process so that everyone can have an equal chance to vote independently. In that sense, I like the idea of universal design per Jakob's inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/when-the-solutions-for-disabled-becomes-the-new-standard/thanks for your comment as it obviously made me think!al
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
congrats indeed. How much fun can be for a wheel chair user to be appropriately empowered to freely cast a vote. This is worth promoting

think_a_wheelchair_user_s_daily_struggle.title: Think! A wheelchair user's daily struggle

flat_pack_polling_booths.description: Light weight cardboard polling cubicles and vote collection boxes form the core of modern recyclable polling equipment in Australia.
flat_pack_polling_booths.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Interesting use of recyclable cardboard!I can also imagine that it might make easier to set up polls and have mobile versions of it (per the discussions started on other inspirations). You could also imagine a smaller transportable version of the ballot boxes...

Yes - they are light weight and suited to mobile polling places and the ballot boxes do come in different sizes. In our system most votes will be counted in the polling place in the hour or two following the close of the polls, so the boxes just serve to keep the ballot papers safe until counting starts.As Greg Baker sets out in his inspiration the number of votes cast in any one polling place would usually be about 1000 to 2000, except for remote places which might vary from 6 to a few hundred.

flat_pack_polling_booths.title: Flat Pack Polling Booths

when_the_solutions_for_disabled_becomes_.description: I would like us to dig up some great universal design, examples where designs for disabled are that universal that non disabled people prefers the solutions. The trouble is to recognize these as disabled solutions since you take them for granted.
when_the_solutions_for_disabled_becomes_.creator: 04e53dae2f54dc421469f3b54994d2d1

comments.text: telephone. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elisha_Gray_and_Alexander_Bell_telephone_controversy
I really like your inspiration Jakob. It's totally about design for all. This is a good example of that http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XdMpz_YQt74

Thank you for sharing Jeroen, a good design approach pointed out in the video! Looking at the extremes; designing for the weakest as well as the fastest etc, and if it works out for them; the people in the middle will sort the it out as well!

That's so true. Josh Treuhaft also shared this as an inspiration on open ideo. Maybe you can team up with him to get this in to the concepting phase http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/goodgrips-what-s-good-for-arthritics-can-be-good-for-all./
The electric toothbrush was originally invented for people with limited motor skills!http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_toothbrush
Great example, absolutely a preferred solution by all kind of people!
Just had another idea! Easygrip knives - also originally made for users with arthritishttp://www.kvillage.co.uk/sites/default/files/imagecache/image_node_lightbox/stores/easy_grip_knives_sq_2.jpg
...just to add the electric 'cigarette' was originally rolled out for flight passengers, and now is being widely used for those who are trying to give up smoking!

I also like those toilets better! Another thing that I like and is suppoused to be for people with visual disability are the Tv remotes with big buttons, and any 'shift' options or anything like that, just the basic!
I am totally with you on the big buttons but, could you give an example of the shift option?

The 'shift' option is a button that you keep pressing while you press another button of the remote, so the function of that second button changes. This means that you have twice as functions as buttons. For example, button representing "1", when you press the "shift" button, serves to control the screens brightness. It may give you more options but all those second 'shift options' are so small written, and are so many, that I just prefer it simple.

Great inspiration. I like the idea of shifting the focus: broadening rather than shrinking in various boxes; instead of designing specific things for various populations / audiences, to design for all, thinking that in fact, we can all get more.For the bathroom, I did not think of the train, but I thought of airports toilets for disabled: great when you're with luggage or with kids... voice when you are at traffic light: there are some like this in Paris. At first I found them weird (and I'm not really used to them as they are not that many), yet I sometimes thought that for kids, it can be useful as they don't always watch the signals when crossing the streets, a nice reminder.

Great thinking! Reminds me of the signage of Mexico City's metro system - as another example of design for a particular population segment that has broad appeal. Originally created to work around high rates of illiteracy - instead of words, each station is assigned a simple logo and each line a color. I definitely benefited from this easy to interpret labeling system the first time I visited Mexico City b/c I didn't speak Spanish then and was quasi Spanish illiterate.

Hi Simon,Interesting, this connects to a few posts about portraits and symbols for electing parties or candidates. When I read your post, I thought about sound branding and jingles with unique association that is not language dependent. Think about the very specific Nokia ringtone, the iPhone ringtone, the welcome to windows sound etc. They are all specific and you can recognize it and associate it to a particular brand etc.

funny that you mention sound - while doing some quick research on technology for people with disabilities - one suggestion I came across was to program cellphones with unique ringtones for different types of callers for people with visual difficulties and to program cellphones with unique vibrations for people with hearing difficulties - maybe there is some potential here to harness these ideas for the election context?
You got me to think more about sound insperation: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/audio-announcement-2212-the-sound-of-voting-/#video-li-item-0

Jakob, I love this list!  As I have been reading a lot of the inspirations, a question that has been popping up a lot for me is whether we should be framing potential solutions in terms of making it accessible for a selected group of people with disabilities (assuming the rest of the population would continue voting using some variation of the status quo), or whether we should be looking to completely overhaul the system to make a new status quo, that would be accessible to everyone.  I like the direction your inspiration points - let's make a new standard, that allows voting to be accessible to those it otherwise would exclude, and at the same time, improves the experience for everyone.

Nobody ever complained about a car being too easy to drive or too easy to get into, right? Inclusive design should, by definition, lead to better solutions for everyone, regardless of the inspiration. Definitely a way forward.

Haley, I believe the question you had in your head reading the inspiration is important and I do not see this as either or. Questioning the status quo might give a universal solution, but it might not.. So digging deep into and look into the unique needs and solutions for various disabled is probably the way forward as well, and in the end that might be the way to find that universal solution after all.

This all fits into John Clarkson's proclomations that it is "normal to be different". There is a Microsoft report from 2003 where they estimated only 21% of the population NOT to be affected by some form of disability, so you are right, it is a general problem to address universal design/accessibility. Lots of other examples of things were designed to solve specific disabilities - the typewriter was original to help blind people write, the transistor was originally invented for use in hearing aids, the closed-captioning on American TVs, invented for deaf/hard of hearing is actually most commonly used by people sharing beds with sleeping partners!
Brilliant inspiration!I will be very interested to see the concepts that flow from this.

Hi, Jakob. You are absolutely right - there are many examples of solutions which make life easier to all of us. Some time a go I read a book by Elaine Scarry, called "The body in pain: the making and unmaking of the world", and she had a nice perspective on things. At a certain point in the book she talks about how the telephone is said to have been invented as a solution for people with hearing impairments. She analysis the case and gets to the conclusion that the telephone has ultimately had the effect of changing a (dis)ability (not being able to quite hear the person next to you) into a "super-ability" of hearing a person on the other side of the globe.I guess that what this means is that, sometimes, one should not settle for trying to achieve "normalcy", but rather to overcome it.

I like yours and the authors thinking as well as your example. Overcoming disability and normalcy, by adding a superpower to people and more ability. Thinking of the telephone you mention and who that might not have had the ability to use it. People that are deaf or without speech missed out on the full potential of the phone, today there are a lot of speech to text software and if it does not already exist I guess we soon have a live silent mode in the phone automatically typing out the words of your fellow on the other side of the line. The introduction of video calls over phone was highly welcomed by the deaf and is quite universal with the same platform for all and ads more ability for more.
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Hi Jakob,Funny enough, I was just reading about this book:Design meets disability by Graham Pullin.It talks about the beauty that design brings to concerns that should of been taken a long time ago. Think about the Eames iconic bentwood leg splint. There is a huge misconception about the quality and aesthetics of design for disability, just as many perceived green design at earlier times as an ugly-hippie like product. Now look at all the great sustainable work being done.http://www.core77.com/blog/book_reviews/book_review_design_meets_disability_by_graham_pullin_15597.asp

A highly inspirational perspective, Jakob. When riding the new BRTS system in Ahmedabad, India last year  I was really loving some of their accessibility features too. Like LED route status screens and level boarding. Thanks for bringing up this significant provocation!

Jakob, I love this list!  As I have been reading a lot of the inspirations, a question that has been popping up a lot for me is whether we should be framing potential solutions in terms of making it accessible for a selected group of people with disabilities (assuming the rest of the population would continue voting using some variation of the status quo), or whether we should be looking to completely overhaul the system to make a new status quo, that would be accessible to everyone.  I like the direction your inspiration points - let's make a new standard, that allows voting to be accessible to those it otherwise would exclude, and at the same time, improves the experience for everyone.
Absolutely agreed Jakob and Haley. Many opportunities to jointly improve accessibility and the broader experience for the marginalized, and us all!

when_the_solutions_for_disabled_becomes_.title: When the solutions for disabled becomes the new standard!

banking_extends_itself_to_the_countrysid.description: Win win. Both the bank and the customer benefit equally. And everyone's happier :)
banking_extends_itself_to_the_countrysid.creator: 77208aacba5d7a92cf76832d55c0ba1e

comments.text: Hi Tina, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.
oops the pictures were the best part! let me try again!

epic_democracy.description: A portable halal cart, sound proof cart located at the most visited places like pharmacy, banks, train stations etc.
epic_democracy.creator: e5ef6afee0cc6567de8978188492d0bb

comments.text: I like the  concept and the way you went through the different steps of the process. I can see this concept helping various people with accessibility issues.It could also make access easier by simply providing more places to vote and by increasing the options, you reduce the stress of people who need more time to vote because of accessibility issues. I went through some of the personas http://www.openideo.com/fieldnotes/openideo-team-notes/personas-for-concepts/ and it seems that your concept could help many of them. That might be worth giving one or two specific examples...You might want to think what are the resources needed.

Welcome Poly NYU-folks! I agree  your concept would be strengthened if you include a few scenarios using our personas link above. Looking forward to how it goes! One thing I'm confused about  is there a particular reason you are referring to a portable *halal* cart? Is this similar to other food trucks and carts? Perhaps you'd like to include a link to an image of what you're referring to so others here are clear?
Hi again, as I was going through the inspiration, I found this one which reminded me your concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/pop-up-voting-center

epic_democracy.title: Epic Democracy

the_universal_polling_place.description: Polling places are "found spaces" re-used for voting. This makes it difficult to provide similar access everywhere. This concept suggests a longer-term project to research and prototype an ideal universal polling place
the_universal_polling_place.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3
the_universal_polling_place.title: The Universal Polling Place

vote_anywhere.description: People should be allowed to vote at the places they visit most
vote_anywhere.creator: b8873a156dc35dc99b69d0f93ebe22fc

comments.text: This method would definitely make the voting process more accessible to voters.  If voting was as easy as going to the store where I get milk every week that would be great.  I wonder how these store owners would feel administering the voting process and how they would be additionally compensated for their efforts.  One other concern is the time and effort needed to train all these people.  It may take a long time and a lot of manpower but I think adding voting booths at some popular places makes a ton of sense.  I know I wouldn't dread the voting process as much as I do if I could do it an establishment I frequent everyday or everyweek.  I hate having to look up where the voting center is, get directions, find parking and navigate a place I don't know.  This solves that.
and why not send your vote with the Amtrack driver or engineer?

Another concept that touches on the nature of how people/voters interact with other routine and civic activities.  Like the focus on making voting accessible in places where voters already frequent.  Thanks.
Thank you Dean

Hi Sana, some great thinking here! One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.

Interesting concept Sana building on several inspirations (voting while commuting, voting at the pharmacy, etc.). I like the idea of building on people's practices and routines to make the process easier. The concept Polling day every day http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/polling-day-s-every-day.-vote-when-you-can-when-you-want-during-any-period-of-an-election-term./ also plays with this idea. It might be interesting to build on this. It could also be interesting to start picking 2 or 3 locations or activities where voting could take place and see how you can unpack the practicalities involved in this: how to vote? with what (a paper ballot? online?)? how to make sure the vote is safe? ...

Sana, I thought you might want to build on this concept as it's looking at two specific locations, taking into account the social practices associated with these spaces: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/use-your-bank-or-doctors/

vote_anywhere.title: Vote Anywhere!

tell_a_story_enact_a_scene.description: Let's take away intimidation from the voting process, especially those with disabilities, by educating and informing people via storytelling and role-playing!
tell_a_story_enact_a_scene.creator: 782b7ce25247ac9aac16f1675d70e4cf

comments.text: Hi PriyankaGreat concept that I think fits well with Justin L.'shttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/radio-technology-and-the-election-experience/ Radio ServiceI have left a link to your concept in comments on his concept.With regard to addressing the personas (Ashley's question) here are some links I included in Justin's concept too http://www.pbs.org (USA Public Broadcast Service)Australia's SBS network (Special Broadcasting Service)  http://www.sbs.com.au (radio, tv and web) and a local volunteer service of Radio for the Print Handicapped http://7rph.org.au/history.html
Great stuff! Thanks Paul...

Hi Priyanka,Great concept - and thank you for building on mine!  Feels great to collaborate on this issue together.I appreciate the concept of moving away from fear of the unknown by creating an accessible story.  One question I have been wondering with regards to my TOGETHER: Communal Educational Voting concept, and could apply here is the possibility for "politics" to get in the way of the message.  In your case, how could we keep it a "community" gathering, as opposed to a politically sponsored event that attempts to win people over to their side / ideology?  The ability for influential politicians to take advantage of the system could prove a challenge to allowing people to make an informed decision.Would like to hear your thoughts - as I am thinking through the same questions!

Thanks Matt!I've tried to address this issue in my revised concept. However, you question about influential politician misusing the system is a good one - and a tough one! I am still stinking through this. What are your thoughts?

Hi Priyanka,I'm not totally sure - as the beauty of each of these concepts is 1. the simplicity, and 2. the adaptability to any context.  If it becomes too complex, with too many rules (about who can present / tell the story) the simple, communal aspect can be lost.  One thought is, though, that the storytellers / presenters could be partnered with a local humanitarian non-profit to both put the event on, and help filter out people who may be harmful to the process?  It seems like being able to tap into the resources of an NGO would not only help make these events a reality, but would provide a type of more unbiased "safety net" for sharing all types of ideas and information (not simply the views of the elites, etc.).  Beyond that, I'm wondering if there could be a mobile voting platform to allow people to easily text who they would like to present?  The most votes wins.... Maybe this could keep more honest storytellers at the forefront?  Think of a rating system like Yelp with reviews of certain people... Just a few thoughts.  Not an easy challenge, but well worth exploring!  Please keep me posted on your development!!!

Hi Matt,Thanks for your input. I like the idea of attaching this concept to a NGO of sorts. I think it will help boost credibility and possibly keep politics at bay.I like the idea of using a rating system, but it may complicate this system. I'm playing devils advocate here: Given that the idea is to alleviate uncertainty and fear, this could seem like added work and responsibility. Thoughts?

Priyanka - love the concept! As you build, you could also think about other types of medium to tell stories. I was involved in a project to educate and change behaviors of several thousand coal miners in South Africa, many being illiterate. We used theatre (as you have here) but we also produced an animated comic and a song (the later might seem a little crazy here, but there may be application in voting in developing countries).
Thanks Mark!I've updated the concept to include animated short films. Thanks for the inspiration!

At a recent accessibility conference, I saw several systems that let you make an animated character use sign language - adding another mode of communication to the mix. There are a lot of possibilities for better communication and instructional design around elections and how to vote. This concept is a great start in pulling together some of the best practices to do that. Mark: I don't think that using entertainment techniques like animation and music are crazy at all.
Great! Thanks for your feedback.

Hi Priyanka, some great thinking here! One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Also, how might these scenes and stories might be scripted and packaged - perhaps as downloads or toolkits - so that anyone could share these lessons in their community? What are the different stories to be told? For instance, I'm thinking for a person like Charlie (see the personas) it might be helpful to have a story about crowds and the different sounds and people he might expect. I'll be excited to see how this develops throughout our Concepting phase.
Love the feedback Ashley! I'll surely consider the personas and update this concept.
Great! Can't wait to see how it evolves :)

Hi Priyanka, I live the idea of using stories to make elections really tangible. Enacting  a story, or learning through stories would be a great way to explain many aspects of elections. For a few examples from US elections, you might think about it to explainThe whole election process from beginning to endTypes of mistakes and how to correct themHow the ballots are countedIt wo uld be great if the people in the stories could reflect the range and diversity of voters. It could be subtle education, but also ensure that everyone can " see themselves " in the stories. Ashley's suggestion about starting from the personas is a good one.
Thanks Whitney! love the feedback. I'm working on revising this concept and will post it soon.
Hope to see you back with updates soon Priyanka! We'll be choosing the concept shortlist to move on to Refinement next week, so be sure to get in your updates before then :)
Concept updated! I'd love your feedback...

I like this idea.  Especially if we start incorporating new technologies and voting processes in order to facilitate accessibility needs, some people might be nervous about learning these new voting technologies.  It can be nerve-racking for anyone to go into the voting place for the first time, more so if unfamiliar technologies will be involved.  Community role playing could help people become comfortable with the voting procedures before the real voting day.
Thanks Eric! This concept is still raw, and needs polishing :)

comments.text: i think this is a cool idea that solves in part the problem of illiterate voters, but few are the countries that can afford secure e-voting right now. the other part of the problem for people who cannot read or write is the lack of access to information. it is, in my view, a tremendous problem because these people, most of the times incredibly poor, do not get the chance to seek out and chose their own representatives that would hopefully turn their lives for the better.
Its quite  a commendable idea. Its kind of a sign language.
Great. It would be great for the designing of the accessible Uls for voting to begin.
good idea. However, the design of the images and icons should be made in a way that has one interpretation for everyone especially in a multi-cultural communities. :)

using_fun_videos_humour_to_understand_a_.creator: 31706233153bff2053a20f5ef611ea80

comments.text: Carly - this is such a great point - it's often forgotten how powerful humour can be to engage people. If we can create engagement, we can educate. I think half the problem is that, disabled or not, people just feel left out and are disengaged.
Ha =) Was definitely entertained, engaged, & educated.
And who doesn't like cat videos? :)

Yes Ccarly, important topics should be explained in various ways and good storytellers should definitely be involved in doing so. It is not only the vote itself that is important to a democracy; the well informed voter will make better choice.

ipad_video_resource_for_poll_workers.description: An iPad with videos that provide poll workers step-by-step instructions on how to set-up the accessible voting machine, and how to activate and cast the accessible ballot would help to ensure privacy and independence for voters wirh disabilities.
ipad_video_resource_for_poll_workers.creator: 52ccec73edeaf4de1a4b377644cdef1c

comments.text: LouAnn, great point. I like the way you are thinking about how simple technology can make elections more accessible by supporting the people who run the elections. It's a simple concept, but one that could address an important issue we've heard about in a lot of the inspirations.

Great points linking accessibility concepts to the manner in which those of us supporting the elections process interact and provide resources.  Those elements are critical.  And, the advancement of tablets and similar devices really open up new possibilities in this regard.  Thanks.

Training is an important part to assisting people in the voting experience and your concept highlights this well. I wondering since it will cost money and time to distribute iPads that this idea could be an application so anyone who works at the polling center can download the videos and instructions onto any device. Look forward to seeing this concept visually as well!

Fab start, Lou Ann. We're anticipating discussions to flourish here and your ideas to evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right. Here's an example of how built up ideas can get over the course of a challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/localfood/winners-announced/public-kitchen/ Let's bring on the builds and spell out the specifics!

Hi Lou Ann, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

confusion_and_empowerment_.description:
Want a more informed voter? Give them a cheat sheet.  

http://awesome.good.is.s3.amazonaws.com/misc/goodvoterguide.pdf
confusion_and_empowerment_.creator: 2e5ee009c21e833dceee5d3e41bb9465

comments.text: Excellent idea. When I lived in the US and voted at my local polling place, it always felt like a pop quiz I wasn't prepared for!Now I am living in the Netherlands, so I vote via mail-in ballot. It usually takes me several hours to fill out the ballot, because I check the websites of each candidate as well as 3rd party sources like the League of Woman Voters in order to educate myself. Even then, I never feel like I have enough accurate information about candidates - especially for smaller, local candidates.When I return to the US, I will sorely miss the luxury of mail-in ballots. Why can't everyone vote that way, if they choose?

I've run into this information problem every time I vote in a local election. Information about the candidate's postion on major issues would be really beneficial to voters, many of whom just don't have the time to do a lot of research ahead of time. The debates have been very successful in the republican primaries partly because they have been a way to see candidates stand next to each other and state their positions. They provide a opportunity for compare and contrast easily. I could see voting cheat sheets as kind of debate spark-notes, not everyone has the time to watch and take notes on the debates. One hurdle to overcome: what information is and is not shown could be a huge partisan issue.

Hi Anna,this is a great point. I don't vote in the US but I voted once in local elections in France and I was quite uninformed about what I should understand and know. I feel that often time a summary / synthesis would be great.To Drew's point, the question is who designed them and who decides what information to put? You could imagine groups involving different parties and opinions putting them together.
Hey, another related inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-art-of-choosing/

Hi Anna, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

_yes_it_was_cool_and_i_was_there_.description: Voting is about trust and evidence. I propose a tangible artifact augmented by reliable technology with a digital infrastructure redundancy. This idea is about  evidence from the mail that can be read with hands and eyes to the secured ballot box.
_yes_it_was_cool_and_i_was_there_.creator: 91628eac4696da0b9c0145b4fb722b70

comments.text: Great thoughts, Jason  great focus on the user experience!

_yes_it_was_cool_and_i_was_there_.title: "Yes it was cool and I was there"

national_database_for_rating_voting_syst.description: a rating database for electoral officials to refer and voters to give feedback – would help us understand the constraints and strengths of different voting systems and help implement the effective ones in lesser time frame .
national_database_for_rating_voting_syst.creator: 9899c15bb86db71258da54175790a096

comments.text: Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Mamta! We were excited to see your concept grow out of your own desire for more learning and information on our topic.During this Refinement phase, it might be fun to think about how your concept could work in tandem with others in our shortlist, like Lucy's http://bit.ly/xBObFc or Graham's http://bit.ly/wwrQ9i. Let's get specific and start thinking about what this database might look like and do. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Thank you OpenIDEO, i am excited to see what this might leed to and how best can it help us address the issue/challenge.
Great stuff Mamta  we're looking forward to your updates & replies to discussion evolving here.
Thanks Meena, just updated with limited time in hand , was away ! hope it helps !

Congratulations Mamta!Looking at Lucy's and Graham's concepts together with yours I can 'feel' a strong association between them.As you said in your comment on my queue management concept 'in order to help design a waiting room it is useful to know how long a voter may have to wait' - so for best practice purposes it will be useful to know and compare certain things about polling places - things like:comparative statistics for ballots, machines etc. that databases are good at analysing (your concept); hints & tips, efficiency measures, ways of doing things that are good to share from a people perspective (Lucy's concept); andstandards adopted, exception reporting and mapping (Graham's concept).-and tying them together.

Great thoughts here Mamta Like you, as an outsider, I have found the US system confusing and each idea that comes up raises more questions. Daniel Castro floated a concept for bringing together much of this datahttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/crowdsource-election-accessibility-best-practices/ Your concept is a great way to make it understandable and accessible.With so many jurisdictions and limited concensus the task is daunting but needs to be done.

Hey Paul, i have followed the post by Daniel  and its a great concept.  Crowd sourcing would be one of the best methods to do so. With the help of technology and connectivity such a database would help any country not only USA, however it would require resources and dedication of certain kind.I do believe it will make the process effective in long run and building upon the practices continuously would  benefit larger audience. Thanks .
I like how you've built this concept based on clarifying your own confusion. Turning a negative into a positive  way to go!

It is indeed a great way to go. I love how you build upon not only your confusion (which I share as Paul too), but your attempt to clarify it. Great extensive research. I also agree with you that the diversity of practices across states is also an important element (not always easy to understand) and being able to get a snap shot view  can be valuable, even for American citizens. I can imagine something like a travel guides with a set of criteria that would be standards. This might even help sharing best practices and standards across counties. I also like your use of visualization.

Dear Anne, in my attempt to understand the whole process, i felt that there are issues at implementation level in some states which in turn affects the final percentage of people who could or could not vote. I feel the database would help in getting clearer picture on ground . However tying up the whole thing at national level would need collaborations from within sates and between states . I am also concerned about the political limitations of the same , as in would one state like the other state to follow their footsteps ! Thanks , i am fan of data visualization as i myself don't like reading data beyond a point !!

vote_vote_revolution.description: Why use our hands to vote at all? Why not our feet? Why not our palms? Why not a stick? Why not our voice? Can we revolutionize the voting process? Inspired by childhood. Built by the OpenIDEO student chapter at NYU-Poly.
vote_vote_revolution.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: I like this idea, Ashwin. It, in my view, can also be useful to develop games that teach and train young and old, about importance of voting and how to vote.
Of course, playfulness can go a long way in internalizing learning.

Hey Aswin, as mentioned in the article ,i agree the electronic machines are simple enough for people to operate but we have many more here to figure out  during the process of election. The simple interface of evms make it really accessible to people irrespective of varied dis-abilities.But if it has to be touch- pad it could be the same interface on the floor or onto the wall .I feel having it on the floor might create some vision  related issues , like Meena says try out the prototypes ! cheers.

Thanks for the great feedback Mamta! You're right, putting it on the floor may be extreme but I guess the takeaways are EVM's with larger interfaces, engraved buttons and light & sound feedback. We're sure to  upload photos and videos of our prototyping sessions.
Hi, I like Mamta's idea of keeping the principle of the concept - touch based and bigger interface - and explore its location: floor, wall, big tablet.

Nice one, NYU Poly OpenIDEO Student Chapter! Perhaps this could be trialled at a few polling stations before a full commitment across the board? Prototyping would give the opportunity to tweak and evolve based on real-world use.
Definitely Meena. In fact, the next item on our agenda is to focus on prototyping.

long_lines_waiting_to_vote.description: One problem I see with elections are the long lines to vote.  This makes voting inconvenient and difficult if you don't have time, patience, or energy to stand in a long line.
long_lines_waiting_to_vote.creator: 59ce4f71e16c7f4f27abffcca4d3d39c

comments.text: I might be less motivated to vote if I have to wait in long lines!There aren't a lot of  complaints about long voting lines in my country. I think the main reason is that everyone has their designated polling station, and less than 1,500 voters are assigned to each station. In addition, your designated polling station is mostly close to your home, so if you think the line is a little bit long, you might decide to go home, take a rest and come back later.

I remembered CarrotMob, (from a previous challenge on OpenIDEO) They had some great ideas on how to make waiting in line more fun. watch this video as inspiration, jump into 4minutes and 22 seconds if you just want to see the queuing :http://vimeo.com/925729watch the whole video if you never heard about CarrotMobI think there could be some rules in elections against letting politicians doing campaign in and around the polling stations. but it could maybe be done with independent organisations setting up music, other entertaining events...

Are politicians in your country doing campaign on the election day?? In mine (Spain), not only is forbidden to do so, but the previous day to the election is 'reflection day' and neither party can do campaign (neither on the streets, nor in the media). Nor any political demonstration can take place on that day. Have you that 'reflection day' too?

Laura, we also have "reflection night" in Taiwan! At the day before election, all campaigns are supposed to end at 10PM, or they will be fined. However, in the past there were candidates who didn't end the campaigns on time, because they think the fine was worthwhile for the extra time...

I've had to wait in lines in the past, which like many other people noted is not a fun experience. I'm wondering how we can think of ways to improve that experience to make it more comfortable and informational?

I guess this is a problem with a vote on only one single day. We in sweden used to have vote on sundays. But during the 1990's the system changed to also include pre-voting if you were somehow busy during the election-sunday.Nowadays you can vote by mail, and also polling stations are set up in public libraries, city halls, up to a month in advance (if you are working abroad, or planning a holiday trip) so you could more easily schedule your vote during work hours or whenever.And IF you would change your mind during the last week of debates, you could go and vote on the voting-sunday, and only that last vote would count, and nullify your pre-cast vote. (but hardly anyone does change party-allegiance so close anyway)this is for the low-tech approach, obviously online voting system would not require any travelling or standing waiting in line at all. So you could do that from work or from your couch.
It's nice to hear about the flexibility and options Sweden provides!

I'm also thinking: how about those people in fast food restaurants that come to you while you're in line to ask for what you want to order and send the order wirelessly to the kitchen? Is there anything we can learn from this experience as well?

Nice thought Sarah.  I don't think we even need to go to those extremes... why not let them (if they choose) fill out their ballots at home before hand if they wish (print them, like southwest does with boarding passes).  Then they can simply come in submit in person at a much faster rate.   My comment above elaborates.
Hi Andy. Absolutely! Just throwing ideas out there to help us push our thoughts a bit further and not settle for one solution. The more the better!

I was in Columbus, Ohio in November 2004 during the general election.  As can probably be expected in this key battleground state, the lines on election day were longer than can be imagined (hundreds deep) and turnout was extremely high (plus it was raining at a decent pace!).  While it was encouraging seeing so many people dedicated to their voting rights, it was nevertheless disappointing to see the ramifications of high turnout.  Those with disabilities suffer from long waits and bad weather disproportionately.  Rapid ballot casting is critical to the success of the current system (which uses physical ballots to deter hacking).  Allowing people, should they choose, to bring ballots which are pre-filled out at home and need only be confirmed/submitted on site would save minutes per person and dramatically speed up the process.

Hi! Like Carly, I never had to wait in line to vote neither. I live in Spain and polling stations are also everywhere (schools, high-schools, neighborhood center's, etc). And there is not a really advanced technology being used for voting. There are just paper lists with the names of all the people in that area of the city, and besides the name, you can see in which of the four our five tables of the polling station you have to go to vote. I guess that this is also avilable online, but I never used it, I just go to the station and look for my name on the list!

I live in Canada & I have never had to wait in line to vote so this comes as a shock to me! Maybe more polling stations are needed so each location is responsible for less people overall? I have voted in schools, church basements, community centres... I think it's important to note that polling stations don't require a ton of set up so they can be almost anywhere with designated space!
Great point. Waiting in lines is a big turn-off for many who cite it as an easy excuse to put off going to vote. Social media and messaging tools could be put to great use here as well.

democracy_kit_envelope.creator: e5ef6afee0cc6567de8978188492d0bb

comments.text: Love the idea of borrowing inspiration from Netflix! Also that there's an education component (all the tools you need to make an informed decision) plus the ability to mail back your secure ballot.

Indeed I like the fact that you have been trying to take into account as many elements of the process involved in voting as possible. The netflix option in combination with the online option is very nice. I like the fact that also you thought of the ease of use by simplifying the process whether it's for online voting or sending the ballot. Last I like the idea of presupposing registration. It reminds me of when you receive a survey for jury duty: you receive it and it's up to you to prove that you are not eligible. In this case, if you cannot vote, you can just ignore the democracy kit.
Great brainstorming & analogous thinking guys!
