interactive_stimuli_voting.description: Combining output interfaces (Audio and Video) even in different languages, with input stimuli interfaces (switches, camera mouse, speech recognition, oral mouse, etc ), we can make voting accessible to practically all people.
interactive_stimuli_voting.creator: 29cb2448018800ab65a9de297548b6e0

comments.text: Dan, I believe you've just extracted the marrow from the idea. Interactive stimuli is just a way to mark the ballot, but there are still many other issues to solve. For example, mixing this with Priyankas Voting Vans, Nat Mannings Crowds sourcing and so many other ideas, we might end up with a universal solution for an accessible election experience for everyone.

I can't comment either way on immediate feasibility, but what I like about this idea is that it gets to the idea that we have a lot of diverse tools out there for "marking" a ballot, even beyond pens, mice, punch cards, thumb prints, etc. The language of "interactive stimuli" and the visual here may distract from the fact that there may be ways to reconfigure the whole voting process that take into account voting orally, with gestures, with other devices, with eye-blinks, tapping one's feet (I should stop now...). Thinking about alternative methods of marking, forces a consideration of how much the whole voting infrastructure could be changed. This is a huge challenge, of course, but once that's really compelling.

Hello Shane. I see your point and believe that your observation would be absolutely accurate if we were looking to find an integral solution for all people's everyday needs. But you have to remember that we are only trying to solve a very specific need, which is casting a vote, and in that sense we can be much more flexible in the solution, taking advantage of which ever physical resources each person might have, as well as from a combination of selected interactive stimuli interfaces available in the market.

I'm not so sure that this is a workable solution. Assistive Technology is very personal. The technology that suits one individual will not suit another person. I fear that it would be effectively impossible or hugely expensive to have a full spectrum of Assistive Technology at every polling station.

interactive_stimuli_voting.title: Interactive Stimuli Voting

design_for_onboarding_tutorial_habit_bui.description: Starting with young people, design training and activities to build on previous knowledge using civic building exercises combined with awareness and empathy exercises to illuminate barriers to the process that exist for many.
design_for_onboarding_tutorial_habit_bui.creator: 914da3c8c41d1f207de84e6bd8f010fe

comments.text: Lots of great ideas Sharron.  One of my favorite elements is involving young people in the election polling process.  When you think about the voting centers, the thought that comes to mind is older men and women who have administered the testing forever.  They are often grumpy and don't make you feel any better about yourself for voting that day.  I think allowing some younger people to learn from these people and offer a new sense of excitement and education to the process could help both parties.  Allowing these kids to earn community service hours is a great idea.  This could also be a great resume builder for a high school student trying to be accepted into college.  Every little bit helps and if they can help inform other kids about the election process while earning community service credit while improving their chances of getting into college, it sounds like a win all around.

Sharron, wonderful to see this concept amongst the winners. Education at all levels is so fundamental and although this has a principle focus in the election process it represents a model for raising accessibility awareness in other areas too. I hope to be able to follow the progress of this concept into the realisation phase.

Hi Sharron - really great concept.Sorry I haven't got here until now.I can see this linking in with Annie's Voter Help Hub ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voter-help-hub/ ) and the other support networks.Would also see some condensed version forming information available in polling places, especially if we could successfully implement queue management so this could be something available for people to interact with while waiting their turn.
One thing I'd love to have clarified here is what "Grind" refers to in the title of your post. "Tutorial" + "Elder Game" I can understand but "Grind" has me stumped.

Hi Meena I read it as related to spaced repetition and other methods of internalising/owning understanding of the process. Usually involves lots of practice (like learning a musical instrument) but would be good if Sharron could clarify it.

Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add relevant posts that you've mentioned in your Virtual Team field to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get an email notification and are likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

One of the things that I like about this concept is the emphasis on long-term knowledge. We've had a lot of discussions about the challenges of helping today's poll workers interact more effectively with people with disabilities (see Let the App Decide). It's intriguing to think about how we build this awareness across society.I also like the idea that education about disabilities is woven into a broader curriculum. Many of the schools in my area require community service - working in elections would be a great way to not only get students involved in solving problems in new ways, but give them a better view of what it means to be an engaged citizen.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We really enjoyed the time and effort the workshop team put into this concept and love that it reaches kids at such an important time in their own development.During this Refinement phase, it might be fun to think about how to start designing these educational materials  maybe by interviewing an elementary school teacher, for instance? Let's start building out what this program might actually look like. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Great stuff Sharron! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add posts which inspired you like My Voice, My Vote to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get an email notification and are likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

Meena, I tried to add the URLs to these inspirations https://openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/a-gerontological-approach-new-york/ and https://openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/my-voice-my-vote but when the Update published, it did not appear.

Sorry to hear that Sharron. Would be great if you could send us a ticket via our Support tab (on the left of most pages of our site) and give us details about what's happening when you try this. That way someone at our helpdesk can assist you to get things sorted.

Our group was really passionate about this idea because we thought it would allow us to fully explore the idea of accessibility while giving citizens hands-on experience with the voting process from an early age.

ivoter_platform_be_an_intelligent_voter.description:
This is an online platform built by a joint project among some universities in Taiwan.

Nice one, Szu-Yin! It reminded me of this post too: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/vote-compass-for-literacy-and-engagement/ Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add that post to your Build Upon feature. voting_from_abroad.description: Sometimes transportation makes it difficult for disabled persons to get to the polling booth.  People abroad are encouraged to register and vote, why not doing something similar for those in the country unable to go to the booth?
voting_from_abroad.creator: 74e2c829ff2b9f7ef7cb2f7a37112b2d

comments.text: The Netherlands has a similar system. Citizens living abroad can vote by mail, and it would be great to allow others, who have difficulty in coming to the polling station, to do so as well.

For French residents living abroad, you need to register to your consulate and then you can vote by mail or in some cases like in NY, they organize poll stations.A few days ago I received an email from the consulate offering me to vote either by mail or electronically for the June elections... The third option is to go to the polls set up by the Consulate. It's the first time I heard we had an electronic option in France. Also I found useful the push from the consulate. Of course, you first need to go and register at the consulate, but when this is done, they do contact you with reminders. From my research, voting by mail is possible with people with disabilities in France if they signed up for this option. A few other inspirations pointed to that too. I haven't found anything about electronic voting but I'm sure it will become an option.

Japan has a smilar system, too. However it allows to vote only for national elections. Citizens living abroad have to register and submit a document which proves that they have lived in their current place more than 3 months. Also they need to visit the nearest diplomatic office to vote, which is often difficult for them. I think Japan is very behind in electronic voting and I hope it will become a more realistic option.

voting_from_abroad.title: Voting from abroad

vote_party.description: Make it an American tradition. Create an event, just like the Superbowl, that is centered around voting, friends, family and a good time.
vote_party.creator: 51d133637a5ecad9bdf9ac40c800abfd
vote_party.title: Vote party!

election_symbols_in_india.description: A significant number of Indian voters are illiterate, so Indian elections use symbols on ballot papers (designed such that the texts about candidates & party names are secondary). This ensures that voters to make the choice that they intended to.
election_symbols_in_india.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7

comments.text: I love the accessibility of this idea. I wonder if similar images can be designed more simply (read: bolder and more iconic) for more universal recognition?
Hmm...can definitely see how these symbols make voting much more accessible.Curious whether this affects how much people vote by party vs. candidate.

Vincent: yes, in India, a lot of voting is party-oriented and not so much by specific candidate (though, the lower you get in the scope of representation i.e. municipal limits as opposed to national elections, knowledge about specific candidates also makes an impact). There are a bunch of other factors as well.In terms of accessibility, we must note that elections in post-independence India began in 1952, when illiteracy, rural population, and relative lack of media were huge factors. Symbols made it more easier for people to identify political ideals (e.g. hammer-and-sickle for the communists) and participate. Formal education, or the lack of it, was not a discouragement.So much so that parties protect symbols like a corporate entity would its logo and other branding.

Thanks for the helpful explanation Ramanand!About your last point, that's exactly what I was thinking, the logos really become very valuable branding assets for the political parties, though this isn't a bad thing, if it's conveying authentic ideals.I think I remember seeing somewhere how a bunch of elephant statues were required to be covered up during an election for this very reason (represented a particular political party).

Heh - the elephant episode is a little unusual because the govt.in the state (UP) that's going to polls soon had erected giant statues of elephants  (its party symbol) and the election commission thought it would unduly influence voters. In India, parties that have symbols like, say, bicycles and fans have been known to distribute these before elections etc. :) So ordinary objects take on greater political symbolism.So the use is far more sophisticated than say, the use of the donkey and the elephant by American parties, and tends to retain loyalty to the symbol (and thus to the party) than a candidate who may leave the party some day.Unavoidable side-effects of the system, perhaps, and one for the semioticians :)
I'm learning quite a lot about Indian elections from you. Thanks Ramanand =)

Thanks for this great inspiration and discussion. I did learn a lot about elections in India. It seems that the symbols and images can indeed be a great way to convey information to rural populations. The distinction between the party vs. the candidate is an interesting one.  I guess you could imagine having a picture of the candidate instead of the elephant or the clock, or both the picture and the symbol.
Seems also to be quite fast for the voter, which leads to less queues etc.

election_symbols_in_india.title: Election Symbols in India

older_adults_are_not_all_alike.description: When we think of making voting accessible, we have to recognize the many different needs of different people. From research with and about older adults, we developed our 4As model: People differ by age, ability, aptitude, and attitude.
older_adults_are_not_all_alike.creator: a43aee6b398af0c5dd808ea1e975f9de

comments.text: Ginny, I love this.  You make a really important point: Even though we may share some features, we may not share others. This is one of the most inspirational parts about accessibility for me. When we make things wheelchair accessible its also easier for mothers with baby carriages or travelers with suitcases.  If we making polling places accessible for people with a wide range of needs our elderly in all their diversity--as well as many other people--will be able to use it.

Ginny, I was thinking more about the scales you propose. How do you think they could be used for voting-place accessibility? Is there a way the scales could be printed out at voting stations and people could point to where they are on the scales to help indicate the kind of help they need? Or perhaps there are other ways to use them?

older_adults_are_not_all_alike.title: Older adults are not all alike

what_we_vote_with.description:
With Bar Codes, there are no two same ones.  Every voter should get a ballot with a bar code.
 So, everyone's vote will count, be registered and accurate.
what_we_vote_with.creator: 2d68e11009e99cbe629daee4755b68a2

comments.text: Ray, I hear what your saying... it's just the start of an idea.The Barcode would be for accuracy.  It could be registered on the other end as just a "NY Voter" or "NC Voter" -- so the people in the right states get them... but then they can scan it in, and get their vote accurately counted.  And/or, you could get the Bar Code Ballot at the polling place - so your name is not attached, then use it to enter your vote.I'm blown away when you hear of stories where thousands of votes/balltots in certain ounties just get "lost".  How is that possible?  This is just a way to try to keep every vote counted.It's a start...

Bar codes on ballots violates secret ballot requirements because they make it possible to link a voter to his voting record.  This very issue is before the Colorado supreme court at this time.  Regardless of any benefits such a system might provide, the resulting loss of ballot secrecy is unacceptable.

Hi Daniel I like the thinking here it is compatible with Whitney's ideas that the ballot that is cast only needs the voters actual choices not all the options. It would also help to cut down on the size of the ballots to be counted/audited manually.For completeness I shall link to your concept from my bus ticket (size) ballot idea.

Hi Dan, Great concept :) I think in the future phases, we might integrate some aspects. Could you please check my concept and share your comments?http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/instead-of-ballots-send-everyone-a-gift-certificates-which-can-be-cashed-or-used-to-buy-things.-/

Hi Daniel, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the right hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Hey Daniel, great to have you onboard for our challenge! I thought I'd point out a couple of tools that might help you evolve your idea over time: our Tips for Concepting (http://bit.ly/AdbEH2) offers some guidance for your concepts, and our Guiding Principles (http://bit.ly/AiJnLW) helps explain our focus on accessibility in elections. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

IF, for instance, you used the Bar Code idea - it would be private.  It would just be a scan code.  Imagine it like an airline ticket.  Their Name and State would be on the stub... they can rip it off, before they go to the polling place - and therefore have a Private Ballot, with no name on it.  Some places alreay use computers, so the technology is there.  Computers are transportable... so they could be shared for Primaries, since a lot of states have their Primaries at different times.The same people whp volunteer on voting day would still have the same function... they could administer running the bar code, under the scanning gun.This whole process would help the skeptical voters - because then they could see that their vote would be equal, and accurately tabulated.For people in rural areas, they would get the same feeling... that they have the same equal vote.  The bar code won't swipe twice - so it ensures only voting once.Is the bar code the way to go?  I don't know... It's just an idea.I'm happy to help with more ideas...Dan
Great thoughts Dan. Keep 'em coming!

Sticking with the bar code idea:For people with Sensory or Conitive disabilities... If they know who they want, they could "pre-order" their bar code ticket.They could fill in who they want... then get the ballot mailed to their house.When they go to the polling place, they can scan their bar-code ticket, then all of the candidates they wanted to choose, get tabulated the way they wanted.  So, this idea could help with accuracy.  It can help empower people with disabilities too.Their votes would count equally, and they could easily do it.

If the "computer-order" idea works... Everyone could place thier order on their computer.  Their pre-ordered ballots then get mailed to them.So, for people with language barriers, they can do this in their own home, then just go to the polling place and give their bar-code ticket.For Troops over seas, they could have polling stations at their bases.  Their bar codes are labeled with their home state.  The computer then tabulates it for that state.And/or for overseas troops, they all get their pre-ordered ballots with the way they want to vote.  All of the bar-codes, ON BASE, then get flown together to a place in the US (Washington, DC, for instance)... then all of the ballots are scanned on US Soil.  All of the ballots get casted for their own state.
People already get absentee ballots... so to make Bar Code Ballots would not be a big change (just an improvement of the ballot).
People already get absentee ballots... so to make Bar Code Ballots would not be a big change (just an improvement of the ballot).

Just a quick tip: you can always go back into your entry to update your concept with some of these other great builds and additions. It'll help newcomers understand your concept quickly and easily. If you have other questions about how OpenIDEO works, you might want to check out our User Forums http://bit.ly/new_users.

The Bar Code Ballot only has their bar code and Home State on there... so no Political Party would be on there.  That means no one knows anyones Party Affiliation.  It would not affect the voter, or the polling place volunteer (with Party Affiliation).

what_we_vote_with.title: What We Vote With (Bar Codes)

super_clerks.description: So what if you can not go out today? Inform a local super clerk, and he will come to pick up your vote.
super_clerks.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: Do you guys feel like the respective government should be more involved with the voting process? I'm thinking that the government should fund a super clerk service, considering how poor voter turn out has been recently in the US. I added a similar concept yesterday utilizing the postal service for this purpose but now that Im reading your concept I feel like local governments could hire one day public volunteers every four years and utilize them as you describe. Putting them through a registration process similar to what notary public goes through could also ensure responsibility.

I really like your idea of super clerks with mobile devices. It is particularly useful for populations who have physical disabilities or do not have access to the internet and cannot vote online.Regarding the cost of this service, it could be offered free and as a public service for pre-identified populations. For example in your tax return, you might identify yourself as a person with difficulties to go voting. Then "super clerk" would be used for those populations with priority, and offered as a "public service". I believe that can really help increase the participation to ballots.However, regarding who can be a "super clerk", I see that as a very important function which required a high level of responsibility with a profile and training that can be defined with strict rules and controls in order to insure they will not influence the vote.

Thank you Yannick:) I would like to create a method (something like the app concept I suggested before) with does not need a training.  However, you are right about the responsibility of the clerks, and it might be a bad idea to have 16-18 year olds take care of it.As for the service, do you think it is too much to create a concept where even in case of an unexpected situation, such as your kid getting sick, you can inform a super clerk to stop by?

For some specific situations (i.e if the person is sick and unable to get out of home at the last minute), there could be a telephone or internet hotline to ask for a Clerk to visit you at home (like an emergency doctor would do in case you are sick...)In case this is justified, the service if free of course (public service);-)
What is the "fee" for, if a voter doesn't vote?  Why would the clerk come out then?  There isn't a fee for voting, right?

Hello Amanda, you might have seen http://bit.ly/xSSvby in the inspiration phase. Voting is compulsory in some countries (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compulsory_voting), which means that the people are given a fee penalty if they do not vote.It is a good argument whether this proves that instead of paying a fee, people staying at home can pay super clerks, or not. Do you think financing such a service should be by the government?

It seems that financing possibilities for this concept is partially a function of the voting system (compulsory vs. optional).Another issue though, is how to handle the security/professionalism of the mobile voting process.In the case of a primarily technology-based system (such as what I proposed here: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/ ), a lot of this will be designed into the device/online system.Still, and even more so for a more analog-based system, mobile clerk training/certification will be key to alleviate concerns arising from having individual, independent voting clerks with limited oversight.

Hello Vincent, whether we use high tech or lower tech solutions and embed the security in the mobile systems, a voter would need to be physically alone while voting. In that case, may be mobile 'closed booths' would help.You are right that having individual voting clerks might create problems. It is better to have teams of young people. If the process is enriched with gamification using an easy mobile device interface and motivating young people to 'collect more votes,' may be there would not be a need for training.

Many states allow the use of absentee ballots for individuals who are unable to get to the polls on election day. (Others allow it, but voters need to provide a reason for requesting one.) I like your idea of providing assistance--after all, those who make it to a regular polling place can ask for assistance from clerks as needed--but I do think it could get very expensive very quickly.

Thanks Martha, the main reason I wanted to bring a clerk to one's home, is to make sure of that a person keeps his/her vote private. I know a friend in CPH who did the absentee voting and it all worked fine, but in some parts of the world, many families would be there to influence the votes of each other.

Hi Cansu, I head up with an investigation which might be of your interest, the government of the United Kingdom conducted a range of pilots of new voting systems, including a number of pilots of remote electronic voting (REV) systems. I read it from a paper but it's easily found on internet and has been adopted by many countries already.

Continuing investigating I also found that in Canada they have developed laws which included a similar system: the article 243permitted to vote at home at the request of the voter, where an officerelections will be moved to assist them. You might have a look to see what are the constrains that they have and also what has been succesfull.
Hello Natalia, thanks a lot for the input:) Do you have a link to the information? It would be great. I wonder if they faced any problems with that system, so that we do not make the same mistakes.
Great that you are considering the need for privacy within this concept, Cansu. Looking forward to collaborative discussion and builds here.
I wonder if using such a low tech 'closed booth' solution would actually work.. For sure the booth should be portable and low cost, but I need to develop a much more effective solution..

I see an analogy with Micro-finance and a challenge there is in Banking on how to offer people with banking service in rural areas in Africa. Some Micro-finance institutions work with mobile portable devices with secured mobile connections. The Micro-finance Banker can visit farmers or local communities in secluded area, in order to make all type of banking transactions. A key is to create a human contact, to bring information to people, to educate on the benefits.

super_clerks.title: Super Clerks

bringing_the_voting_process_into_everyda.description: What if you could access all the information you needed to become an informed and qualified voter during your everyday routine? Our plan is to harness technology to make the voting process more accessible to all voters.
bringing_the_voting_process_into_everyda.creator: a610669548f25670fbed4f6cfcfc288e

comments.text: Interesting thoughts, guys  great collaboration. I was especially intrigued by your inclusion of the tabel (image 3) which showed the break-down of why non-voters failed to register.

I really like your problem space dealing with low absentee voter rates. One of the major concerns in remote voting kiosks is the verification of the voter. Biometric identification/ voter cards might help in this regard. But the US govt. does not have a database of its voters( due to  privacy related issues) which makes remote verification complicated.

bringing_the_voting_process_into_everyda.title: Bringing the Voting Process into Everyday Life

online_balloting.description: Given the wide nature of accessibility to the Internet these days, online balloting would make it easy for all voters to access their specific ballot style without the concern of transmitting votes through the web.
online_balloting.creator: 15bc333ac3aa5d4214332fe95e5efcb2

comments.text: Amanda, I am skeptical about the idea of online voting. In October 2010, the U.S. government created a beta for an online voting system. The beta was completely infiltrated within 48 hours, with the hackers able to change, erase, or create any votes. Its a good concept but I question the feasibility.

Even if the ballot is not cast online, there is a lot of value in being able to mark your ballot with a well-designed computer interface. We know that absentee ballots have much higher rates of errors - especially overvotes (voting too many times, and thus invalidating your vote in that contest). This could be a way to provide the benefits of an interactive ballot to remote or absentee voters.

I totally agree with you Christian!  I think the Internet can be a really hard location to put that much trust in.  One of the work-arounds for this might be just a ballot, rather than actual "online voting".  This way hackers can't manipulate the vote.

To pick up on Whitney's point here - one of the advantages of online forms, properly designed, is that where mutually exclusive selections are required this can be built in to the system i.e. so you cannot make two choices in a race where only a single choice is required.In Australia where we have preferential voting and must number our preferences it would eliminate accidentally including two numbers 9 in a 15 'horse' race etc. And in our case the system would electronically sort the output into the order of our choice so we could be sure we had it right.

Amanda, this is the complete package so far as online ballot preparation is concerned. I am uncertain if voter verification is entirely necessary unless and until the vote is actually to be cast.Casting it online would require immediate verification; postal casting would be similar to how Rachel described it in her concept; andin person casting might be better handled in the usual way.As I mentioned elsewhere (in line with Whitney's comments on Mark Anywhere http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/ ) the completed ballot (printout or whatever) only needs the actual choices made. This is what inspired my bus ticket size ballots (or as Andrew Baranak suggested parking slips) which could easily be posted, carried to polling places etc.There is a multiplicity of sensible compatible options here in this challenge. Would love the opportunity to visit USA and participate in creating a pilot.

So, you make a good point about voter verification from just a ballot perspective.  Just like Whitney's idea about picking up a ballot from a public place (like a library) you wouldn't need to hand over your voter registration card just to pick the ballot up, right?  It brings up an interesting question though: How do we verify based on the number of logins to the site that all the ballots that are returned are returned from the right people?  For example, if you can mail in your ballot, how do you provide proof that it is you that filled it out unless we can secure a way to know that the only way they would have filled out/marked that ballot from the online form is with verification?  Maybe a PIN number security?  Maybe James idea of ATM verification: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voting-via-atm-network-/ ?  I think it is important that we have the ability for people to submit their ballot somehow without necessarily being forced to leave their own home if they are incapable.

Two good points here.Online balloting fits the Mark Anywhere model wonderfully well, including the possibility of reducing the size of the printed ballot to just the selections made, and including a machine readable representation of the vote like a barcode or qr code,For the verification step there are two issues:first to establish your online identity which would need to be similar to online banking;then to generate a number or code plus date and time stamp to identify the ballot which can be verified against a database on lodgement.In every system there has to be some level of trust - such a code printed on the ballot as machine readable means nothing to the person opening the posted ballot and the code either matches in the database or it doesn't. I think the system is quite manageable.

Amanda, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We really liked your unique and comprehensive take on online balloting.During this Refinement phase, it might be helpful to consider the steps we'd take to start testing out and implementing this concept. What are the puzzle pieces that would need to get pulled together in order to make this idea a reality? You might also check out Andrew's related concept for more inspiration: http://bit.ly/wQ0RVC. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Awesome!  I can already think of things other users have considered that would help flush this out!

While I was Secretary of State in Washington State (1980-2000), one of my election staff's top priorities was making voting accessible for EVERYONE. Our state has now gone to 100% vote-by-mail and initiatives like this are more important than ever. As we promote the conveniences of vote by mail, we can't forget about voters who may not be able to mark a traditional absentee ballot. We must ensure that there are alternative methods available so that every voter can access their ballot independently and privately. The ideas presented in this concept do just that, while ensuring the security of the voting process. Great job!
Glad to have you joining our efforts here Ralph! Your perspective will be very helpful as our challenge moves into Refinement.
Fab to have you chiming in here Ralph  with your on-the-ground expertise!

Great, comprehensive thinking Amanda! One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve  maybe including a persona scenario or two. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.
Amanda, Tasha from "personas" fits the role for your concept
I like your well thought out elaboration. As Meena mentioned! Let's consider some "personas" to incorporate their needs. Voting is an exercise for all

I like your idea, it allows a separation of the individual logging into the system from the ballot to maintain the secret ballot.  Another option that could be added is to allow a post-mark challenged voter (I always get responses out late) to drop off a pre-filled ballot at a polling station.

I like that idea.  That would fit perfectly with this concept, too, since part of an online ballot is the ability to access it in any more.  Then there wouldn't be a time constraint filling it out like at the polls.

Restricting the information on the ballot to just the voters choices and making it human and machine readable would cut down on paper and make it easier to carry (in wallet or purse) to take it to a polling station, or fit in a smaller envelope for posting.

Awesome build & new concept Amanda! Have now referred & linked to it from my online voting concept.You may also want to check out Whitney's related "Mark Anywhere" concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/

Agreed Vincent - great concept Amanda!I would also particularly refer you to Whitney's comments about the physical ballot only requiring the voters choices, not the whole range of options.Provided the physical ballot can be machine and human readable the casting machine could then confirm the choices and provide a similarly small receipt.To that end I proposed bus ticket size ballots which would be cheaper, take less space to store etc.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/bus-ticket-ballot

online_balloting.title: Online Balloting

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

brazilian_eletronic_system.description: Here in Brazil, we have a electronic voting system, that make the process and the result's  calculation really easy. The device also has a sound system and braille language (blind friendly). And now they are implementing biometrics identification.
brazilian_eletronic_system.creator: fd7a9a65f6424ff87c02e3dbba1103ea

comments.text: I love the idea of using biometrics to identify voters and the ease and inclusivity of this method. This tackles the issue highlighted by Ginny here: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/stop-fraud.-make-sure-absentee-ballots-get-to-voters./ Maybe it would be possible to extend this to a service so that similar devices are taken to people who are unable to go to voting stations.

Nice one Carla! We also suggest you note some highlights from the video on your actual post. We find this makes it more likely you'll trigger a collaborative conversation here  and creativity loves company, right? More tips at: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire

Another point to consider about elections in Brazil:-it usually happens over the weekend (mostly Sundays), or nearing a holiday. This makes it easier for the majority of voters to take their time to go to polling stations.-(it is MANDATORY to vote).

Thank you for this insight.Here is a critique - somewhat outdated but nevertheless having some salient points as well as a number of red herrings.( http://www.e-voting.cc/static/evoting/files/rodrigues_e-voting_in_brazil_p85_94.pdf )Whilst it focuses on Brazil as an early adopter of e-voting the discussion has broader implications.

thanks Paul for the link. Just for those who might want a more exact reference, it was a 2006 conference paper: http://www.e-voting.cc/stories/2510688/ I read the abstract and it does raise importance issues about the introduction of the technology and the importance of managing technology adoption, esp. when the stakes are high like in the context of elections. I guess it will be interesting to read the paper with the biometric identification project in mind.

Her visit to the dentist http://www.doitmyselfblog.com/2011/ill-take-my-coffee-in-liquid-form-please/ and her frustration as the dentist went to talk to her husband was really moving, and made me realize how often we might make these kinds of mistakes. thanks!

comments.text: Thanks Jiangxuan. I like how you use the OpenIDEO interview quick start to understand the issues that immigrants might encounter. It is interesting to see that she has such a positive experience. It is also interesting to see that she voted in all elections. I guess voting was for her meaningful and important as a new American citizen. It would have been interesting to understand better how her experience in the US compared to her previous experience in China. She probably did not have language issues but maybe she knew or heard of people who did. That would also have been interesting.Last, I'm wondering "what is she expecting from online voting?" If you have the opportunity to talk with Menyan again, please share with us some more details!I like the point you made about informing and providing context: providing people with background / context information so that they feel in control seems indeed important, in particular when you go to vote.

thank you~well, I remember some pieces about online voting, but they are all imagination ^^. we don't know if it's possible or any troubles will appear. just couple of ideas: like online shopping, you don't need to go anywhere, log in with your ID which should be unique for each citizen (maybe contains SSN) and under each issue, relative introduction and news are linked( or you can google about things you are interest in or uncertain about). like Amazon, you can see detailed picture and description about the product, then you make purchase based on that.and also, you can use online translator to help, when you have language problems~~ (people can make better decisions, if they truly understand the questions, ^^ i always wish i could use dictionary during exams)and maybe, by using online voting system, you can stop whenever you need, you don't have to finish everything by once. the system can remember where you stopped last time. I will try to ask her more about this ^^
Thanks Jiangxuan for the extra information.

Way to go Jiangxuan! Love seeing your use of our Interview Starter Kit to seek out personal voting experiences and insights. For anyone else who'd like to join in, check out the kit here: http://bit.ly/z4qMZb

the_online_election_guide.description: In the Netherlands we have a Parliament that exists of 150 members divided between 10 political parties at the moment. But every election 20 parties take part. To help people to choose we have an online elections guide
the_online_election_guide.creator: 324905aefb58c08771149a326741025c

comments.text: It's really interesting how many countries have polity/position guides to help voters sort out the differences between parties and candidates. This is a strong global theme.  Is the Stemwijzer created by a government office or a non-profit or political organization? Does that make a difference?This has made me realize that no one has mentioned the League of Women Voters. At the national level, they are an advocacy group for good government. At the local level, they run debates for local candidates, produce unbiased election guides. My mother was a volunteer for many years in NYC. She taught about how to vote. I remember her mini-version of the levers used for voting at the time that she used to demonstrate the process at community meetings.

Stemwijzer is created by a non-profit organization that stimulates political and social participation. But I just read on Wikipedia that most of there income are subsidies. I think it could make a difference, but as I can see it they are unbiased.De Stemwijzer also organizes so called shadow elections on HighShool in the Netherlands to promote participation in politics when they reach 18 and get their voting rights.  In the Netherlands we are less active as a society with our voting rights, then in the USA i guess. People here are quiet lazy on these topics. We don't have much people such as your mother that are active in debates.

the_online_election_guide.title: The online election guide

build_a_better_voting_system.description:
Ralph Waldo Emerson famously said - "Build a better mouse trap and the world will beat a path to your door."
Building a better voting system requires combining the best solutions to individual problems into a coordinated whole.
build_a_better_voting_system.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Hi Paul, thanks for chiming in with your great early concepts! I like how this one presents an integrated election system that leverages different needs and abilities for different communities. As you continue to add concepts and join conversations, it's good to keep in mind that our challenge concepts should focus specifically on supporting independent and private voting for people whose access is limited, rather than more generally on voter turnout (although they are clearly linked). Be sure to check out our Tips for Concepting for more http://bit.ly/AdbEH2  and keep up the great work!

Thanks Ashley - although I have yet to add the inspirations on which I built this, I had in mind 1) Can an integrated system be built that brings most of those currently having limited access into the mainstream?; and2) What provisions can be made for those remaining?I freely admit I am still too ignorant of the complexities of the US system and gratefully accept input from IDEATORS like you and Vincent who have firsthand knowledge.It is at times like this that I should like to instigate an OpenIDEATORS Question & Answers Forum within each challenge - I keep coming up with questions, the answers to which would greatly assist developing concepts.

Hi Paul. The voter registration rolls are maintained by counties. There are current projects to modernize them. One positive effect for voters is that it makes it possible for people to have more choices of where to vote. This is not a voter ID, but moving the voter registration rolls to an electronic database. When combined with the ability to print out the right ballot for any voter, anywhere in the county, this adds a lot of flexibility for voters. On the other hand, I suspect that it's unlikely that there will be a National Voter ID card in the near future. There are some current political debates around voter ID. One report (by the Brennan Center for justice) says that "as many as 11% of people eligible to vote do not have government-issued photo ID.That percentage is even higher for seniors, people of color, people with disabilities, low-income voters, and students."

Thanks Whitney I am gradually getting a picture of the US situation. Does what you say about rolls being maintained by the counties mean that registration to vote in presidential elections is dependent on these rolls too?We now have a single enrollment requirement for national,state and territory legislatures that means the roll is effectively maintained nationally for the benefit of all jurisdictions. this is a short extract from tha AEC website ( http://www.aec.gov.au )"The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) maintains and updates the Commonwealth electoral roll  a list of eligible persons who are registered to vote in Australian elections. All States and Territories have joint roll agreements with the AEC. Electors only need to complete one form to enrol for Federal, State and local government elections.If you are an Australian citizen who is 18 years of age or older, it is compulsory for you to be enrolled at your permanent address."In this case a centralised top-down approach allows consistency and efficiency of maintenance so that states can concentrate on keeping their portion up to date.

It's always interesting to untangle the habits/cultural memes and the legal framework for elections in another country. The US is a federal republic, and not a parliamentary system. Although on the some levels this does not affect much, it does affect a lot of the specifics.There is really no such thing as a "national election" in the US. All elections are run by the states. So voters only register once for any election, from federal down to the most local issues. It's just bottom up rather than top down.Federal laws set some national standards(notably HAVA and the Voting Rights Act), but with a few exceptions the federal Election Assistance Commission offers advice and guidance, which the states may adopt. It also distributes national funding to the states to implement accessibility under HAVA. One of the important roles of the EAC is being a central point of communication for best practices and shared resources. In the states, elections are administered by the counties. The relationships between the state and county election offices varies - some states have strong state offices; others don't. So: voter registration rolls are maintained by the counties. The first step of modernization is at the county level. Some states are already moving to a state-wide database. Obviously, this affects the degree of flexibility in choosing a polling place. I should also point out that counties (and polling places) vary in size, depending on the density of the population and geography. There are rural polling places with very small numbers of voters, and urban ones that handle up to some 20,000 voters. This makes a difference in making elections accessible because it also means that both needs and resources vary a lot.Just to give you a range: Los Angeles has over 4 million voters Bexar County, Texas (San Antonio) has 890,000 voters.Banner County in Nebraska has 537 registered voters

Nice job, particularly breaking down the tiers of voting.Though I might quibble with the phrasing of the category labels (due to the value judgments that seem to be implied), appreciate and find your systems approach quite helpful.Thanks Paul!

Thanks Vincent - you are probably right about the phrasing. I think I need to slightly review the structure too which I will do in conjunction with publishing the collaborative concept map in the next 24 hours.

priority_queue.description: Similar to the priority seats in public transport or the priority boarding at airports for elderly and families - there should be a priority queue for voting. It should be for people with disabilities and other limitations.
priority_queue.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: Great idea Stefan!  This is just another simple but brilliant idea that eliminates a reason someone can use not to vote.  I'm sure that story about the lady who got to the voting center and left due to the long line is a common one.  Honestly, it is something I think about when I'm on my way to voting.  Allowing certain groups of people quicker access to voting will make their voting experience quicker and less burdensome, while it will also speed up the process for everyone too.  For example, a mother with several young children waiting in line can be just as bothersome for people in line around her as it is for her.  The kids could be crying, whining, or simply upset.  Letting them go quicker in a priority line will ease the stress level for that mother while also keeping the other line calm and quiet during the waiting process.  No one wants to wait too long, but certainly no one wants to wait in line behind a crying child.
Well done Stefan!This has always been a very practical and achievable concept.Would love to see how its implementation is achieved - given my incapacity to observe it at first hand.

The U.S. Election Assistance Commission has some signage and graphics that it makes available to local election officials. See page 10 of this document - http://www.eac.gov/assets/1/workflow_staging/Page/69.PDFI wonder if any of the designers in the community could build off of those styles to propose a "priority queue" sign or something similar?

Should be possible to devise something that follows the guidelines and resembles bus/cycle routes.I am finding discussing things here is giving me ideas to blend in my queue dispersal concept, so they can be complementary not mutually exclusive.With regards to signage I am investigating some details of an audio sign product out of the UK. You both might like to have a look at the promo here: http://www.innovasolutionsonline.co.uk/promo.asp?a=na
Hmmm don't know why the link is not active - maybe this is betterhttp://www.innovasolutionsonline.co.uk/promo.asp
That looks very interesting.  Even if poll sites just use printed signs, I think having these signs might help educate the community that accommodations are available.

Here is the response I received:Hi Paul- Im  assuming that you have visited the NovActive demo video on our website, link below.The system works best with signage constructed in the tray format, i.e a large, flat surface (where the text/icons/graphic are displayed) and 4 edges which are called the return.A variety of material options are available- Dibond, Aluminium, Foamex etc.The return is typically 25mm deep to accommodate the hardware/speaker/power source. The body of the signage acts as an amplifier for the small speaker attached to the back of the sign.The message can be activated by a push button or a movement-activated PIR sensor- either way, a 9mm hole is needed in the base of the tray to allow the sensor/button to be on the aesthetic face of the sign.The SD card memory is sufficient for several hundred message options.As far as your specific application is concerned, NovActive, probably using the PIR movement sensor, would do the job.The sign will either function using batteries or a supplied source of electricity, but this must be specified at time of order.Regards,Michael ThompsonBusiness Development ManagerInnova Solutionsand the extra questions I have now asked:Judging by the size of the "hand wash" sign in the video I imagine an A4 page (or American letter size) would be close to one of your standard sizes.Do you have a "ball park" price for a standard sign of such size with PIR and battery, and simple push button for comparison?Do you have an idea of battery life in terms of number of activations and message length?In a US polling place environment we might be considering perhaps 2000 activations in a single day but I imagine this would not be limiting.Would the PIR range be variable/adjustable?Finally what volume might the speaker typically produce?Sorry for the barrage of extra questions but your product seems almost unique in the marketplace.

I thought the message might alert voters in general, but sight impaired in particular, to the face plate signage that could be embossed and or braille instructions or a tactile map etc. according to need.In one of the other threads here I have sought your opinion (and Stefan's) on making a "special needs" ticket issuing machine the first point of encounter within the polling place for ALL voters. I thought the signage could be incorporated or be alongside.
Guys i'm so sorry if didn't have more time to react to your input. Maybe open ideo should implement a sort of Co author or wiki type system....

I was thinking about the same thing. I would have loved to have a co-author and I also wish that I had more time to refine my concept. I'm on an East Asian time zone and it seems the majority of users are in N. America, meaning that collaboration is a bit out of sync when it comes down to the wire like this.

Agreed Stefan and Graham (I'm on Australian Eastern summer time).Also I only have dial-up access most of the time. I looked at collaborative options during the Social Impact challenge and have been investigating them ever since.with one or two promising options.We could discuss the ideas in Charlotte Fliegner's Resources Section? thread in the User Forums once time pressures reduce again ( https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20670342-resources-section )

Ooo I love it when feature suggestions pop up in these conversations! We are definitely working on some new features that'll help people collaborate on their concepts. Paul, you're right to point to the Forums, but I'd actually recommend you head over to the Feature Suggestions thread (http://bit.ly/GRWZGY) - there's a great list of community-suggested ideas and we read all of them :) Keep up the great work!

Thanks Ashley!Charlotte's thread is a part of Feature Suggestions - just focusing on possible Resources Section/Page arising from the Social Impact Challenge. I posted a comment about my prototype of geolocation/meeting/local challenges - and a tool that I find useful for complementing the collaboration map. So I thought they might provide a starting point for discussion.I am happy to start a new thread with similar content if that is preferable.
I really like the layout you've created Stefan  really helpful to understand how this priority queue works!
Great update Stefan!

Hi Stefan - congratulations on both short-listed concepts.I'm sorry I should have said that earlier.As I said in my last comment below Keith's I have revised my thinking about how to handle a priority queue in conjunction with my ticketed dispersal.It will be necessary to issue 2 sequences of tickets - priority and general.To do this I propose that ALL voters first encounter the priority ticket machine where those voters with special needs will receive their ticket and directions to a priority waiting area situated closest to the verification/ballot issuing tables. General voters can at this point be redirected to their ticket machine and proceed accordingly.The reason I mention this here is because I believe that this ticket machine should also be the initial information point/signpost for the priority queue.I should like your thoughts on this.

This is a really great idea, allowing those with disablilties vote qucker, making the votinng process less strenuous for them. Also, this can be done with minimal resources. Good job making the final 20!

You are right Keith.That's why I should like to continue to collaborate with Stefan on jointly improving queue management. If making waiting more comfortable for everyone (as I hope 'Dispersing the Queue' can achieve) then prioritising some people with disabilities by addressing their particular needs earlier in the process can be more meaningful.For example (and in the tradition of public transport/airline prioritisation) priority seating and wheelchair/scooter space near to and with clear passage to verification tables will be factored into my waiting area design. Giving them numerical priority might be another issue.
I have revised my thinking on this.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Stefan! We really liked how simple yet effective this idea could be.During this Refinement phase, let's think about what this priority queue might actually look like in a polling place, maybe by sketching it out? Also, how might we incorporate some of the lessons from other concepts that you've mentioned here to build out the signage, voting methods and other details for this concept? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Congrats on this post being today's online Featured Concept!

Great thinking StefanThis should be applied universally.In the meantime this represents an idea to be incorporated into some of the broader concepts like T. Annie Nguyen's Voter Help Hub ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voter-help-hub/ )I shall incorporate it in my Mapping, Accessibility Rating and Traffic Reports concept too - I hope this will be acceptable.
Bring on the collaborative builds!

This is indeed a courteous concept.  Serving the needy will uplift their experience on election day.  Without this, votes will be disadvantageously missed as many are reluctant to turn up.  Every vote counts.
Cheers for your great build Stefan!
I imagine Stefan's concept would sit well alongside the Genius Bar for Voting idea too: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/a-genius-bar-for-voting/
Thanks for the hint Meena! I incorporated the great comments and added "build on this" links to the concept!

Stefan, nice concept! Some poll places will give priority to people with disabilities. For example, in the State of Georgia:"If you are 75 years of age or older or have a disability and you arrive at the polling place between 9:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., you will not be required to wait in line. However, you will need to tell a poll worker if you want to move to the front of the line." I think your concept illustrates how to integrate this much better into the poll place. Perhaps this concept can be integrated with others that are looking into improving the overall signage at the poll place?

Agree heartily Daniel.The Georgia statement is a bit legalistic - modern signage is utilising easily recognisable graphic icons (like those Stefan has illustrated) I think of road signage with petrol bowser (gas) icons that are accompanied by a knife and fork if meals are available and/or a bed to indicate accommodation. In this case I can imagine something like a sign with a straight arrow for the main queue and a branch arrow to icons for the types of priority accommodated at that particular polling place. I guess the challenge in this is to settle on a limited range of easily understood icons.

Paul, do you know if there is a way to incorporate audio into signage (cheaply). Many of the voters who might need special assistant might not be able to see the sign. Certainly, we could add some Braille to the signs, although many people with vision impairments don't read Braille.

In the Vibrant cities challenge one inspiration included scan-able QR codes and/or a mobile number that linked to audio information for tourism in formation associated with signs - I will try to find the reference.
I will still look but on reflection maybe you are thinking of direct 2-way communication with polling station staff from the point of signage.

Another couple of thoughts might be to emboss the signage and or incorporate piezoelectric or cheap mp3 audio like is used in greeting cards - but as to how to alert those who cant see the sign to its actual presence and function I don't yet have a formative idea.
This isnt exactly the link I was thinking of but a variation on this could be set up at building access points with wifi/bluetooth type technology.
oops ( http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/inspiration/question-box-an-information-resource-for-the-community-/ )

I was looking at some of the QR code alternatives like Blippar http://blippar.com/ and Aurasma http://www.aurasma.com/ and even Google Goggles. Rather than using unintelligible black-and-white boxes these apps use image-recognition. So perhaps it would be possible to standardize certain "help/assistance" images in poll places and then embed additional information and multimedia. Since these are still just paper signs, the costs would stay low. (Now whether anyone is using these apps is another question.)

Hi again Daniel I have built a small concept based on this one and our discussion here. Maybe it will open this discussion up generally but also relieve space here for discussion on other aspects of Priority Queues http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voter-friendly-and-interactive-signage/

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.

This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

develop_an_option_to_vote_using_your_tv.description: Interactive television technology offers an easier accessible way for people with disabilities to vote privately and independently.  More homes have TVs, people are familiar with their controls, and there is much commercially available AT for TV.
develop_an_option_to_vote_using_your_tv.creator: de3743e8e11b28cd190d73eb48bfb7e6

comments.text: Inclusive technology here. Good.

The concept sounds great, but what about the hardware cost ??  An analogy is digital-2-analog converter boxes when TV network stations went to digital transmissions in 2009.  People living in funded homeless shelters or motels converted into low-cost housing for the poor could not receive converter box vouchers because the government stipulated your address must be a home residence.  The shelters & converted motels were all registered with USPS as commercial business address.  Millions of poor people needed to use a friend or relative's address in a residential zone to  apply for a voucher, and it must be an address that had never submitted an application.  You'd have to factor how poor people who can't afford the hardware cost to acquire this equipment.  Voting is a Constitutional right; forcing the poor to expend $$ to upgrade their TV is creating an economic barrier to discourage the poor from voting.  Online voting would be a better option.  The poor can use the public library or use a friend or neighbor with online access to borrow their PC to cast their vote.

Hi Greg, really nice inspiration! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.
Hi Greg, Great idea to think about what technology is available to almost everyone.

This allows people to vote from many different places (which can raise comfort levels for some people, cuts cost for others and may be less time consuming for many) and it addresses security, which I believe to be important factors for people who aren't currently voting.
I have just begun to examine these two sites:http://www.biometrics.gov/ andhttp://www.biometrics.org/

I love this idea. I did lots of work with biometrics about 8 years ago when it was a new, exciting technology. It's inclusive and unique which really would help reduce barriers to allowing everyone to vote!

Interesting, Alissa. We're looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire
Great thoughts. After all, matching a face to a picture id (which is a common current form of identity verification at physical polling faces) is also a form of biometrics, whether digital or analog.

This is cool Alissa!  I think ideas like this are huge in moving toward trying to navigate the challenges surrounding what remote voting looks like.  I am looking forward to seeing the conversation around online/digital/mobile voting develop, and I hope this type of technology gets pulled into that conversation.  I also just read this inspiration that way up the same alley: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/vote-from-anywhere/

employ_people_to_overcome_the_obstacles.description: Instead of relying on volunteers and good will use the public purse to pay people to overcome the obstacles to voting experienced by the disadvantaged.
employ_people_to_overcome_the_obstacles.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: In Spain election officials are selected by drawing lots, and they have to work a whole Sunday for no more than 60euro. The next day they have the right to work 5 hours less; this expense being supported by the government.So, with this system, there is a monetary cost for the government, an organizational cost for companies, and a personal cost for the selected officers, which don't use to be very happy with their selection. And this could be solved by offering election officials jobs to people. I like your inspiration, simple and efficient!

Interesting concept, still 10 days to go.. but I guess if you also employ a few people with various disabilities in the teams, this will add local hands-on experience and push local solutions in a more user friendly way. Adding some good feedback system (maybe openIDEO style) to pass on for next year and it could evolve over time.

From my experience of being employed in a range of such positions over the last 30 years there is plenty of scope for including people with disabilities amongst the election workforce. Doing so would provide encouragement and empathy.

Absolutely, like this idea, Paul. At the very least, using the know-how of people with various disabilities in planning the run up to election day would ensure that a wide range of concerns can be met. And having trained representatives from various disability groups present on election day would allow voters with particualar needs to be dealt with in a discreet and unstigmatising manner.  In Ireland elections take place on school days and generally in schools that are closed for that day, so the campaign staff are often, unsurprisingly, teachers, who are essentially being paid twice for that day - I think many here would appreciate if the temporary jobs went to some people for whom, as you say (a) the job would be more meaningful and (b) a few extra dollars/euros would go a long way.

Paul, this is a great point: it's hard to design for people you don't "know" - that's one reason why user research is so important. A similar point came up in one of the Election Assistance Commission public round tables on design. An election official asked for ideas about how to help his office and poll workers work with people with disabilities more effectively. One suggestion was to include them on his team. Many government offices have internships, and of course they all have staff.One theme I hear in many accounts of the experience people with disabilities have in elections is that the workers are trying to be helpful, but may not have the tools and the knowledge they need. It makes me think of two questions:- How can we help elections workers provide better support?- How can we involve people with disabilities more in running elections?By the way, in the US, citizens are hired as poll workers for election day. They are paid (though not very much). There is always some sort of training, though this varies a lot from place to place. One of the EAC's early projects focused on recruiting and training poll workers. There might be some inspirations there: http://www.eac.gov/election_management_resources/poll_worker_best_practices.aspx

thanks for the response Whitney. I am generally ignorant of most aspects of US election arrangements but fairly familiar with what happens in most Australian polling places. Whilst it would probably be impractical to expect wheelchair bound staff to physically set up a polling place they would be quite capable of fulfilling most other functions. With a little forethought and technology it would be quite possible for blind staff to perform a range of tasks to assist both sighted and vision impaired voters.Part of my thinking in including this notion was that using people to provide the service of access to voting beyond established polling places eg. taking polling into nursing homes and hospitals should be relevant, consistent and remunerated. If it can be done here in Australia then I'm sure it can be done in the US as well..One of the biggest barriers to consistency is probably optional voting but I'm sure there are ways to accommodate that too.

employ_people_to_overcome_the_obstacles.title: Employ People to Overcome the Obstacles

more_info_does_not_mean_clarity.description: Languages, Parties, Supporters; These all lead to confusion.  We need to create ways to lower the amount of information to make voting less intimidating, while providing with voters with access though better created ballots.
more_info_does_not_mean_clarity.creator: e65334b24d5148fb70e310ea4fa85cf2

comments.text: You make a great point about how complex elections in big, multicultural cities are. And about how overwhelming the information on the ballots can be.  I worked on a project with the Brennan Center for Justice to propose changes to New York's election law that would make it easier to design clear ballots. Drew Davies, Oxide Design Co, who is also the Design Director for AIGA's Design for Democracy worked with us to create mockups of what the ballot might look like with the EAC Best Practice Designs.You can see a before-and-after here: http://www.wnyc.org/articles/its-free-country/2011/jun/09/designing-clearer-ballot/We found that in talking to election officials, it was very powerful to show a ballot that represented good design principles instead of just talking about it. We're still hoping that New York will adopt better ballot design.
Great point about the power of visualising ideas, Whitney. That's certainly something we'll be encouraging in our own Concepting phase for this challenge!

more_info_does_not_mean_clarity.title: More Info Does Not Mean Clarity

Yes I agree!Voting preferentially, as we do here in Australia, might be analogous to adding items to a shopping cart in order of preference. Confirming the vote could be like using the 'credit card like' ID card inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/personal-identification-number/ from Dema Mittal
