remove_the_stigma_associated_with_voting.description: Voters in newly democratic countries sometimes have their fingers stained in an effort to cut down on electoral corruption. Despite being a positive action it can inadvertently mark a person out as a 'collaborator' and make them a target of violence.
remove_the_stigma_associated_with_voting.creator: 8cd97515ad2f05101eb2b20d02a4716e

comments.text: Dan - this reminds me of the voting in Zimbabwe where people were persecuted if they did not have a mark. Have a look at www.zimbabwesituation.com/jun28b_2008.html. It's a long page but there is an interesting story there; one quote in particular caught me eye  "Many people were warned that they'd be attacked if ZANU-PF Green Bombers, their youth militia, found that their fingers hadn't been dipped in ink (normally this is done to prevent people from voting more than once). In this case, there was an effort to use it to scare people into voting.". Let's also not forget that it is also someones right not to vote if that is what they want to do.

Hi Mark,The Zimbabwen election story was one of the things that drew me to this issue in the first place. You're totally right in that the ink stain is as much about people choosing not to vote as it is about voting. The issue is the mark removing the right to choose.

Good point Dan. There are people that want to express their pride in voting & support for the elections, others (and some of the aforementioned individuals are included in this as well) have very legitimate safety concerns.Enabling choice would be great. For example: (1) having the option of the "voted" stain being put on one of two areasvisible finger, or another specifically designated & checked area that is more easily covered up, or (2) having some other confirmation systemlike eligible voters being crossed off a listand then giving "I Voted" stickers/objects that can be used or not used however the voter wants.

remove_the_stigma_associated_with_voting.title: Remove the stigma associated with voting

polling_day_s_every_day._vote_when_you_c.description: A system that enables me to vote and also change my vote at any point in time during an election term. A system that contains a right to actively register a "no vote" to enable those who feel they are not served to express this and be recognised.
polling_day_s_every_day._vote_when_you_c.creator: 9721c2b4ce2564fcfde2e4cb90d2e398

comments.text: Dear Tom, That's really revolutionary. A real change to all election model.  The only point is how can it affect the vote response. I mean, the "election day" works as a call to action. People know there is only one day to vote and they take it in mind. If you give a wider period to vote, the call to action is less strong and it could reduce the respond rate. Additionally, nowadays there is a constant information about voting statistics: not based on real data, but in "declared vote"; a longer period would allow people to speculate with their vote.  Anyway, it must be explored as an interesting option.

I believe the initial concept is an intriguing one worth exploration but also that this response is right on and was my initial concern upon reading. I feel that while this may enable proactive folks with mobility and time constraints that it also may provide an opportunity for the procrastinators out there to let it slip due to the 'call to action' weakening Vicenc mentions.Further, I would also want to consider the effects early voting would have on the process itself. I know that news agencies have pulled back on projecting winners and announcing tallies till completion due to the impact on voter psyche (i.e. believe one candidate has an insurmountable lead and doesn't bother voting). In the information age, I would consider if this was a considerable threat and if so, what could be done to mitigate effects? I would be interested to learn more from those more adept in the social sciences.Tom, I do like the concept; in my case it is often the most compelling concepts that seem to fuel the most compelling questions.

Thanks for your comments, I feel the time to act on your preferences is when you feel it is right for you.  The current call to action you refer to is the call to action that suits the candidate timing and not the voters.

I had similar ideas.In our swedish electoral system, we are allowed to send in postal votes 4-5 weeks in advance (from home or abroad). And some of the larger public libraries have got polling stations set up in the last week before the election day. So we have 3 different options to cast our vote, in case you are on a vacation trip, or working on election day.But there is a neat little thing in this; if we change our mind during the last weeks of campaigning, we could go to polling station on the election day and vote again, and only this last vote is counted!!! (and our earlier votes strucken away from the record)!!!It can be true that having one official election day is required to get high attendance. But I would think that it could actually increase the turnout if you were allowed to vote (by mail or online) as often as you want to. (less people that "stay on the couch" during election if they can vote whenever they can)If you only voted once, and never changed your party allegiance or political ideology, you are automatically voting on them in all elections. You would never need to renew your vote!!!Until you change your mind, of course, when you want to vote for someone else. (or choose to erase your vote in an active act of protest...)I believe this could raise the actual voters to nearly 100%.Several counting systems are of course possible: there could be only one day, when the official record is counted of all the votes during the last period of voting (similar to these election days, once every fourth year)Or it could be a vote-count on regular intervals; every year, or four times per year if you wanted. or even more often; monthly/weekly/daily... that would be very interesting! voters could become extremely interested in checking the news constantly for any corruption or new propositons and legislation that we don't agree with ;)The public would be influenced by daily news and any scandals, and politicians would be able to check the numbers directly, to see the effect that their work and efforts has on the support.It could cause higher competitiveness amongst the politicians to do proper work and stop messing around with stuff that we don't want. Consumer Power? (i dont think it would become a risk of ending up with silly laws; like getting cigarettes and alcohol for free or anything like that?)Plus on the practical side, you could rearrange the polling stations to suit certain groups of voters, according to a schedule. To offer special support and assistance for one type of disability per day of the month.

I like the trust component in the Swedish system Johan.With the ability to change the vote it means that you trust the system (government) not to count your vote more than once. I guess it means that the postal/early votes are held unopened until it can be established which vote is the one to be counted. That happens here with early and postal voting although voting more than once is illegal  so not opening them until the roll is checked is more a fraud prevention measure.

I think this concept really stands out because of two variables this solution effectively tackles.1) Time: which clearly constrains accessibility for voters (people who are abroad, sick, have other commitments...).2 and most importantly) Trust: giving people the chance vote during a longer period of time and to even change their vote could prove to be a very powerful tool that would foster transparency and reduce questionable campaign-focused tacticism. This would hopefully help politicians looking beyond the election date and start building strong, long-lasting relationships with engaged voters (an anti-disaffection).As I see it, the current model is like hunting (one shot, short term, high risk), and this change would hopefully get us closer to something more like 'growing and harvesting' (long term, reliable).The idea of doing this through trusted institutions like banks, hospitals, etc. has also great potential for trust building and presents many advantages (economies of scope) as there's already a secure and spread network that would need minimal set up.

With reference to Vicenc Alvaro's concerns below - harvesting votes early but with reviewing them for results would provide a means to count participation and could easily generate data that could spur voters and parties to greater participation and shame people living in low voter response zip codes. A key feature of the he system would be to allow a means to change/update ones vote - perhaps by invalidating barcodes of previous votes registered to a voter?  I wonder if this could impact the way people think about changing their minds on political issues; would they vote as soon as candidates were announced, on clear campaign bullet points, or would they wait and look to absorb more campaign information/misinformation down the line?  I would also say that a No Vote should only be allowed as a half vote towards a party - to provide a means to criticize the party who should have served your interests.  To vote but not vote would be sitting on the fence & the message would be lost between the two extremes and not empower people in a party to fight for change.  Feedback is an important part of all systems.

Great input. This concept touches on some of the data points we gathered during the initial phase of our Voting Systems Assessment Project (VSAP) through voter surveys and focus groups.  It would be interesting to delve further into how the length of the voting period would be defined and how voters would "finalize" their ballot and then be enabled to track the receipt and processing.
Great point Dean. Folks might like to check out more on our emphasis on Privacy and Independence over on our Tips for Concepting page: http://bit.ly/vote_tips

Provocative thoughts, Tom! We're looking forward to collaborative discussion here. If there are comments that you would like to use to build upon your concept  you can add them using the Update Entry button on the right. Bring on the builds!

polling_day_s_every_day._vote_when_you_c.title: Polling day's every day. Vote WHEN YOU CAN & WHEN YOU WANT during any period of an election term.

urban_voting.description: Anyone who lives in an area with public transportation will receive free public transportation ovn Election Day to a simpler kiosk
urban_voting.creator: f91f9c5f8d927116d939fe1c610870ef

comments.text: I believe that the present voting system is not progressing with current technology and needs of voters. How many people in the inner city do not go to vote because they don't have transportation? Anything that could help people just get to the polls could make for a radically different election.

Or maybe we can create an online voting system to let voters vote online instead of physically traveling to the voting center. While the number of computers and smartphone users is growing fast, a secured online voting system will be favored by lots of voters since they will be able to vote in their homes or even on the go!

I think this is a great idea.  For me, one of the biggest obstacles to voting is actually getting to the voting center.  Offering free transportation would be a great incentive to get more people like myself who want to vote but are somewhat lazy and occasionally looking for an excuse to get out of doing something.  Living in a city like Boston, this eliminates that excuse and is just one more reason that is making voting easier and more accessible.  Great Idea!
How you would prevent people the hood from taking advantage of this system?
How would they take advantage of it?

They would use the cards for other purposes like what students do with student metrocards. A black market could erupt out of nowhere. People could possibly trade the cards for more useful things like corn/maize ,etc. There are some neighbourhoods "hoods" where you get anything for $12 you know.
Paco I don't understand your objections here.From my reading of this it refers to single destination return trip for 1 person on 1 day.
Great collaborative thinking guys! Just wondering  were you brainstorming as part of a student group?

No actually we are actually a freelance design team often hired by Cato to do independent bipartisan research. We stumbled across this website and figured we can contribute. This is a great cause and we hope to inspire change.
Great stuff!

urban_voting.title: Urban Voting

_my_life_as_a_happy_vegetable_.description: Danish documentary about a man with ALS.
_my_life_as_a_happy_vegetable_.creator: c163efb5a68aa55f4a3101790339a9c8
_my_life_as_a_happy_vegetable_.title: "My happy life as a vegetable"

instead_of_ballots_send_everyone_a_gift_.description:
Reveal your vote by using your gift
Voting will instantly pay-off and more people will be willing to vote. 
Shops are everywhere and POS machines are connected to secure electronic transaction systems. 
If election costs $2/person, make it a gift
instead_of_ballots_send_everyone_a_gift_.creator: 1f39aff8633fe285c340e16956b9bacf

comments.text: Hi Ziya, this sounds like a creative idea. It reminds me of an idea a citizen in Arizona had. He wanted everyone who voted to be entered into a state lottery. Each election there would be one lucky winner of a $1 million. His proposal did not pass, but if it had, it would have run into some federal laws that restrict compensating people for voting. You can read more about that here -- http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/17/us/17voter.htmlI'd like to hear more about how your concept would work for a typical ballot with a dozen or so races or ballot measures on it.  How do people mark their selections?

Hi Daniel,Thank you for the reference. I agree that, any kind of compensation for voting will degrade the idea that voting is a civic duty. However, I think what I am suggesting is not much different from giving a candy to someone who votes. I think I have to explain it with a hypothetical scenario about how it might work... but of course implementation will be much more complex.. Take it as just an oversimplification:It is like opening a credit account for each candidate.You have connected gift cards (if one is used others get deactivated), and the one that you use for your shopping will withdraw $x from one of the credit accounts. You will know which one is which before using it (like a sticker with the candidate's name on it). But to use that you would have to remove the sticker or something like that.At the end of the day, what you have to do is check which account used how much credit. The infrastructure may be the current electronic transaction systems used in stores (visa-mastercard etc..)I know that this is somehow disruptive and is not easy as it seems. But, looking from an abstract point of view, major points are:- Reuse of the safe and widespread electronic transaction systems used by banks which are conveniently available in almost every store.  (Makes it easier for people to access and makes results almost instant)- Embedding the seriousness of execution of a civic duty into a daily routine of life, making it look more pretty - Stimulation of economyI think this is what I can say...Thanks.

Interesting thoughts, Ziya  and thanks for the scenario. You might want to add this to your actual concept post to help others engage with your train of thinking here. You can update your post by hitting the Update button on the right of your post. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

The way I imagine it is that the "ballot" sent in the mail has barcode stickers for each candidate. There would have to be an expiration date (which is the end of the election.) When someone uses the barcode, the POS communicates the vote upward, and then the rest of the barcodes for other candidates are disabled.

instead_of_ballots_send_everyone_a_gift_.title: Instead of ballots, send everyone a $ gift certificate which can be cashed or used to buy things.

portland_used_ipads_for_accessible_votin.description: Oregon became the first state to test the use of iPads to aid disabled voters last year. They ran the pilot of software developed by a company called Everyone Counts.
portland_used_ipads_for_accessible_votin.creator: 47c372cd686d783f48ecf954a92214a9

comments.text: Nice one Will! And your provocative questions are sure to provoke discussion here  and that's such an important part of collaborative solution seeking.

Cheers Meena - this should be fun. In the spirit of  collaborative solution seeking, I asked a few Peruvian friends how the mandatory voting works in Peru for people with disabilities. I was as interested in their perceptions and whether or not they knew about the procedures as I was in the ultimate answer. Although they did not seem to be able to describe it clearly, it sounds like each person who might need assistance is able to be accompanied by someone else that can vote on their behalf. I like it for its simplicity but have a feeling we can do more to create as fully and truly a democratic process as possible.

That fits in with the moral philospher Martha Nussbaum's theories about voting, that all people, even people who might be regarded to be incapable of voting for themselves because of severe cognitive impairments, should have the capability to vote, even if that means to be represented by a family member or carer who is likely - or more likely than most through that relationship - to have the interests of that person at heart.

I think this is an interesting innovation, one of the many great uses of the ipad or other handheld digital devices. I agree with the questions you bring up regarding scalability (and I lament the concerns about paper trails and accuracy!), but on top of that I want to connect this with another inspiration mentioned by nathan waterhouse about ideo's wounded warriors (http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/wounded-warrior-designing-homes-for-the-disabled/) -- and a quote from the metropolis article on the same project--"Wounded veterans dont want to be coddled, they want to be challenged. They need homes that help them reclaim control, that dont make them feel different from their wives and children." I wonder if maybe we can integrate the ipad without making disabled people feel coddled with so much extra work required for their voting. Maybe ipads stationed by census tract or a mobile (i.e. food cart level of mobility) service that makes it clear that it is used by many to underscore that feeling of "coddled" yet emphasize convenience.just some thoughts!
excellent food-for-thought inspiration!

Great linking of thoughts Molly! This is totally a vital concern here. In fact, the whole voting system could likely be overhauled to have efficiency gains for all and, perhaps more importantly, an environment that makes the playing field feel level and equal for all. Again, how to scale a solution that deploys iPads or other modern tech will be part of the challenge.

Cool inspiration Wil!2 tangential things I found interesting: 1) some people's need for a paper trail (i.e. backup verification, increasing trust in the system), 2) "Everyone Counts" stressing that their software platform is hardware agnostic, i.e. you don't necessarily have to use the most costly or likely to be stolen solution. Also, in relations to Molly's comment, apparently "Everyone Counts" offers an eLect Mobile station, "bringing the ballot to remote groups who may not have access to a traditional polling stationsuch as voters in a remote village, in nursing homes, at a military hospital, or in a deployed military unit." http://www.everyonecounts.com/solutions/voting-centers

Thanks Vincent. Re: your 2nd finding - it's true. Everyone Counts stresses a hardware agnostic approach but found that the iPad was the favorite with users (perhaps no surprise there). Again, as we head toward a solution that hopefully levels the playing field for all voters, I think that some economies of scale could be achieved that ultimately make the hardware more affordable.Also, good to know about the remote effort too. Thanks for digging!

portland_used_ipads_for_accessible_votin.title: Portland Used iPads for Accessible Voting Before It Was Cool

plain_language_matters_to_voters.description: We must be sure that ballots use language that all voters understand. This study showed that voters were more accurate on a ballot with plain language instructions than on one with traditional wording.
plain_language_matters_to_voters.creator: a43aee6b398af0c5dd808ea1e975f9de

comments.text: Another great example of universal design - when the language is easier to understand for certain groups of people, we all benefit!
Ginny, thanks for posting this great report. It's great to see that people in the study not only liked the simpler language, but were able to vote better when the instructions made sense.

plain_language_matters_to_voters.title: Plain language matters to voters!

the_voting_tree_voting_with_physical_obj.description: Instead of 2D image-based voting interface, what if we voted with physical objects? This could be more user-friendly.
the_voting_tree_voting_with_physical_obj.creator: f7befc67e4b1ddf3a03d496537760671

comments.text: I like this approach a lot. I often feel that the moment when I drop the ballot in the box is THE noteworthy moment. That's the moment I vote. This inspiration reminds me of these toys where you must drop the  cuboid, the cylinder ect in the fitting holes. It would be good to involve the kinaesthetic and/or haptic perception in voting through specific shapes. This could create a positive (more 'secure'!?) experience for people who a visually impaired as well as for people with arthritis. Often solutions that lead to 'more feedback' also create a better experience for not impaired people. Voting with physical objects could even be combined with the inspiration "Politics of Symbol/ Region / Caste". ;)

Nice one Alissa  that's a great inspiration from your own experiences of audience voting. This may spark a number of physical voting solutions and we look forward to discussion here and more comprehensive ideas which may build on this in our upcoming Concepting phase which starts in a few weeks.

Great inspiration! I like that a lot:) Having a physical object would emphasize the role of ones Vote. It is hard to imagine how important one vote is if as we look at charts with numbers of millions... Also imagine, if someone would not vote, and keep this ball (or other physical object) at home...it will stay there for the next weeks and the person will move it from place to place untill she would have to throw it away...But how symbolic and meaningful is throwing a "vote" to a trash bin! It is important to make people realize that. The physical representation would make voting easier, but also more fun and more significant. Thank you for your story and idea!

the_voting_tree_voting_with_physical_obj.title: The Voting Tree: Voting With Physical Objects

i_have_read_and_agree_to_the_terms_of_vo.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

Thanks Ashley! The points makes the challenge more clear.

find_out_book_your_time_slot_.description: the analogy of prior appointments( doctors) where one can make a phone call to find out how much is the rush, book appointments and leave home  accordingly, helps the staff at voting booth to stay informed and is convenient for the voter as well.
find_out_book_your_time_slot_.creator: 9899c15bb86db71258da54175790a096

comments.text: I got an idea; if you made it optional for people to book a specific time slot, you would have contact info for those.So if any one of the time slots (together with a digitally calculated algorithm that estimate un-scheduled voters for that time of day) became full and your extra staff are at another polling station; you would be able to use those contacts, to email or call them, to ask if they could come in 30 minutes earlier or 30 minutes later, to shuffle them around in the timeslots, and reduce waiting in line. and give more time to call in your extra staff and adapt to the unscheduled voters...not sure if that would help more than marginally, but anyway, I just had to post my little idea. Best of luck!
Glad to see you chiming in here Johan!

Hey Johan, yes true, we can provide a more customized experience by keeping them informed, another thing , at few restaurants -they give a token number and small display screen in front and people can trace the token numbers to know how much more time for their order to get ready. Here too we could have a manual display system which tells people how numbers are changing as every voter votes, such a scorecard kind of analogy helps people in not loosing their patience as they see things moving in queue !!

Another restaurant service: the blue plastic pucks. If you order your food in fast-food-counter or lunch-diners with only buffet-style-service at a counter. And you wish to eat something that is not in the buffet, or if you are vegetarian or allergic (or just wish to remove one or two items off the standard precooked hamburger). You order, pay and get a puck. You go sit down at a table. And when your dish is ready in the kitchen, your puck will buzz and light up with flashing diodes. So you go back to the counter and pick up your food!i just thought of it as an addition. Say if there are many voters that requested assistance, those should be given priority, and the others arriving at the same minute could be given such a puck, or just a flag with a number on it, so they know they are in the queue, and are the next priority, that are going to vote in just a couple of minutes.
Yes these thoughts go back to my concept of dispersing the queue so each person can relax and see how the queue is progressing.

Great concept Mamta! I like how you've picked up on the need for flexibility in staffing  that sometimes will be busier than others and so this advanced notice might help prepare poll workers for a rush. I'm curious: would voters need to call ahead? Could they book online? What might the website look like if they booked online? I'm eager to see how the concrete details in this concept develop throughout the phase.

Terrific ideas Mamta! I am building this into a couple of my concepts where Ashley's questions about online booking could be highlighted and linked. I have been wondering how to avoid having such a system abused - which of course is as much a cultural issue as it is a practical one.

Thanks Ashley, i feel it has to be a/the medium which most of the people can access. While all these mediums could be used in isolation or all together, i am exploring possibilities and intervention to propose minimum changes and bring out the maximum output, i was looking for a simple and effective strategy which makes everyone's job simpler. At the same time during our discussions i noticed mention of less funds for such initiatives , so am also trying to think cost effective and handy way of doing the same in American context. Thinking ... ; ) Paul , I agree , the same should not be an excuse for people to get lazy or misuse. Lets figure this out together ; )

Hi again Mamta.I should like to extend your idea a little.First it might be helpful (especially if you must use a particular polling place) to be able to make these appointments in the week or two before polling day, as well as on the day itself. Then it would be like making appointments for a check up. My instinct (which may be wrong) tells me that people with accessibility issues are likely to be reliable in keeping their appointments.Secondly, part of the skill of a doctor's receptionist is to establish if a patient will need a long or short appointment, and is one reason for having the receptionist control the appointment book. In the context of voting the making of appointments will, to some extent depend need. Ashley's questions about online booking raise issues about being able to identify the voter, their specific need and how long the appointment should last. There are various ways of addressing these issues and in solving them it should be possible to minimise misuse.Finally (for now) part of my concept (voter traffic reporting) is based on knowing approximately how quickly voting is happening, how many people there are in the queue at the moment so people can know, if they turn up at the polling place in the next ten or 15 minutes, approximately how long they will wait. The proposal is to have this information online but also displayed at the polling place so people already in the queue have an idea of how much longer they will wait.I am now adding reference to your concept (in mine) in the facilities information section whether, or not, a polling place uses appointment bookings and in the links section telephone and online appointment links (as if your concept is already a reality).

Thanks Paul,sounds great . I agree people with disability issues would keep their appointments as long as they are in control of it .I think visiting the same voting poll would require staff and other resources. In order to make the prior appointments effective and accessible to as many people as possible, i was thinking of a web based helpline -kind of structure where one can send a voice message or a text message, giving three preferences ( in order of preference)  for time slot. They will receive the confirmation online or on the mobile and in case of any change/delay or a query the poll worker could message them on the already available phone number -like airlines inform that the flight is delayed by certain time or hour and sorry for inconvenience !! There could be another section where the voter can choose the preferred medium of voting that is paper ballot or audio or for multilingual ballot .This can also help the poll workers to dedicate a  staff for particular hour for certain voting equipment and share trained poll workers !

comments.text: In terms of Concept Personas, this concept could assist Minjun, the recent US immigrant* with vision loss. Educational materials for children to help their families could include large images of the candidates, paired with their names, to make it easier to find their names on the actual ballots.*I'm puzzled as to how a *recent* US immigrant would be voting in an election? There are plenty of immigrants who have been in the US for decades without getting to a significant level of English fluency, but they've been there long enough to be naturalised citizens.p.s. I can't figure out how to add Bookmarks or other Concepts this was built on!

community_elections_with_no_campaigning.description: What if we just didn't have campaigns? What if we voted for people in our community, people we know and trust? Then they got together and voted for the next group of people? A delegate system based on trusting those we know.
community_elections_with_no_campaigning.creator: 0364a05366edf872fa5c32a7502a5916

comments.text: Very thoughtful notes River, thanks for sharing them with us. I think there's a lot of truth to what you're saying, but it also feels very "big." I wonder if it might be helpful to think about how to break this big thematic idea into different chunks  what pieces or elements could we think about as small steps to move towards this kind of community groundswell?

I agree, and at the same time cannot stop to wonder how this broader way of thinking about elections could be made to work together with some changes like these:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/polling-day-s-every-day.-vote-when-you-can-when-you-want-during-any-period-of-an-election-term.

Hey River, i agree to the intention and direction of your concept.It is appauling to see politicians and parties blow off money on extravagant and show off during elections.However it would be difficult to put so much trust on another set of elected body to represent a community or might be a slow and reverse process.But i was also thinking that how can we 'the people' who go and vote should vote for parties that have performed and not get easily carried away by the pompous campaigns on the name of democracy. (which happens in developing nations a lot )  Can we build measures or figure out ways which are more reachable and transparent to common people to help judge who performed better and may be by peer pressure we can discourage parties not to waste money and perform rather !

the_power_of_enfranchisement.description: When the democratic process is open to everyone, regardless of race, creed, gender or disability, people feel empowered, emboldened and embraced.  In Iraq, the purple finger was a symbol of this power force of enfranchisement.
the_power_of_enfranchisement.creator: 3c5a9e3aa2b68d7d01758a4c5a33d584

comments.text: Inspiring images and message. Making voting more of a cultural and community-based activity in addition to a civic duty is likely to allow more Americans to embrace the experience and get their vote out. Inclusivity is key!

this is a wonderful idea!  it would be interesting to target communities in the US with low voter participation and display images like this of people around the globe (esp in places like iraq where voting can be dangerous) exercising their right to vote.  engage youth, people with disabilities, elderly, etc in the voting process.  then on election day, take pictures of voters displaying colorful "i voted" stickers/pins/flags & assemble a collage for that community.  the collage could say something simple like, "thank you," to be displayed in the community as a image of individual and collective activism.  i think this could be a powerful and heartening exhibit of social agency.

Color and sign! It is a very great example! In Italy, we have a "book" that the Township  gives to every citizen. Every  ballot one stamp with the date. You can't vote without it (to be sure  you vote just one time) but it could became a proud icon!

Nice one, Jim. Here in New Zealand we can get stickers at the polling booth which say we have voted and folks tend to wear them with honor on voting day. Great provocation to think how we might enhance the status of having voted and amplify the completed act
Great example and powerful images!

the_power_of_enfranchisement.title: The Power of Enfranchisement

if_people_cannot_access_technologies_tec.description: Electronic voting machine in India provides secure and easier voting experience to Indian populations where illiteracy is a major issue.
if_people_cannot_access_technologies_tec.creator: 77cfbd410bb1a32c4b63cce4aa4ddbed

comments.text: The video (3rd thumbnail) you attached, also brings up some interesting  security concerns about electronic voting machines (in this case, parallel paper backups are recommended, though there are also other possible remedies I'm sure we can come up with).Quite relevant for us to think about, especially for solutions involving technology.

Hi Vincent,you have pointed out is quite relevant problem and we can not ignore this.I think security is one of the major issue for this process. Also making process accessible to everyone,we have to think of its other aspects as well.Thanks for your feedback

Hi Deepak,I have the same concern about security as Vincent. Advanced technology gives too much control to certain people who are equipped with knowledge, which sometimes results in a fraud.Personally I think voting itself should stay analog as much as possible. Perhaps here technologies can help people for mobility, communication or distribution/collection of information.

Hi Katsuyoshi,Yes, there will be lot more security concern, If we adapt a medium which is advanced technology driven. I am also in favor of the approach which is analog in nature and where technology is a part of it, but plays very important role.

telephone_voting.description: Apart from the innovative 'marble voting' used in Gambia, and the commonplace paper-based ballot, the next simple technology for voting is probably the telephone. As such it should be included in any mix of voting options.
telephone_voting.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Thanks Paul for developing up this concept and providing extra explanatory content.I am providing a link here back to my Inspiration item and a link to the Telephone Voting Standard for reference.  http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/#c-ec41ef687e3f1e8093e81b7dd0243a2dRegardsTim

Thanks Tim - I know that the basic premise of the challenge is mainly to look for new ideas but given the relatively recent development of the standard it seemed appropriate to me to build a case for extending it to new jurisdictions. Thanks for including the links I will incorporate them in the concept too.Do you know if there is a way to prototype the basics for a fictitious or perhaps old (eg G.W Bush) US presidential ballot. For a prototype the issues of inflexion etc. could be ignored.Perhaps even a written script  in the form of a flow chart would help to further visualise the concept for those who can follow it.
Recent article on an app that helps blind people text:http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-17105225
Thanks Amelia - I will look at this. Anything that gives people with disabilities confidence in using cell phone technology must be helpful.

telephone_voting.title: Telephone Voting

Deaf employees are taught to become leaders and advocates for the full inclusion of hearing-impaired people in society.
let_the_market_build_the_solution_low_co.creator: 342e8032933511b2d698ff24dbdaf030

comments.text: Nice example of innovative social business model, where beneficiaries are key to the solution. Thanks for sharing Will!
Yes I agree in general - provided the employees are being adequately remunerated for their acknowledged dexterity.

state_residency_dissuades_university_stu.description: Out-of-state students can only vote in elections in their "home" state, or the state in which they are a legal resident. This is done by absentee voting, which is a a tedious and bureaucratic process.
state_residency_dissuades_university_stu.creator: 90e9fcdfe518e47fbca8ec28448cb8c2
state_residency_dissuades_university_stu.title: State Residency Dissuades University Students from Voting

establish_a_voting_holiday.description: Setting aside election day as a national holiday would allow for a more relaxed voting atmosphere, and provide time for individuals to volunteer at their local polling site, better inform their vote, and cast their ballot.
establish_a_voting_holiday.creator: 9c961fba09bbd1b47f50466d7270666f

comments.text: This is really a great idea! It would create a sense of community as one day would be all about, and emphasize the importance for everyone to go voting! great that you linked it with voting fairs!

Interesting Idea. I'm originally from Colombia and as Eduardo said before, voting is regarded as an all-day event. Elections are held on Sundays and there are some additional incentives, including a certificate that allows you to take half day off from work any time you want to. It's definitely a good complement to the other concepts being posted.

Hi Alex. Your concept is a very interesting one to merge with other concepts. My family is from Latin America and they have always regarded voting as an all-day event. Elections are on the weekend and furthermore, they are obligatory. A voting citizen has to pay a penalty fee if he/she doesnt vote. Although Im not sure how popular a penalty fee will be in the US, it could be an interesting experiment in a local election.

Interesting thoughts, Alex! In my home country, New Zealand, voting is done on a Saturday rather than during the week. Another collaborator here on OpenIDEO brought up the concern that people may go on holidays rather than stick around to vote if a holiday was declared for elections. Perhaps you and others here would like to discuss this issue further as you develop your concept. We're especially liking how you are proposing to link your idea to other concepts being posted on the challenge. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right of your post. Looking forward to hearing how your collective ideas evolve here!

I had definitely considered the possibility that people would go on vacation, which was less of a concern with my original idea: a voting from home holiday. I had imagined a merger of the election holiday with the concept of bringing the ballot box door to door (similar to the super clerks concept). I wanted to open up the idea to connections with any number of ideas though. As for people leaving however, there does seem to be a number of examples where a celebratory atmosphere increased voter turnout. I also imagine it would be difficult to take much of a holiday on election day in the US (where my experiences are from), which is tuesday.Although the day off is more relevant in the case of weekday elections, I still think an election holiday would help bring people together around the idea of voting, inspiring more people to vote and to volunteer.
Nice one, Alex. Hoping others chime in to build on the fab start you've made here!

I think it should be in the middle of the week so that people cant plan long vacations. May be along with elections they can engage in other social activities like meeting friends or finish other stuff as well like plumbing related issues or checking up wid docs.... the holiday concept actually works very well in India and at the same time it will keep people more relaxed throughout the day .
Hey Alex, cool. It never clicked me, i took it for granted . It has always been a holiday in India and i assumed its  a holiday everywhere until u posted this; P

This is so fun:) If the election holiday is held on a Wednesday (while I think it is better to continue it for more than a day) then the people would be less motivated to leave their city. Plus, if there is a community celebration, like a state carnival, then they would rather join those events.

Agreed! Although more than one day off would increase the number of vacationers, I imagine it would also put people even more at ease, allowing at least a full day (if not more) before election day to discuss and learn about different propositions and candidates. And I love the idea of a state carnival on election day, especially now that I'm imagining using carnivals as polling places.
Bring it on! Let's think about what kinds of specific celebratory events would engage folks  especially considering our focus group of those who face challenges around accessibility!
What about calling it the DEMOCRACY DAY? and addressing communication campaigns in the previous weeks, targeted at each group, and detailing the alternative forms of votes that are available to them.

establish_a_voting_holiday.title: Establish A Voting Holiday

harnessing_the_mobility_of_food_trucks.description: Food trucks that tweet their locations and routes have a unique mobility and flexibility that would be useful in reaching voters who may not have the capability or time to register/vote. What if there were "Voting Trucks" to address these issues?
harnessing_the_mobility_of_food_trucks.creator: 4c3318cbb2e1066c5bf52861f2f37e74

comments.text: Joyce, this is a great! I love any idea that involves bringing an experience to the local community. This makes people feel like they matter, and would encourage people to get out and vote.  Love it, love it, love it!

I love the Voting Truck concept and I've always been intrigued by the possibility of "bringing the vote to people" and not the "people to vote" but in order for it to actually work from a practical standpoint there needs to be a serious set of checks and balances in order to prevent fraud from either those voting or collecting votes. Although I am less than thrilled by our current system, it at least limits the possibility of folks being able to vote multiple times by restricting their voting opportunities to one specific location on the day of the election. Additionally we, as a society, have the notion that less folks at the polling place (administrators and voters alike) makes it easier for sketchy things to occur. These issues need to be resolved before your idea could realistically be put into action but I think that could happen pretty easily. This is a great idea.

That's a really good thought. In my district, they still use a hard copy list to check if a voter is eligible to vote there. If a district had more than one truck (which would be necessary in many of them) perhaps they could sync up to a shared, electronic list to share with other trucks which registered voters have already checked in.This doesn't necessarily account for fraud on the administrators' side, but I'm sure different checks and balances could be implemented in an electronic registration sheet.

Good point! I really like that idea. In college, I remember lining up behind the "C" table to check-in for voting, and then being herded past a certain checkpoint in a gymnasium to access the voting booths. The only thing that was deterring me from re-entering the building and trying to vote again was that the entire campus/town was there and the lines were winding around the block! In addition to an electronic registration sheet, there could also be a person who stamps your hand as you leave the truck after voting. If the stamp was the sort of ink used at clubs and bars that don't fully wash off until about 24 hours later, the volunteers could wave a black light on the back of every person's hand as they enter the truck to vote to check for stamps. That way, no one could enter any voting truck more than once!

I really like the stamp idea! Good call!  I personally work on a food truck and there are already difficulties with the process now.  The window is too high; you can't hear customers or they can't hear you.  Plus it's not that big in there. This idea would require a larger truck with an efficient layout to process voters quickly. But if people will go to a truck, why can't they just go to a building which will definitely have a handicap ramp for accessibility? Anyways, I think a voting app would be a pretty cool thing to have. Like scoutmob, you can only check in when you are at the voting location/general area and you can only use it once. It's private because you're the only one staring at your phone, hopefully. Bonus, instead of all text on the ballot, there could be closing statement video clips from candidates with their name. Like an interactive ballot!  And you can choose if you want to view the clip or not. That would be nice.

To build on Przemyslaw Pawlowski's comment, I wonder if there is an opportunity with "Voting Trucks," not only to have a ramp or lift to bring people with disabilities into the truck, but also for ballots to be brought from the truck to the front door of voters who are, for one reason or another, homebound. It seems that a mobile-type polling place could have such a capacity (whether or not it makes sense or is necessary, I am not sure). But as one example of why this could be beneficial, I could imagine that on a icy winter voting day, certain people would have legitimate reason not to want to leave the safety of their homes, even if the polling truck was parked right outside. Being able to bring the ballot directly to their front door could give these people the ability to vote.

You are right Brad - I live in Australia's coldest state but the temperature rarely gets below -5 deg C (20 F) so (except for very occasional flooding and snow) we tend not to think about being generally restricted by weather. The challenges we face (though not in my state) that are addressed by mobile voting are more related to remoteness as well as places like nursing homes.Although there is a lot of support for smartphone and computer technology taking the existing technology (in Australia's case pencil and paper) to the marginalised and the populous generally still makes sense.
Made me think of library bookmobiles, which are like a mobile branch of a library.

That's a great analogy! I love the food truck concept, though it seems like something that would mostly be appropriate/accessible in urban areas. This made me think something that is kind of a cross between food trucks and library bookmobiles: Meals on Wheels, i.e., a volunteer network of voting delivery.
Great Idea!!
I love this!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Great inspiration Joyce, I'm imagining a swarm of election volunteers (see Alex's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/portable-ballot-boxes/) dispatching from the mobile voting trucks to reach even more citizens and remind others to cast a ballot.
Hello Joyce,Truly wonderful inspiration that stimulates ideas and emotionsCheers
Look forward to seeing this idea build out in the concept phase!
Agreed! Great ideas Joyce!

Great inspiration !! I also found similar to this inspiration. In India 'India Voting' has started its awareness campaign to promote voting among youngsters and other citizens, urging them to cast their votes. This is done by using the mobile vans. These vans carries an Electronic Voting Machine (EVM) with a ticker which counts the number of people who cast their symbolic vote. The local NGO run its mobile vans across the city. Here is the link for picture and more details http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=59108&n_tit=LS+Candidate+Priya+Dutt+Joins+India+Voting+in+its+Campaign+to+Urge+People+to+Vote+

Great! When I closed my eyes, imagined my granny or visualised cases posted first thing that came to my mind was a mobile voting place exactly like this idea. It can get everywhere. Should be constructed in such a way that a person can get inside and vote in private (e.g. behind venecian mirror door), this can be done by lowering suspension and a ramp on the side or back. A person can identify oneself via personal ID put into a slot like a credit card or a small scaner (at this stage a person can assist to do that for him/her without violating a secrecy). Commands can be seen and heard at the same time with visual pictures of candidates with a "tick" box aside. Options or commands can be given by voice or qwerty pad, ball-mouse, infrared joystick or touch screen at the same time. If needed a language option can be chosen - a language one speeks best. I just cannot figure out what to do when we have a person with hearing and seeing disability or illiterate with hearing disability.

Joyce, I love this!  Its such a fun and creative idea, and would make voting physically accessible to people without eliminating the 'social' aspect of voting.  Thanks for sharing bringing this inspiration to the table!

I love that idea. I was actually thinking about the DeWalt vans that used to drive around to construction sites demonstrating the tools and offering assistance/replacement. I can totally see "Voting Trucks" driving around, maybe with iPads or some other mobile device that people can then use to vote. It would also be a great way to bring access to senior citizens and others who are unable to drive to voting centers. Really great inspiration!

Hello Joyce,What a powerful and positive inspiration. I can visualize the Voting truck passing by in my street! I really like the combination of the old food-truck and social media. Bring voting to the people!

harnessing_the_mobility_of_food_trucks.title: Harnessing the Mobility of Food Trucks

credit_card_voting_using_mobile_phones.description: Use Credit Cards to Vote Securely using any Mobile Phone.
credit_card_voting_using_mobile_phones.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: I guess you've never had your credit card number stolen.  (Not that I have, either, although I did receive a letter and a new card from my credit card company saying that, for security purposes, they were changing my number.)
Steve, there is a physical signature associated with the credit card transaction.

And when does that get checked?  What do I do when I pull out my phone to vote ten minutes before the polls close, swipe my card, and get back a message back saying "It seems you've already voted."?You have an interesting idea, but the devil is in the details.A physical signature on a credit card transaction (which, BTW, doesn't exist for telephone or internet transactions) allows me, when a fraudulent charge appears on my bill, to successfully challenge that charge and have it reversed (with the merchant and/or the credit card company absorbing the loss).  You need to work out the analogy for reversing (or preventing) a fraudulent vote.One possibility: All mobile phone votes become provisional votes, not counted until after the signature has been checked.  They get timestamped, and if more than one comes in from the same voter, they all get flagged for special attention.  Perhaps the voter gets contacted and asked to come in to verify which signature is really theirs, in case staff can't tell from comparison with the signature on file.  If there's more than one with a truly valid signature, the one with the earliest timestamp is the one that's counted.Of course, when a credit card number is stolen by a store employee, they also have access to your signature, as it's on the slip that the merchant retains. I could imagine someone being paid to capture an image with their cell phone, and the buyer having access to an expert forger.  Or not even an expert forger; just print out the image of the signature, place it on top of the screen of the voting phone, and trace it.(There's also the lack of an auditable paper record, the same defect that affects proposals for internet voting.)

Hey Steve,Thanks for your suggestions - Part of the inspiration phase is throwing out uncritical wild ideas while working out the "crinks" in the concept phase. I'm a fan of paper myself and am well aware of the possibility of credit card fraud (having been a victim once). Of course there would be some supervisory mechanism and some blending of physical paper in the process.BTW both paper and electronic ballots are subject to fraud:http://www.indianevm.com
It's an interesting technology Avi,  that no doubt could be adapted to read a range of 'encoded plastic' including the Indian National ID card described elsewhere.

Hi Avi,This is very helpful for election organizers because they can use an existing authorization system and just need to distribute a simple device for each. (I am a web developer and currently researching about credit card companies for my e-commerce development project.)I wonder if there is a way to help people to understand this advanced system. I imagine people who need this voting method, like elderly, are not so familiar with digital devices. Perhaps when people received this Square device, someone needs to provide an explanation for each and make sure him/her fully understand the voting method.I also imagine people want to know soon after voting whether their votes have successfully sent or not. When I observe people who rarely use the internet, they always worry a lot about their form submission. Maybe people want to have live chat support via Skype or telephone so that the operator can confirm his/her vote immediately?I think this inspiration has a very interesting point of view. Thanks for sharing it!

This is a great idea! If we can eliminate the burden of the time required to vote (eg, leave work early, get to the church, wait in line, drive home) we can make the voting process more inclusive to people who care about it less. Many people don't care enough about voting to devote 1 hour of their day to it, but these same people might be willing to devote 5 min to vote from home.
Hi Avi, nice idea. Be sure to hold on to it for the Concepting round  we've got quite a bit of the Inspiration phase to work through first! :)

credit_card_voting_using_mobile_phones.title: Credit Card Voting using Mobile Phones

use_of_facial_detection_and_finger_print.description: Use of software like Veriface and automobile biometric scanner to give access to the user.
use_of_facial_detection_and_finger_print.creator: 6a86eece32828960588f9da0387a5608

comments.text: This is a great inspiration.One of the issues that has to be addressed in any proposed voting method would be the validity of the vote - did each person only vote once?  did anyone steal anyone else's vote by voting in their place? etc...If voting were authenticated by a face scan and a finger print, it would ensure that you were the only one that could cast your own vote.I wonder if there would be a way of compiling a face/finger print database without people feeling as if their privacy were being violated.

Wonderful inspiration Suganya.As Jessica suggests the combination of these two biometric ids should provide proof positive of a person's identityThe fingerprint id is also in use in a range of pc's.Questions of privacy are usually vexed because we feel the need to know who has information about us and what the can do with that information.The facial recognition database already exists, worldwide, for those who have embraced membership of the faddish Facebook and released their photograph(s) through that social medium. Agreements by such organisations not to share personal information with third parties don't apply to the information you yourself freely share with the community. For many of us other facial databases already exist too - drivers licence photos, passport photos - the retention of these photos varies between jurisdictions and their use is usually strictly controlled.A database of fingerprints also already exists for some (predominantly those of interest to the police) - extending the use of fingerprints as a part of an integrated identification system for electoral purposes would raise issues of trust.Personally I have a greater trust in government than in private enterprise but I know others will have a different opinion.

Thank you Paul. Yes privacy does matter when it comes to such database systems. I also have greater trust in government. When they can have our social security number and other details secured am sure this kind of systems can also be safely secured.
Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link

use_of_facial_detection_and_finger_print.title: Use of facial detection and finger print scanning to authenticate and connect the user.

skype_to_vote.description: How easy would it be to log into a Skype like government database and vote?!
skype_to_vote.creator: e5ef6afee0cc6567de8978188492d0bb
skype_to_vote.title: Skype to Vote

a_genius_bar_for_voting.description: IDEO Palo Alto recently hosted a brainstorm for our Voting Challenge. One of our ideas was to focus on customer service at the polling place and create a "genius bar" for voting.
a_genius_bar_for_voting.creator: 6a75b6ebe0dd913f0971ada060e2f7ea

comments.text: The suggestion of using hotel staff to train poll workers is an adequate technique, especially because customer service is harder said than done. Another analogy for this new focus on customer service is what Ritz Carltons did for the hospitality services. Their motto of ladies and gentlemen serving ladies and gentlemen exemplifies how highly-trained staff can create a superior experience for users. One way to try out this concept without incurring a lot of infrastructure investment would be to partner with local coffee shops. Some of these places are already known for their comfortable and friendly lounges, so their environment would be fitting to this concept.

Interesting ideas Eduardo would be good if polling places became a comfortable environment where instead of a long queue people could sit, read, play with their kids etc. while waiting their turn to vote.If this could be done with making the voting faster and easier then more staff time could be devoted to helping those having various difficulties.

I like the idea of partnering with local coffee shops, which tend to already be part of the community and informal hubs for the exchange of information. Many also host regular community events, so could be a logical place for voters to find election details and share concerns. Plus, coffee and cake!

Excellent point that poll workers are the face of the voting experience -- their levels of friendliness and expertise will largely determine the voter's experience. I like using the Apple store and its genius bar as the example as well, as many of us do expect a higher standard of customer service and expertise there than in other retail environments.Can we further support poll workers and improve the voting experience by studying Apple stores as a model for community-based voting and civic-education centres? If we look at some of the characteristics of Apple stores (I've referenced this site: http://www.ifoapplestore.com/the_stores.html)- welcoming environment - award-winning architecture with light-filled spaces and bright interiors, large wall posters, seating areas for waiting for others and absorbing information- zones for hands-on, real-world use - Could these include voting simulators on iPads or similar devices, so voters can try out and get comfortable with the voting experience and interface before going in to do the real thing?- a sit-down theater area for instruction and demonstrations/"Studio Bar" for assistance - an inviting area for education about voting concepts, issues, and process- a children's area - for single parents, parents who bring their children with them- public restrooms!- an open Airport wireless network- a diverse staff, including older employees- a schedule of in-store events and instructionThree levels of checkout/voting experiences, depending on time constraints and needs of the voter:- roaming poll workers with iPads or other devices that would allow "express lane" voters who are comfortable with the process to vote and check out - "standard" checkout/voting stations where most voters would go to place their vote.  Stations would be of different heights and sizes to accommodate wheelchairs and other accessibility needs.- a "Genius Bar" where voters can ask questions or request additional assistanceOr maybe Apple stores can just be converted for the cause around election time. :)

The "conceirge" model and element -- and the redefining of the roles of the community members who provide the direct, on-the-ground services on Election Day is a really important piece of the conversation.  Thanks for highlighting that -- something to consider in looking at all the concepts.

Really intrigued by the idea that the answer to accessible voting could be as simple as re-thinking the role of the volunteer staff. Just this morning I passed by a voting station set up on my way to work and noticed the volunteer's responsibilities merely checking voters in and sitting idly waiting for the next. This added benefit to the job has the potential to entice more volunteers; however could also hinder if the task becomes too cumbersome.

Agreed Stacy and great concept IDEO Palo Alto Team.I particularly like the idea of 'day before' appointments.In my concept on dispersing the queue http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/disperse-the-queue/ I propose an expanded assistance role but fall short of calling it a 'help desk'. The concept was based redefining the voter as the client of the polling place and on the way some banks have refocused their queuing.Combining this Genius Bar concept with several others including Whitney's brilliant concept for when where and how ballots are marked http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/ T. Annie Nguyen's Voter Help Hubhttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voter-help-hub/ andMamta Gautam's Appointment Booking concepthttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/find-out-book-your-time-slot-/ and others I can see a more relaxed, less stressful voting environment emerging where assistance for those who really need it is an important focus.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Way to go, guys! Especially like the idea of drawing upon experience of customer service experts like hotel staff, to inspire poll workers in this direction.

a_genius_bar_for_voting.title: A Genius Bar for Voting

Here's an example of how built up ideas can get over the course of a challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/localfood/winners-announced/public-kitchen/ Let's bring on the builds and spell out the specifics!

who_knew_being_part_of_something_could_f.description: When I voted in the 2011 Chicago Mayoral election, I had all the info. I knew who, what, where, how and when. But for some reason, I was still filled with self-doubt, and anxiety. Then I thought about  how someone would feel with less confidence.
who_knew_being_part_of_something_could_f.creator: bbe38514a39c38f89ffd168573733920

comments.text: Great personal story. Thanks for sharing!

Really wonderful insights Anna, thanks so much for sharing. I especially like your point about wanting to join a bigger movement of people doing something important, together, all at once. It's definitely something for us to keep in mind during our upcoming Concepting phase.

who_knew_being_part_of_something_could_f.title: Who knew being part of something could feel so isolating.

voter_support_network.description: How can we use the social nature of elections to create a support network, helping voters with general elections information, but also with accessibility help?
voter_support_network.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: I really like the idea of creating infrastructure for volunteers who are willing to help out on election day (or even during early/absentee voting periods); particularly if the volunteers come from a place that links the voter to some sense of community. One thing to think about is whether the vetting of volunteers is necessary. If so, perhaps an institutional affiliation, geography, or interest groups is the first step in such vetting. I guess I'm more hesitant about volunteers from the crowd-in-general and more excited about a limited pool.

Dan, I think your point about vetting volunteers is a good and important one. Even assuming good intentions all around, it's important that they get some training (where are the answers to questions) and some coaching (what are the boundaries - what questions can they answer, which ones are not appropriate). I don't think this has to be extensive. There are models we could draw on. There is a certification for peer-counselors in various worlds. The National Institutes of Health has online training for protecting people who participate in research. Can you help think about what should be included? Perhaps you could make this a separate concept. A number of the concepts involve using people from the community to help support voters, so it could be applicable to any of them.

Hi Whitney, Perhaps what should be included in any vetting or certification depends on what aspects of the election process--and for which voters--they'd be supporting. I don't think I have enough for a full concept yet, but I'll be tossing it around.

voter_support_network.title: Voter Support Network

the_election_festival.description: Why not extend the voting period to ease the pressure? Can we integrate some voting mediums such as mobile trucks and out-door voting?
the_election_festival.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: I agree, the use of personas has really brought this concept to life. I like your idea around reducing bottle necks and reducing the chance of errors. I counted votes one year and remember the painful delays while people caught up and then the issue of having to recount them all again! If time pressure wasn't so critical, the process would have been much smoother.

Thanks Louise. Interesting to have your experience re. counting votes. It seemed to us that several issues raised during the inspiration phase were linked to time: queues, stress for people with accessibility issues, motivation to vote, and possibly counting. We thought that if you were to extend time, you might also multiply spaces (esp. as spaces used by poll stations might not be available for more than one day).

Another thought we had was the parallelization of processes inspired by the latest trends in computing. What if there was dual voting lines? One line would get their I.D checked and then vote while another line would vote first and then get their I.D checked (invalid I.D = invalid vote). Thus, we can make effective use of "down-time" in terms of booths and manpower, thus making the queues even shorter :-)

Nice thoughts Ashwin. I think that this concept is a nice addition to the community aspect highlighted by Cansu in her concept on celebrating elections: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/elections-a-community-celebrationIt might be nice to integrate both concepts.
Great use of the our personas tips sheet guys! Really helps everyone engage with the great ideas you're sharing here.
Thanks Meena! We did find them very useful as we worked on the concept with Ashwin and other members of the OpenIDEO student chapter.
Thank you Meena. The personas also helped greatly when exploring different user stories through role-playing. We feel that this particular tips sheet can be used universally. Great work guys!
Fab that you guys have used the personas for role play!  Great ideating build on the tip-sheet.

the_election_festival.title: The Election Festival

airports_as_stressful_as_moving_houses_a.description: As I was reading about long lines, difficulty of access, lack of understanding, I could not help thinking of the experience of going through security in airports. Can we learn from this stressful experience to make voting more accessible?
airports_as_stressful_as_moving_houses_a.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: There may be more security at the bigger airports, because they anticipate more travelers.  - It is helpful, when airports are prepared.  But, even at O'Hare and Midway, I've got through security in 5 minutes.So... with voting, to make it less stressful - Study from previous years, which are the most populated/busy polling stations.  Is it just the number of people? And/Or -- Is it the time of day?Can you have more volunteers at certain hours of the day?So, you can boost the volunteers at certain hours of the day (early moring or after work, for instance).  And/Or - have the extra volunteers do just one job of the process -- such as checking IDs. And/or They can get their name, and find it on the sign-in sheet, before they get to the front of the line... so you've sped up the ID checking time, and the sign-in time.  If certain areas pass out numbers (like a deli), then give one volunteer that duty.

Thanks for this comment Daniel - is there a concept in this to re-design the experience at polling booths in USA - you might like to refer to Greg Baker's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-we-ve-learned-from-a-century-of-better-than-99-turnout-in-australia/ - whilst the challenge is focusing on improving access for less mobile or incapacitated voters anything that reduces frustration and stress at polling stations must be beneficial.

Great contribution.  I live in Chicago and here we have two airports O'Hare (huge and monstrous) and Midway (smaller and smarter).  I travel in both and I am always struck by the intelligence of the design in the Midway Airport.  The security lines are separated into categories "expert traveler," "casual traveler," and "family traveler" each with an accompanying picture.  You choose which you should go in.  This gives travelers not only a way to feel more in control but also self-select how much assistance and time they will need to make it through security.  Maybe a similar approach could be used for voting.
Terrific addition Sarah  here's hoping it'll inspire a concept or two in our next phase!

wow, what great inspiration, AL! Travelling is something we choose to do and in some people's eye, is a necessity but isn't always a pleasant experience. Great analogy to voting. I WANT to build on this inspiration for the concept phase...
Looking forward to seeing how you build on this and to maybe collaborate on your concept... :-)
Hey Anne, i completely agree , i am literally sleepless the night prior to boarding my flight and the anxiety continues untill i land safely. I really prefer trains somehow ! Interesting reference !

I think its interesting that you bring up airports a reference, I think we can learn much from airport services to realize elements that coalesce to create and even enhance experiences. One thing that I think is crucial is realizing the value of human contact. Now with the advent of "self check in stations" where you can print out your own boarding pass, there are new means of navigating the system. Because of the newness and relative unfamiliarity its so helpful that they have workers stationed at these kiosks to assist the users if they need it. This human element is like a temporary guardian angel--there to assist and ensure the desired outcome for the user--really key when dealing with important transactions that are stages in a larger system. With airports and travel there is a sense of agenda that is parallel to that of voting, and I think the value of the expert should be regarded as a crucial element of the service. With voting and travel you want to make sure you are doing it right, and nothing is more reassuring than an expert's helpful direction close at hand.
*experts

Thanks Molly. I am glad you found the analogy meaningful. I agree that people as providing inspiration, connection and help are key (and that emerged from several inspirations). I like your point about thinking of human as temporary supports when introducing changes and new technology.

airports_as_stressful_as_moving_houses_a.title: Airports "as stressful as moving houses", and voting?

comments.text: What do you think about using book mobiles to bring the polling station to the disable, or setting up polling stations in doctors offices and hospitals?
Both are excellent suggestions - check out the various voting van and mobile options too

well it`s about voting vans or buses, i think is is less expensive buy vans than rent a whole place and adapt it for impairment people, the problem is: what about the wait area?? i hadly think that you may buld a comfortable area with only a van or a bus...perhaps they can be used to reach the poeple who can`t go out voting but...with the fuel prices, it may be more than expensive than send a mobile device adapted for impairment people and reclaim it after the election is over.finally, i think the idea of setting the polling stations in hospitals is great for the phase 2 of my idea...after all, there is no better place to find specialist in disabilities than a hospital...definitely Suilen O'neil you`ll be part of my virtual team :)

You raise some good points here Christian.Using a combination of all the types of places and ways to vote we can hopefully cover everyone.Keep up the good creative thinking and bring it into the refinement phase for the concepts that make it there.

comments.text: Visualization is indeed very powerful, and I'm pretty sure resonates with a design community like this one ;)How can we translate the power of the iconic to other modalities that particular groups may prefer/rely on, e.g. audio  for people with blindness? What would be the equivalent of a "ringtone" for different parties/candidates?

Yes - audio and touch are the two that come to mind for blind voters. I would be interested to know if blind voters in USA can be assisted by relatives or a person of their choice as is the case here in Australia. The Australian Electoral Office goes to great lengths to provide fully inclusive voting.
With the huge growth in information graphics I think this sounds like a very logical next step!
Very interesting, Jim  especially when you think of it in potential combination with practices like Sarah noted in Morocco: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-election-poster-wall/
