election_analytics.description: Verify that your vote was counted and visualize the election results by city, region, and country – in real time.
election_analytics.creator: d2cd3db5ea4b789b678422e8499a9267

comments.text: Hi again Mike - to return to two things in this Analytics concept of yours:Firstly - I readily concede the desirability of using Analytics to provide a real-time count (as I have intimated in another comment)  I should also like to see them contribute to real-time information that enhances movement through the polling station by algorithmically linking them to systems such as Team S.O.Y.'s "online bookings" in their Comfort Waiting concepthttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/comfort-waiting/ Secondly, on the issue of trust -Having taken part in a number of elections, where I have been a team member involved in physically counting paper ballots, I have no problem in trusting the "system" here to properly count my carefully, correctly completed ballot. Perhaps naively I would trust the machine to get it right too, and if it couldn't read my ballot that it would be manually interpreted and counted. However I can see the other point of view too. I mentioned in an earlier comment another concept "in the pipeline" (its been there on hold for nearly a week) - on hold because without direct experience of the US system I cannot satisfactorily answer these two questionsTo what extent does having the voting machines verify and count the vote in the presence of the voter contribute to bottlenecks in throughput at the polling station? andWould separating the casting process from the counting process (eliminating immediate feedback on vote quality) make casting votes quicker and easier?Perhaps I shall just float the concept tonight and anticipate a barrage of comments around this issue of trust.

Alas - one other quick question.When I check my data usage for my connection I get the disclaimer that it can take up to 2 hours for my data usage to be updated. I accept this as reasonable.Would you see a similar disclaimer on your receipt (perhaps saying "Under normal circumstances it will take approximately 30 minutes before you can verify this receipt online") as too restrictive or as acceptable for "real-time" verification?I don't mean this as a disclaimer for legal purposes (that's a whole other issue) but simply practical.

Hi Paul, I'll try answers. Bottlenecks. There are differing opinions on this question. HAVA requires that voters have the opportunity to review and correct their ballot before casting. The design of the overall election system, and the design of the individual parts both contribute. And can be organized for better or worse experience. In a way, systems with paper ballots + a scanner already have this separation, but with neither particularly well optimized.The thing that is important is that the ballot marking .. Design + any mechanism .. support voters in marking their ballots as intended, even with the large US ballots.Delays: I think that a short delay is perfectly reasonable. I think it would be better to have a delay, with more accurate reporting, than the alternative.Interested parties already obtain daily data from election offices. They use it to track turnout.. For example,whether absentee ballots have been returned. They use this to adjust their own efforts. The innovation in this concept is in asking the progress of the election (though not interim results of course) more transparent to all voters. Several of the other concepts could use these analytics.

Thanks Whitney for such useful answers, particularly the interpretation of HAVA. The idea of reviewing my own ballot paper for correct marking (which here in Australia is my responsibility), feeding it into the system and then having the system (in the form of the scanner) review it again before allowing me to cast the ballot is completely foreign to me. However, thank you for the explanation which has determined me not to submit my other concept.I also seem to have misinterpreted Mike's concluding statement, "They can also visualize how their decisions match up to others in their community, city, and so forth." and subsequent comment on my expressed concern about influencing voters in later time zones, as implying that the data presented to the public would indeed be real-time interim results.This was a silly mistake of mine in view of the fact that I built on Mike's concept because I saw that it could provide some of the metrics necessary for the real-time reporting of voter traffic on which a part of my mapping concept would depend.

Now applying the principle to my own experience I can see that, once the data is released at the close of polls, I would be able to compare my own choices with those made by everyone else voting at the same polling place, in the same precinct or city etc. I can also see potential political and commercial value in matching data in such analysis with data collected from other sources. To use a facile example it might be possible to conclude that communities given to purchasing large quantities of peanuts might also vote in favour of reducing taxes on bananas.

Thanks for adding me to your virtual team Mike! I'm glad to hear my inspiration got you thinking :) I think the element of trust is really important for all voters. I wonder if there might be other accessibility elements that get "baked in" to your analytics? For instance, could voters have the opportunity to provide real-time feedback on their local polling place and its accessibility options?
This analytics concept was one of my inspirations for the Mapping, Accessibility Rating and Traffic Reports concept and another in the pipeline.

Ashley - that's a fantastic idea! Adding real-time communications would be an easy way for people to share information about what to expect at their polling place. In a way this could tie in with Paul's wayfinding concept at polling locations (which I have some personal experience with because my polling place over the last several years has changed three times and is never clearly marked)... for example, if the someone has a hard time finding their polling place, they can use the analytics tool to post a comment that helps other voters find their way more easily.Paul's signage concept is here: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voter-friendly-and-interactive-signage/

Thanks for linking the signage concept here I will add a build of this concept in it. I think I have already built on this Analytics concept for my earlier Mapping concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mapping-accessability-rating-and-traffic-reports./ ) but in the event I have not I will make sure I do on next update.In that regard I find the term "build on" just a tad misleading (but I cant think of a better one). When I joined OI during the Social Impact challenge I thought of "building on" as meaning the concept built upon had precede the challenge being developed - it has taken me a little time to realise that it is both legitimate and desirable to "build on" subsequent concepts when making updates and revisions.

Hi Mike - conceptually I think this is great but I have some issues with both components.Analytics - like the USA our principle time difference between east and west is 3 hours and last election (for the first time) election results being analysed on the east coast were broadcast on the west coast before the polls closed in the west. Nobody knows or will ever know how much the trends broadcast affected voting in those places with polling booths still open. I expect I am old-fashioned but I would prefer all votes to be cast before analysis begins, but once that last polling booth is closed - go for it!Receipt - I think a randomised receipt is a good idea to allow you to verify that your vote has got into the system, but I think it should be a removable (tear off)  part of the original ballot paper that voters can opt to remove or not. There are two reasons for this:1 - generating a receipt through the voting machine adds further time to the process of casting a vote. I believe the casting process through the machines is a major cause of bottlenecks and delays (I am preparing a concept to partially address this); and2. - generating a unique random number for the ballot is far easier when it is printed than reliably retrieving the next random number, in real time, from a possibly nationwide centralised database.As to knowing how one voted I the only problem I have with that is the time factor mentioned above and the (presumed) fact that most people interested in making the analytic comparisons will either remember or can make their own record.Notwithstanding my comments I shall build on this for my next two concepts. Keep up the great thinking!!

About the time issue of several time zones on election day, I think it would be worth to check out how this concept would work together with this one: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/polling-day-s-every-day.-vote-when-you-can-when-you-want-during-any-period-of-an-election-term.

Thanks for the comments guys! There really is no data out there to help us understand exactly how a system like this might influence the votes of others in later time zones as an election unfolds, but I don't imagine it having a much different impact than the 24/7 election coverage we've been seeing by news media (which continues to be more in-depth and multi-faceted each election cycle).  What is would do, however, is allow election data to bypass the news media middle man and go directly to the public (via the Web).

Mike, I personally have no problems in "knowing" how the election is progressing. but I can see that some people might jump on the band wagon or alternatively vote for the underdog. However I think this will be an inevitable trend so maybe we just embrace it and, as you say, go directly to the public.Johan - having just said my piece above I think the idea of having an extended voting period is probably sensible provided it includes at least one weekend day. The media here raised some questions about this idea when it was implemented in the recent Egyption elections but I have heard no feedback about it.

Fab idea, Mike! As you continue to develop your ideas you may also want to consider how folks with various accessibility issues might interact with the analytics you are suggesting. eg. Could the analytics be processed by screen readers for those who face issues around sight?

Good point, Meena. To be honest I have a very limited understanding of how those types of technologies work, but I'd love to dig into it and see if analytics could be made more accessible to a wider audience that way!

And one more thing you might want to check out is our new Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Because great ideas start with people, right?
Those personas are great and have me thinking about ways this concept could be iterated to improve accessibility on a physical scale... back to the drawing board!

Mike, I love this build and how you extended my concept's framework on individual voting receipts & publicly available voting data, and brought its usage application to a whole new level with visualization & analytics!Just added 2 links directly to your inspiring concept in my online/mobile voting concept: ttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all
http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all
Thanks Vincent... and thanks also for sharing so many awesome resources on your concept!

election_analytics.title: Election Analytics

we_already_have_the_tools_28_states_have.description: This is a straightforward approach to what is already legislated, but is not utilized: 'no excuse' mail-in voting. Campaigns and activists use existing tech (voter rolls) to encourage people to mail their ballots in. We have already piloted this.
we_already_have_the_tools_28_states_have.creator: 0b970ec2b14e71d62ad51372bd700de0

comments.text: Hi Ryan.  You might want to think about how no excuse absentee voting can be improved so that people with disabilities can take advantage of the option. For example, paper forms that come in the mail are often not accessible for blind voters. How can we build on the no excuse absentee voting to make sure everyone can take advantage of this?

Good stuff -- and a very applicable story embedded in the comments that speaks to the principle of flexibility and options in voting.  I wonder how this social voting concept could be broadened beyond traditional no-excuse absentee voting (vote by mail) in light of the anticipated reduction in services via the USPS. Thanks.

Great stuff Ryan. As we are particularly focusing on enhancing access to the election process for those with accessibility challenges  perhaps you'd like to outline some potential scenarios for those with specific challenges (mobility, visibility, etc) for your concept. This will help others engage with your idea within the key themes of our challenge. You can update your concept at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right. Looking forward to see your concept and conversations here evolve!

Another thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve.

Hey Guys,Thanks very much for the feedback. What I'm proposing is a ridiculously high-touch system, incorporating both a bit of research (though it would be automated, based on voter rolls) and a whole lot of shoe leather. But, as my research indicates, votes are expensive! So, a campaign might as well ensure the value of what they are investing. Having the Social Voting team go one step further and help those with accessibility challenges is a natural step. Quick story for thought purposes: my fiancee and I were working tirelessly on the mayoral campaign here this year - literature all over, meetings here etc. Voting day came and our roommate simply didn't make it to the polls. Why? A full time job and responsibilities after work. For him, a healthy white male, accessibility in this case was a challenge. Thanks for all your passion,Ryan

Also a way to identify those who wanted to vote and DEMONSTRATE to them how their vote(s) could have made a difference in a tangible way, with simple statistics, without necessarily blaming, might be a good thing? Everyone wants to avoid "guilt" and lack of responsibility. So what can we do to make not voting as unacceptable say as ... fill-in the blank ...

we_already_have_the_tools_28_states_have.title: We already have the tools (28 states have 'no excuse' mail in voting)... we're just not using them!

_i_voted_but_can_we_please_talk_about_so.description: Name two things you shouldn't discuss at the dinner table. I bet politics is one of them! How can we expect people to participate in the process or know about the issues while avoiding the subject?
_i_voted_but_can_we_please_talk_about_so.creator: 12323b2c5a9a157e6f95596e58ed993b

comments.text: Good point. These taboos or inhibitions do indeed represent hurdles to the kind of deliberation we might hope to see from an engaged electorate. I also think that some of the histrionics we see in congress/parliament contribute to a perception that talking about politics inevitably gets messy. Part of the solution might lie in restoring faith in the deliberative process, and debating in general.

Election issues in some parts of Africa are considered a taboo subject. It is associated with pagans or non church goers. Even attempts by mainstream churches to urge their Christians vote has been received with significant resentment. Efforts to convince catholic Christians that this is the method used to elect top church leaders like the pope has not yielded significant results especially in rural areas. The reason why some do vote is because they believe they will benefit materially when ruling party representatives come to share tins of tomatoes or cups of rice.
Really nice thoughts Joel, thanks for sharing!

Great thoughts and well stated!I'm sure you are right. although the use of social media may begin to buck this trend in part because it is an impersonal but influential space.It's actually a very thorny problem because although the issues may be discussed (problems with access to health care, public transport etc). the tenor of discussion usually removes the politics and just focuses on the problems.There is some hope for this in things like the occupy movement - just as are civil rights.

Here is one link that I found by googling "why people don't vote in elections" It talks about a recent survey in California and sheds some light on the question.  http://usgovinfo.about.com/od/thepoliticalsystem/a/whynotvote.htm What floored me was the statement "The first-of-its-kind survey sheds new light on the incentives and barriers to voting ..." - is there a renaissance afoot? The section headed "Even non-voters say voting is important" is illuminating too. Gives me hope that perhaps the first US state to have the courage to introduce compulsory voting and give its citizens the real opportunity to express their opinions might reap the advantages mandatory voting provides http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/countries-with-compulsory-voting-may-provide-useful-lessons-about-voting-accessibility.../

Love the link! I spoke with an Australian friend who mentioned compulsory voting as well! An interesting idea, and a very explicit way to increase participation - though it does make me wonder if requiring a person to vote undermines the freedom of an individual to choose not to vote (a bit meta, maybe!).I thought Facebook was interesting during the most recent election. I remember they placed an "I Voted" button on the homepage that one could click to indicate to friends that they voted. I imagine everybody who clicked it didn't actually vote, but it's interesting to consider what motivates a person to click it and to imagine ways we could make it verifiable.The fact that non-voters still say voting is important is so, so interesting to me. They say it's important, but just not important enough for them to do it too. "What we say vs. what we do."

Compulsory voting doesn't restrict freedom to choose nobody - informal votes (just a blank unmarked ballot) are perfectly legal - but mandatory voting is a great way to give everyone the opportunity.If electronic voting is introduced more widely in Australia it will still be legal to 'vote for nobody', even if biometric ids are introduced they will only be used to confirm that you have turned up to vote not how you voted.Yes you are so right about "What we say vs what we do"

_i_voted_but_can_we_please_talk_about_so.title: "I voted" - but can we please talk about something else?

currency_design_for_the_visually_impaire.description: Many countries design currency notes and coins in such a way that the visually impaired can better recognise and use them.
currency_design_for_the_visually_impaire.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7

comments.text: Anne-Laure: oh, I haven't heard of such carved symbols. From my experience so far, the EVMs simply have paper prints next to the buttons (where the symbols, candidate and party names are printed) ; you then press the button next to your choice. For blind voters, I had read of a possible addition where they have some information in Braille next to the buttons. My feeling is that carved symbols would be harder/more expensive to produce. But that's an interesting concept in itself.
Thanks. I might have misunderstood and / or got inspired :-)I'll double check.
great inspiration! I was talking today with an Indian student who was telling me that on the voting machine the symbols for each party was carved and thus recognizable by touch...
I just realized I was maybe not very clear :-): I meant the electronic voting machine they used in India when he voted...

Anne-Laure: oh, I haven't heard of such carved symbols. From my experience so far, the EVMs simply have paper prints next to the buttons (where the symbols, candidate and party names are printed) ; you then press the button next to your choice. For blind voters, I had read of a possible addition where they have some information in Braille next to the buttons. My feeling is that carved symbols would be harder/more expensive to produce. But that's an interesting concept in itself.

I suppose the trick is how to delegate "meaning" to each of the shapes/textures - but then this could be a feature of candidates' campaigns - "vote for me, I'm the soft furry guy!" or "My policies are rigid and unyielding, like the square edges of my voting token." You might just have invented a whole new metaphoric language for politics.....
Great example of how we can build accessibility into everyday things.
Great idea. I was playing around with some similar thoughts, and this gave them a bit of a direction.
Great example, and love how many of these design choices like sizing bills based on value benefits so many: visually impaired, foreign tourists, cashiers, etc.

comments.text: Hi there  interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the right hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.
Mobile voting could be a very good option if there is a remote monitoring system to ensure cards are not stuffed into the box

ada_checklist_for_polling_places.description: A checklist for implementing the current ADA regulations. Useful for seeing what challenges are met when arriving at the polling center. Might make an argument for bringing the polling to the voter instead.
ada_checklist_for_polling_places.creator: 14d2b3364a376d542a66fcd9fde335a6

comments.text: Paul, In the US there are options for voting "absentee" - your ballot is mailed to your home. The difficulty is that this is just a paper ballot, so can be an accessibility challenge. In some states, notably Oregon, everyone votes by mail. There are vote centers with accessible systems for those who prefer to vote in person, and for people who cannot use either option, officials will drive to the voter's residence. That was one of the motivations for the iPad voting systems featured in a couple of other Inspsirations. The easy portability of a tablet is a real advantage in any sort of mobile polling place.
Seems very comprehensive requirement brief.What options are currently available to those with disabilities to vote from home or in their residential institution?

Hi Vincent, thanks for sharing this! It's an incredibly thorough look at how election officials can improve the accessibility of their polling stations. I know it's not time for Concepting yet, but here's one seed to plant in the meantime: while the doc is super thorough, it's also really long and wordy which makes the information difficult to digest. Perhaps when we head into Concepting it's worth thinking about how these tips and tricks could be presented more visually and in an easier-to-read format? Just something to think about :)
Thanks Ashley, great idea!
Great overview of physical requirements - thanks! I appreciate the idea of how challenges of physical barriers are addressed by voting from home.
Thanks Sharron!

ivote.description: The use of tablets provides voters a more accessible and enjoyable voting experience.
ivote.creator: df95fa3dd6fe094ae07556d59e9a1d4a

comments.text: This idea needs some work. iPads are not cheap at all. Could you possibly use a cheaper tablet? Could you design a system using alternative fuels using corn?
Note: the tablets are not limited to iPads

For the bulk of voting this and other online options will become a reality in the future.How would you envisage incorporating the need for a physical ballot that can be audited?You might like to see how your system would allow the people in the personas to cast there vote privately and securely.http://www.openideo.com/fieldnotes/openideo-team-notes/personas-for-concepts/

I think what the article says is that the Kindle buttons were too small for her to use. They'd originally tried a book reader for kids. That interface worked, but the content was wrong. This was a way of giving the Kindle a tactile keypad.

With only a few days left in Concepting, have a think about tools, resources, trainings, or technologies that might create opportunities for leaders to role model their behavior and attitudes. What might this look like? Who might lead it? Can't wait to see what you come up with!

voting_on_the_web.description: It's time to take the voting process on the web for the people can't reach out to the voting machine due to their disabilities. We do many of our tasks like banking, shopping, paying bills on internet then why can't voting.
voting_on_the_web.creator: dab84ed1e9ad88ca749f9f919e0aa6cb

comments.text: I am agree with you Drew. No wonder it would be a revolutionary if we take the voting process on the web. But as you said ensuring the integrity of the system is a massive hurdle and it will take some time to develop such system. Till then employing a system with available level of encryption can be made available to the physically handicapped people. In the due course a research can be focused on to develop an advanced encryption so the system can achieve a high level of security necessary enough for critical process like voting. The lessons learned from the system for the handicaps can be utilized in this research.

This is interesting thinking Prasad. It would be in line with the approach being taken to allow people with some disabilities to vote using the telephone in Australia as described in Tim Noonan's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/ The security for this system is based on the telephone banking model which has proven successful in Australia for a number of years.

I've seen your link Paul and I'm really excited to know that a system like tele-voting is already in use. Its unfortunate but in my country I've seen people skipping important process like voting because for them its boring to go to the polling station. Such a system can increase the percentage of the total voting as in India almost everyone has a cellphone. Great initiative by Australian government.

I am certainly fully on board with the concept of moving voting entirely to web. As you can imagine, there are massive hurdles to overcome to make a system like that truly secure, but what's an openIDEO challenge for if not to figure out a new way to overcome massive hurdles?I'm wondering though: if we can develop that system, why would we limit it only to those labeled as having "disabilities". If we have the system, why not allow anyone, regardless of label, the ease of voting online?

I agree with you about not limiting any solutions to those with disabilities - and the brief implies universality. Similarly the focus is on the US system but it would be nice if some solutions could be applied in places where web access and perhaps even telephone access is not available. This will mean several solutions but then that is usual in an OpenIDEO challenge.

video_voters_guide.description: Just as you receive a printed booklet outlining the arguments on both sides of ballot initiatives, what if we made a video version that aired on everything from TV news to YouTube?  Better yet, have it be interactive as well.
video_voters_guide.creator: 3c5a9e3aa2b68d7d01758a4c5a33d584

comments.text: I'm a big fan of voter's guides. Keep in mind most Americans do *not* receive a voters guide, even in referenda heavy states. As far as I know, it's a uniquely Western thing (California, Oregon, Washington State.) Interestingly, I wonder if it would be easier to introduce a video voters guide in states that no not have it, rather than trying to introduce a paper voters guide first.
I like how you've been clear that these supporting materials would be created by the election office  ensuring they are non-partisan while providing essential information.
Meena I agree, great point! This will be essential and, in my opinion, a much better way to educate than the soundbites (which typically aren't non-partisan) currently on TV.

Education via a video does appeal to different learning styles (reading isn't for everyone and I do agree that the small text can be quite challenging for some esp those with vision limitations). In addition to the educational element of the issues and candidates on the ballot, I think voting options (mail in, electronic, etc.) and any "how to" components would be of value to include, as well.

Cheers for reposting this fab idea Jim! I'm looking forward to seeing how it gets iterated over the next couple of weeks. Perhaps, as an image for this post, you'd like to sketch out some scenes from the video, to help everyone get a sense of the kind of content and conversations that would take place in the video?

video_voters_guide.title: Video Voters Guide

the_heart_button.description: The disabled can be ignored socially or treated as "special". How might we solve for physical needs and emotional needs, by avoiding social stigmas?
the_heart_button.creator: edaa59d5e115ae6571365e763291c048

comments.text: What brilliant example of the less articulated issues involved with disabilities. I wonder whether there is a possible route for designing a social aspect into such a private matter as voting. I know a lot of people who are very proud of voting and their voices being heard and they often act as social catalysts, even encouraging others to vote. But where does the balance lie between the right to privacy of vote and ability to shout it from the rooftops?
Wow, lovely story thanks Tom, it's always so great to have an open mind and be inquisitive - it usually gets to such touching observations like this one.
That's a lovely story. Thanks for sharing it.

smartphone_concept_for_aiding_the_visual.description: A concept video showing how smartphones could aid visually impaired people. I especially dig the virtual menu idea, where hand gestures control the application.
smartphone_concept_for_aiding_the_visual.creator: e206876cf2d052a069d13d2040d4ed41

comments.text: Seems likely to see more of these kinds of digital helping tools in the future. Definitely something to keep in mind for this election challenge. One design question I extract; how can the voting centers be designed to support such devices now and in the future? If the voting solution does not get to the universal point of one fits all, I definitely see the compatibility with such devices as one of the patch solutions!

Thanks for your comments Jakob. I think Vincent's suggestion of Kinect-like senors embedded in self-service machines is a great starting point for your question; although, I agree with your point of universal solutions and wonder if/how this type of technology could be applied.

I love the way this vision combines technologies into a really seamless experience. It reminds me of some iPhone/iPad apps I've been playing with:OMoby uses both bar/qrcodes and visual recognition http://omoby.com/pages/index.phpVizWiz is another. It has both visual recognition and volunteers in a social network/Mechanical Turk. In addition to the pictures, users can ask a question and get an answer. http://vizwiz.org/

I agree Whitney.  I like the seamless experience and also the ways you can receive and contribute data through a mix of sensory channels - voice, vibration, face recognition, hand gestures, etc.  I'm wondering if for a voting design concept, we can apply just one or two elements of this navigation platform to ensure that the interface is simple and doesn't require too much training time.

Agreed, I'm floored by that concept video's seamless experience and ability to handle multiple streams of information.Wonder what'd it be like to have a Kinect-like sensor UI in a self-service machine. Certainly the cost of these is becoming more accessible.

Lovely additions, thanks! I think the combination of OMoby + VizWiz + Kinect-like sensor grounds this concept and makes it awfully practical.It also makes me wonder how this technology could benefit voters beyond those who are visually impaired. What other features are needed? Are there additional inspirations that could connect? I'm curious to see if this concept could be fleshed out.

smartphone_concept_for_aiding_the_visual.title: Smartphone Concept for Aiding the Visually Impaired

proxy_voting.description: Delegating somebody to vote on behalf of others can have two benefits: [1] People are able to vote who otherwise wouldn't be able to vote, [2] The person casting the vote on behalf of somebody else can also vote themselves.

comments.text: Great insights Yarun, and welcome to OpenIDEO! You raise an interesting point here: for some, voting by proxy may be the only way of casting their ballot. However, as we get into Concepting, we'll want to try to think about solutions that enable anyone the chance to cast their ballot privately and independently, ie: without proxies. Stay tuned for more details as we get into Concepting next week  we'd love to have you join in!

informed_decisions_personalized_to_you.description: Political discourse today has become so abstract that we can no longer link ideas to concrete effects to our own, personal, individual lives. What if there were a tool/resource that knows you and can show you the concrete effect of your vote to you?

comments.text: William, I'm loving the start of your concept here! To help you think about building it out even further, you might want to check out our challenge's Guiding Principles http://bit.ly/AiJnLW, especially the section about accessibility in the context of this challenge. While we are curious about election access across the board, we're really focusing on enabling private and independent voting for people who are currently excluded due to disability, language, location or other restriction. How might you weave some of these accessibility concerns into your great concept?

And one more thing you might want to check out is our new Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Because great ideas start with people, right?

Super inspiring! Agreed with Paul about the opportunities.
Thanks for sharing, really inspiring and I agree too! I think a great concept could start from this post!

hey , check out this film called 'music within' based on the same spirit of how one guy goes around forming an organization which acts as bridge between people with disability and job opportunities-how each one fits in- in different job profiles .  http://images.search.conduit.com/ImagePreview/?q=music%20within&ctid=CT2790392&searchsource=53&start=0&pos=6

quick_and_easy_voting_system..description: How to eliminate long waiting queues and create accessible voting.
quick_and_easy_voting_system..creator: 6a86eece32828960588f9da0387a5608

comments.text: There is definitely something to be said about the ease and efficiency that must occur within the voting process for the general public to endure. Perhaps there is a way to combine the need for accessibility with the shrunken voting queues and create overall a more efficient system.It is interesting to propose an ATM machine as voting booth; but I am even more enthused about your idea of combining online technology with the voting process. Since the number of cell phones is growing exponentially, its interesting to think about voting as an iPhone app. Since the iPhone relates individuals to the rest of society yet is a staple of individuality, it seems like the perfect tool for voting. If voting can occur in the privacy of one's home; the technology of the smartphone/cell phone can help in providing voting abilities to the disables. The phone can read out loud the name of the candidate, provide direct access to his or her opinions, and recognize speech as a source of input. It would be interesting to hear some further ideas about incorporating iPhone technology into accessibility!

Yes it interesting to incorporate voting system in I-phone or smart phone as they are increasingly popular now a days. I really like your idea of voting in the privacy of one's home. I think 'privacy' that's the most important thing when it comes to voting.

design_to_read.description: There are a lot of words associated with elections: names of candidates, instructions for voting, information about candidates, polling places and so on. How can we help people who don't read easily?

comments.text: Great list of aspects to be considered  this will be great for folks to refer to as we move on the upcoming Concepting phase.

comments.text: An op-ed today by Richard Thaler echoes your theme:Making Good Citizenship Funhttp://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/14/opinion/making-good-citizenship-fun.htmlIt has examples of ideas to engage citizens in civic behavior by making it fun. He ends "The moral here is simple. If governments want to encourage good citizenship, they should try making the desired behavior more fun."Richard Thaler is a professor of economics and behavioral science. With Cass Sunstein he wrote Nudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth, and Happiness. Sunstein is now an official in the powerful Office of Management and Budget, Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs
Hello Whitney,Thank you for sharing this link. It is really inspiring. I love the way it emphasizes on fun in areas that always had been so serious!thanbk you

voting_should_be_like_google_translate.description: Google translate provides solutions to its users that would be useful in voting.
voting_should_be_like_google_translate.creator: 59478f587f18664cb34313dfc9c66970

comments.text: Easier ways to translate elections information would be a great basis for a concept. In the US, alternate languages are required when there are enough people in an area who speak them. And many cities provide material in additional languages, even if they are not legally required. The hardest part is probably making sure the translations are accurate and unbiased. A way to let voters quickly and easily switch between languages would be great.
I'm excited by this conversation and how it might spark the beginnings of a concept in our next phase!
Machine translation should be as unbiased as you can get, but the accuracy is still lacking (in some languages more then others of course).

voting_should_be_like_google_translate.title: Voting should be like google translate

make_polls_really_useful.description:
Most polls ask something like "If an election was held today/tomorrow who would you vote for?"
Although this provides some information about elector preferences for candidates and parties it wastes the opportunity gain motivational insight.
make_polls_really_useful.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: I like your idea of more meaningful poling questions. It would indeed be a change to get input on how to change the democratic system in a way that people to feel their vote matters.Besides there is never a party that has a program that represent you and your values for 100% So I think in poling it would be great to see what issues matter to people. Which of the issues/promises makes you choose for the person you would vote for, would be an interesting follow-up question I think.
Thank you Nymphaea - I think your idea for a follow up question is very good.

If I look at the outcome of the elections in Belgium, where voting is compulsory, I think it does effect the outcome but not in a positive way. It seems to me (personally) that people who do not like the parties in Parliament will cast a 'protest' vote. They vote for something different then the current parties in power, but not necessarily because they agree with their political views either.

That is an interesting observation.Here in Australia where voting is compulsory too but where voting is still paper based our usual "protest" vote is an informal vote which favors no candidate at all. It is perfectly legal to cast an informal vote and an important way to allow people to choose not to influence the outcome. That's why I titled one of my inspirations "Compulsory Voting - the Ultimate Freedom of Choice"

make_polls_really_useful.title: Make Polls Really Useful

voting_paradox_a_lesson_for_internet_vot.description: Reducing barriers to voting can in fact lower voter turnout. This seeming paradox applies in the case where a low-cost, private voting option is provided (e.g. mail-in). The reason is that social incentives play a large role in voting behaviour.
voting_paradox_a_lesson_for_internet_vot.creator: 3b4f9efb9c61908827acfe041560ea08

comments.text: I'm very confused about that first paragraph. If the conclusion that no elections have been decided with "just one vote", then why are all other votes needed. Why not just let one person choose, the first votes submitted on election day is enough and is the decider? ;)Misconceptions like that is what makes people not participate.And I can bet that the design of the swiss mailing-experiment was not so great, and probably their process lacked reminders for people at the deadline.Does anyone have pictures or more from that?I browsed one report that Levitt & Dubner based their facts on. And interpreting those statistics like they did is quite wrong, when the average turnout generally in Switzerland and in Europe was dropping in most elections and referendums. Not everything becomes a fact just cause it is written by bestselling authors.

The first paragraph refers to the impact of an extra vote. It just turns out that in few cases will that vote make a difference to the outcome of an election. I agree that it is a bit misleading to focus on the influence of just one extra vote, after the fact. On the actual voting day, voters do not know how many people will be voting and who others will vote for exactly (although results of previous years can provide guidance), so it will be hard to know whether your vote will have a decisive impact. This lack of information is what drives many people to vote, I think. People tend not to vote when they believe there is some certainty in a 'not-close' election. It would be interesting to see how the Swiss mail-in vote was set up. Perhaps there were some flaws that caused a drop in the number of votes. I think that the Freakonomics analysis warns us that we should not place too high expectations on internet/mail-in voting techniques. That said, I also carry away the lesson that if we do want to use internet/mail-in voting techniques, we have to think more seriously about how they are designed. Participartion could be increased through innovative graphic and packaging design and/or through a mutimedia experience that mimics the physical voting process and community feedback.I was not able to find information on the Swiss voting experiment on the Freakonomics website, even though the NYT article said that it was there. I cannot vouch for their research but I know that they rely heavily on statistical techniques, which means that even if voter participation is declining, they might still be able to link it to the mail-in portion.

i found out on wikipedia that the Swiss have carried on mail-votes. And the trend is steady but low generally on both mail-votes and polling-station-rates. I guess the interest in Switzerland politics was higher before they started to experiment with new options. and it generally dropped.

Michael Traugott, a political scientist who studies elections and turnout, pointed out that we also have to consider the political climate as well. In my state, school board and school budget elections are held in April, not part of the general election. Turnout is usually very low. But one year, there was a big controversy about a budget question in our town. Voters rejected the first budget, in an election with relatively high turnout, and a second one had to be prepared. At the election to vote on the revised budget, the turnout was over 95%.
Great! I am also believer of making local politics relevant and connected to peoples everyday life. (and I don't just mean glossy ad campaigns or mud-slinging on tv or internet)

Interesting subject area!The vote paradox is in fact linked by the critique of rational theory. Raymond Boudon, the sociologist who developed it, opposes to the conception of rational choice developed by the economists. In brief in the case of vote is not rational that people participate as soon as one vote doesnt matter, but is rational from their other good reasons (a concept created by Boudon). One of good reasons to participate to vote may be the desire to be part of a public (social) event (like you allready shown). That is important to find out the motivation of going to vote before to propose solutions. You can find more at this link:  http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/rfsoc_0035-2969_1997_num_38_2_4601 unfortunately this text is in French.

Great point and something we should all keep in mind.  No matter how good our intentions, if our efforts have the opposite effect of what we want (greater voter turnout) or no effect at all (but at a higher cost with a new program to implement) we should be ready to refine or abandon them.I like your suggestion that social media could help bridge the gap.  Like clockwork on election day my friends will post that they voted.  If voting were mostly done at home I imagine we'd see more and more people posting on social networking sites in order to mark the occasion in some fashion.
Combine this with compulsory voting and you have potential for very high turnout. Social media could then be used to help each other do our civic duty.

I think social media can help bridge the gap, as an adendum to the voting process, as you suggest. I feel an exclusive mail based/web based election would lose the sense of event and occasion which is vital - reinforced by the spatial aspect of the voting centre, the voting booth, the black box which contains the vote - its almost like a voyage to the holy-of-holies at the heart of the democratic process. The physical presence of the voting centre gives a visual accompaniment to the mailed/web-based vote, without which it becomes simply like hitting "applaud" on openideo (no offence meant!)

If it is "too easy" to vote, then might some people vote differently? The time and effort needed to vote might reduce the amount of "impulse" voting (even now, it would be interesting to know how many people make their decision or change their mind on their way to the voting booth?). It could also weed out those who have not invested the time to think or act politically; forcing such people to vote could have unintended consequences and seems unfair to those who have invested their time and energy. But perhaps this discussion is tangential to the issue of increasing accessibility for those have currently have difficulty voting.

You are right in a sense that the discussion is tangential because a shift from optional to mandatory voting would require both a mind shift and the political will to achieve it - both of which are beyond both the remit and the capability of this forum.As to unintended consequences I think that would be short-lived in the overall process - and in a two horse race changes of mind might well balance on another In the longer term "having to vote" is likely to increase political engagement.

In replying to a comment on another inspiration I have realised that many people may have a misconception about compulsory voting. Mandatory voting does not mean you must choose one or other candidate there is and always should be a choice to vote for no-one. It is the process of voting that is compulsory - not the choice of a candidate.When the process is compulsory then creating the infrastructure to enable everyone to vote is justifiable and cost effective.

Good point. While compulsory voting might create some weird dynamics at first, it should be beneficial in the long term as people take more responsibillity. But we may still want to think about techniques to reduce impulsive voting.I agree that there needs to be a way to put in a 'no-vote' or spoiled vote.

I am such a Freakonomics fan! Thanks for bringing in their insights. And here's a tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link

Nice to meet you, fellow Freakonomics fan! I just finished reading their first book and I might have a look at their latest book soon. Thanks for the tip about linking - I have changed the text to include a hyperlink.

Interesting angle on suggesting use of social media, Michael. We're looking forward to seeing what thoughts this might spark amongst other collaborators here and how this might manifest in the upcoming Concepting phase.

voting_paradox_a_lesson_for_internet_vot.title: Voting Paradox: A Lesson for Internet Voting

mobile_voting_system.description: This is a concept for a mobile voting system, based on a simple user interface to verify identity and a unified, colour coded system of voting.
mobile_voting_system.creator: 8506b0b189d29273029430e3d6414324

comments.text: Szymon, there's a lot going on in this concept and I'm loving it! I really like the mobile aspect of it, and how you've tried to simplify the choices by color-coding options. I'm also excited to think about how these mobile units could be connected to the cloud to upload results securely and remotely. I think my only hesitation is the iris scan - for me personally, it makes me a little nervous and might not be my preferred method for ID. Might there be other ways to verify someone's identity in advance of using one of these mobile units?

I agree, I initially thought of cards, but those can easily be lost or forgotten. Biometric fingerprint scans are problematic due to skin coarseness and moisture. Maybe face recognition, though that's going down a similar route as iris scans. Perhaps this would have to be a card/key after all. Seeing as the mobile units would need to be staffed anyway, the same people could also verify the cardholders identity. I was trying to move away from an ATM style PIN system as memorising yet another set of numbers for use once every couple of years didn't seem like an elegant solution.

mobile_voting_system.title: Mobile Voting System

get_a_reminder_from_mailbox.description: It is not bad to receive a detailed mail about the election from the government.
get_a_reminder_from_mailbox.creator: e5ef6afee0cc6567de8978188492d0bb

comments.text: I think this is a great idea. I missed the inspiration phase of this challenge, but would have shared an experience from living in France: before each phase of the election, every household is mailed a packet with a one-page flyer about each candidate. I found the format of the materials to be very engaging and encouraged me to actually learn about where each candidate stood on a variety of issues, and with very little effort on my part! Even though I couldn't vote, it made me feel more included in the electoral process and motivated to participate. Including a sample ballot seems like a great addition to this type of information.While this form of distribution doesn't address language/illiteracy issues, it can be a good start for accessibility to information for those voters that don't have internet access.

Hey Carolyn, i like the fact that one page flyer was provided. We  have something called my neta ( my leader )  -http://myneta.info/ website for the same However mailing flyer is surely more accessible to people and you are not leaving anything on chance, but such services are possible in smaller countries. In larger democracies we have to use all the possible forms of networks from word of mouth, internet, mobiles etc in order to reach max people.But what i find  interesting is that the flyer acted as a trigger for you to find out more ; )

It might also be good to consider how this would work for students going away to college.  High school students often register to vote using their parents' home address, and then in the following four years are at school for elections and might not receive the mailed package until they return home after the elections.  How might we keep this population in mind?

you are right yoon ji, this is a problem may happen for sure, like students, they move pretty often, and each time they need to call banks or cable...to change address, very inconvenient ! maybe we can develop something like google locator ~~well, let's keep thinking~^^

If they have to go through the hurdles of changing address for banks and administrative things, you could imagine that they will be offered the opportunity to also change their registration address.Moreover, I don't think this concept is necessarily dependent on whether you are registered or not as a voter. As Carolyn mentioned in her comment, she got the voting information in the mail although she was not able to vote.

Interesting thoughts! Given our focus on those who face accessibility challenges  perhaps you'd like to develop your concept further to consider those with language, visibility and comprehension issues? You can update your concept at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right. Looking forward to seeing how your ideas evolve.

Maybe this is something that connects to other users' suggestions of a disability registration process. Potentially offering a pre-registeration based on particular disabilities (as this would not be as much of a confidentiality issue in regards to voting, assistants/family members etc... could help with this process) and appropriate materials could be sent to the database for the issue at hand. Potentially something that comes in the form of an audio disc or translated materials to combat language/visibility/comprehension issues.But I really like your idea of making more digestible, branded materials that are both informative and aesthetically pleasing.

Maybe you can also build off of this idea -- http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/election-web-site-templates-consistent-access-everywhere/ -- to create a template or guide to help election officials present this material in multiple, accessible formats.

And one more thing you might want to check out is our new Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could meet their needs? Because great ideas start with people, right?

Nice start indeed. I like the simplicity of it and the possibility it gives to people of getting the information even if they do not have access to the internet. Daniel's idea of thinking of having templates for this paper form (similar or different from the web template) is a great idea. It will help making the information easier to understand.I can imagine having a braille version. You could also imagine using images or symbols per some of the inspirations: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-election-poster-wall/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/election-symbols-in-india/this might help with literacy issues.

Hi. I really like the start of this concept! You may want to look at some of the voter guides that are produced by election officials (http://www.voterguide.sos.ca.gov) and the sample ballots that are often distributed by mail before an election. Perhaps you can find ways to build off of these initiatives (which varies by state and county) to better meet the needs of people with disabilities.
thank you Daniel, we will keep working on this

get_a_reminder_from_mailbox.title: Get a reminder from mailbox

tablet_toting_door_to_door_voting_volunt.description: Mobile computing allows election administrators to take the voting ballot out of the booth and directly to the voter at home or in the office.  By visiting registered voters door-to-door, the elderly, busy or forgetful voter is reached.
tablet_toting_door_to_door_voting_volunt.creator: 6fb22b95a0a04089111f5d2506690dcf

comments.text: This seems really similar to the census, who hires workers to take geographic information from citizens. They give people short term jobs and allow are very effective in getting the necessary information. I think it would be very effective. Great Idea!

Hi Nathan you have some interesting ideas here.I saw your concept and Andrew Baranak's Ipad Absentee Votinghttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ipad-absentee-voting/ as having similar but also complementary attributesI also can see this idea tying in with the various Voting Van conceptsFinally I built on this concept as one of the inputs for creating tangible ballots.Keep up the good thinking.

Hi Nathan, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

tablet_toting_door_to_door_voting_volunt.title: Tablet Toting, Door-to-Door Voting Volunteers

comfort_waiting.description: Waiting in line for voting is a hassle. Waiting in a long line for voting is even worse. If you could pre-book online, be served while on the line, engaged in an activity while waiting and be rewarded, wouldn't that be great?
comfort_waiting.creator: 97fa522f342b5fface534b5c73e1a544

comments.text: Interesting, guys. Perhaps you'd like to start to tease out more specifics on this  like what kinds of questions would be asked? And any thoughts on how folks are visually challenged will engage with the questions? Looking forward to see where you get to with building this concept over the remaining week of the Concepting phase.

Likewise, I think it'll be nice to see how this concept evolve building upon concepts like the priority line and rethinking election queues (see my previous comment). I personally that you might want to focus on how your concept allows to rethink the queue by either having a priority line, but also by redirecting people or just doing some of the registration / signing up up front (I'm thinking here of the starbuck model where while you are in the line, so will come and take your order). I also like your idea of building upon the idea of pre-booking your election spots. It reminds me of art exhibitions in Paris where you can book a slot from 9 to 10, or 3 to 4. You still have to queue when you arrive but much less than if you haven't booked. Making this visible online and maybe even when you arrive will help people plan when to come and vote. This will be reinforced by the priority line concept...
true, it will shorten the time to queue for people who have booked their time online. Thank you we have added that to the concept.

thank you Meena, that is an interesting point. we have add to the concept "trivia questions from all different kinds of subjects (politics, history, music, academic). A number will be displayed so you can text your answer and like trivia games on airplanes, people standing in line can play against each other and have contests."

This is an interesting concept which I can see as complementary to 2 other concepts that you might want to build upon:the priority line: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/priority-queue/and also on the rethinking-election-queues: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/rethinking-election-queues/I like the idea of providing people with pre-booking or at least information on how crowded is the poll station.I also think that having someone who can do the signing while you are in line could help. It reminds of Starbuck. I can also see how you could think of having kiosks similar to the check-in booths in airports.
Hi again,I was thinking that this concept was complementary to your idea of online booking: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/find-out-book-your-time-slot-/

I agree AL and am building on it (and the appointment concept) as complementary to my concept on mapping what polling stations offer for accessibility and to smooth voter traffic ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mapping-accessability-rating-and-traffic-reports./ )
Paul, I've tried to go and check your concept but can't get redirected to it when I click on the link. Maybe you haven't published it yet? Please let me know. thanks.

Sorry AL and thanks for your patience.It is republished now I hope.I have reported problems with publishing and updating that are related mainly, I think, to my 45.2 kbps dial-up connection.Sometimes when I update it republishes and sometimes not.Occasionally when I navigate away from one of my concepts I get a message that I have "unpublished" the concept again.I am pretty patient about this but now realise that it can affect my interaction with others on the site too.
No worries Paul. Technology has glitches. I'll go and check your concept again. thanks!

Some great ideas here.I have been thinking a bit about the analogy of banking queues. One bank I visit runs Mr Bean videos for people in the queue - I guess it can be a turn off for some whereas I and no doubt others are sometimes sad to have to move to the teller.In Australia where I gather queues are generally shorter and elections are always held on a Saturday schools are very popular to set up polling places. Since it is a Saturday the school can be dedicated to the purpose - car parking is generally adequate and often such activities as car washes, cake stalls and sausage sizzles take place. When families vote together common culture dictates that only one person need stand in-line if the queue is long.I am particularly interested in your general online booking system which as AL says complements Mamta Gautam's idea of voter appointments ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/find-out-book-your-time-slot-/ ). I shall build on your system in my (complementary) concept to smooth voter traffic ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mapping-accessability-rating-and-traffic-reports./ ) which at present is only geared to knowing how many are already there, how quickly people are voting and therefore approximately how long the wait is.Another thought has just struck me too - you could choose to get an SMS/email/online alert (as a paid service) if too many people make a general booking 'after' you - say if, when you book only 10 people are in the online bookings but you n eed to know if the bookings grow to more than 50 people. (I shall add this in my concept too and refer to it in Mamta's.

comfort_waiting.title: Comfort Waiting

audio_announcement_2212_the_sound_of_vot.description:
Bell towers are calling on the hours or announce a marriage, minarets telling it’s time to pray and sirens telling you that the airplanes carrying bombs are moving in. 
All Iconic features in our society relying on the wide reach of sound message.
audio_announcement_2212_the_sound_of_vot.creator: 04e53dae2f54dc421469f3b54994d2d1

comments.text: Great analogous thinking, Jakob!

Very nice indeed. It reminded me of the warning sirens ringing (around noon I think) on the first Wednesday of each month when I was a kid in Paris. It's a test siren, a memory of the WW2, to inform people of a danger. I kept this sound in my memory. It frightened me as a kid. It shows how powerful sound can be and how you could create some audio memory structures...

I agree! Very nice take! Here in Oporto where I live there is a famous and gorgeous old church tower called "Clrigos" - a delight for tourists. Everyday by 6pm, when many people are about to leave work, the bells in the tower play Beethoven's "Ode to Joy" from the 9th symphony. Could you imagine a better music to announce the end of your working day?

audio_announcement_2212_the_sound_of_vot.title: Audio announcement − The sound of voting

empirical_voting.description: Designing empirical voting system to overcome the obstacles
empirical_voting.creator: 80c975a728662e96e907ced80c543914

comments.text: Thank you Paul for the link on Australian voting. I am really amazed by it's efficiency and how much it relies on the effort of every individual. Clearly it has evolved over the years but unlike other evolving things, it didn't loose its "human touch"Thank you Alessia, you used excellent examples and words, by far better than what I was thinking of. You're perfectly right, the main issue is hysical vs virtual. I hope that more people will write about ideas involving physical objects and more interaction between people.

Great suggestion Kam and excellent comments from Alessia and Trevor.There seems to be an increasing tendency to incorporate new technology even where existing technology (eg, paper and pencil) are generally working well. Braille technology has been around for a long time and works well in many circumstances to assist the blind with interpreting text material. At other times audio is more suitable but clearly of no use to the deaf.Having a range of simple solutions to these handicaps is probably a strength and the point about making people feel their contribution is worthwhile is very well made.With regard to transparency, trust and the possibility of interference the more people are used to do things in the process the better. You might like to look at Greg Baker's excellent summary of how the voting process is conducted in Australia - simple, based on paper cardboard and people power. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-we-ve-learned-from-a-century-of-better-than-99-turnout-in-australia/

I agree but sometimes I wonder "Am I too old style"?Thanks to this challenge I'm getting more and more conscious about the difficulties  for many people in accessing the vote process but, from an ethical point of view, my issue is: should the voting process be the same of sending a text or an e-mail? Or shall we keep a kind of boundary between processes/actions with a deeper democratic value?I think that the choice to move somewhere, to "bring your consent" has a different meaningcould you imagine a demonstration without people or more, have you ever experienced the energy of the people gathered together in a crowded stadium to listen to the same music? I hope so! Of course you can play an mp3 with a dolby surround equipment in your living room but it has nothing to do with the powerful experience of being at a concert! They are two different things.That's why I personally think "yes, we should improve a system which the main point is to let people feel they're part of something, no matter what"!All these thoughts made me remind to one of the most powerful images of the recent history about the power of one:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9-nXT8lSnPQI'd like to hear more from others about this issue physical/virtual...

"It shouldn't be changed, it should be improved by designing it to overcome its handicaps."A very good point. We have to improve upon what is currently in place. Otherwise voters may reject a change that is too drastic.

empirical_voting.title: Empirical voting

the_quiz_system_2014_issues_based_voting.description: The Quiz System attempt to rethink fundamentally shift how work and in the process create a flexible system that scales gracefully, is adaptable to multiple formats, and sidesteps many accessibility issues.

the_quiz_system_2014_issues_based_voting.title: The Quiz System — Issues Based Voting

stop_voter_suppression_in_florida.creator: 6d149f8b3f7f858c5f5d83e110d8c844

appealing_to_identity_increases_particip.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Good contribution for participatory democracy.
Fascinating finding.

I think this connects to Timothy Wilson's work (see his book Redirect, and a lecture on YouTube; www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tk4bdpA6oz4)"Presenting the very latest research, he shows that the key to transforming our lives lies simply in learning to redirect the stories we tell ourselves."
