politician_tells_her_opion_in_sign_langu.description:
Danish politician Linda Kristiansen tells about why we should vote for her at the Danish election 2011 and gets translated into sign language. 
She also translated her written material into Braille.
politician_tells_her_opion_in_sign_langu.creator: fabeacc75ec9dce98ddda9c56ca6043c

comments.text: Interesting inspiration bringing together the importance of involving all populations, by facilitating the voting but also providing access to information (central when it comes to voting) to all.
Yes - exactly. I love the way she manages to get her political message our by herself doing what she wants the society to do as well. Too many politicians have dobbelt standards.

politician_tells_her_opion_in_sign_langu.title: Politician tells her opion in sign language

diy_absentee_ballots.description: Instead of trying to produce one ballot per voter, what if we put ballots everywhere and allowed voters to cast their ballot wherever they could verify their identify?
diy_absentee_ballots.creator: 60232536b14c394d61d0df747dbf4241

comments.text: RachelLove the freedom this gives to the voter and how complementary it is to Whitney's Mark Anywhere.It also fits with so many of the mobile and kiosk type concepts too.Your suggestion for verification of online ballots is excellent and overcomes much of the security issues surrounding online casting.I think there is a similar way to approach posted ballots too - just can't bring it properly to mind.I should like to give a plug here for Whitney's suggestion that any printed version of a completed ballot (or one stored on an SD card or the like) would only require the voters actual choices (not all the people or issues they didn't vote for). This would allow for a much smaller ballot to be posted or cast in person. (Hence my bus ticket size ballot concept). Such a printout could be easily made machine readable for easy casting and counting.

I love the idea of making it easy to get your ballot, and separating marking and casting.At the ITIF Accessible Election Design Workshop, one of the teams also explored the idea of being able to vote and register simultaneously."This concept reverses the usual process of first registering and then voting. In this concept, a person can take a step toward voting when they are motivated by the issues, gets the appropriate ballot, and then register when they decide to actually vote. For example, they might send in their marked ballot and their voter registration form at the same time, like Election Day registration."http://elections.itif.org/projects/design-workshops/concept-personal-voting-guidance-system/

Great creative thinking Rachel!I love the innovative way you used a special verification code to separate the act of voting (so it can be done anywhere), from vote validation/identity verification!Thanks for building on my concept as well. Am now adding a link to your great concept in my online/mobile voting concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all

diy_absentee_ballots.title: DIY Absentee Ballots

create_a_support_community_of_poll_stati.description: A crowdsourcing service providing tips, advice, best practice, tools & knowledge from other poll stations around the country & potentially globally to provide support for poll workers to deliver best in class universal design experience for everyone.
create_a_support_community_of_poll_stati.creator: 88042d0941bd6e65ac8b383c2fbc2f10

comments.text: Really nice mockups Lucy! I also like your thinking about dividing the site into Issues, Solutions and Discussions.

If I were to setup a poll station I would be interested in the best practices that would benefit all (or as many target groups as possible). I could be helpful when each solution is tagged with which types of disabilities benefit from it.This platform could also include a description of the barriers a person with a spesific disability face in the elction process. That would help the poll workers to understand why a solution works.
Thanks I've been really inspired by your comments and tried to build in some of the feedback.

Supporting poll workers is a great idea -- they are at the front line, and just as in a retail setting, the voters' experience with them colors their whole experience. A Wiki is a good option, as would be an iPad app for accessing information about how to serve different voters' needs. iPads are expensive though, so we should also consider going old-school, with telephone hotlines for poll workers who need assistance. In the US during Thanksgiving, turkey supplier Butterball has a toll-free number for cooks with questions about everything from how long to cook a 14-pound turkey to how to quickly defrost a bird. Why not a similar toll-free number for poll workers, who could access pre-recorded messages for different situations or be connected to a switchboard of polling center experts, some of which could be based out of poll stations themselves?
great points Charlene, I'll try and incorporate that into my next iteration. I've made a few changes already so any further thoughts you have are most appreciated.

Lucy, I like the idea of improving the voter's experience through improving the poll worker's experience. It reminded me of your other concept ("Train the Poll Workers with Empathy Tools"). It seems harder to provide every election office with the same amount of knowledge, but it seems easier to provide every election office with the same set of empathy tools. Maybe there is some way of combining these 2 concepts to make the sharing of poll worker's experience more convenient?
Thanks I've been really inspired by your comments and tried to build in some of the feedback. There's some more I'd like to add though, so any feedback you have is great.

One thing we've seen is that there are a lot of great ideas and resources around the country (and world), but it seems to be hard to build on them so that every election office has access to all of the best practices. Supporting collaboration and sharing materials is a great idea.

Agreed Whitney - there is half an attempt on the EAC site where membership of a network is available to election officials.There are so many great similar concepts around the idea of sharing information we need a way to amalgamate them and then refine them collaboratively.

Yes. I'd suggest that it would be great to have input not only from election officials and poll workers. But also from voters. Create a stronger feedback loop and a way to capture the small practices that can evolve into more formal programs.
Thanks I've been really inspired by your comments and tried to build in some of the feedback.

Hey Lucy ,have a look at my concept .http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/national-database-for-rating-voting-system/.I was looking to develop a database that incorporates feedback and view points from electoral officials , poll workers and voters -for different county's to decide which is the best practice under what constraint. The support community would help in maintaining and updating the database form a poll-workers point of view. may be the poll workers can directly add to my database concept ... just a thought ! cheers .
Thanks I've been really inspired by your concept and tried to build in some of the elements - i think there could be an even greater combination of the two concepts though!

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Lucy! We really liked that your idea taps into poll workers, a crucial community to consider in any of our concepts.During this Refinement phase, let's think about what this crowdsourced platform might actually look like, whether through sketches or even basic mockups. You might also check out Daniel's related concept for more inspiration: http://bit.ly/xXnRq6. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
I've been thinking of an idea like this as well.  Have you thought of specific mechanisms to accomplish this?  I was thinking of a Wiki and/or a chatroom.
Hi Darren, I think a wiki could do it, but maybe a sort of mash up of yahoo answers, OpenIDEO and a wiki?
Feel free to build on this with your own version of it if you have specific ideas!

Can see this fits with my comments on the vote.gov project and Daniel's broad best practice crowd sourcing. It also fits to some extent with my latest concept for mapping polling booths and supplying information to help voters decide where and when to vote.

create_a_support_community_of_poll_stati.title: Create a support community of Poll Stations & Workers (Updated)

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

harness_grassroots_organizers_to_be_acce.creator: 570843c74a1c88405f529349168abc0c

comments.text: People generally hope for improvement in all their actions. However i salute the US for its democratic processes. Lets hope that more improvements would be incorporated into U S election practices for a better world.

Melanie - really interesting. You touch on a couple of things that are starting to resonate with me in this phase:1) The solution is likely to be complex and as such we need to consider combing many interventions in an overall 'system' to get real impact2) You picked up on the training element; in many change programmes I have been involved in this has often been overlooked (usually due to more focus being applied to system design) and as such is something we should keep top of mind as we start to concept.
Great thoughts drawing upon your experiences Melanie. Looking forward to hearing more in the upcoming Concepting phase in developing this idea further.

harness_grassroots_organizers_to_be_acce.title: Harness Grassroots Organizers to be Accessibility Advocates

can_we_re_design_the_language_of_electio.description: Terms such as "accessibility"  are increasing dropped in favour of  "inclusive" and "universal", with a corresponding effect on how we view the ethos of "accessibility".  What effect can this have on the experience of elections and politics?
can_we_re_design_the_language_of_electio.creator: 03de4375881b84c0d6e8fa374e6c66f7

comments.text: Interesting ideas Eoghan.Will be interested to discuss any concepts built upon this.
Wonderful insights Eoghan. Looking forward to your involvement throughout our challenge!

comments.text: Hi Ashutosh - it already exists - check out this submission. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/

comments.text: Efforts put in here are commendable. Your findings are also true and I as well appreciate your statement that people turn when they see ques.Like I mentioned before in another build up manual systems have a place in life. They can never disappear. Their life span is as long as man's existence.

Hi Greg. The system is quite similar to Spain's, at least regarding to the 'paper-technology'. But I'm amazed by all the options that you have if you are not able to be at the voting station on the election day. This is quite complicated in Spain. You have to request the right of postal voting until ten days before of the election (and to do so, you  have to go to the post office in person, and they will send you a documentation that you have to receive also in person, documentation that you will need to send from the postal office as well). So, if you are abroad or have a trip, at the end it's most likely that you don't vote.

This inspiration has little relevance to the United States. As the author noted, "You enter the polling site and your name is marked off one of a half a dozen or so paper rolls by one election official. This paper roll gets sent to the electoral commission after the election and electronically scanned to make sure nobody voted twice. (And also to make sure that everyone did vote because it's compulsory.)"Compulsory elections certainly would entice a large majority of citizens to vote. However, that is never going to be the case in the US.The logistics of distributing ballots to 22M Australian citizens is far less substantial than that of distributing ballots to 315M United States citizens.Unless I'm incorrect, though Australia has voting guides in multiple languages (http://www.waec.wa.gov.au/voting/making_voting_convenient/), there is no law stating that ballots must be prepared in any language other than English.

"The logistics of distributing ballots to 22M Australian citizens is far less substantial than that of distributing ballots to 315M United States citizens."-- Yes, a US election would require 15 times as many printed ballot papers, and 15 times as many election officials and therefore cost 15 times as much.The 2007 federal election cost around $150,000,000 to run, but that includes party advertising costs. The electoral office has a large pool of money which it distributes to each registered political party based on their proportion of the primary vote in the previous election for the party to use in advertising and communication. In this way, even a small minority party which doesn't win a seat will at least get a chance to have their voice heard.The actual logistic cost of distributing votes and running the vote count is much cheaper than this. But even so, I don't think a USA election costs less than $2,250,000,000 to run anyway. Anyone got any numbers on this?

Just thought I'd weigh in with a quick point about Kai's comment: although we are eager to explore US-based stories and inspirations, we do want to learn from examples around the world  not only does it broaden our view of the challenge topic but it helps us think creatively about our potential solutions during Concepting. If you have more questions, be sure to check out our Guiding Principles http://bit.ly/AiJnLW  looking forward to seeing more of both of you in this challenge!

Kai I can agree with you that is unlikely compulsory voting would be introduced throughout US, it would take a huge mind shift.As far as logistics goes I can't agree though. Im sure the US already has more than 15 times the printing capacity and economies of scale would be in US favor. Employing more people, maybe even 15 times as many for even a short time would be a productive boost to the economy. I think you would actually find many benefits - but as we agree it is unlikely to happen.

Great summary that covers most of my inspirations and morehttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/build-trust-in-the-system-and-achieve-confidence-in-the-outcome/ http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/compulsory-voting-the-ultimate-freedom-of-choice/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/flat-pack-polling-booths/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/employ-people-to-overcome-the-obstacles/In particular I am glad to see you include a picture of a typical polling place.My experience is not as extensive as yours but essentially similar.One of the things that makes Australian elections cost effective is their compulsory nature.and the corresponding capability to match infrastructure and resources to demographic distribution.Still even in the US it should be possible to mount cost effective polls using a sufficient margin of error in expected turnout.In the light of Australian experience I shall be very interested to see the final outcome of this challenge.I shall be very surprised if a people centred option is selected over a technological one, but we shall see.
Very interesting voting system. I honestly hope that the results would surprise you Paul. I really hope that a people centered option would be selected:)

comments.text: That's a great insight Christian!  It turns out that's how much of voting originally started. As Doug Jones explains on his website on the history of voting: "The word ballot has been described as being derived from the diminuitive form of the word ball in Italian, ballota, and in fact, many early ballots were small balls. In classical Greek, however, the root is the verb for casting or throwing; indeed, we cast ballots, but the Greeks did not read this word as requiring that they be round balls. In ancient Athens, votes were taken by issuing clay or metal tokens to each voter, and the voter would vote by depositing the appropriate token in the appropriate ballot box, or perhaps in a clay pot that served as a ballot box."Source: http://www.divms.uiowa.edu/~jones/voting/pictures/

Thanks, Daniel. That's interesting, and now that you point it out it seems so obvious that"cast a ballot" is related to throwing a ball. At least it shows I'm not totally off. (But I guess I should have lived 2500 years ago, give or take a few centuries, when my ideas were still fresh :-) )
Interesting idea! I'm trying to envisage using tokens for preferential voting. Would you see voters given multiple tokens or using the same token multiple times?

Immediately, I think I'd prefer multiple tokens (arranged in order), since I think the design of the token should represent the choice being made. But I really don't yet know enough about the rest of the system to be sure. If the choice is binary, yes or no, then it's easy. But with dozens, or even hundreds of options, it might be impractical.
Great inspiration. Thanks Daniel for the historical perspective. Very useful. As for the physical nature of the tokens, indeed you can play with colors, but also shapes and even adding braille.
Great discussion, guys! Looking forward to what this might inspire n the upcoming Concepting phase.

brilliant thought Christian! Here in London, the supermarket chain Waitrose is using the chips system for customers vote what local/community projects they want to be supported. Not only it is effective in showing preferences, but I saw how much it encourages others to vote too... Love the simplicity!

what_s_in_a_ballot.title: What's in a ballot?

award_a_vote.description: In the 'Voting using Marbles' scenario, voters 'put something in' and count up the votes. What if we 'take something out' and count down the votes?
award_a_vote.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: The 'take something out' vs 'put something in' is a brilliant idea.Marbles may not be the most cost-efficient solution but as a concept it is plain genius.From how easy it would be to count (or weigh) the results afterwards, to how easy it really is to avoid what happened earlier this week in Russia.This may not be a winning concept on itself, but I am sure it could be used in following phases of the challenge to perfect the final candidates.

I like this. I wonder about other ways that marbles might be introduced to the election process--could attendees or viewers of public debates also let them roll when they hear an idea they particularly like? The visual and auditory components of inserting something solid seems like an interesting way to have voters not just sit on the sidelines until the day they cast ballots.

Hi Cansu, I love the originality of this idea. Have you thought about how this process might work while still ensuring voter privacy (i.e. protecting the anonymous vote)?You may also want to think about how this will work for people with disabilities, such as people who have mobility and dexterity impairments and might not be able to easily handle an object.
Hi Cansu, This is a great idea, it would definitely motivate people to go to the poles, finding the winner would me much easier if he/she had less objects remaining.

the_voice_of_decomcray_if_you_can_use_a_.creator: 344fad0c08b631fdfb8b196e23deafea

comments.text: Thanks for this inspiration Tim.It is substantially the basis of a concept I am developing and incorporates all of the components that I have developed (and more), although the language and context are rather more formal than I have used.Also being an Australian I have been trying to get my head around the USA registration process, which seems to be more haphazard than the simple and straight-forward process we enjoy.For Australian use IDs of 6, 7 or 8 digits would provide a little fewer than 100 million unique numbers. This would potentially be insufficient for the USA, especially if it was offered as a general voting option.The other hurdle in the US seems to be, for some, a lack of trust in the juxtaposition of the User ID (potentially user identifiable data) and the 'marking' of the ballot using telephone keystrokes.On the plus side the non-preferential nature of some US ballots should make the actual process of voting easier.

Hi Paul - thanks for your comments - great that there are others interested in this viable approach.  My understanding is that in the US the elections are conducted on a state but state basis, which would somewhat mitigate the number of uniquite voter IDs that would need to be generated, as well as the numbers would likely be reduced on eligibility criteria.  Also telephone voting could be restricted to polling centres such as was done in Victoria in 2010 or from the location of the voter's choice as was done in NSW.Australia does have a complex preferential voting system with relatively large numbers of candidates and this standard is designed to accomodate that complexity if required, however as you point out the implementation and usage would be more straight forward with non-preferential voting.Just saw your fleshed out concept and you seem to have a good appreciation of key factors involved. Thanks for the commentsTim

It is really interesting to see a system which I would call tele-voting is being used in Australia. A similar model with really help the people in developed as well as developing countries. In future this system can be upgraded to take the entire voting process on the web. However the tele-voting as described above is more secure than the web but a new advanced encryption can be developed to make web voting available.

This telephone approach was used in conjunction with a internet voting channel to allow voters to work in the modality that suited them or their technical capabilites best.  To register the user had the choice of calling a Call Centre and for assistance with their registration or they could use a secure and accessible web form.  And thanks for your comments  :)

go_to_them...just_like_in_church.description: When someone disabled wants to take communion, the priest comes to them.  In church, the priest will actually come down into the congregation.  Couldn't election officials bring ballots to the homes and hospitals of our most critically disabled?

comments.text: Jim - maybe you could team with Matt Callahan http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/ease-of-election-experiences-fostered-by-activism-on-campus/ and come up with a concept to mobilize students to deliver voting capacity to those home or institution bound.Here in Australia when candidates are canvassing and door knocking they often leave material that not only summarizes there own or party points of view but offer to arrange transport or other support for voting to the elderly or house bound.From what Matt says perhaps students could deliver material on a bipartisan basis and determine in advance those households where people may have difficulty attending polling places.

This is not only a good solution for single voters who can't go to vote but also for homes for elderly people. Voluteers could additionally put up a ballot box in a common room in the home for those who don't need assistance for voting. I'm wondering in general: How do people vote who live in homes? Do people vote who live in mental homes?

In Australia the answer to the second question is usually 'yes'  although there must be circumstances where people are incapable of taking a decision, even with assistance. For those living in nursing homes and similar institutions or who are in hospital they voting process does indeed come to them. This also applies to remote communities, although I don't know what criteria are used to decide on this.The cost to do this can be considerable but it is paid for through general taxes. The fact that voting is compulsory in Australia is one reason that the cost is both justified and accepted by the whole community as a shared burden.

It's happend in Italy. When disabled wants to vote 1. they can go with "familiar assitant" that she/he should be register to the township before2. If they can't move the township have to organize a personal visit with a ballot box in hospital, home.
Great analogy Jim!

It's a great point. A few other people have posted inspirations about the program in Oregon in which election officials go to the homes of people who can't use the mail-in ballot or go to a polling center. I wonder how many other place we could use for polling places that would be easier for people to reach and make participating more convenient?

Great analogous inspiration, Jim! We're big fans: http://bit.ly/oi_analogous This might lead to a number of potential solutions in the upcoming Concepting phase  in combination with discussion going on about security elsewhere across this challenge.

accessitiblity_through_community_story_s.description: "Community engagement can be a huge challenge for any project. But for four years now, the Mobile Voices project in Los Angeles has helped immigrant and low-wage workers create stories about their lives and communities—thus empowering themselves."

blind_person_excused_form_poll_worker_du.description: In Belgium it obligatory to vote. And poll workers are called upon, like you would be called upon for jury duty in the USA. My blind collegue was also selected to be a poll worker at the last elections. He resigned because of his disability.
blind_person_excused_form_poll_worker_du.creator: 5449d3181ab4b4428c022493cba0171d

comments.text: Great story Nymphaea - and interesting to hear that working as a poll worker is civic duty.How easy is it for the blind to vote in Belgium? Do they have to attend polling places or does the process come to them?Would there be a role for your colleague in helping other blind voters - especially those voting for the first time, or voting in an un familiar environment?

I spoke to a blind girl friend about it. When she goes voting she goes with her parents and let them fill out the ballot. This is easy for her, and as long as she trust her parents to vote for the candidate of her choice she does not see the need to go to an other voting location where they have an accessible booth set up.

Yes - here it is accepted that blind voters can choose a trusted friend or relative to cast a vote in the normal way without assistive technology. The same applies to illiterate voters. Officials are trained to deal with these situations.I have seen officials also delicately deal with the opposite - where a husband (usually elderly) insists on helping his wife "make the right choice" the two have been delicately separated to allow the wife freedom to make her own choice.

I like the way you are thinking about what we could change about the procedures to let everyone participate. We created the system, so it should be possible to change it so that it doesn't create disability.What other process or technology decisions can we make differently to be more inclusive?

blind_person_excused_form_poll_worker_du.title: Blind person excused form poll worker duty, Belgium.

blind_leading_the_blind.description: Blindekuh Restaurant in Zurich allows sighted people to experience dining in complete darkness.
blind_leading_the_blind.creator: d2cd3db5ea4b789b678422e8499a9267

comments.text: hey mike , i haev heard about this restaurant through a friend.I found it very very fascinating , a different experience and yet complete in itself. Are there any visual ref of the same available........ just  curious to know all the details possible ; )
Nice, taking blindfolded trust walks to a new level =)

blind_leading_the_blind.title: Blind Leading the Blind

crowdsourcing_the_election_experience.description: Ushahidi's tools such as Crowdmap have been used to monitor elections and empower citizen participation.
crowdsourcing_the_election_experience.creator: 6cd7038cd88581c062b9e71d5e195a0d

comments.text: Ushahidi is such a great example for many challenges and all the more appropriate when we talk about elections. Well done, Nat!

Hadn't heard of Ushahidi before, Nat (which, having checked it out a bit more, might sound a bit crazy, and is to my eternal shame!). Thanks for posting this. It could be a great tool for seeing how different places and districts feel toward specific policies, and become a sort of map of "ideas".

voting_challenges_for_a_military_family_.description: As I was thinking about voting accessibility, I wondered what challenges a military family would face with voting especially with relocation and deployment.
voting_challenges_for_a_military_family_.creator: 804befd1eeda87662269044045aa3f56

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Wow, thank you for this honor. This is a wonderful challenge and I am very excited to see what we all learn from these inspirations.
Great research Audrey!
Thank you for checking out my inspiration Keme!
Welcome to OpenIDEO Audrey, and thanks for sharing these interesting and thoughtful insights with us.
Thank you! This has been a really great learning experience.

Hi Audrey,Thanks for your post. I come from a military background, and ironically never could vote. I have shared my story here- http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/increasing-efficiency-of-proxy-votes/I absolutely agree that we need to look into this largely absent society, to make voting more accesible.
Thank you for linking your inspiration and contributing to mine.

mobile_town_halls_campaigning_on_the_sub.description: Take all the elements of a pre-election town hall--candidates, citizens, campaign literature, debates, voter registration--and put them in a subway car!
mobile_town_halls_campaigning_on_the_sub.creator: 68039f05f89fe63864c50905295b54e3

comments.text: Fab idea Sam! Be sure to hold on to this and repost it during our Concepting phase. In the meantime, let's see what other examples we can find where mixing people, transportation and conversation leads to new connections and community building. What other examples might we learn from to inspire our thinking?

mobile_town_halls_campaigning_on_the_sub.title: Mobile Town Halls: Campaigning on the Subway

ballot_cards.description: There are many variants, versions, types of votes/ballot cards/ballot boxes. I find some are confusing, big risks that some voters mark their vote incorrectly just out of confusion. See Florida recount incident 2000.
ballot_cards.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: I'm very interesting in the way each level of government has its own voting card and color. This sounds like it would really help sort out the different offices. US elections are very complicated, partly because we are not a parliamentary system and vote for so many different offices, from national president to local school board.... all on the same ballot.

Hi, I just added an instructional video. If you could take a closer look on the voting ballot papers you could also see on the edges one or two or three or none black lines. They are as signal, and are along with the colour of the paper visible from exterior, through the punched out gap in the edge of the envelope, so officials will be able to see for what election each envelope is voting for, from outside, to make counting process simpler.Of course all envelopes will later become opened and counted anyway, but it might help with sorting and maintaining the secrecy/integrity/privacy of the vote.
Please note that I say this scandinavian system is not really perfect. I just describe it to give you inspiration to improve it, to make you think "outside the box" :) :D haha

Hello Johan, as many have said before, we in India have visual reference or Logo for each party. For people who can not read/write, it is much easier for them to vote. This could be included in all the above for making it more user friendly. :)

Sure!In sweden the major political parties have an official abbreviation of their official name, and also a wellknown flower to make distinctions clear from other parties.So if I wanted to vote for Social-democratic party, i could look at the ballot-sheets for the big S, or the red rose, that is their logo/symbol.With computerized systems, there are Icons possible, to make clear distinctions between thousands of different softwares, so why not also do official computerized Icons for political parties?More ideas along this thread for the concepts???

Hi, Johan.As a Norwegian, I'm used to a similar system, but with enough differences to make your description quite educational. It was interesting to see the photos you put up, and how many paragraphs you needed to explain the system's simplicity. ;-) Not perfect, indeed.I think it shows how confusing we've managed to make something basically simple. I think it would be easy if it were just about putting a slip of paper in an envelope, but we added so much information and options most people never use: Forms that don't need to be filled out, choices that don't need to be made, a wide array of different ballots for the same party, but different purposes; several different elections (local, regional, church) run in parallell, with unclear boundaries It reminds me of certain software I don't use. I think it raises the question of what we are actuallyexpecting the voters to take a stand on, and how much that varies from country to country and election to election. And also: To what degree does the system for voting decide what we can ask?Thank you for sharing. The similarities to, and differenences from, what I'm used to really made me look at some of my assumptions in a new light. :-)

Mange Takk. Very Good points.One valuable thing from your text is about software, that we have installed on our computers only we imagine it might be useful some day. Perhaps you can evolve some of that analogy towards better election process. Write it as an inspiration if you think you got some more stuff behind that.And I promise that I will try to work on shorter and fewer paragraphs :D haha

Oh, by the way, swedish state is completely separated from church now. So the election for local church authority is now separate from general elections. in fact they are moved to alternating years, so as not several elections/referendums can come at same season and confuse things.

ballot_cards.title: Ballot cards (Scandinavian system explained)

surprise_medical_issues_.description: What happens if you get sick on election day? Or get a migrane? Any number of chronic or random conditions can put you out of commission for that one, vital, day.
surprise_medical_issues_.creator: b2dd08a69dcdac5a20a7b90b5c4b759f

comments.text: Drew, I am glad you highlighted this important point. Many of the accommodations made for voters assume that the voter knows that they will be unable to go to the polls on election day. However, as you point out, there are many cases where there is an unexpected event. You may want to take a look at some of the different absentee voting requirements of various states to see if there are existing practices that we might be able to build on to better accommodate these voters. Are there changes that election officials can make in the short term to better address this need?

This is indeed a very good point Drew.I think, but don't know specifically, what happens here in Australia is that there is a range of acceptable contingencies for failing to vote (since it is compulsory here) but little can be done to afford people the opportunity to vote if they are unexpectedly unable to participate on the day. This is a further argument for making available alternative ways of voting and/or possibly extending the time for voting beyond a single day. However extending voting times means that human nature (some people have a propensity to leave things to the last minute) will ensure that a small percentage will still be unable to cast a vote because of such emergencies.One possible solution might be to provide those who are in a position to notify election authorities of their circumstances to apply for a late absentee ballot with a grace period for lodgemnt - perhaps this already exists in some jurisdictions - but even this would probably not cover all cases.

Daniel, great point. A little light research into absentee laws in the US shows that (at least at first glance) such last-day absentee ballots are not possible.  http://www.longdistancevoter.org/absentee_voting_rules#.T00CovEgfw2There are, however, such things as emergency absentee ballots which can be picked up in person right up until (and including) election day. http://www.longdistancevoter.org/california#.T001WPEgfw0These might not help someone who cannot leave the house, but may be a good system to piggyback a solution onto. I'll try and work on turning this into a concept for the next phase. Do  you have ideas on how such a solution might look?

True , there could such unknown factor as hindrances. The same could be facilitated by allowing such people to vote later on providing genuine reason proof (that wud be difficult ). May be one could call a help line and tell them the problem and see how to take it from there .! interesting point .cheers

Excellent point. It's possible that the "proof" could simply be that the person signals their desire/intention to vote (e.g. by calling a hotline or going to a website) on the day of the election. Though in certain types of emergencies, even taking this small step may be impossible.

surprise_medical_issues_.title: Surprise medical issues

translation_options_for_naturalized_citi.description: Audio/Visual Translation - A possible solution for people who speak english as a second language.
translation_options_for_naturalized_citi.creator: 804befd1eeda87662269044045aa3f56

comments.text: I was reading through some of the other comments, which mentioned visual representations of candidates and policies on ballots. I think this is a great idea for those who do not speak the native language. My mother is an American citizen who does not vote, becuase it is too difficult to comprehend policies and candidates. Visual and audio translations would help solve this, but:1) An instant translation technology with a user interface should be used, since it can instantly translate a variety of languages and not limit the languages used (that paper translations would). Having limited language choices could be leaving out certain markets.2) Any audio and video translations should be implemented into the advertising campaigns/informationals, as well, in order to convey the proper message ahead of time. Those with language barriers are generally slower to comprehend the translated messages on the spot and would need the advance information to digest to ensure proper voting.

translation_options_for_naturalized_citi.title: Translation Options for Naturalized Citizens

i_voting._learning_from_estonia.description:
Internet voting, or 'i-voting', is a system that allows voters to cast their ballots from any internet-connected computer or mobile anywhere in the world. 

With a national ID card and incorporate with mobile ID, the voters can cast secured votes.
i_voting._learning_from_estonia.creator: fe0b1647a27d122cab05d18627477f55

comments.text: Great local insights Cathy! I'm particularly intrigued by the idea that you can vote as many times as you want, with each vote canceling out the last!

I agree! I think the idea of changing your vote is very neat. I also like the fact that it's very green and convenient! One potential concern might be internet security because I know for one that's why many countries are reluctant to use i-voting.

When it comes to e-gov related topics, people are usually quite skeptical on the security issue. The e-gov system implemented in Estonia handles this problem with a common ground called "x-road". It means that data is not actually transmitted directly from ministry to ministry (or in some cases, private clients). The processing of the data, or the so-called application layer, all happens in the x-road. Ministries have their own proxies to connect to x-road, and have full control/monitoring of data transactions.

i_voting._learning_from_estonia.title: i-Voting. Learning from Estonia

helping_people_to_chose_who_to_vote_for_.description: Whenever there are elections coming up in the Netherlands you can go online and use Stemwijzer.nl to find out which of the parties are closest to your own values by simply responding to a set of statements. You don't have to read all their programs.
helping_people_to_chose_who_to_vote_for_.creator: 5449d3181ab4b4428c022493cba0171d

comments.text: Interesting observations Nymphaea.A similar system was described in another inspiration (I think from Canada).If I can find it again I will post the link here.You might like to compare notes.
Thanks that would be interesting.

helping_people_to_chose_who_to_vote_for_.title: Helping people to chose who to vote for; Stemwijzer (The Netherlands)

ai_votar.description: As I finish answering the questionnaire, my artificial intelligence App, tells which candidate to vote for. Of course I have the final say, but I love it that itconsiders all my choices, my goals, the candidate, the economy, and even my gutt feeling.
ai_votar.creator: 421540ac05e795a118fdbd9cd4f88592

comments.text: I think there is a lot of potential here. The challenge is reconciling the simplicity required for app success with the complexity of political considerations of a voter. In the hazy field of political terminology, a definition of terms will be critical for the validity of the apps measurements, and the user's understanding of them.

Thanks for the comment, Kris. You are absolutely correct. We cannot expect a majority of voters to understand the complexity of how their needs can be met by candidates. Computers are great in bridging the gap between the simplicity of the selection and that said complexity ... I have looked around for an interested party to work on this but haven't. Yet.

ai_votar.title: Artificial Intelligent Voter App

down_with_the_butterfly_ballot_accessibi.description: I cannot believe the horrible, error-prone, design of American Ballot Papers.  Better readability would help all but especially those with vision issues.
down_with_the_butterfly_ballot_accessibi.creator: 94292e3ffc2c71d299d570b8fe937804

comments.text: Thanks Tristan and Whitney, Hello all,Great questions about guideline adoption. In the years that I worked with Design for Democracy (just after those guidelines were published), the resistance we ran into had more to do with voting system constraints and local election laws, for instance, than any lack of desire on the part of election officials. For more of Design for Democracy's perspective on adoption challenges--and working with them--please see our "top 10" list on the subject: http://www.aiga.org/ballot-design-top-10/But, here's hoping this forum will generate solutions that transcend many of these challenges!

The U.S. Election Assistance Commission (www.eac.gov) worked with Design for Democracy to create design guidance templates so that all election departments can create well-designed ballots, instructions, signs and other materials. It would be a great start if more election departments adopted these best practices.

As an Indian, I share your amazement at the designs (and even the multiplicity of methods) in the US :) In India, we have had simpler designs, beginning with ballot paper and now electronic voting machines (despite their flaws, these have worked well). There is much to say in favour of having a standardised system across a country that most voters can understand.

For sure! The goal primary for ballot paper design should be to ensure it's easy to use and reduces error.  Having a consistent method also means that, usually, any random errors will generally even out.

Tristan, thanks for sharing this inspiration  it's great to see you back on OpenIDEO! And Whitney, you make an interesting point: it sounds like the tips and guidance are there, but they're not necessarily being adopted by election departments. During Inspiration, it'll be great to explore first how other countries are tackling these questions of accessibility in the layout and design of their ballots. And during our upcoming Concepting phase, perhaps we'll be able to get at some strategies and tools to incentivize and motivate election departments to adopt these standards?

This is exactly what I thought about immediately after reading this post, Ashlety. "But, wait, how do we make them actually use these?". I think it's a key question to think about moving into Concepting.

Wow - the more I hear about US election processes the more glad I am that I reside in Australia for voting purposesIs there such emphasis on 'freedom of choice' that they can't simply turn guidelines into legislated legal requirement?I know the Australian system is not perfect but it works very smoothly even with variations in counting methods between the states.
Amen!

down_with_the_butterfly_ballot_accessibi.title: Down with the Butterfly Ballot: Accessibility Starts with Making the Current Ballot Papers Readable

year_round_voting_center_stores_equipped.description:
My idea is targeting to the group who couldn't vote on the Election Day.
By installing voting kiosks at stores and having store managers as poll workers, we might be able to provide year-round voting services.
year_round_voting_center_stores_equipped.creator: 6e75a6fc07caaa04191c4cbe89e9433c

comments.text: Ting-Han I like many aspects of this concept.1. There is no reason that people cannot vote ahead of the election day provided the right mechanisms are in place;2. Provided store managers are given the appropriate sanctioned access to mark voters off the roll there is no difference between using them and poll clerks for this purpose.3. Andrew Baranak and a team at Georgia Tech have an idea for combining Ipads for voting with kiosk hardwarehttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ipad-absentee-voting/ this could form the basis of a physically small kiosk.4. I think there is a need (in many cases for a physical ballot) - on the basis of comments from Whitney Quesenbery in the concept Mark Anywherehttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/ the completed ballot only needs the voters final choices - not all the options I proposed a Bus Ticket (size) Ballot that could be activated  at the kiosk, then reinserted for auditing/manual recounts and a receipt issued.5. These kiosks could also be used in mobile polling places like voting vans or sufficiently portable for hospital wards etc.

Thank you for linking me to other concepts, Paul. I think the concept of "Mark Anywhere" provides a feasible way to save time on the election day, and more importantly, the idea of retaining physical tickets takes care of the voters who aren't familiar to new technologies.

Ting-Han although this concept didn't make the shortlist I still think many elements from it are worth incorporating into concepts like the voting vans and I am sure that when ITIF undertakes the final design exercise they will take all the best elements from all 155 concepts.
Great collaborative concepting, Ting-Han. Looking forward to some of the folks you've linked to here swinging by to chime in and build this idea even further.

year_round_voting_center_stores_equipped.title: Year-round voting center - stores equipped with voting kiosks

remove_pre_registration.description: If you have several hurdles before even the election day starts, you will get lower participation. A system excludes because: Some missed the deadline to register to vote, others feel it is too much work, and some are only confused by the process.
remove_pre_registration.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Johan, there is a new study that finds about 1 in 4 Americans are not registered to vote, that 1 in 8 registrations is inaccurate or out of date, and that the costs of voter registration is very high (especially compared to Canada). Here is the study from Pew: www.pewcenteronthestates.org/uploadedFiles/Pew_Upgrading_Voter_Registration.pdf

Thank you, Daniel! Quite shocking to read that so many as 1.8 million deceased are still registered!2,75 million are registered in more than one state!Possibility for someone to tamper or try to fraud the system, if this isn't sorted out before the upcoming election!And nice to see that an idea I had about Upgrading or ReCreating the registrations was shared by such an important thinktank. I sure hope that I can work for any organisation like that in the future!I have read some about origin of pre-registration, it was once another obstacle to take an IQ-test first, primarily for minorities that where outside the white male middle class. Yes, that included in some states unmarried women! and african-americans. Huge discriminations occured!

Thanks Daniel - very important information in understanding a huge underlying problem. Both Sarah and Johan refer to a National ID Card. Australia rejected a move to introduce a National ID Card system (hence the complicated procedure to opn a bank account described in one of my other comments). I gather there would be similar resistance in the US to a National ID Card, although this could simplify matters considerably.
Daniel - on reflection I think the Pew Report warrants an inspiration of its own.- if you would like to contribute one.

I agree with you Johan, this is an important point! Same thing in Morocco, for the new Constitution referendum, they removed pre-registration and allowed everyone to vote just by showing their national ID cards. Participation was much much higher than usual.
Agreed and nice graphic to illustrate.

Sounds sensible depending on how the parliament is organised. As long as you can be identified to be eligible to vote that should be sufficient. Our eligibility is determined by primary residence so provided you don't move between one election and the next you are assumed to be eligible to vote in the same electorate as last election. If you do move you are required to re-register within a couple of months of moving - its not any more onerous than telling your utility supplier your new address.

Also it is important for first-time voters to know how the process works, and how to navigate it.What is the legal age to vote in USA? 18-21? Do the schools teach about it?my theory is that this pre-requisite is a remnant of the older systems, that disqualified some people out of lack of income or inteliigence. People that were not free was not considered to have a say in the elections. such as slaves, married women... Yes, it is very recent that all females got the right to vote.

Sarah - how well accepted is the national id system in Morocco? What else is it used for?Here we have an identity check to open bank accounts and establish eligibility for social benefits - we need 100 points of identity with various ids such as drivers licences, passports, birth certificates and credit cards carrying different point values. It usually means you need at least three items of identity to pass the checks. This system was introduced because the citizens rejected the idea of a national id card.

Paul, what kind of banana-republic do you live in? In sweden it is enough with only one method. Either national ID-card OR drivers licence OR Passport.And with any of these you can get bank account and with that get an e-legitimation online, that is valid for all your bank errands aswell as your yearly tax-declaration and the political referendums/elections.Some banks now don't accept passports anymore, cause of the risk of them being counterfeited is much larger than the trusted registry that issues both the drivers licence and the ID-cards. (our birth certificates are stored only digitally within this nation-wide registry, we would almost never need one copy for any type of practical use other than at our wedding i think)But credit cards is never valid for any identification here, because it could be issued by foreign banks that not have same reliability or safety of records.It is extremely interesting to find out these different cultural differences. Don't know if there could be some concepts to construct around this issue? what do you think, Paul, Sarah?

I agree Johan - with the banking system here they have gone over the top with identification. It is related to combating money laundering and trying to capture the 'cash economy' to extract income tax.Since the banks are private institutions without positively identifying operators of bank accounts the government has limited access to the identity of transactions. Even signatories to accounts for companies, clubs and societies have to be identified in this way.It has been like this for about 20 years.Returning to the question of pre-registration Sarah mentions using national id cards - if the voting officials have access to checking or recording who has voted (to avoid multiple voting) that should be sufficient. Again my ignorance of the US system limits my thinking but if it was simply presidential election then being able to check that an individual has voted should mean you could vote anywhere a polling booth is available. I'm not so sure about other elections in the US - for instance using a national id card would that be sufficient for voting in state elections?

remove_pre_registration.title: Remove Pre-Registration

voting_aye_or_eye.description: The vision-impaired are challenged when trying to maintain one of the most important aspects of independence - that of casting their vote.
voting_aye_or_eye.creator: a27dde9d48bc6ef262e68a408640d585

comments.text: Wonderful insights here Tracie, thanks for sharing. Your friend's comments definitely inspire me to think about simplifying and streamlining for accessibility!

voting_aye_or_eye.title: Voting - AYE or EYE?

rethinking_election_queues.description: Today IDEO Palo Alto hosted a brainstorm for our Voting Challenge. We were particularly curious about how polling places could be redesigned to make the process of waiting in line and casting a ballot less confusing and rushed, and more private.
rethinking_election_queues.creator: 6a75b6ebe0dd913f0971ada060e2f7ea

comments.text: Seems like if we're looking to design a more accessible voting experience, we should just skip polling places (and the related queues) all together. Isn't the most convenient and accessible polling place each person's individual home?
I suppose it depends on the person's home (if they have one).And everyone is different. Some people love going to shop at malls, others would rather shop from home online.

As all the other comments, I really like the idea of the two lines. I guess one could add the priority line: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/priority-queueI can also see this being combined with the concept of comfort waiting: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/comfort-waiting/in particular, the fact that if you're in a rush, you can register / sign in while being in the line. The online option can be useful too. I like also the idea to give a chance for people to think over the election materials.For the special curtain, I had a clarification question: I was wondering if currently the booths have or don't have curtains. In France, the booths have curtains and it does indeed give a sense of privacy.

Good question. I'm not sure about curtains on booths and whether it's standard across locations. But I believe that in this case the curtain is meant to separate the people waiting to vote and the people actually voting. So while protecting each voter's privacy remains important, this second curtain also blocks off private space for voters to request personalized voting access away from the watchful eye of other voters in line. Hope that helps!
Thanks Ashley! It does help.

I think Ashley is right. My reading of the curtain's purpose was simply to provide confidentiality to voters when asking for private voting access. If I read it right this creates another queue of voters who have their ballot but are still waiting to vote. Here we have no curtains and the next voter leaves the head of the queue to collect a ballot as space to actually vote becomes available.I am not sure if this was intended to accommodate those who are anxious and/or self-conscious in seeking assistance - if so I am uncertain to what extent it would help.
How about a Biometric "Fast Lane" or something like the Disney Fast Pass system?
As always interesting and thought provoking ideas Avi.There was an inspiration around Disney theme parks - do you know if it described the Disney Fast Pass system?
http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/disney-parks-experts-in-crowd-management/http://boingboing.net/2012/02/10/walt-disney-world-tightens-the.html

Thanks for the links Avi - they make interesting reading.I can see situations where fast passes could be issued to voters with special needs, even before they leave home, to allow them to bypass the 'normal' queue once they arrive at the polling place.

Great thinking here!It seems that in the US so many elections take place on weekdays, whereas ours take place on Saturdays. Besides being more convenient for many voters it also extends the choice of available polling places (particularly schools) that have the room to set up sufficient private space to vote, usually have adequate parking, often have appropriate and adequate wheelchair access etc.On the question of queues there is a huge amount of research on queuing (of which I have no specific knowledge). From experience the issue seems to be tackled in many ways. Once upon a time banks (here) had a separate queue for each teller now there is a single queue, sometimes supported by a ticket machine that establishes your position in the queue but allows you to sit and read while you are waiting or perhaps even go outside again and await the call to transact your business (such ticket machines have been included, in various guises, in other concepts and inspirations.Where you gain an established place in the queue it tends to relieve stress a little. If you miss your cue to collect a ballot, perhaps because you needed to take a child to the toilet, you are not penalised by going to the back again but only by losing a few places in the queue.What if instead of having to present identity to receive a ballot you presented it to receive a ticket & reserve a place in the queue, then presented the ticket in exchange for the ballot? Furthermore, if in presenting your identity you could establish special needs, the 'system' could allocate you a number already recently used to move you near the head of the line. I dont know real figures for US polling stations but, for example: Suppose you present your ID to receive your queue ticket and the next number would normally be 157 but your record on the roll (or on your ID) indicates special needs - if, at that time, clerks issuing ballots are processing numbers 123 through 135 (and assuming all prior numbers have been processed) the 'system' could issue you a number like 119 which would place you at the head of the queue to receive a ballot.There are now 2 queues one (resembling an ordinary queue) to receive a ticket which reserves a place in the second queue according to need. Turnover in the first queue would be much quicker than in the existing system whilst the second queue becomes dispersed for greater comfort and benefit.I shall float this idea in Team S.O.Y.'s concept of Comfort Waiting (see AL's post here),  Stefan Ritters Priority Queues (same reference) and build on it in my concept for Reporting Voting Traffic ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mapping-accessability-rating-and-traffic-reports./ )
Actually on reflection I might float it as a complementary concept as well.
On rereading this concept I think some of the other points you raise like signage at different points in the queue might be better managed with a 'dispersed queue'.

Nice thinking you guys. Couple of thoughts:1) like what you highlighted at the end - the implementation aspects are going to be really important when the solution requires changes to the way people do things2) the segmentation idea is great! I did wonder whether there would be scope to think of other ways to segment - people that are still undecided could get access relevant candidate materials (inc. audio/brail); people with genuine issues with waiting around for long periods such as elderly or disabled could go through a 'fast-track' (again borrowing from the airline analogy you used)3) These ideas could also be used to think about how queues are managed through the day; given variable patterns (e.g., high demand before and after work) the resource allocation at the booths could be shifted (e.g., more 'in a rush' queues for workers pushed for time to vote at lunch) and with appropriate communication to the voting community it could help smooth demand fluctuations.

Oh, great thinking around the management of queues throughout the day Mark! Hopefully our concept might inspire some others - especially around the implementation questions you mentioned. How could we help poll workers and election officials understand these changes and adopt them?

A useful tool I used a lot at McKinsey was the Influence Model which helps frame activities in 4 buckets ("I will change my behavior if..."):1) Understanding and commitment ("...I know what I need to change and I want to do it"): in our case this is about the heart and minds of the poll workers, so actions could be around a communications strategy; this is particularly important if we are challenging the status-quo as unless they believe in the the new system they are unlikely to change their behavior2) Capability building ("...I have the skills to behave in a new way"): for us this could be training days, education videos, mentorship schemes for the poll workers, literature etc.3) Role-modeling ("...I see my leaders behaving differently"): this is very powerful and often overlooked; an action here could be to work closely with poll station leaders to ensure that they act in a way that supports the new system e.g., they could man the 'want more time' line and show the other poll workers what a good service looks like. We could also move up the chain a little and get more senior people doing this - how about the head of the Electoral Commission running a part of the station and getting it televised so all the poll stations see it?4) Aligned systems and structures ("...the systems reinforce the desired change"): this may be a little too corporate for us as this is often about targets and performance metrics etc., but there are some things that could work e.g., there have been inspirations and concepts about real-time performance of poll stations - these sorts of visual systems can be very powerful if designed appropriately.Apologies for this length but it's quite an in depth topic. Happy to explore more if there is interest.

Terrific points Mark! I'd actually really encourage you to think about designing concepts that meet one, two or all of these buckets. It's fun to think about how each of these bullets could be ideas in their own right, and I bet the community would love to help you flesh them out!

Like the idea of managed queue control throughout the day. I had thought of this as well. Certainly you'd want more quick moving lines in the morning and from about 5pm until polls close. A lot of this depends on space. Some polling stations in more rural areas or smaller cities are quite small, with only 2 or 3 voting booths. For the "Need More Time" line, you could add a separate booth or table outside of the queue with additional sample ballots and pens and explanatory materials for those who may need assistance voting due to disability. Again, thinking of an airport where space is given outside of the queue to fill out customs or immigration cards. The "Made Up My Mind" line should be spatially removed from this section of the polling place.

Brilliantly Simple...Simply Brilliant! The 2-line segmentation, explanatory signage, & privacy shields can certainly help everyone (both those who want to vote quickly, and those who would appreciate more time or help, regardless of reason), and relatively simple to explain/implement (vs. some of the other concepts) Reminds me of airport segmentation such as for security (staff/frequent traveler vs. regular traveler vs. flagged risk) or customs (country citizens/residents vs. other countries' visitors).Will need to think more on building on this brilliance =)

I like these ideas. I also feel the rush when voting in a polling place with a large line behind me - or lots of movement around me. The airport security line is hectic not only because you imagine all the people behind you in a hurry but also because of all the activity ahead of you. It's the visual chaos rather than the actual passing of time that gives one the impression the idea of needing to hurry up. The special curtain idea is a simple solution to make the whole voting process more private. Simple placement of the booths so that voters do not feel like someone is standing behind them would also make the process feel more comfortable and less rushed.
Glad to hear you like our concept Graham. We were excited that rethinking the queue would benefit all voters, not just those with accessibility needs.

rethinking_election_queues.title: Rethinking Election Queues

personal_identification_number.description: A Voters ID card along with Personal Identification Number (PIN) similar to your bank card can be allocated to all the citizens. The Voter can use this pin to vote from ATMs, Super Markets, Phone (like mobile Banking), internet, printed forms,etc.
personal_identification_number.creator: 79863f6a7f7cef2054a175ef331bf75e

comments.text: Interesting thoughts Dema  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.
Yes Meena, got what you mean here. :)

This post gave me an idea tied to credit reports.  Our credit cards, banks etc put together a report to assess our financial stability and consistency.  What if all voters were eligible for a 'consumer voter report' that allows voters to see their voting history? or perhaps even more important, can we use the idea of 'voter reports' to create more informed voters about how they live and how they vote and whether the two are in line with one another?

This is a very interesting way to potentially build voter turn-out in the long term.  If people were able to see a report of how they've voted over time, along with data about whether the issue/candidate won and what happened afterwards (e.g. the program was passed in 2000 but was never funded, remains on the books) it would give people better insight in to how their vote has made a difference over time.  If they feel it has made a difference they will likely continue voting.  If they feel that it hasn't, perhaps they will be inspired to become involved in their communities beyond simply voting on election day.
Thanks Campbell and Jessica for adding. On adding further, this data can be used by organisations for statistical comparisons also.

Yes, we have similar system here in Sweden, it is called E-legitimation. Issued by banks, but used for validation of identity and confirmation of delivering our yearly tax-income-declaration over internet or text-messaging from all different types of phones.
Hello Johan, Please share more. Are you facing any kind of problem? I feel something like this will make life easy for all the people who have problems in commuting.

yes, i agree, but there is always some percentage of people that do not understand or want to use these modern phones/computers. So I think it should only exist as an option, for efficiency.Or combined with proper assistance for disabled/impaired of handicaps and for senior citizens.

personal_identification_number.title: Voters ID card with unique Personal Identification Number

portable_accessible_ballot.description: A portable, durable device that interfaces with accessible ballots with sounds, pictures, buttons, brail, voice commands, and language options.  The device could be used at conventional polling places and also brought to remote and rural locations.
portable_accessible_ballot.creator: f6844333dd23181f6a5f75a28ce7af4a

comments.text: Hey Gregory , i find this verr handy. Is it being used anywhere or you making a proposition to combine both as a concept ! Nice - i like this straightforward solution !

Thanks!  I don't know if it's being used currently.  Certainly an iPad has the ability for voter identification that so many are suggesting: retina scan, fingerprint...  In the end, I think it's important to remember that we need to change the experience to fit the incredibly diverse user base (i.e. the entire voting population), not the other way around.  I suppose this idea is part inspiration, part concept.

portable_accessible_ballot.title: Portable Accessible Ballot

mind_read_my_vote..description: This technology now exists. Just search TED or google. We can provide this technology say in centers or the likes to allow those who can't read, write, speak or move to have their vote casted.
mind_read_my_vote..creator: 421540ac05e795a118fdbd9cd4f88592

comments.text: Yep, I agree there is great R&D potential. I think in ten years input devices will be a thing of the past. Even speaking will perhaps be reduced somewhat.
I like your concept because of the research opportunities

For mind-reading votes... it depends that state you're in.You could change your mind in minutes.  What if you just saw a commercial against the person you were voting for?The good thing about physical voting (or anything else) is, you can think it, THEN act on it.  It is interesting...

Interesting comment, Daniel. Hopeful in such a case they will accept a process whereby when you register your vote then YOU have registered it??? Hopeful when the technology is mature then it becomes standard procedure and be accepted as evidence. Just like voting via a website or the likes.

Perhaps you'd like to add specific links to the technology developments you are referring to, Sidi? We trust that this will trigger a richer and more focused discussion on the intriguing conversation you've started here.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fVhggGSjXVg

I think this will be commercialzed soon. Just a matter of time. The video shows a person removing a block in the form of a computer graphic just by thinking about it. This is amazing let me tell you and it will affect so many aspect of our lives ...
This technology came up during the inspiration phase as well: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/brainwave-controlled-interface/ . Video, image, & some discussion here.
Nice one guys  we're looking forward to onwards conversation from here...

When posting http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/brainwave-controlled-interface/ I had something like this in mind to. But with the tools potential I would rather think this will be something disabled will adapt to use for much more than voting. And the users will be able to use such devices to control "normal" interfaces for the voting.This seems also quite expensive and you can not expect everybody who would benefit to have their own, so if the government is seriously trying to get every bode to vote, this is probably one of the special equipment to invest in that could help any disabled to vote.

yah ... the costs... Hopefully the cost will go down quickly like what happened in the PC world and everyone can have have that interface not just to Vote but communicate with technology at large. http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/en/pattie_maes_demos_the_sixth_sense.htmlHe said that in few years time all computers will come with 'minority report' like interfaces with them. http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/en/john_underkoffler_drive_3d_data_with_a_gesture.html
Sorry, image coming soon... Promise.
If you're having issues uploading an image  please let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site.
