not_informed_voting_in_turkey_is_up_but_.description: After interviewing some Turkish students, I found that it really isn't a problem of people voting, its the problem of people voting for whoever they thought looked good on the card. I found they were relatively uninformed and really know the issues.
not_informed_voting_in_turkey_is_up_but_.creator: 96c77162db6f992708aaa62418a743bd

comments.text: Important and interesting insights David!

not_informed_voting_in_turkey_is_up_but_.title: Not Informed - Voting in Turkey is up, but information may not be abundant.

an_election_integration_into_the_college.description:
THE BUBBLE PROBLEM: 
We address the problem on college campuses of how students exist within a bubble, disconnected from current events.  Our process integrates the election seamlessly into student’s lives and could feasibly be applied elsewhere.
an_election_integration_into_the_college.creator: 5a81ff70f4557875dd4dde2b2cec045b

comments.text: I know this challenge won awhile ago, but I just wanted to say that this is an incredible concept. The one thing I kept wishing in college was to pop that bubble, and feel like I knew what was happening. You should launch this concept nationally. Starbucks partnerships. I'll submit this to friends at the University of Southern California that can execute.
Hi Kallin- Sorry we just saw this comment! We'd love to get in touch!

I was very happy to see that this idea made it through and was a winning concept.  Students need information and ESPN and Sportscenter don't inform them of the issues of each election.  Many of the TV's in dining halls at college campuses show MTV music videos and you would think this would make sense for them to show the news.  Great idea.

Congratulations on a winning concept! I think this idea is a perfect example of offering education where it is needed the most: in our classrooms. I am sometimes sadden at the lack of motivation of my fellow generation to empower our vote and our country. By making these issues readily accessible, one can only hope that our natural inclination to do something about what we are disgruntled about will take action. Information is power. So is coffee. Congratulations to the team for being amongst the winning concepts!

I do like the idea of the coffee sleeves very much.  I think it is might be taking the assumption a little to far when they said that most college students are addicted to coffee or some form of hot drink, but I do agree that most college students drink these drinks. It is also very true that most college students, and young people in general, do not have a  firm grip on current events and the important issues in elections.  Part of it maybe due to our lack of feeling the direct effect from them, but being more informed would definitely be a good thing.  The sleeves put on your coffee would be a great way to inform college students.  While your sipping on your coffee or waiting for it to cool a little bit, you now have something to read that will help you become more educated on important issues in the election.  I think the sleeves should be given at random instead of letting the coffee drinker choose, as I think this would slow the ordering process down and not let coffee drinkers learn all the issues.  I think each day of the week they should offer a different sleeve with current election issues.  Most people only drink coffee once a day so each day giving them a different topic would be important for them to make a truly informed voting decision.

Hi DFA Cornell. I hope your winning concept inspires advocacy groups and election officials to think about all the bubbles we live in -- and take up some of your innovative ideas for ways to incorporate elections into our daily lives in subtle, but noticeable, ways.

Congratulations team on being amongst the winning concepts. This idea is so innovative and I think the prospect of extending it beyond the cafe has great potential too. Maybe for your grocery shop idea you could combine it with biodegradable paper bag stock or a series of sticky labels. Regardless I shall be interested to follow this concept through realisation, despite my remote location.

I like... The simplicity of the "Click, swipe, vote" process.  Removing barriers and pain points feels like a crucial step for this demographic.I wish...There was a way this process could build connections across and outside of the college 'bubble' and make it easy for students to tap into the larger dialogue around election issues.    What if... There were a way to create locally centered forums and discussions around issues- what might be a critical issue for one neighborhood could be very different from what is important across town.  Also, what if there were a way to use this process to incentivize participants- perhaps the voting sleeves are cheaper, or you get a discount (or even free drink!) after casting your vote?

Interesting thinking Ben - as you say 3 step simplicity is likely to appeal to the demographic. Sadly that same simplicity also encourages minimal engagement (certainly better than none) but reminiscent of SMS and Twitter as means of serious discourse. I applaud the suggestion of an interface to discussion and would hope that students would afford the time for interaction before the voting step.

Minimal engagement is an interesting point, Paul. As college students we would argue that people are engaged more than ever via Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, etc. We intend to use these existing platforms and existing behaviors to create a hub for discussion and information. This would be where students found information about where to vote, how to register etc. We believe that when it comes time to vote, people will have already made an decision. We love the Click, Swipe, and Vote for its convenience. It is very much like a self check-out or express lines at grocery stores-- the rapidity supports our pace of life. Thanks!Ben, tapping into the local area is definitely an area we'd like to explore. Our revisions will surely reflect this, thank you! An incentive would definitely increase motivation to visit the web site and ensure a full-cycle experience.

I guess my point was more that engagement through twitter or facebook alone is minimalist and I'm glad to understand that you see this as a pre-election initiative too, allowing students to enter meaningful dialogue around relevant issues. I agree that most voters have made up their mind at the point of voting and think that this concept will provide an opportunity for students to become better informed.

Just a note: we are thrilled about the comments that were given to us and that we were able to use Open IDEO as a platform to conceptualize making an impact on our campus! Whether we are chosen or not, we applaud everybody's participation. It is truly enlightening to see people working towards a better world through and with design.
Interesting idea. Any idea on how secure this actual system would be? How would you ensure the identity of the person voting? What if they were to get their ID card stolen?
Our revised version will discuss security. Thanks for bringing it up!

I really like the idea,and I think it would be super effective in reaching out to college students. However, I think there are ways that This idea can reach even more people, who may not afford the trendy and expensive cafe's. This idea could be spread to lower-end eateries and reach more low income areas, where the importance of voting is still not stressed enough.
I agree, perhaps we can extend voting to the neighborhood Delis. There are plenty of them scattered throughout major cities that many people buy their groceries and lottery tickets from.

I agree Sackes. I think it would even be better if we could spread this the masses through the massive American fast food industry, this will allow for ideas to be spread to populations outside of cities

Maybe a larger audience could be reached if the same idea was implemented but instead of using coffee, the advertisements could be added on to foods Thai people purchase at grocery stores. Everyone shops at a grocery store and the products sit in the homes of people of all economic classes
Great discussion guys! Design For America Cornell: feel free to update your concept based on any collaborative discussion which is developing here to strengthen your idea.

If this idea was to transcend to grocery stores, what would replace the coffee sleeves? There are multiple fabulous aspects about these: the tangible experience for the customers interact with them, the empowerment of choosing which issue is important to each individual, and the feasibility of printing on the sleeves.Perhaps the choice of issues wouldn't happen immediately, but one would be directed to the website where that would be the greeting. The user would have to choose which issue was most important to them before continuing? On the other hand, instead of adding additional branding to products, which would create rather complex negotiations, what about other items in the store. Shopping carts and baskets would limit the experience to just the grocery. However, paper and plastic bags could replace the coffee sleeves well.Awesome discussion everyone! Thanks for the input.

I'm also a college student, and while I can't speak for others, I frequently find myself stuck in the bubble, largely out of touch with what is going on in political and world affairs.  We are surrounded by a plethora of information sources and media outlets, but ironically this abundance of information can seem daunting for many college students, given our hectic work schedules.  I like your idea because it brings the political discussion into the daily routine of the college student, hopefully sparking meaningful discussion during those infrequent periods of downtime between class and work.  It will be important for the sleeves to initiate discussion immediately without having to visit the website first, and then once the discussion gets started the website will provide resources to keep it rolling.  On a logistical note, how will you offer different sleeve selections?  Will it be random, or will people be able to request the "energy policy" sleeve?  It might take some ingenuity to implement the latter into the cafe's work routine.  It might also be worth considering other outlets for the information, such as napkins, plates, or even handing out a non-utility item with each purchase, such as a cardboard token.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We were excited that you've tapped into youth voters in this concept, but that there's also potential to replicate this across voter groups. During this Refinement phase, let's think about ways to start bringing this concept to life. For instance, maybe now's a great time to reach out to campus dining and talk through the steps you'd need to take to get the coffee sleeves designed and distributed? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
It seems like there must already be a neutral online source that informs people about election issues have you looked into that?

Nice build on some of the early inspirations for better integrating elections and voter education into daily life. Using QR codes on "everyday" items like coffee cup sleeves is a clever idea. I don't think this is limited to university campus, though I can see the "bubble" effect you are addressing. If the QR code was combined with a strong logo or icon indicating that the information comes from the elections department, it could also be a good way to share reminders about election dates, links to ballot questions or other "official" information. I mention this because the question of making the links trustworthy seems important (both issues of malware, but also being able to distinguish partisan information from campaigns from official sources).

I agree with the concern about trustworthiness... we are all blasted with partisan information during election time, so students might have difficulty believing the neutrality of a source. If this could be very clearly neutral and trusted, it could become an incredibly valuable resource for everyone. Maybe this could be achieved by including strong arguments and information from many sides of every issue.
Interesting concept. In some states, public university ID's are official state IDs (which presumably could be used for voting).
Great thinking, guys. You've touched on some exciting possibilities here  which could certainly be extended beyond student engagement too.

an_election_integration_into_the_college.title: An Election Integration into the College Campus (Cornell University)

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

yelp_for_poll_stations.creator: 88042d0941bd6e65ac8b383c2fbc2f10

comments.text: Great idea Lucy. I can see how you can build off of the Voting Information Project (http://votinginfoproject.org/) which is making all of the data about poll places available in a reusable electronic format. What about pairing this with something like Get Satisfaction (http://getsatisfaction.com/) that is used for resolving complaints and issues in the private sector?

Great tips, Daniel! Note: if you add links to comments without parentheses in future, they'll come up as active and folks can click on them directly. eg. http://votinginfoproject.org/http://getsatisfaction.com/
Allowing a space inside either end of the parentheses achieves the same result ( http://votinginfoproject.org/ )

user_designed_solutions.description: The outreach efforts of an AmeriCorps member w/ disabilities at the Silicon Valley Volunteer Center proved more effective by multiple folds because she designed the process as an insider.  Same strategy would be beneficial for election accessibility.
user_designed_solutions.creator: c6d9a3c90ef090051bbf5759c5368045

comments.text: Great focus on user-driven solutions Khin. You raise a great point about including relevant people in the conversation. Here at OpenIDEO we encourage our collaborators here to speak with folks that we are designing for  plus, if possible, talk through potential solutions with them too!  An example from the Inspiration phase was our Interview Starter Kit: http://bit.ly/oi_interview

Hi Khin, welcome to OpenIDEO and cheers for joining our challenge! A couple of points: you might want to check out the list of resources at the left margin  there are lots of tools and details outlined there to give you a sense of the community of people we're designing for. Also, any chance you have an image to go along with your post? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

user_designed_solutions.title: User-Designed Solutions

porta_potty_inspiration_how_might_we_con.creator: 68c03a76152dc53fdd2c7c7ab07f2721

comments.text: Love this provocation =)

how_the_elderly_move.description: What is it like for the elderly to read the fine print on a label? To grab something from a top shelf? To push a shopping cart? MIT's AgeLab created a suit that simulates the physical mobility constraints experienced by the elderly.
how_the_elderly_move.creator: 578d686fd16e309fca4a57379c6cd484

comments.text: Many people I know (even those that are quite sympathetic to others) have expressed that they've never truly understood accessibility issues until they were injured and had to be on crutches or in a wheelchair for a time.Things that they might not have thought about otherwise (such as stepping onto or off of a curb to get where they were going) were suddenly critical tasks that had to be done with extreme care.Having election designers be able to experience what it is like to be physically restrained from moving or have vision impairments (without them actually having to suffer any injuries) is a great way to increase their empathy and get real changes implemented into their designs.

Hi Adriana,I also found this simulation exercise by the UNESCAP to better understand the difficulties of the elderly and disabled.http://www.unescap.org/esid/psis/disability/decade/publications/z15009gl/z1500917.htmSome extra inspiration :)
This is a great exercise Camila. Thanks for sharing!

Absolutely, anything we can do to bring creators & beneficiaries closer together can help bring about a better end result, whether through  observation, interviews, simulated experience, participant observation, co-creation, or designers that are also members of the end user group.
The great thing about this, is it really builds deeper empathy by experiencing a little of what it's like firsthand!
Yes! I agree. Thanks Vincent, for inspiring my post. Building in a direct empathy experience into the design process is critical.

how_the_elderly_move.title: How the Elderly Move

5_minutes_result_driven_elections.description: Most of voters ask a common question " What is for me ?" This inspiration will give ideas on how to make the election process interesting, exciting and more involved
5_minutes_result_driven_elections.creator: 337e865f92fc3b02bd963a8cbd68a6a3

comments.text: Your article reminds me of a long thought of suggestion. May be independent electoral bodies would start lending a hand to school elections of prefects etc so they can start getting used to the proper way of conducting democratic elections before they mature. This way I am sure future leaders in the future must have had their mentality about governance transformed before they actually get involved in public leadership and take Africa out of the mess in which we find ourselves today. Fine post.

Thanks a lot Takang Pamela for your comments. Your attempt to fix the issue at root level is really interesting. Inducting good practices at a younger age is best way to develop characters in people . Singapore is the best e.g for this and they implemented it very successfully in Cleaniness. You can't find anybdoy litering and eating in public transports .. because these habits are started in School . Even i am in that perspective that schools should start teaching leadership , soft skills, relationship building , team work skills in big way to transform people to face the future .. Very nice comment

comments.text: This is very interesting... it seems as though we are missing a huge opportunity by not allowing previously incarcerated citizens to vote.  It is very challenging for previously incarcerated citizens to become an integrated member of society when we deny them rights like this.  The woman in the video speaks very well to this as a case of a contributing member of society who is denied a right granted to citizens.

Interesting thought Carios !! I came across one article where there is a long debate on ' Should we have holiday on the election day?', the pros and cons. Though this topic is not relevant to the above challenge but a good point for thought. here is the link http://www.businessweek.com/debateroom/archives/2008/10/election_day_should_be_a_holiday.html

Interesting point, Carlos. Keep in mind that we're keen to focus on supporting and innovating around existing electoral systems. Check out more details on our challenge Guiding Principles: http://bit.ly/vote_guide
Of course you should have titled this "*Stop* Making Voters Go Away".  Because some people like the idea of felon dis'ing.  All new election technologies should be prison-tested.
the go-away factor aside, "Prison-tested" is a great idea in itself! When else is this segment of society ever engaged? "Prison testing"  could address participatory obstacles in so many ways.

I have read and re-read about this fact of life in the United States and still cannot believe it.  As a Canadian, I have followed the political system quite closely my whole life but I am quite unfamiliar with the justice system in the US and voting.  Felony disenfranchisement for those out of prison--who have "paid their debt to society"--is a disgrace to democracy.

portable_ballot_boxes.description: Portable Ballot Boxes like the one in the image have been used in Kyrgyzstan (among other places) to collect ballots on a door-to-door basis.
portable_ballot_boxes.creator: 9c961fba09bbd1b47f50466d7270666f

comments.text: Great example of meeting people where they are to engage in the voting process.  Could we take it one step beyond and engage this demographic prior to the actual ballot casting?

I love this idea.  It would be extremely useful for many of the groups the brief specifically asked us to focus on such as homebound elderly people, people with mental or physical disabilities that make it difficult (or impossible) for them to head to the polls, people in remote areas (especially if they do not have access to a vehicle).  It would also benefit other people not specified in the brief such as a primary caretaker for someone that cannot be left alone (and cannot easily be taken to a polling place) or even parents of young children.I was thinking about a way to ensure that the ballots could not be tampered with once they've been deposited and I thought about the boxes that are used for emptying parking meters in Los Angeles (and potentially other areas).  The parking attendant has a key that allows them to remove the coin container from the meter, but they can't open the coin container.  The box the attendant is pushing has a special way of connecting to the coin container that allows the coins to be emptied into the coin container.  The attendant does not have a key to the container so they never have access to the coins.The mechanism wouldn't need to be that involved since ballots would be deposited into the ballot box directly, but, the box itself could be designed to be tamper proof and unopenable (until it's time to process the ballots, of course).

Hi Alex, really simple, effective idea!  To build on Jessica's fail-safe solutions, the other question os tha of the election volunteer "influencing" the vote of vulnerable voters - some way of ensuring the ballot sheet is filled prior to their arrival would address this though.

Hope you can develop a concept around this - perhaps in conjunction with some of the other 'mobile' voting inspirators. Just one thought about security - securing deposited votes should be straightforward (padlocks, security ties etc. as conventionally used) - what mechanism should be used to secure unused ballots perhaps a key operated dispenser or, to borrow technology from a few other inspirations, a biometric (say fingerprint) dispenser set to accept only biometric information from the appointed official.

Thank you for the ideas! When I first posted this, I pictured in my mind a method of collecting ballots similar to voting by mail, which is how I've always voted. In particular, I imagine those who register to vote in this way would receive their ballot in advance, and fill it out to be collected on election day by some manner of mobile ballot box truck (I loved the idea of combining portable boxes with the accessibility of food trucks). This would definitely help with your point Eoghan, which could certainly be an issue.As for ballot security, I agree that the ballot box itself should be closed securely but simply, using a padlock for example. As for unused ballots, there would only be as many ballots as registered voters and the vote by mail system already has systems in place to check ballot validity (specifically, through a signature check). Ideally, however, this would be replaced by some form of biometric check, to help those who might have difficulty signing their name.Thank you all for the support, especially since this is the first inspiration I've ever posted. It's amazing to see so many developments come out of a single example!

Very nice inspiration. I agree with Paul: I'd love to see the concept emerging from this inspiration and other mobile inspirations. I find really intriguing your point about voting by mail being your "prototypical" voting experience as for me (and for many it  seems, from the inspirations posted) it is about going to a poll.

Thanks for the great example Alex. This and some of the other "mobile" voting examples could be focused in neighborhoods or communities with low voting rates or other indicators. Imagine a cast of election volunteers dispatched from mobile voting hubs could reach many otherwise disenfranchised citizens.

Hello,I like the idea and I don't think that it's difficult to do it door-to-door, it could minimize congestions during elections days by reducing the effort done by the voters (to go vote) to the effort of few "postmen" collecting the votes.I like the idea:)
Great global insight here, Alex!

comments.text: I was very intrigued to check out your demdash as I certainly seek political knowledge to best decide who to vote for. I should have noted your choice words "social curated" because I was not expecting the social element nor was I interested in logging into facebook or joining a site that did not show its value to me before joining...I think though that this could be good for groups with disabilities to use as a platform if they support a specific candidate who supports their needs. But I feel like its value is not so apparent despite the beautiful design. Maybe because I entered the site with different expectations (i.e. a resource of candidate information) I was disappointed, but I think its not so much a replacement of propaganda as it is a forum for group voting... I'd rather see a break down of political positions (the what/why) rather than the who - whose voting for who. Again, maybe I don't understand because I consider voting to be more personal and independent, less of a group activity. nevertheless I think trends and information mined from your website could be very insightful, since its founding have you noticed anything like certain groups voting together or reacting to another groups vote?
Interesting to see a little of the complexity of US presidential elections.

elections_a_kind_of_festive_season_in_in.creator: 77cfbd410bb1a32c4b63cce4aa4ddbed

comments.text: This is a very good personal illustration of the complexities underlying the voiting process.

I think the best way to prevent tyranny and create true democracy is to empower ordinary people. People not in the circles of power. If people are not reliant on governors, then they will not be held to ransom by them.

Would you say that people meet up with their friends and see celebrities and get free food and drink etc and vote as their friends do, or vote for the candidate who has arranged the most food, and not vote for the candidate who will do the best for the long term welfare of the town? Thus perhaps major problems to be targeted would be education and private voting?

Hi Zack,You have pointed out very thought provoking problems. Yes, these things still happening in India during the election process, especially in rural areas where candidates arranged free food, money etc to the voters to attract them in short term. But casting the vote is completely private, its totally up to the voters that to whom to select, they can cast their vote independently with the help of electronic voting machines.Since I mentioned in this as well as my other inspirations too is that illiteracy is one of the major issues especially in rural areas, where people can not differentiate between a  good candidate, who will be beneficial for them for the long term welfare. Thus I think that major problems where we have to focus would be education, security, ease of use as well as the accessibility to vote.Thanks for your commentRegards,Deepak

Hi Jack,Such malpractices are not new in democracy anywhere in the world. Even in 19th century British electoral system.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SO0nDGPA5wBut it is important to clear out such loopholes and build better systems to prove it to ourselves that democracy is transparent and fair
Nice link of History lecture Akshay... also it gives us a deeper understanding of electoral system from historical point of view.Thanks.Deepak

Thanks Deepak for sharing your experience. I like how you highlighted the social aspect of the voting process. I also think you did a good job in showing how it can be a difficult experience with someone with no accessibility issues.Thanks Akshay for the link. I've started watching the lecture. Really interesting. It's indeed important to put things in perspectives and to look at historical evolution of various electoral systems. To the literacy issue, I think it is an important issue. I believe that even in countries where literacy seems to be less of an issue, education still matters. Democracy intrinsically requires education (if not you always have the risk of tyranny. This was already at the core of the debate around the creation of the Greek democracy in the 5th century BC).

voting_through_the_postal_service_.description: A election day holiday coupled with a visit by a voting attendant bringing the polling station to your door would combat many issues affecting voter turnout in an effective, compassionate, and patriotic fashion.
voting_through_the_postal_service_.creator: 140605efb36a7c873cd283782a863081

comments.text: Here at OpenIDEO we think of it less as theft as co-creation ;^) Wow  it's a comprehensive concept you've got going on here, Shaun! We're anticipating discussions to flourish here and your ideas to evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right. Here's an example of how built up ideas can get over the course of a challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/localfood/winners-announced/public-kitchen/ Let's bring on the builds and spell out the specifics!
Of course I was just playing with my words a little I guess :).  Thanks for the support.

How could we additionally encourage voter education prior to this event? If we are approaching these "couch potatoes" with ballots who have not participated previously in elections and, therefore, have not felt the need to be informed on candidate platforms, is it possible that they have not researched and would give uninformed votes that give a skewed view of the national choice?I really like your idea and think there is a really great foundation - just trying to play Devil's Advocate a bit!

I guess I was assuming a focused holiday would get more people involved and worried about educating themselves in general. As far as uneducated, non-voters are concerned, I feel like many of them if given a chance to get involved in the process might be encouraged to reflect on it as well. While there may be many who don't take it seriously and cause some skewing of an honest election I think the benefits of additional participation on a large scale by all sorts of people would compensate for this skewing. From what I was reading last night, the more educated portion of the US, those more likely to understand the issues, have shown the least voter turnout as of recently anyway. Initially I was thinking the postal workers could provide pamphlets but that doesn't seem too feasible as far as time/resources are concerned. Ill be thinking about more ways to integrate voter education though, you brought up a good point. Thanks for playing devils advocate I needed it!

Thanks! Yeah, that's an interesting angle, the first thing that actually popped into my head was the use of automation in reading ballots. So say you had to mark a certain box or something like that and just the way left-handed handwriting differs from right-handed could, potentially cause the system problems recognising the vote.

disperse_the_queue.description: Use ticketing to reserve a voters place in the queue. After that voters no longer need to remain "in line" but can find a more comfortable way to await their turn to collect a ballot and vote. Special needs voters can be accommodated too.
disperse_the_queue.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: A lot of sequential thought put into practice. Congratulations on presenting this insightful and ready-to-go solution
Thanks Patricio.
Wow Paul, what detailed updates you've made during Refinement. I'm really enjoying the care you took to show how each persona's voting experience could be improved. Great work.

Thanks Ashley.I hope our sight-impaired IDEATORS can read it too. I just didn't manage to complete the links to other concepts properly but I might try that about 3am US time today and hope I can re-publish properly while most IDEATORS are sleeping.
Paul, very impressive and detailed updates! I really appreciate the efforts you put in developing scenarios for different personas and situations. thanks!

Thanks for the encouragement AL - I had three things in mind:1.Comfort Olowo (in one of the other threads here) correctly identified that dispersing the queue does not per se directly assist most voters with special needs, but can do so in conjunction with a Priority Queue; henceUpdate 1 focused on the personas in the priority queue where (by presumption) the general queue was dispersed (i.e. hopefully no long queue to join before reaching the door);2. I thought a narrative approach was useful first for our sight-impaired IDEATORS (of which I think there are a few) and also because it would be difficult for me to tell the same story in video or pictures;Update 2 is intended to address some points raised by James Meyer and illustrate that the environment created by dispersing the queue can accommodate some aspects of other concepts (Mark Anywhere, Voter Help Hubs, Poll Station Rating, Poll Worker Support etc.)I budgeted 3 hours to prepare the narrative but  (with collaboration on other concepts actually took me 6 hours). So I was unable to iterate a third time.3. My firm belief is that making the Poll Station environment more pleasant for everyone does actually assist those with special needs and, while online voting may ultimately become the norm, polling stations are likely to remain in the US for some time to come.
Thanks Paul for providing the rationale for the different updates. They do make sense and are helpful. thanks!

I wanted to chime in and add a bit of my experience as a pollworker here in Ohio, and how it would relate to this concept. (I've actually been a pollworker in two different counties, which is unusual.) The smallest voting district is a precinct. A precinct may have as few as 500 registered voters or as many as 3000-4000. Ideally there is 2000, and typically there are 4 people who serve the voters of that precinct on election day. (What each of the four people do is actually different from county to county.) For each precinct, there may be 3-5 voting machines.Anyway, I have worked an election day in which there was only one precinct in the room. Obviously in that situation, this concept is superfluous. But I have worked an election day in which there were 15 precincts in the same room. It so happens that the voting machines could be programmed to be used by any of those 15 precincts so the middle of the room was full of voting machines, and the tables where the pollworkers sat lined the edge around the center. In situation like this, there is often a table at the front of the room with pollworkers whose job it is to direct the voters to their correct precinct. That's the type of situation in which this concept is quite suitable. The fact that the voter has to go to the exact precinct even though the machines can serve all of them is is an anachronism of habit and law. With minor changes though, this idea could work quite well. (Keeping in mind that the one disadvantage of large groupings of precincts is that it requires voters to travel further to vote. The single precinct I mentioned above was walkable by many voters, but in the massive 15 precinct grouping, located in an industrial area of my suburban/rural county, driving was a must.)

Thanks for the feedback from your experience James.As my experience of poll working  is only here in Australia where queues are rarely more than 10 minutes waiting time.I only had the extreme examples like Florida 2000 to indicate there may be some need for queue management.My next update will (I hope) relate to this concept in conjunction with some of the others where, hopefully fewer and or smaller voting machines would be normal.I am aware that queue bottlenecks occur at different points in the process and that other concepts may eliminate long queuing.altogether.Did your 15 precinct experience result in long queues for verification or were the bottlenecks more at the voting machines?

That was a low to medium turn-out election, with a simple ballot, so there wasn't much queuing (ha, as an American, I have no idea how to spell that word.) When bottlenecks did occur, they occurred at verification: In the one county I worked in, the pollbook (the book with the voter's names and addresses, in which the voter signed their name) was split into two (A-J, K-Z, something like that) so two voters could be verified simultaneously. In the 15 precinct county, there was only one pollbook, which held things up considerably. Moreover that county assigned the job for the entire day, as opposed to allowing us to rotate jobs. Ideally the most able bodied person would get the pollbook job because it's vital that it moves fast, but more often than not I find that this doesn't occur. I didn't work the Ohio 2004 election, where there were major queues, but I got to see them. That was all a problem of machines and really long ballots. Somewhere in my files I have my Ohio 2004 ballot so you can see how complex it was, but I can show you my Ohio 2008, which was still fairly involved: http://www.scribd.com/doc/86050712/Sample-ballot-Franklin-County-2008

Thank you James - the copy of the ballot is enlightening -and you have given me an extra piece of the jigsaw (at least so far as Ohio is concerned). Here the pollbook is a simple list of names and addresses put on to a laptop and simply ticked off for each voter presenting themselves (no signature is involved). Each clerk verifying identity has a complete list (soon I think to be online). I can see that dividing the poolbook A-J K-Z would make a single ticketing system less effective and require some sophistication in queue management.when queues are long and make ticketing superfluous when just a few voters are in the polling station. This probably means that counties would make individual decisions on queue management depending on how difficult it is to manage peak flow. Judging by the copy of the ballot this is also a major consideration in how quickly each voter can actually cast a ballot which is ultimately what determines how quickly voters will reach and leave the head of the queue.

Well keep in mind, I would envision using your system in a massive precinct where all the pollworkers had the *same* pollbook, so it didn't matter where the person went. They could be processed by anyone. If you want more information on pollworker duties, here is a link to the pollworker training manual for the other county I worked in. I haven't bothered downloading it, but I'm sure it has samples of the pollbook. http://vote.franklincountyohio.gov/precinct-official/precinct-official-training.cfm
Great Refinement moves, Paul! Brilliant to see you not only iterating your own concept  but joining conversations across other shortlisted ideas as well. Top notch collaborative attitude!

Thanks Meena - real-time collaboration is a bit of a challenge, given time zones. I think many of us can see a bigger picture where our individual concepts contribute to synergistic solutions. Sometimes too combining some concepts will remove the need for others.I see queue management as an interim measure on the way to situations where turnover is so rapid that queues are eliminated and would be very happy to see this happen.
Brilliant update!

Hi Paul, you mention above that voters in need can be given priority with this system (just as in some banks, bank users are given priority by giving a number in faster line). How do you think the system can see/know that a voter is in need? Can this information be used with an additional valuable, like also setting how the voter can vote? We talked with Whitney about integrating our concepts; please check our latest conversation on the wall: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/diversity-in-voting-let-the-app-suggest/

Yes Cansu I have been giving your question some thought, prior to you asking it, but your question and input are very valuable. In many cases the ticketing system (equipment), if used, would either need to be pre-existing (as Daniel has suggested may sometimes be the case) or set up for one or may be a few days each election. That being so it would probably be a relatively simple system, not particularly capable of knowing voter profiles, and hence voters would have to self identify. However if it is possible to link to profiles this would be particularly useful.The easiest point at which voters can self identify is when they receive a ticket and seek to join the priority queue. I shall be discussing this with Stefan (tonight I hope) as that part of queue control is his concept.

Hi Paul, it is true that the ticketing system can be kept simple, and be implemented anywhere today.Involving a voter profile, combining the two concepts, can work in two cases. First is if you borrow the existing ticketing kiosks from the banks during the elections. These kiosks already have a screen where the customer selects the kind of banking service they need and get a number accordingly. Updating a software with the 'voter app' should be simple, and would make full use of the technology in hand.Second would work in the long term (may be not that long) when this ticket is also an 'e-ticket number' which can be taken using your smart phone on the way to the poll.These are definitely not things to change in your concept; they can be considered as some future opportunities which would and create a long term value.Besides all, I remember you saying that you once volunteered as a poll clerk. Do I remember correct, I am not sure. I am trying to collect some stakeholder feedback on the wall of my concept. It would be great if you could jump in an comment with your experiences:)((By the way, I mentioned above that bank kiosks let the customer select the kind of banking service they need/or even select that they are existing users of the bank and get a number accordingly. I guess integrating this method to give priority to some voters is a bit more transparent and less confusing than giving an old number used before. In that case there are usually 3 lines of numbers running at the same time))

Thanks for the feedback Cansu and I shall have a look at the things being discussed around you "app" concept.Yes I have several years experience of working as a polling clerk here in Australia where the paper ballot and manual counting is generally so simple and straightforward. The USA system was a mystery to me until this challenge.Just to clarify about the tickets - I was actually thinking that the ticket machines may not be screen based at all. It would depend upon the budget of the county running the polling place. At the very basic level it might consist of mechanically issued tickets and a couple of LED displays controlled by the clerks.

Hey Paul, congrats ! To build on this - I feel in order to decide what should a waiting area ( lounge accomodate ) one really needs to know the tentative time a voter is likely to wait. So let us assume the wait time would vary from 10 minutes (tolarable) to 30 minutes (in-tolarable)  and we need to cater to both the situations. While going through your concept i recalled one of the inspiration from our challenge (http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/doing-something-useful-whilst-waiting-inline-apple-stores/ ) which looks at how apple stores have dealt with the wait.Another one about adding coffee- http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/just-add-coffee/ In addition we could look at waiting lounge at airports - a comfortable seating is good enough for people to relax and get talking ! There has been a repetitive mention of display screens, i was wondering if we would like people to go through a video showing safety tips ( ref inspiration by me - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-hostess-facilitate-physical-demonstration-of-the-process-just-like-air-hostess-/ and florin on demonstrations before a flight takes off http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/vote-safety-demonstration-/I was wondering if we could have similar video displays (before voting. )If a display screen is very expensive how about  a popup  book like brochure ( cant help thinking about one of my inspirations-tell a story with pop -up books and musical cards - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/tell-a-story-with-pop-up-books-and-musical-cards-.-/ ) brochure(cheapest and easiest to produce ) which talks about the safety tips or the procedure like in travel guide but inclusive , graphical and multisensory ! I feel if we could ensure a place to sit/ hangout a lot more can be done while waiting without making a  voter realize that its THEIR TURN NEXT ! Cheers .

Thanks for the wonderful input Mamta.The question of waiting time has been concerning me and I agree adopting a range like 10-30 minutes is a good guide.I have held off beginning to describe the environment formally in a concept update as, unlike airports, hospitals and doctors rooms these may still be temporary installations. As such it will be adding to the duties of staff/volunteers and the furniture and equipment inventory.I think the educational opportunities are excellent provided the main objective, of notifying each voter when their turn arrives, is achieved.I am also thinking (hoping) that in creating a more congenial atmosphere for voters it will also be a better experience for staff and volunteers.Finally, and this came from discussion on Stefan's Priority Queue concept there will be a need to prioritise for disabled voters in a slightly different way. Rather than necessarily sending them all to the head of the queue it will be necessary to physically locate them with good clear access to the voting area.Please feel free to add more ideas - I will be incorporating them into the main body of the concept in the next day or so.

simply brilliant!In China banks utilize this system as well. They have super long queues because allot of people have to pay their bills and reload their electricity and phone prepaid cards on the same day.The ticket numbers are displayed on screens and called for in at least two languages (Mandarin and English). I can imagine in LA it would be besides English, also Spanish, Mandarin, and Korean?Potentially you could get a text to tell you before it's your turn in case you left the building.Also this opens up possibilities in designing the waiting area. It needs to have the right atmosphere, not just yet another clinically boring waiting room with a big TV screen, right?

Since voting only occurs a few times a year, perhaps one idea would be to look for places where this is already implemented and the election officials could "rent" not only the space, but also the queueing systems for the day. Options might include other government offices like DMV offices, social security offices, etc. or banks.

Thanks both of you for these productive comments.There certainly are systems for SMS queue calls but they are not cheap, and possibly overkill for occasional use unless, as Daniel says they come as part of the building "package". The challenge with using existing systems is that it seems most US elections are held on regular business days.Mark's suggestion is a good one - about displaying waiting times (which we discussed elsewhere too). The audible messages could include current waiting time every few minutes if it exceeds a particular threshold - say 10 or 15 minutes.

My apologies Stefan. It was disingenuous of me to dismiss the SMS suggestion . It deserves inclusion for those situations where it can be usefully deployed. I am struggling a little to know what sort of queue length and turnover we are dealing with here.  A queue of 40 people here (in Australia) would be in and out within 10 minutes. You are right about creating a good atmosphere in the waiting area, although I first imagined that being free to move around, sit (if there is sufficient seating), or simply be inside rather than outside would be attractive to voters.
This does solve the issue of waiting on a line, however, people with disabilities aren't being assisted through this design. Also, voting would start to be a lot like the butchers shop.

Thanks for the comments Comfort.Can you help me to make it more useful to people with disabilities? For instance if everyone can wait their turn in comfort do people with disabilities still require priority in the queue or simply appropriate assistance in accessing appropriate equipment?We will be collaborating with Stefan about this as I see his and my concepts as working to the same aims.Do you have experience of long queues for voting? If so can you give me some idea of waiting times. Here in Australia a 10 minute wait would be unusual.I should also like to know in what respect you think the voting would resemble a butchers shop. The process here is simply to better manage the queue. I have done some subjective research and advice to first time voters seems to be to complete a practice ballot prior to actually voting. Using this system one could do a practice ballot in relative comfort while waiting. Practice ballots could be available from a help/assistance desk to anyone before or after taking a ticket to join the queue.Any further thoughts you may have will be appreciated.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Paul! We really liked that your concept takes the stress and anxiety out of the voting experience  something everyone can appreciate and benefit from!During this Refinement phase, perhaps we can start thinking about how this new system might impact the actual layout and design of polling places. Might even be fun to sketch out an ideal polling place layout, with space to wait comfortably, read visual signage for hearing-impaired voters etc. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

To build on this - at the time of getting your number you could also  an estimated voting time (by knowing the number of people in front of the virtual line and the average voting rate). If the wait is long they could choose to leave the polling station to do other things (like get lunch if they are trying to vote in the lunch hour!).

Thanks Mark I will incorporate your suggestion and link it with my other concept for Voter Traffic which has an in polling station reporting of turnover compared to queue length for waiting times http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mapping-accessability-rating-and-traffic-reports./
Like where you're going with this, Paul!
Thanks Meena.I will do some incremental updates tonight and see if I can address the personas.
Bring it on! We're loving how the personas are helping folks fine-tune their ideas.

Hi Paul, great concept! I also just updated the 'elections - community fair' concept embedding the same method thinking that local banks would provide the service:) I have been looking for what this technology is called, and found it to be 'giving a sequence number,' is it correct?

Hi Cansu that sounds correct since that is what is happening mathematically. I had not really thought about what the process might be called  A similar system is used here in the fresh meat and fish sections of the supermarket. In this case they have a roll of paper tickets with numbers in sequence, you take a ticket then while you are waiting for your number to be called you can look at what you might want to buy. It only gets used when there are more people to serve than people behind the counter providing service.

comments.text: This is a good point - not just for students, but anyone who lives in rented/temporary accommodation. Every vote I have missed has been because I have moved house since the previous election and not re-registered in my new place in time. It reminds me a bit of when you have to register at a new doctors everytime you move - you don't get around to it, until you get sick - and then the last thing you want is to have to go through a long registration process before you can even get an appointment!

Very true, i know the feeling I was an architecture student and lived in a daze in the hostel ! After  that i have never been in my home town, always been shifting places and hence could never follow up with the process of the voting process !

Thanks for the honest telling of your story - which must be repeated regularly all over the country.You mention that a National ID with residency details would be useful - what other purposes could you see for such an ID?

This is interesting, was it meant to be a complement to the national identity card scheme in India? (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11433541)
Ollie, I don't think its complement to the National Identity card (AKA AADHAAR scheme) but yes both system uses the bio metric - finger print and iris scan technology.

Ah, well then perhaps it could be effectively applied in places where those kinds of biometric identity cards already exist! I imagine it would be much faster than looking through an electoral register to see if the person can vote or has already voted.

I love this!  Also, companies (for profit and not) are doing amazing things with very basic cell phones, for example helping the unbanked  bank and access that money remotely.  Often, villages share these phones for such purposes.  While confirming identification is a potential issue, it would be great to see this type of banking access via cell for voting in really remote locations.

comments.text: In my area, female genital mutilation has been practiced from time immemorial. Civil society organisations including mine-Dynamic Action Group, are doing a lot to sensitize populations on the danger associated with this. One action like you mentioned that produced results is economically empowering both female mother perpetrators and girls victims. Mothers were empowered because a pre sensitization survey indicated that one of the reasons they did it is because it generated them finances which supported them a great deal.

The Guardian had a great piece on this story recently: http://bit.ly/vlI9Jm. I loved hearing about ways that access to the bicycles allowed the girls to have more time to study, and I'd be curious to hear if they increased safety as well?
great article, thanks!

Great inspiration Tina! I think it points particularly to the role of transportation more broadly and the importance that transport can play in increasing accessibility for elections. Thanks for sharing.

redesign_the_ballot_create_a_political_g.description: Much can be done for accessibility through sound graphic design. There have been improvements in ballot design through guidelines, but how can we take clarity, iconography in political communications to the next level––before citizens get to the box?
redesign_the_ballot_create_a_political_g.creator: 570843c74a1c88405f529349168abc0c

comments.text: Melanie, thanks for sharing this inspiration. I think you're spot-on that a better core ballot design can increase usability, ease, and accessibility to ALL people. (But to be fair, I'm a bit biased, having been a co-author of the EAC document on which Ric and Jessica's "How Design Can Save Democracy" article you cite.)I also like that core design and usability principles can get us a more accessible paper ballot in the short-term, but those same principles can also be applied to an interactive, on-screen ballot experience in the future.

Great inspiration Melanie. From what I've read, it seems that development of a better graphic system for the basic paper ballot is very important, even if ultimately supplemented by online or other means of making voting more accessible. In the Challenge Brief, you may have seen the link to this page: http://www.nfb.org/nfb/HAVA_legislation.asp. If you scroll all the way down to the bottom, there is a survey of blind voters, "Blind Voter Experience Report (MSPower Point)," which suggests that larger fonts is one of their primary concerns. Also, this PDF discusses the testing of a carefully designed new ballot in Nebraska: http://www.eac.gov/assets/1/workflow_staging/Page/73.PDF. While further research is required, it seems to suggest that many aspects of the redesigned ballot improved voter experience. It also calls for a standardized, national ballot design, but interestingly points out that the main barrier is that, currently, many state and local laws determine ballot design.

I love the idea of graphic icons which are representative across disciplines. Not that these icons should take away from reading or comprehending, but rather as a guide to quickly orient someone in the search of a specificity. I am an architect and use these types of icons often in my drawings to delineate program for my client to quickly get a grip of the concept. Seems to work great!

Thanks for the note, Stacy! Funny thing. I work at an architecture firm  (but come from a social policy/learning science background) and that is where the inspiration started. We have a constant need for clear symbols and icons. Perhaps not-so-surprisingly, The Noun Project itself was actually started by a former architect who saw a huge gap in this visual language (and the fast-growing Pinterest too...)  - http://the99percent.com/articles/7125/The-Noun-Project-From-Sketchbook-To-Startup and http://mashable.com/2011/12/16/pinterest-design/. Love that you made the same connection! Rock on. We'll have to dive deeper into this concept in the next phase.

What a small world! I am currently studying architecture and over the years, I have seen the shift in students needing a comprehensive graphic language to communicate between each other. I think Rem Koolhaas was probably the inspiration that started this concept, although projects like the Noun Project have made leaps and bounds above Koolhaa's original spark. So excited to see this language being applied throughout the architecture realm and beginning to disperse into more fields.

Love running into like minds. I love that the architecture profession is beginning to morph, and it will take a movement of young designers to help shape these new ways of looking at design needs and put them into action. I look forward to collaborating. Cheers! (Ah yes - I meant the noun project was inspiration for this openIDEO inspiration. But yes, Rem Koolhaas indeed.)

if i could comment with pictures, i would have put one of florida. seriously, though... this will become more of an issue as our population ages, and as a corollary, vision deteriorates. tablet or other visual electronic devices can complement the ideas and inspirations that you mentioned above. @good stuff!

Love this idea! There are so many bland, gray-scale ballots out there. I think this has the potential to not only increase clarity, but the appeal of voting as well! An aesthetically-inviting and clear design that doesn't overwhelm could really improve the voting experience.

You bring up such a great point. We have to think about the end user - the voter. If the voter is confused and intimidated, they may not vote or vote the next time around. Also, if a voter doesn't understand the protocol and unknowingly mismarks a ballot, their vote may be thrown out.
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Hi Melanie, great inspiration!  I think design is also key for this.I was a bit in shock when I saw how complicated it is for people to vote in the US.. it seemed so confusing! No wonder I have read online about claims of "fraud by design" in previous US elections.My girlfriend works for an organisation supporting elections in African and Asian countries (like in Tunisia recently) and she mentioned the Tunisian paper ballot another day. I can't read arabic but it seemed so much simpler!   (a found a picture online here: http://www2.2space.net/images/upl_news/111023/1319359804.jpg)My experience in Brazilian elections has also been with very simple design (I posted an inspiration about that too). I'm pretty sure that's a key issue throughout this challenge. Well done for your research too!

I described about swedish system, please take a look at it, and think about what is pro's and con's of each version of ballot sheets: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/ballot-cardsI would like to hear your thoughts and comments because of your experience with many different countries systems

Terrific inspiration Melanie! I love how you've shared some great examples for us to learn more about using visual design to share information and affect behavior. It made me think about the Occupy Design site too  have you seen it? http://occupydesign.org/ (in fact, I might just add it as my own inspiration :))
Love it. Great one that I missed. Definitely add to your inspiration. Looking forward to seeing this challenge flourish. Cheers!

online_checkin_applied_to_voting_to_enab.description: Just as Southwest Airlines began letting customers skip much of the ticket registration process, so might local election boards improve the process by allowing voters to pre-print and fill out their ballots prior to entering the voting booth.
online_checkin_applied_to_voting_to_enab.creator: 92b3cfe4eb4274b7945f4b7ab67166eb

comments.text: I think this concept is really compelling, Andy. One thing to consider as it moves forward is weighing the pros and cons of actually printing a final ballot at home, or simply completing the ballot at home and printing out something like a barcode or QR code to bring to the polling place that prints an official ballot for review when you arrive in person and scan your code.Even easier for some might be being provided with a QR code on a mobile device for scanning at the polling place, instead of being required to print anything. The latest mobile-based airline boarding passes are a great example of this. Here's a quick image example in case people aren't familiar with this technology: http://www.oxidedesign.com/download/Airline_Boarding_Pass.PNG

Great analogy.One of the teams at one of our recent workshops came up with a similar concept. Not only would it help reduce lines at the polls, but it would be a real benefit for many people. If you don't work quickly, don't like being in crowds, need extra time to make decisions, or interact with the ballot, being able to mark your ballot in your own time would be great. As Vincent points out, this still means that you actually cast your ballot at a polling place, where you can be checked against the register. This is one of many great inspirations that could be fleshed out into a strong concept.

Intriguing process redesign to alleviate this polling line bottleneck, and ensure people don't feel time/peer pressured while deciding on their votes! And identification security is still maintained at the point of ballot acceptance, rather than ballot handout.There could be an issue of the desired ballot type (such as special paper) not being easily printable at home. However, you could also imagine these ballots (and maybe special machines if necessary) being available at public places like post offices and libraries, or even ballots being sent to everyone's mailbox.Hoping to see your inspiration get fleshed out during concepting ;)

Interesting discussion. Seems very similar in essence to current postal voting in Australia but applied on a wider scale.With regard to the queuing bottlenecks - they occur here in Australia too and can be a bit of a bother in bad weather. However with compulsory voting Australians have turned this civic duty into just another excuse for social activity with charity sausage sizzles, cake stalls, car washes, car boot sales and various other enterprises. The only activity positively forbidden within 100 metres of a polling booth on election Saturday is vote canvassing. Since everyone 18 or older must vote peer pressure is virtually non-existent and friends and families will often turn up together to vote making the process of queuing far more bearable.However, having said that, I too will be interested in developments arising from this inspiration.

online_checkin_applied_to_voting_to_enab.title: Online CheckIn - Applied to Voting to Enable Rapid Voting

disney_parks_experts_in_crowd_management.description: Disney wants guests to be happy and happy people don't spend hours waiting in line for a ride.  Some Disney tips and tricks for keeping lines short and waits pleasant.
disney_parks_experts_in_crowd_management.creator: d02f11d07dc073625590a7ba338ca614

comments.text: I like this analogy. Disney is great at managing crowds which is important for voters. I suspect there are other things we could learn from them as well - they are in the service business (which you could argue the voting system is in parts as well), so every interaction with the customer (e.g., buying a ticket, getting a drink, making a complaint) is designed to reinforce the experience they are trying to create. They also need to make sure this is consistently followed by the thousands of staff they employ, so learning about recruiting, training, managing staff etc. could also bring some insight.

It's a great idea... what things might we be able to have in line, especially for polls where it is easy to predict long lines (e.g. early voting, or metro areas of 'battleground' states).  Maybe a video about how to use that particular ballot?  Or even stuff that's not related, but otherwise useful info... i.e. posters that say when are leaves collected in that neighborhood?  When is the next fire-fighter fundraiser?  How much snow is too much snow to park on the streets?  etc. etc.
You're right! That would be a great time to provide people with additional information about their community that they might not be aware of.

I love the idea of pairing complementary community activities with waiting to vote. It's a perfect time to learn about what will happen if an earthquake seriously affects our neighborhood, etc. Many people feel a surge of patriotic emotion/oxytocin when they vote so maybe it would be a good time to have a fair of local volunteer organizations that people could join or at least follow.

I like the idea of the community activities. It would be a great way to get groups of younger (not quite voting age) people involved. It reminds me of some of the big city marathons - they'll have local bands set up and play along the course as well as cheer squads from local high schools cheering people on. You could have local high school groups provide entertainment (for those waiting in line) which would have the added benefit of getting them used to going out to the polls on voting day (so they'll have that habit already when they are old enough to vote).

@Andy - You're right!  That would be a great time to provide people with additional information about their community that they might not be aware of.@Erica - I like the idea of the community activities.  It would be a great way to get groups of younger (not quite voting age) people involved.  It reminds me of some of the big city marathons - they'll have local bands set up and play along the course as well as cheer squads from local high schools cheering people on.  You could have local high school groups provide entertainment (for those waiting in line) which would have the added benefit of getting them used to going out to the polls on voting day (so they'll have that habit already when they are old enough to vote).

disney_parks_experts_in_crowd_management.title: Disney Parks - Experts in Crowd Management

ez_ballot.description:
Which ballot would you choose if you had EZ or Quick ballot? 
This ballot structure of the EZ ballot works same way for all outputs regardless of modality.
ez_ballot.creator: 2c98c532e2e08a395885656721417c12

comments.text: Good idea Tina and I like the explanation through the video.  This definitely broke it down and made it pretty simple to understand and the viewer was able to see the process in action.  Great work.

This is an interesting interface for an "electronic pencil".  That is, after the voter has made all of her choices, a nearby printer should print out the actual ballot-of-record, for the voter to verify and then deposit into a secure ballot box.  But without a paper ballot-of-record, this suffers from all of the defects of paperless voting.

Hi Tina, Yilin, Xiao and Jon, This is a great start at a really difficult problem. Finding a way to make the voting interaction work well in a linear interaction would be a big step forward, especially on some of the long US ballots. Lots of areas to explore.
Tina's canny EZ Ballot concept was a winner on our Voting Challenge Challenge. Her prototype video & visualisations were a brilliant additions to the Realisation phase. Rock on Tina!

Well done Tina - the simple and intuitive approach has such advantages for providing interaction with ballots for all circumstances (including our proportional systems here in Australia). Like Andrew Baranak's Ipad idea Its portability makes it ideal for a variety of situations, including both potential voting vans but also conventional curbside voting. I'm sorry it was so difficult for me to do justice to collaborating across all concepts in the refinement phase.I am looking forward to updates of progress during realisation.
Tina, what a great video you put together! Nice job refining your concept here.

Tina, I can clearly visualize how EZ Ballot enables people to vote from anywhere. As Priyanka mentioned in her "Voting Vans" concept, the EZ Ballot could be used at a designated polling station (such as a voting van) and it could also be carried anywhere to help those who couldn't easily visit the polling station.I am also impressed by EZ Ballot's intuitive interface. Whenever a machine asks me a yes/no question (for instance, "Do you want to delete this photo?"), I always find myself responding to the questions quickly...sometimes even unconsciously selecting the wrong choice. Maybe the EZ Ballot could have some designs to prevent people from making their choices too fast? Such as freezing the yes/no function for 10 seconds to ensure each voter took some time to understand the questions being asked?

Tina, I like the way you have simplified the voting process - it's one that might work well for audio ballots or for single-switch interaction. But, I wonder about unintended consequences of breaking one contest up into multiple screens (one screen per candidate). There is a lot of documentation of the impact of order within a contest giving advantage to the first names listed. (That's why almost all states have a formula for determining order or rules for rotating names on the ballot.)  How would you make sure that voters were aware of all of the choices in each contest?Once the voter made a choice, would they see the other candidates, or would the system just skip ahead to the next contest?

Whitney, Thank you for your thoughtful comments. I've been thinking about how voters will be made aware of all the choices in each contest in this concept. What if we have the first introductory screen that displays all the candidates names visually and with audio before they select their vote? For example, the screen will speak we have A, B, C, D, E for president. You are allowed to have only one vote. Please hit the next button on the right side of tablet when you are ready to vote This first screen should be a requirement for voters to see and/or hear all of the candidate options first.Then, when the voter has made a choice, the system would move to the next contest. However, before finally casting all their votes, the system would display and read out a review page so that voters can confirm or their choices, or change them if they wish.

I think this problem is solvable from my reading of the concept. The screen may say "your choices for President are D,B,A,E, and C" The next screen will then say, "Do you want to vote for D" ...no."Do you want to vote for B...?"etc. I say that, though I am fairly sure that some states require that all the candidates for a particular office have to appear on the same page.

This seems like a great solution. Simplifying the process makes it super simple for most people to access. By combining audio and visual feedback to the user, you are basically ensuring accessibility. Where exactly would these stations be? At current poll stations?
The idea is great, I can clearly visualize a simple voting system like this that works for all.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist Tina! We appreciated how streamlined and intuitive your concept is, and we loved your sketches!During this Refinement phase, let's think about ways to incorporate some of the great feedback and questions that folks have shared below. There's lots more room for iteration and development, and we're excited to see what you come up with. For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Tina, what an impressive concept!  I like how you are thinking about providing voters different options depending on their needs and making it simpler. The two-button input voting system and the simpler screen might also be useful for voting applications on a mobile device.I'd like to know what you are thinking about doing for contest selection.  For example, will the system go through each candidate and each race? Or will the system prompt the user for the race first, e.g. "Do you want to vote for president?" Each has different benefits and limitations.
Very intuitive concept Tina!This could also be implemented on current touch screens by devoting areas on left and right as the yes no buttons.

The nice thing about real buttons is that they are tactile and provide affordance that screens don't have. One of the other concepts suggested that a standard tablet could be adapted for the more limited interactions of elections by putting it into a case. For example, hiding the "home" button on an iPad, or making a tactile button that mimicks a touch point.

Found the other concept that shows a hardware adjustment to limit a general-purpose device to voting functions: iPad Absentee Voting http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ipad-absentee-voting/
Yes you are right about the tactile aspects of real buttons Whitney and I do like this concept on that basis. I was thinking of the Ipad Absentee Voting as the other option.
Would a third button be confusing. I was thinking that the original could be "Next" and "Previous" with a third "Yes/Select" and No would be default without need for button.

Hi Laura,thanks for sharing this post, you made me remind to this great Italian dancer, Simona Atzori, born without arms.
