accessibility_map_v.2.description: A polling station map that shows which station can be easily accessed by people in wheelchairs and also shows with which voting mechanisms a station is equipped. Creating awareness and giving information on billboards, sport events, malls, lobbies.
accessibility_map_v.2.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: I like the concept. About the braille version... tactile maps can be really hard to understand, it is an art in itself to create a good one. So I guess for the braille version it is probably most effective if it is a text based version. Maybe a list ordered on distance or user satisfaction, with the exact street address. The address can be given to a taxi driver for instance or used as input for a navigation system.And when you are making a digital text version it could be a table where you can sort on the various characteristics. This would help people that are not good with maps. It could make it also an interesting tool to measure the level of accessibility in a district. This could possibly add pressure to policy makers.

I really like the idea. Many people have smartphones, iPads and other mobile devices with wifi or 3G services. Since many people cannot change their voting district, what if the voter could use their mobile device or laptop to download a digital copy of the map and input their address to be told exactly where they need to go in either step by step direction or through gps.
I would also want to add directions by public transport. Not everyone owns or can drive a car ....

Stefan, it is a great idea to have apps and physical maps at the same time. I like the concept of posting physical maps not only to give information about location, but also to create awareness that election day is coming. I also like the idea of clear icons that could tell you vital  information about a poll station with one look. Pictures speak better than words, especially if the icons you use are adapted from icons we see daily.

I thoroughly agree - the lack of easily recognisable icons was a design flaw in my mapping type concept, and the exposure for the election, the polling places, what they offer and possibly new technologies could all be incorporated into physical as well as apps and online mapping.

Congratulations Stefan for being selected! I like the idea that the map could also be used to ask for being assigned to another poll stations, or maybe to just advocate for more poll stations addressing the needs of voters with accessibility issues.I also like the information as well as co-creation aspect of it. It might allow to make transparent the gaps between the legislation and the reality of the poll stations. For one of my inspirations I did some research on the situation in France and realized that although there was a law regarding accessibility very few poll stations actually implemented it. There was also a video in one of the inspirations where a person in a wheel chair was trying to go to vote but the "accessible entrance" was not open...Per the openIDEO team comment, it will be great if you could try various designs with a few people - to see how they interpret it, but also maybe what they would want to know.
This idea is great. I like how you were able to incorporate a physicalMap and also an app into this design.

Stefan, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We were especially excited that your concept both raised awareness and provided practical information to voters.During this Refinement phase, it might be fun to think about taking your fab sketches to the streets and getting real user feedback in subways or tube stations? What do people like? What makes sense? Or what's confusing? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Your concept makes everyone aware of location. I like it
You might like to look at Colour Coded Votinghttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/color-coded-voting/ to see if there are any things to incorporate for refinement phase.
absolutely! one could start by choosing the color that is on the voting card, and then it fires up the polling stations within that colors voting area!

Well reconstructed Stefan I will link back to this from my Tactile and Narrative Maps too although their focus is more upon navigating near and inside polling places it is vital that people know how to get to their polling places and what they will find when they get there.

Nice one, Stefan  and great that you've soldiered right along and taken the comments into consideration. Great collaborative attitude! Loving what you've got going on here  and that you've developed some sketches to flesh things out further.
Agreed Meena

comments.text: Sidi, I really like this concept. There are so many aspects of voting that can be confusing or difficult -- from trying to figure out where to vote to actually getting to the polls. Having a voting buddy would make it easier to work through these problems together, share information or even share a ride. I look forward to seeing how you can further develop this concept and I'd encourage you to take a look at some of the specific accessibility needs of people with disabilities.

Thank you, Daniel. I have added a few concepts, like developing an App to help find a buddy(ies) and staying connected with them till voting and after. I am also working on other concepts and hopping to post them soon.

Find buddy to hook up with and vote based on:1. Date of birth2. Opposite party (encourage debate and learning from opposites)3. Zip Code4. Sports interests5. Coffee fans 6. Single parents7. International buddy voter8. Voter of same cultural heritage9. School 10. etc.

Great to see you drawing on your personal experiences here, Sidi. As we are focusing specifically on supporting independent and private voting for people whose access is limited  perhaps you and others would like to discuss scenarios for including folks with challenges around language, visibility, mobility, comprehension, etc within the scope of your concept. We're looking forward to where the conversation might lead!

_70_of_lean_transformations_fail_due_beh.description: While at McKinsey I applied Lean techniques (an improvement philosophy pioneered at Toyota) to many organisations such as hospitals. My key learning: behavior interventions are a key and often overlooked element of holistic system design
_70_of_lean_transformations_fail_due_beh.creator: bdb2a550eedb3a50a53c86c353853d46

comments.text: A holistic view of things is needed in development and progress reason why IDEO launches challenges for organizations, so as to have holistic views from entrants, then exploit to come out with best of decisions.

Thanks Takang! I agree, the opportunity to get a holistic solution is a great benefit of OpenIDEO. Of course, holistic can cover many things, such as groups of voters, geographies, disabilities etc. What I was trying to convey in this post is that holistic also means looking at the 'softer' side of design (i.e., mindsets and behaviors of individuals), so for example, if you look at other places where organisations have to provide a great service to many different types of people (arguably a part of what you are trying to do in the voting process), such as hospitals and hotels, many of the great examples you can look at have a heavy focus on these 'softer' elements (e.g., Ritz Carlton (the international hotels group) have a rigorous process to recruit, train and mange their staff, and have some innovative approaches, such as each member carries a card reinforcing that 'Guest Satisfaction' is their highest mission - it is titled "We are Ladies and Gentlemen serving Ladies and Gentlemen" - which helps to create mindsets and behaviors that are in line with the business strategy, but more importantly are applied consistently across all locations.). It is things like this that I believe can be applied alongside the 'harder' systems design choices to create a stronger solution.
Welcome to OpenIDEO Mark and cheers for your thoughtful inspiration! It's going to be incredible helpful as we start designing concepts next week. Hope to see more of you in our challenge.
Thanks Ashley! Looking forward to being a part of this.

_70_of_lean_transformations_fail_due_beh.title: "70% of Lean transformations fail due behavioral effects", McKinsey. How to be part of the 30%!

comments.text: Hi Ryan, cheers for sharing this very personal account with us. If you get a chance, it would be great if you could provide a bit more background on the article and why you wrote it (for instance, folks might not check out the direct link and realize your article was published in 2008). Adding a bit more context to your post will help all of us get up to speed and understand your story even better. Thanks again  looking forward to seeing more of you in our challenge!

Yes, thanks for the comment Ashley. This article was written in the middle of the general election, 2008. Why did I write it? I found my position kind of hilarious and somewhat emblematic of many, many others at the time. I posted it here in an effort to take us back a few years to that time when many of us were more involved in the political process than we had ever been... and most likely discovering its operational quirks and, hopefully, opportunities for innovation. That's how it has worked out for me. I have an idea that I piloted during this years mayoral race that I'm excited to contribute during the concepting stage. Thanks!Ryan
Great insight Ryan, thanks for this update! And excited to see what you have in store for Concepting :)

voting_.description: As I kept reading various inspirations, I wondered how was the voting experience for people with disabilities in France where I vote. I could not interview anyone but I went online to search: "Voting when you're disabled? It's complicated!
voting_.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Building a system to trust for those with less senses seems to bee a key issue!
Great job with the research Anne-Laure! The tricks/workarounds certainly point to design opportunities.
Thanks Vincent. I am always fascinated by how innovative people are to make things work and the practices they develop are indeed great inspirations for design.

I notice that you ask the question: How is the voting experience actually for people with disabilities? It is definately an important questions to raise, and I think it is interesting to go through the inspirations here on openideo and notice, that only very few of the posts actually give an answer straight from people with disabilities. Why have no more been able to interview any peope with disabilities? Because we do not know people with disabilities? Because we are afraid to actually ask them? Because they are not engaging in openideo themselves?Your questions raises a lot of other questions. Questions for which the answers could learn us important lessons on the life of people with disabilities.

Hi Tanja,thanks for your comment. I agree that thinking of the experience of voting when you're disabled is key. I personally did some desk research, looking for interviews and blogs, as I did not know any one with disabilities. Yet your question about why are they not more interviews is a good one. Fortunately, there are still several very interesting stories under the empathy mission that can help us understand.

start_in_high_school.description: Use avatars in online virtual worlds to prepare high school students with and without disabilities for voting by immersing them in the entire voting experience from how to obtain information, navigate the polling place and cast a vote.
start_in_high_school.creator: 48b9710b030247dbff4438442287ece7

comments.text: Not sure if teenagers would be excited to play a video game about voting

this isn't a video game, but total immersion of an online persona in a voting environment.  the use of avatars as online personas in virtual worlds (e.g., second life) is widely used by individuals of all ages and is currently being used successfully to mentor high school students with disabilities in math and science.

Speaking of gaming, however, elements of gaming can be used in a virtual world (VW) environment to increase participation and prolong interest. The affordances of VW platforms like Second Life make group and community participation quite dynamic, and it wouldn't be difficult to take advantage of these features to provide increased agency. I won't attempt to list all the possibilities in this comment, but suffice to say group challenges and team exploration could be explored in a VW setting much more easily than in real life (logistics, geography are limiting factors) or with simple text, email, or static online tools. The persistent, 3-dimensional power of VW can not only provide possibilities for simulation not available elsewhere, but for communication, interaction, and creation of persistent artifacts within the environment, you name it. Imagine a team challenge for students in which they had to build the perfectly accessible polling place in-world ...
Great points Robert.Virtual Worlds are increasingly used in education.

Nice one, Jon! Reminds me of the way that Urgent Evoke (a crash course in changing the world) worked: http://www.urgentevoke.com/ I wonder if there might be learnings from their initiative to build up this concept? comments.text: Anne, I was living in India for US-election season and found it very hard to vote as well. Luckily we had a Democrats-Abroad group (I'm not sure if there is a Republicans-Abroad) group that helped us with all the specific steps.  However, it was still challenging and time consuming, and I'm not sure all the US travelers abroad knew of this service. I'd also love for there to be a non-partisan service that is as involved and as supportive as the group in India was. It really felt like an online community.

Hi Anne,I spent the past five months in Denmark and in fact I was fascinated by the voting system there! I was going to write about it now but I saw your post when I searched if someone already wrote about it. I do not know about being abroad, but my friend who, had an injury by then, could vote easily by mail..https://www.borger.dk/Emner/samfund-og-rettigheder/politik-og-valgsystem/valgsystemet/folketingsvalg-og-folkeafstemninger/Sider/brevstemme-til-folketingsvalg-og-folkeafstemninger.aspx#RichHtmlField2Bookmark1

comments.text: Hmm, I think the option of a proxy is important. Not only for people with disabilities, but also for those on business travel.But... how can we use that without limiting the independence of people? I mean: needing a proxy makes people dependent on others, while they might prefer to have the option to vote themselves.

Indeed Arjan, this inspiration doesn't respond to wider issues of accessibility and I didn't really intend to address all issues with regards to making elections more accessible. I suppose that providing many options for voting only helps catering for the many needs of people, which should hopefully contribute to accessibility and this challenge. I just thought of mentioning the "post" and "proxy" options here as I haven't seen those posted elsewhere on the site yet.To the independency point, I guess using the post could be a nice way to help those who can't get to the polling stations but otherwise have a post box within reach as we have here in the UK.

national_voting_id_card_for_usa.description: Looking at the hotch-potch of ways to register for voting in USA perhaps an integrated national approach is the fundamental first step.
national_voting_id_card_for_usa.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: One good thig is we have been using this long ago as a basis for registration. Bt what happens in corrupt economies where even foreigners who are not supposed to have natioal IDs do acquire them?
Your are right Takang  it is almost impossible to overcome the problems caused by corruption at political level.

(Since this it "built upon" http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-we-ve-learned-from-a-century-of-better-than-99-turnout-in-australia/ )...Australians do not have a national voting ID card. When you arrive at a polling booth you just supply some ID from any agency, or if you don't have any ID on you at the time then you sign a declaration to that effect. We do have a federally-maintained electoral roll, though.This does leave open the possibility of impersonation -- in fact it is quite trivial -- but does make multiple voting still hard to pull off.

As you say Greg we dont have an ID card is Oz but I thought one in the USA might give them half a chance of getting decent rolls similar to what we have.I also wanted to gauge feelings about this as it seems a number of other countries have a National ID that doesn't appear to cause philosophical problems.

sensually_maximized_tommy_ballot_201c_se.description: Why is a ballot only visual or auditory? This ballot contains as many input and output methods as possible for universal usage. All the tactile, visual and auditory info is embedded in the ballot, enabling all devices to interact with it.
sensually_maximized_tommy_ballot_201c_se.creator: 2c98c532e2e08a395885656721417c12

comments.text: Great to have you Georgia Tech-heads join us on this challenge! Fab exploration  though I'm a bit confused about the term "tommy ballot"  Can you help me (and any others who are in the dark) to understand this term? Hoping to see more of you all on OpenIDEO  chiming in on others' concepts too.

Tommy was the protagonist of The Who's 1969 rock opera "Tommy" which was inducted into the Rock Hall of Fame and has sold 20 million copies worldwide.  Tommy, traumatized by seeing his father kill his mother's lover becomes blind, deaf and mute. In the meantime, Tommy becomes a pinball wizard: He's a pin ball wizardThere has got to be a twist.A pin ball wizard,S'got such a supple wrist.How do you think he does it? I don't know!What makes him so good?'He ain't got no distractionsCan't hear those buzzers and bells,Don't see lights a flashin'Plays by sense of smell.Always has a replay,'N' never tilts at allThat deaf dumb and blind kidSure plays a mean pin ball.The last song of the album is See me, feel me. The chorus goes: See meFeel meTouch meHeal me.Thus the reference to see me, feel me, touch me, hear me.

I like the idea of a smell-based ballot. Campaigns could send out literature with the candidate's party's smell on them. That same smell is then replicated on the ballot. It might mean that people would vote simply because of the smell and not for any other reason. Then again, that's no worse than some of the reasoning voters use today.

sensually_maximized_tommy_ballot_201c_se.title: Sensually-maximized Tommy Ballot - “See Me, Feel Me, Touch Me,  Hear Me”

re_design_a_place_that_encourages_voting.creator: 19d366a78e9bc2172eaf549b52b71019

comments.text: Hi Anne-Laure, I understand where you are coming from. But when it comes to people picking poling offices there is hardly a design concept in mind, even when choosing the venue. I thought it could be improved upon inexpensively and the points I included don't have to be all implemented, just considered when choosing the venue and simple but effective modifications can be made.

hi Ohood, thanks for your concept. I find the dimensions you use interesting. Yet, you seem to assume that the polling station is a space designed only for elections. However, polling stations are usually spaces that have other functions (schools, city halls, etc.) that are used for an election. How could you imagine these design dimensions enacted in a space while the space has its own constraints?

Anne-Laure - you make a good point that the spaces are used for different purposes and there will be variety in shape etc. There will also be cost to make changes to lots of different spaces. I suppose the question is whether there is a way to cheaply change spaces temporarily with different configuration - perhaps a modular system that could be re-used over time?

Mark, my main point was about being aware of the constraints (and maybe affordances) of spaces used as poll stations rather than thinking as if we could design it from scratch. Your point about modular configurations made me think of Paul's inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/flat-pack-polling-booths/

The flat-pack system with cardboard booths, ballot boxes, barriers  and sometimes even desks works well here. There is a preference for large open areas to reconfigure and good demographic knowledge together with mandatory voting really helps good planning.As you say AL places like school and city halls are often used which also means that at least rudimentary seating can be made available if queues are long.
Nice idea. I really agree with the concept of creating a more voting oriented place to encourage voting. A well designed voting space can provide a pleasant experience for voters.
thank you, I have

comments.text: Your comments are very apt Florian.The proper representation of candidate values, views and priorities.Once these are made available in a form that allows as many people as possible to see and understand them the process becomes more open and people's votes are better informed.In the end we have to trust that when a government is formed they will do what they have promised - although if we are on the losing side we will have to hope we get an early chance to change the government.In answer to your last question I guess it is necessary for interested people to ask questions and share what they discover with others well before election day. Of course where discussion is free and open the candidates themselves should want to get their message across clearly to as many people as possible.

Thx Paul for your contribution! I think that there is a huge box of opportunity for the inspiration phase. I was trying to look on Youtube if we have some candidates that presents specifics of their program and i did not found good videos when Youtube is the largest video website. That would be amazing that each candidate has to have a 15 minutes Youtube video (or other mean) on specific of this program. It would also be pretty great for accountability (we can debate on the video once he want to be re-elected). But it might be better for "inspiration" phase... :) I am going to write a post on that next week.

comments.text: Hi JustinExcellent concept and one that can be incorporated into a range of scenarios during the refinement phase. Here is a link to one of our local volunteer radio stations which although established for a different purpose would serve as part model, especially since it is already aimed at part of the target group for this challenge. There is a flash based site but I deliberately chose the text based link to include here:http://www.7rph.org.au/txt-index.html Sorry I didn't get around to commenting earlier.
This link may provide a little more background toohttp://7rph.org.au/history.html CheersPaul

We also have a government initiated national SBS (Special Broadcasting Service) both radio and television that segments its foreign language programs. For USA which is the main focus of this challenge there is the PBS (Public Broadcast Service) that might take up the opportunity.http://www.pbs.org/

Sorry just keep thinking of linkages for this excellent idea.Priyanka has a concept for story telling that might fit well here for possible content toohttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/tell-a-story-enact-a-scene/

Great stuff Justin  I especially like that you've tapped into radio as the primary outlet; it not only reaches new language audiences but also people without reliable internet access. A couple of questions to help you develop this further:1. Who would run this radio service? The government? A nonpartisan organization? If it's the latter, how might this radio broadcast build on or be different from the BBC, NPR or another existing news source?2. What kind of broadcasts might the radio show promote? Would it just be election day process/explanations? Or perhaps it could include interviews with other voters, or even some of the candidates?We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.
Thanks for helping me refine the concept! Ideas taken!

_ready_to_vote_toolkit.creator: 88c48baa5a7499a0af42ab60addbeaf5

comments.text: Great ideas here, Zhou! We're looking forward to collaborative discussions and builds as our Concepting phase continues. You can add any thoughts from other collaborators that you like to your concept by hitting the Update Entry button up on the right.

Another thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve.

Zhou - I like this concept; in some places there has already been a lot done on accessibility already (e.g., in the Challenge intro video they talk about all the great stuff they have in place) and as such there may be great benefit in ensuring the voters know what support they already have.

I wonder if you even need to have a way to identify the voters for this sort of information. Could this toolkit be available to anyone who wants the information? The material could be in several formats to allow everyone to pick the one that suits them the best - audio, print, visual etc.

Thanks...really like the "tool kit" concept for comprehensive voter education and for distributing simplified, useful instructions.  Regardless of the voting system design adopted, this concept is reminder of the critical nature of the instructional element.

I love the simplification idea of a tool kit and agree that the kit needs to hold all information without being too overwhelming!Did you see my 'Fast Facts' inspiration? http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/fast-facts/someone has tried this kind of idea but not executed it that well... might be a nice area to look at and learn from!

Hi Zhou, great concept! I like how you've thought through the different pieces of information voters need to prepare to cast a ballot. You might want to check out our Guiding Principles for this challenge, particularly the section that discusses how we're using the word 'accessibility' here http://bit.ly/AiJnLW. Perhaps it'll inspire you to think about the different elements of this toolkit that can support independent and private voting for people with different accessibility needs? Looking forward to seeing how your concept develops!

comments.text: My polling place was just changed to be "more accessible".  The new place has more handicapped parking splots, but is much farther away from most voters in the precinct.  I predict lower turnout from nondrivers, especially since our only public transit is book-ahead paratransit that is full during certain times of day.  You could get to the polls, but could you get home?

Hi Shane, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

accessibility_starts_outside_the_polling.title: Accessibility starts outside the polling station

voting_via_atm_network_.description: Using the existing and ubiquitous ATM network, voters are identified (bank card pin + national identification number to ensure uniquness). Can vote directly or print a securely coded ballot to send or hand-in in person. ATMs are disabled friendly.
voting_via_atm_network_.creator: bf65247cb92e7cacb127c0990dcd93df

comments.text: This might have already been addressed, apologies if so. But, a large part of the population doesn't have a bank card, or the ability to get one. Would that preclude them from being able to use this system?

If not using credit card ids it goes all the way back to my original concept question - National Voting ID? not being in US I dont know how many have no card but I expect it is significant - however the concept is certainly visionary and ahead 'first past the post' in the evaluation popularity poll.

@Paul - attempts to implement a national voting ID have received huge pushback, the UK is a particularly good example of this. Therefore, impact can best be achieved by leveraging existing platforms. @Taylor - I'd take issue with "the ability to get one". Much of the unbanked could qualify for basic banking services. Some of the approaches used in developing markets might be useful in this regard. Indeed, this should be encouraged as there is a ton of evidence supporting inclusion in a formal financial system as a means of economic development - and indeed it is the poorer states that have the most unbanked population.http://firefinance.blogspot.com/2009/12/cash-check-without-bank-account.html @Both - the bottom line is though that if voting via ATMs were to be implemented then it would be a compliment to the current system. Those that it would benefit most are the people that do not have time / ability to get to particular voting stations. It is a secure, accessible way of making voting more available. Assuming the unbanked population can already vote through the normal means, the would, of course, still be able to do so.

Agreed James - similar resistance here to national ID despite (ironic) acceptance of compulsory electoral registration - I also have no issue with complementary nature of the ATM voting option and I do think it is a very innovative suggestion.
I agree about the irony. Thank you for your comments. It has been a very enjoyable design challenge and I've enjoyed the collaboration.

Additionally, the video tape security from the atm is very nice for safety reason and has to vote text to your phone for confirmation just like when you successfully transfer the money. On the other hand, this might congest the traffic for people who want to actually use the ATM so perhaps if you can make it a norm to have 2 voting days (say over the weekend) with periodic update on TV of how many people have voted and also area that there are a lot of unused atm, then it might be nice than to have to pay to make machines just for voting day

Certainly envisaged that you could vote ahead of time (hence could choose the postal route). The electronic option would basically see your vote sit in an escrow until they are released for official counting (instant obviously) on the voting day.Making voting more modern definitely has the possibility to increase user engagement and the interactivity between the voter and the system.
This is brilliant!  ATMs are ubiquitous.  Furthermore, there are basically five operators of ATMs in the US so this could be implemented almost overnight.  Good work.
Thanks. Appreciate the positive feedback!
I like this concept and would like to see an ATM as "The" ATM since Voting is a celebration for anyone exercising one's right. Connecting the empathy when using "The" ATM to vote
I like that capitalizing one letter helps improve the empathetic experience .

This video illustrates, ATM cupcake, the empathy I am referring to. In the case of voting, people are engaged to use the ATM and as token of celebration, voting, they get a badge or flag to make that emotional connection http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgzxHNq8Bek
How does this address the issue of disabled people?

Hi Rondelle and James, I found this. You can use those images:http://www.engelsizbankacilik.com/ortopedik-engelliler-icin-engelsiz-atm/default.aspxApparently there are ATMs for different disabilities, but I do not know if they fit all.

This is helpful, thank you. I'm going to do a big update tomorrow and focus on some of the issues raised such as precisely how it helps disabled people and some of the security measures.One quick note though on Rondelle's point. Legislation in 2010 (building on a 1990 Act), made it obligatory for ATMs to be equipped with speech-enabled technology, headset jacks and other items so visually impaired customers can use the machines without assistance. Obviously it is not an issue for deaf people. Wheelchair access is the norm now for ATMs inside banks. It is obviously not an issue for those on the street.
You may also want to check out the video posted by Vincent during the inspiration phase -- http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-s-it-like-to-be-blind/
What about people who are bedridden or those in institutions.

Great question Rondelle. While we are trying to design concepts that can adapt to different situations, it's not necessarily possible to have a one-size-fits-all approach in our concepts. One thought though: I've often seen ATMs in hospitals. Might it be possible for patients, for instance, to use the ATM in a hospital to cast their vote on-site? It's not a perfect solution but it's one way to think about bringing the technology to people where they are.
Agreed. Easier to get people to an ATM than a particular voting booth...
I'm loving the new sketches you added to this concept James!
Thank you!

This idea interests me but wouldn't it be expensive to input software and hardware to increase the privacy and security of the ATM? Should we instead use the money paid to use the ATM to fund the new ATM that will incorporate the voting process? We have 4 years to fund it!

Much of the security would be back end stuff - basically involve a separate server. This wouldn't change irrespective of the machine in question. ATMs are generally now pretty flexible because of required updates over the last few years. In their current state the vast majority of the ATMs have the basic hardware to incorporate this service and software, by its nature, is completely scalable.I'm chatting to an ATM security expert today / tomorrow and will incorporate details in a big updated.

Great Idea, but incorporating this kind of feature into the ATM software will take a while simple because of the nature of transaction and it will also raise questions like in how many different bank ATMs we need to incorporate this feature.. because not all citizens will have account in one bank .. And different banks will have their own process to upgrade and central bank will have their own policies and regulations in incorporating this feature.

In the US this is less of an issue because of the interbank network which connects all the banks - the data is more centralized. In recent years ATM owners have been forced to make some substantial upgrades to their ATMs to make them more accessible. The same would apply here. Such an initiative would be part of a major overhaul of the voting system and would require multi-party buy-in.

I have a comment or suggestion about this and many of the wonderful technology-based solutions posted her to make voting more accessible.  I think we need to better understand how technological applications (smart phones, cell phones, apps, computers, ATMs,Internet) are used by different populations and, more importantly, how information is accessed and shaped in different communities.  As an example, people may use cell phones in rural as frequently as in urban areas or across race and ethnicity, but they may use them more frequently in different ways.  According to one report  people over 65 years of age use cell phones to text and to take photographs.   But they do not use them for entertainment or social networking nearly as often as their younger counterparts.  Another suggests that cell phone use differs across race and ethnicity.  How will these different uses impact the perception and adoption of voting technologies and information? How can we harness existing technology uses to make voting more comfortable and accessible, and how can (or should) we prepare communities for rapidly changing technology applications in the future?

Interesting comments Frances.I imagine that current systems will remain in parallel for some time. In Australia replacing the simple paper ballot for the majority is highly unlikely. The stats are right about us oldies too - I'm 61 and use my cell phone almost exclusively for family and work calls, the occasional text message and even less frequent photo.
Totally agree that systems should exist in parallel. I view these innovations as incrementally beneficial, but not a perfect one-size-fits-all solution.

I have a few thoughts here, some minor, some major (it's a bunch of thoughts actually, partially because one of my concepts is quite similar, so it's something I've thought about. :)"voters are identified (bank card pin + National SSN number to ensure uniquness"--it's probably not necessary to do the SSN check, since the bank back-end can do that. Moreoever, not all states use SSNs in their voting registries. Virginia I know requires it per their state constitution (eh, Virginia is weird.) My Ohio doesn't, but some records may have it. (I know you said for example, so I'm just being unnecessarily difficult. :) "These busy politically inactive people will surely buy something with cash in the days and weeks leading up the the election."--This is a minor thing, but the minute I read that I assumed you were from NYC or a similarly dense city. I've lived in NYC and cash still plays a big role there. It doesn't here in Ohio. In NYC little shops get persnickety about taking cards on small transactions,but that's rare here. In NYC the waiter almost always delivers one check to the table, whereas here waiters more likely assume that they will be delivering a check for each person at the table than not. The point being that many people don't visit ATMs here, so they will be making a special trip. On a related note, in NYC you can turn a corner and see a little room with half a dozen bank machines and across the street there will be another little room with half a dozen bank machines. We don't have that here, even in our most dense urban areas. I'm typing this from my parent's house, which is a 15 minute drive from town, where there are 4-5 banks, and each one only has one machine (always a drive-up machine. Obviously I'm not including non-bank ATMs, found in convenience stores and gas stations, which I suspect aren't really suitable for this purpose.) "A voting receipt would be printed (with choices scrambled in code)." --If the choices are scrambled in code, can the voter unscramble them in some way (as a way of verifying how they voted)? Is that code unique to that voter (so that only the voter can unscramble them) or is the code universal so that anyone can unscramble the ballot? If so, what does scrambling achieve?Small addendum--because write-in candidates are found on ballot, the ATMs used will also have to have touchscreens--so that write-in candidates can be typed in by the voter. (Most new machines are that way, so that's not a big issue.)Finally, one thing to take into account is how long each machine will be used. I uploaded a sample of a ballot that I had in 2008 (it's at http://www.scribd.com/doc/86050712/Sample-ballot-Franklin-County-2008) It's a pretty lengthy ballot, and it would be entirely reasonable for a person to take 10-15 minutes to vote it. If you're annoyed with my points, take heart: look closely at the ballot linked and you'll see my name as a candidate. I lost that election terribly. :)
This is helpful. Much of this is / will be covered in the update today / tomorrow.

James, congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We got excited thinking about the possibilities that this concept presents in meeting people at moments in their daily routines and offering a secure voting experience on the go.During this Refinement phase, let's think about what the voting process and experience might look like using an ATM. Perhaps there's even an opportunity to consider how this concept could match up with some of the other online/mobile app voting concepts in our shortlist? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.
Thank you!

Hi James, like that your concept tries to increase accessibility by leveraging where people already go, and takes advantage of a pre-existing security & identity system.A big challenge here is how to motivate/incentivize all the players in the ATM ecosystem (banks, independent store-placed ATMs, OEMs, network providers, etc.) to retrofit their various systems (whether software and/or hardware in some cases), which is really no small task.This is a significant hurdle, likely entailing substantial costs.May also want to consider leveraging the online banking system. Here's  concept on online voting ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/ ) & leveraging internet banking authentication ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/using-internet-banking-as-a-portal-to-voting-online/ ) for reference.

All very helpful. Thank you. Indeed, getting all the banks to act is a challenge but was overcome with 1990 and 2010 legislation regarding access for the blind. If there is legislation requiring them to act then they do. Clearly such a radical revision to the way people can vote would require wholesale political support. As such, if such an approach were to be accepted then banks would have to act. I think they wouldn't mind too much either because it gets people using their machines...

James, you might want to consider how this could work with the proposed "Mark Anywhere" concept - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/Basically, you could use the ATMs as a ballot marking device. The voter could get a printed ballot at the end -- it would not need to be scrambled because the voter could create as many of these as he or she wanted. The voter would have to mail or drop off the ballot in person. The election officials would still be responsible for authenticating the voter, so this eliminates many of the technical challenges of using ATMs.

Yes - I like "Mark Anywhere" and certainly agree that it would be a simple solution eliminating some of the security questions: the ATM marking the ballot would only know your choices for that instant when you input them - it doesn't get sent anywhere etc. Indeed, noting that some people might not be comfortable with electronically sending the vote, mailing it was introduced in the first iteration of the concept. If the technical challenges could be resolved then it would be a cleaner solution to be able to vote instantly electronically... I'm looking into some of the more involved aspects of that at the moment.
This may be a be off task but is the ATM powered by corn based fuel? If not then would it be possible?

Big debate whether corn based fuel has environmental benefits - largely popular in the US because of the tariffs making it cost effective to growth it, whereas other biofuels are shunned despite being much more environmentally friendly... this is also off topic.I don't think it would be possible because ATMs I think that they are hooked up to the electicity grid but also have their own power supply in the form of a battery.
Will voters be charged a fee for using an ATM machine that does not belong to their bank?

For this service, that would be a big no! In Europe no-one is charged a fee for withdrawing money as all the banks have an agreement not to charge one-another's customers. I suppose in the States they'd still be able to charge if you decided to withdraw money at the same time as voting!

Great concept. I was concerned at first, because, for portability and accessibility to the masses this is great. But at far as access by the disability community, many ATMs still aren't accessible to those in wheelchairs or with physical impairments. But my using the online accounting network access, it gets rid of that concern completely. Awesome.
Great idea - assuming you nail the security.... Surely there is a reason for only being able to vote in one place?
This is a wonderful idea... congrats on the feature here!

James, I think this is an excellent idea. It could certainly be a solution in targeting much more of the voting population. It could also solve other issues. Remember the case of Sheffield (UK), where people left work and queued for several hours to vote before being turned away when the polling station closed at 22.0. While this was a rare instance, the dispersal of people across cities to various ATM points would undoubtedly be more efficient!http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8666537.stm
Great point!

Very interesting concept - basically turning ATM's into voting kiosks.Would complement some additional proposals for voting away from polling places and fit well with Whitney's Mark Anywhere concept, especially the idea of restricting the completed ballot to just the voters choices not the whole range of options on the blank ballot paper.Would also produce something like the bus ticket size ballot I developed a concept for.

I love how your idea propose the use of an existing infrastructure. Specially the repurpose of private/commercial technology for public service. At the same time, I think  it could be challenging to manage the bank-voting association, just in terms of perception. Particularly with regard of the climate of distrust of financial institutions I was wondering if that's something that you have been considering.
Absolutely. There is SOME distrust, that is true. But not enough for people not to use them. Banks still look after all of our money and we still all use ATMs to get hold of it!
Yes, I didn't meant distrut of the reliability of the ATMs but of the political perception... more related to Anne Shoettle comment below...
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thank you!

James,Love how this idea takes a different look at the issue of voters getting to a polling place and provides a novel (and potentially overlooked solution).I'm wondering if you've had a chance to put any thought to the actual on-screen interface. Something that could hamper this idea is a confusing or non-accesible user interface. Adding complication is the fact that many ATMs use many different configurations of screen sizes, buttons, touchscreens, etc. It may be that many older ATMs cannot support the range of input necessary to mark a ballot, because they aren't touchscreen, and have only 8 set physical buttons. It's an interesting additional problem to solve!

Very true. I suppose people are by and large able to withdraw the money they want on a wide variety of ATMs so that gives some credibility to people's ability to adapt. I agree though that consistency would be highly useful! I think this is the case for two reasons: 1. to ensure that usage is as easy and consistent as possible; 2. to ensure that banks, by providing this service, as not subjected to claims that they are impeding voting by a more complicated interface than others.Most bank ATMs now have a color screen. Surely a standardized view would be able to be uploaded to these. Indeed, this does mean than some ATMs simply would not be able to provide this service. Consistency and fairness is more important than those marginal ATMs.And what would this screen look like. Well, as simple as possible, I'd hope. Worth thinking about...
nice, cause at the end the vote is for a bank anyway ;)
Such a charge has been made against Goldman Sachs... it is in Wikipedia, so must be true! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldman_Sachs#Personnel_.22revolving-door.22_with_U.S._government

Are you sure that the ATM can know if a person is a US citizen or not? (a.k.a. does it know if they have the right to vote?) I have a bank account and a SSN, but I'm not a US citizen therefore I shouldn't be able to vote.
I feel like this could potentially be solved by having a database with all the people that have the right to vote and their SSNs... It just sounds like it might have a lot of security holes?
OH also I forgot to mention that I think it's a great idea :)
Absolutely agree and that database is the electoral database... It is a matter of having identification to confirm that you are the person on that database.
Very cool idea !
Thanks... now check out the updated version.
How do you protect the secret ballot, James. How do you keep the vote anonymous, while keeping an open and transparent vote counting system.
Thanks for this Shane - I hope the updated entry above should provide some more color. I hope you like where it is going!
nice idea but in many communities/countries, the use of ATM is not common, most people don't have a bank account.  Good idea for 'first world' countries.
Good point Abdeirahman. Though keep in mind that we are not trying to come up with universal solutions so all ideas are welcome.

Thanks for this. Important point @Abdelrahman. Different geographies clearly have varying challenges. In some developing markets the penetration of ATMs is actually extremely high in the capital cities, which is where most of the voting activity occurs (Jakarta in Indonesia is a great example of this). The challenge there is not so much adoption of banking / using ATMs but rather the security. Unlike the US, where all banks are to each other and to national individual ID information, in many developing economies banks act as islands of information.As such, I think Meena is correct that this idea is most applicable to the US. Perhaps the main advantage being that it would enable voting to occur on a more fluid basis ahead of the actual polling day, increasing convenience and thus increasing access to a huge section of the voting population: those that work and are too busy to go to their particular polling station.

Fab start James. We're anticipating discussions to flourish here and your ideas to evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right. Here's an example of how built up ideas can get over the course of a challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/localfood/winners-announced/public-kitchen/ Let's bring on the builds and spell out the specifics!

voting_via_atm_network_.title: Voting via ATM network

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

do_prisoners_lose_all_rights_including_v.description: One in forty Americans of voting age are ineligible to vote because they are, or have been, in prison.
do_prisoners_lose_all_rights_including_v.creator: a27dde9d48bc6ef262e68a408640d585

comments.text: In my opinion prisoners regain their civic rights and responsibilities once rehabilitated. They should vote.

do_prisoners_lose_all_rights_including_v.title: Do prisoners lose all rights, including voting?

election_web_site_templates_consistent_a.description: Why not have a consistent user experience at all of the elections web sites. Instead of all the individual variations we have today, what if there was a template for the structure and presentation of key information about your local elections.
election_web_site_templates_consistent_a.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Loving the non-partisan goodness on this one!
Nice concept and direction. Go with this.

The Propositions are always tucked up high or to the side on some ballots... so you can miss them if you're not looking.That'd help if it was easier to find, or aware there is a propostion to vote on that year.Just entering in a Zip Code online would help... to find polling stations, and ballots within that district.  Color coding may be an option too? (Different colors for different positions.)---Since you can register at the DMV, you could get the info sent through them too?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I like the start of this idea Whitney! I was just talking about how most places don't have a standardized way for people to find information on voting and voting. Is this website a place for information only or can people vote? I was wondering if people would need to create a profile or login to vote. One way to bypass this is to leverage existing user login names and information people have online.

Hi T. Annie - I think that the concept is focusing on information but Whitney envisages a section givingDates for the next election (and what will be on the ballot - national or local)This could perhaps incorporate animated/highlighted links to online voting sites for elections/polls currently in progress.Could you expand a little on your idea for leveraging existing user logins? You might like to make it a separate concept, that way we could help you build on it and iron-out any obstacles.

Thanks for the clarification. I have a better grasp on the concept. I thought it could incorporate some of the online voting concept aspects, especially if people are going there for information, why not be able to vote remotely? If this was an option, then creating login and an account would make more sense.

For this basic information, no user account is needed, so no sign in. All of the information is public - sample ballots and polling places, for example, are based on address.  All of the features I've proposed are already available on some sites.. this would make them available in a consistent way on all of them. Although some counties are large, and have good technology departments, many are small and have few resources to design and maintain an election site. This would help them by making even a basic site fully accessible.

Certainly 'best practice' standardisation and sharing of resources makes good sense. If such 'best practice' could be introduced across the spectrum of electoral practices and processes it would truly enhance the experience for all.Is there a top-level forum similar to the ECA example in my other post? It is electoral specific - not like CSG and NCLS that seem to be so broad as to lose meaningful impact.

Great concept Whitney.I guess such a template would be appropriate across jurisdictions (council, county, state, federal etc.) but within a given country.In Tim Noonan's inspiration on telephone voting he points out a top-level body for developing and approving standards called the Electoral Council of Australia ( http://www.eca.gov.au/ ) - your concept fits well with their ethos and key directions. Top-level agreement on and commitment to such a 'best practice' website template would also speed its development.
Simple & powerful idea!Having both overseen & directly developed several websites, can definitely see the value in a best practices template for election websites, with accessibility built in.

election_web_site_templates_consistent_a.title: Election web site templates- consistent access everywhere

the_next_universal_election_platform_fac.description: Why not build an election platform on an already existing robust system which is used by more than half of USA?
the_next_universal_election_platform_fac.creator: 2ec61248fe1d25dd65f5402eb502a49e

comments.text: Interesting thoughts Subhadeep  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.
Thanks for the feedback, Ashley. Will surely post it again during the Concepting phase. Best

the_next_universal_election_platform_fac.title: The next universal election platform - Facebook????

fair_elections_in_india_through_a_nation.description: A fairly new unit of the Indian Gov't called the 'Unique Identification Authority of India' is hoping to address the rigged state elections and widespread embezzlement by providing all Indian citizens with a unique, verifiable, ID number.
fair_elections_in_india_through_a_nation.creator: 6ca53c38aff4f2024f8442bd320a8ea2

comments.text: Interesting. Great for security identification. Wonder about people's thoughts on privacy.
Privacy should be no more of an issue than it is with a passport.For most people having a Facebook account would represent a greater threat to privacy than a national ID number.

Food for thought here Josh, thanks.  On Vincemnt's question - I'm not sure scanning fingerprints when turning up at the polling station would do much to attract voters to the polls (the contrary, I'd imagine) - people might wonder what databases exactly were being accessed.  These sorts of data-analysis activities are apt to be farmed out to private companies, and usb keys, laptops etc. can/do go missing all the time.  It's also the sort of thing that would make the most innocent man feel instantly guilty.

Yeah I think there could definitely be issues with privacy here. It's going to be down to how it's presented. It's interesting to note that people will happily tag their friends' faces on facebook because it makes their lives easier and is a useful tool. However, that same tagging tool is essentially putting faces to the names of a huge database of people, which may enable computers to pick faces out of photographs in the future - living up to the fears that people may express over this voting approach.

Most of us have a range of IDs that we use for our own convenience - drivers licences, passports, birth certificates, credit cards - the main privacy component of which is physical possession. An ID card for election purposes would simply join these, although in India a much smaller percentage of people will have the convenience IDs we (in western democracies) take for granted. As for Facebook I find nothing useful in it that cannot be achieved by other means with far fewer privacy issues. In my personal opinion Facebook is a "fad gone bad". Yes I have a Facebook page so like most others my privacy has already been partially compromised - but I no longer include a profile photo. Most of the convenience IDs come with legislative protection for the individual - this is not true of social media like Facebook.

Interesting conversation here, guys. I understand from what you're saying that there's certainly a polarizing conversation to be had around privacy. Might also be interesting, though, to think about how technologies like these can open new doors to the disenfranchised and underserved.Maybe, the paperwork and red tape involved in filling out an absentee ballot could be streamlined through ID technology.  Or maybe we could improve accuracy and reduce foul play of mail-in submissions through ID technologies.Any thoughts?

fair_elections_in_india_through_a_nation.title: Fair Elections in India through a National ID System

arduino_for_disabilities.description: This blog explores how micro-controllers might become empowerment tools for people with disabilities by helping address problems in daily living. With research, many of the applications could be used in, and outside, the voting booth.
arduino_for_disabilities.creator: 66a7c986108a3cac478c37d4739f7c6d
arduino_for_disabilities.title: Arduino for Disabilities

sms_voting_.description: Barriers to voting are a problem for all, these become exponentially difficult when there are accessibility limitations. The idea is simple, remove barriers and make it easy, everyone has a phone and the method has proven successful in Switzerland.
sms_voting_.creator: a27ca8cfa1fab46888c57717d8b325e7

comments.text: Available collaborations and software exist to encourage participation in elections like UShahidi. But these are not implemented surely because of lack of political will for obvious reasons. if governments in developing countries are serious about participation and inclusion then such systems should be incorporated in election planning. This has nothing to do with the size of the country or population. It has to do with political will.

Very interesting. We need to keep in mind the context:  Switzerland is a small country and this explained the success of its "direct democracy" with a lot of referendums and votes made by the citizens. Since Rousseau, the Swiss model has been admired but it has also been discussed that it is not always easy to reproduced because it works in the context of  a small country with a rather small population. However, this is a great inspiration and maybe it could be implemented for local elections first. thanks!

I totally agree with the need for a smaller country for an open democratic model, but not sure how that relates to SMS enabled voting. I think SMS voting is size agnostic, it's more a method of delivery rather than a political or social philosophy. Additionally, if we're talking about L.A. in the brief, the size of the two are quite relevant. But as always, it's good to start small and test, as they did initially in Switzerland.

I guess I reacted to your mention of frequent referendums, just reminding us of the context of use. I was not saying it was impossible.I thought that one reason for Switzerland to develop such a system was its size and their frequent elections. My other thought (but I might be completely wrong) was about to manage the SMS system and that's why I felt maybe starting small was a good idea.

Great inspiration Hesam. SMS Voting + "Direct Democracy" = WOW!Agreed with both of you that smaller populations are more conducive for direct democracy (town hall meetings, and Occupy General assemblies being related examples).In terms of the separate issue of SMS voting, the startup costs & effort to implement the enabling technology would probably be relatively fixed, regardless of population size. And variable costs like distribution would of course increase with size, but would also benefit from economies of scale.However, the risk and impact of a security breach would increase for larger elections (i.e. more benefit for unscrupulous individuals to rig outcomes that affect more people). Thus the time/efforts to ensure security and build trust in the system is likely to be significantly higher.

Hi Vincent, thanks for bringing up the idea of trust and security. I'm wondering if you are used to vote often (for various issues, sometimes "smaller"),  you can get used to an sms system and realize that "it works". I don't know about the technicalities but security breach could indeed be an issue, in particular for important elections. A lot of interesting issues to be thinking of with this inspiration! :-)
I believe the system tracks your input not based on the number of phones or providers you have, but rather your unique identifier.

I agreed that technology should be an instrument to vote, however what happen if one person have more than a cellphone? How is the system when you get more than one operator mobile lines in the country? In that case will need a process of registration that could be limited for some people.
