eye_voting_glasses.description: Using available technologies, the  EYE-voting glasses provide a secured retina identification, personalised community-based information, and register your choices based on eye movements. Information is encrypted and sent securely.
eye_voting_glasses.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: I love that this idea makes it impossible for anyone to know who you voted for.  Some people don't mind sharing who they vote for but others  would rather keep it a secret.  I do fear that the finances involved with this might be high, but it seems that's something you have thought of. One minor concern would be for people who have major fears of germs and other cleanliness issue.  They might not want to put on glasses that a lot of people before them have put on.  Overall, I love the idea.

I would guess that the retinaID would work for most blind people as well, do you know if this is the case? If that is so, accelerometer navigation and audio response could be built in! Move your head to navigate in the system. But how to guarantee that the audio response only goes to the person that uses the glasses? Or would this be to extreme foresight?

Very interesting concept Yannick!This type of technology has been proposed for a variety of purposes including games. If adopted in the games market the cost would plummet possibly to the point where a voting 'module' could become the equivalent of a pamphlet with an attached form - made available at no cost through newsagents, supermarkets and other commonly frequented places. If everything private is done on the government voting server the module could be recycled through the same places.Interesting question about retina ID for the visually impaired too Jakob. From memory the bionic ear developed here in Australia works by direct stimulation of the auditory nerves, perhaps some variation on that technology could supply the 'private' audio.

Nice one Yannick! Seems like a feasible way to make private voting outside a controlled space, guess building in a feature that if someone takes the glasses of, you have to restart so that you guarantee to keep things private.

Good point Jakob! You are right to mention that the privacy needs to be guaranteed thought the whole voting process, with a single person involved. I like your suggestion. Now how can we insure that the device will serve that purpose? Are you thinking of a sensor on it? or an ID (retina ID?) check through all the process AND each time there is a choice to make ? Looking forwards reading more of your posts.

If you can trust the retina ID to be secure and, I guess you could build an application that logs you in and displays your voting site when your retina is verified, if the supplication updates a few times a second and logs you out when verification is lost (still allows blink of an eye) there is no time to take the glasses of and for someone else to see what you saw. When another person looks in the glasses they wold see ther own voting site instead! This all seems workable IF WE CAN BUILD A SYSTEM WHERE GLASSES ARE NOT HACKABLE. Get an idea what a hacker might do: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=apkSkb6Ak3I this was linked as a part of inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/if-people-cannot-access-technologies-technologies-should-adapt-and-reach-them/A hacker might also set up a MAN IN THE BROWSER system, as popular for internet banking fraud. I would suggest that you cannot guarantee a digital system from hackers! But I think you can set up a system where a fraud is spotted if it has occurred. You might be able to verify that your vote wasn't replaced in a digital system if you have a receipt that can verify that your vote was correctly included in the election result. But you need an receipt that doesn't tell other people what you voted, otherwise an oppressor might punish you for choosing wrongly.   I have given such a system some thought and added a suggested solution that could be combined with your glasses. http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/supercheckup-2013-your-perfectly-private-vote-verification-system.-/ when combined with your glasses only the tagged and coloured receipt system of my concept is needed and you would be sent a receipt digitally or printed. Think this is a great combination! And if you approve I like to add the glasses as an distance voting alternative into my concept, and feel free to include my verification idea into yours.A paranoid person might still be afraid that an oppressive system/person would monitor your voting and take action against you afterwards. Could the retina verification be unlinked from you as a person? Imagine a register of retinas that are eligible for the different elections, but that this list doesn't include personal data.

Nice concept Yannick! I like how you've specifically addressed reaching voters who might not make it to polling places, like people in hospitals. I also like that the eye glasses would facilitate the voting experience, but also record input from users on how the system could be improved and adapted for the next time! Hope to see more of you in our Concepting phase.

eye_voting_glasses.title: EYE-voting glasses

helping_people_with_cognitive_limitation.description:
Have you ever thought about what happens during the election to the voters with
cognitive limitations?This concept is focused on making the ballot flexible,
simple, perceptible and mistake proof to help the voters with cognitive limitations.
helping_people_with_cognitive_limitation.creator: 8150e12f5b6c0f72b183a045ea41923a

comments.text: Yilin, Nice start on a list of principles to make ballots less overwhelming. I'd love to see more of what you would do with the design to bring these ideas to life.Would the new ballot extend current systems (like the EAC Best Practices designs - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/election-design-from-design-for-democracy/)?Or would the new design change something more basic to make voting easier for all?

The new design will focus on the information structure of the ballot. The information on the existing ballot is confusing because it's very hard for voters(with cognitive limitations) to figure out the relations between all the information(e.g. the 'candidates' information lays under the 'contest' information, and the 'help' information should always available though the voting process). The new ballot design will re-arrange the information on the ballot according to the priority. And the relations between the information will be emphasized by using some visual, audio, and tactile elements.And also I'm thinking of the way that the general voting systems access these information. It's not about a specific voting system design. The voting systems have something in common about their ways to access the information. Generally, the voting systems access the information of ballot in a linear way. So the inappropriate arrangement of information will make the systems to take more steps to access a certain piece of information(e.g. the 'review ballot' information is always in the end of the ballot. So if the voter wants to review what he already voted in the middle of the voting process, he needs to roll to the end of the ballot to review and then roll back to continue voting. If the 'review ballot' information is designed to be parallel to the 'contests' information, the voters(or the systems) can access this information by only an one-step shift).
The more steps the systems need to access a certain piece of information, the more effort the voters need to spend on to manipulate the system.

helping_people_with_cognitive_limitation.title: Helping People with Cognitive Limitations = Helping Everyone

_human_ability_and_accessibility_center_.description: "Human Ability and Accessibility Center" has been inaugurated in India by IBM India. Its mission is to make information and technology easily accessible to people with visual, cognitive, hearing, and motor disabilities.
_human_ability_and_accessibility_center_.creator: 0fca0b4519a3a092ae8e54612a875e15
_human_ability_and_accessibility_center_.title: "Human Ability and Accessibility Center"

voting_objects.description: If we are to look to digital methods of collecting votes then we must ensure that everyone has the same mobility to ensure that the system is fair.
voting_objects.creator: b0bc396e936b4ed9e314db87f6e451a1

comments.text: Some interesting ideas here Nicolas, with a little overlap to other concepts.Personally I am unsure about how desirable it is to allow voters to change their minds.Do you envisage that the upload of the vote cast would happen automatically so if you left the object at home on the final day your vote would still be counted?

Thanks for your comments Paul.I do agree that the idea of allowing people to change their minds is potentially flawed, in many ways it removes the seriousness of the task. It could have potential benefits. We could canvas votes in the run up to the election to give a view of how the country 'intends' to vote which could give us a much more informed view of the political landscape at any time.When you change you objects political preference it would automatically upload to the election database. When the election closes it is just a case of not allowing any more uploads so you could set your object on the first day, never change it, leave it at home and your vote is still counted.

Hi Nicolas, i like the design craftmanship on your concept. I see high level relevancy especially "a number of transmitters......diferent inputs and outputs systems for interaction accesibility" with what i envision in my concept "voting with a touch" what do you think?

I think that there is a system that could work Patricio. A combination of these concepts with Pauls' bus ticket balloting concept and the idea that votes don't necessarily have to be collected at polling locations. My concept outlines a new, engaging and tangible experience that is accessible from anywhere to anyone. It does now seem to rely too much on the technology. By combining it with your ideas of 'touch' and 'vote collection' there is a new social element that adds warmth back. For alot of people accessibility will come down to physical mobility issues and so having someone collect or help them to cast their vote is important. This has been covered alot during the concepting phase and i like that it now combines into this scenario which also references some other concepts that have discussed mobile voting vans and multiple voting locations etc...

Nicolas, what I like about this concept is the notion of voting turned into something tangible or physical. It brings up for me a feeling that being able to vote is a right and responsibility that we should all literally carry with us, regardless of our accessibility needs.
Lovely description "we should all literary carry with us" in reference to voting turned into something tangible or physical

I think voting periods should be extended.It would help with counting up the vote too.With everyone voting on the same day, it's amazing how many votes are "lost." Changing the vote along the way - that's an idea.You'd have to be aware of people complaining saying that - they tried to change their vote but couldn't.  Then do you have a re-vote because of an error, after the fact?Everything should be digital by now... I think too many politicians like the old way.  Also, when things go digital, it would hopefully eliminate the need to re-district... or re-draw lines.  Zip codes or counties should stay as is, and have the same voting districts.  (More or Less people in an area, do have then more or less representation in Congress.)

voting_objects.title: Voting Objects

what_needs_not_to_be_done.description: I am from the so called 'Third World' country. My little contribution will be from my experience of election in my country. The experience we have is so much what should be avoided in order to have an accessible election.
what_needs_not_to_be_done.creator: d165d4b55054d47e31c296495a6deff5

comments.text: I have another example of what not to do in a democracy, also from Africa.  When election time came around in a village I worked in there were several problems:First, the women who were also usually the less educated, merely followed what their husbands voted which also aligned with their tribe's political party.  As a woman you voted for the candidate with the same tribe as you and/or what your husband voted.   Second, there was a strong lack of awareness of the issues or even the positions of the candidates.  People may have been voting for a candidate, opposed to policies in their favor, yet they had no idea.Finally, election messages were almost always in French, never translated to local languages.  Of course this is a difficult task when there are dozens of languages, and many more dialects, but it seemed in some ways to be disenfranchising.  Without a knowledge of the colonial language, you were left in the dark to form your own opinion.  For several different types of voters, your political information was always coming through someone else's filter.

Natalie what you said is typical of the experience of people in the villages even in my country. Most of the villagers have to be threatened to even register because they don't thing voting adds anything to their lives.

Dear Natalie and Abubakar, i completely understand what u guys referring to here, and is still the case in a lot of villages in India. However, since last  few years -things have improved tremendously because of grassroots efforts in all the possible directions -from education to awareness, to local participation, law enforcement, health and much more and to begin with making people understand what it means to be democratic !

what_needs_not_to_be_done.title: What Needs Not  to be Done!

make_sure_your_voice_was_heard..description: How can you assure that your voice is heard and your vote is recorded?  This applies to both all voters, but could be especially important to those whose vote relies on the assistance of others.
make_sure_your_voice_was_heard..creator: b3989819ef426f3f292d7f48a1ead4e7

comments.text: I was thinking along the same lines. The first time I voted even I wasn't sure if my vote had been recorded. Maybe electronic voting machines could print the details of the last vote cast on a small chit of paper with ink that gets erased automatically within say 15 seconds.

Hi Michael,Here is a TED Talk by David Bismark on voting, trust and verification of e-voting ballot results in the UK. http://www.ted.com/talks/david_bismark_e_voting_without_fraud.htmlIt's cool to be able to go online and check to see that your own vote was counted. I've been wondering, however, if Bismark's system for verification might be modified for US elections, but with added features providing greater voter accessibility...?
OOOOO  This is very cool.  Thanks for posting!
Great provocation about enhancing mechanisms which build trust, Michael.

Hi Michael, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Michael, I agree that voters having confidence that their vote was counted is an important part of a successful election. There are some interesting systems being developed that all people to verify their vote has been counted while still protecting their anonymity. Making these systems accessible and easy to use is still a challenge.  One example of this is a system called Helios which you can read about here: http://heliosvoting.org/

Interesting point raised Michael about giving voters justified confidence that their vote was counted accurately.And cool find Daniel, on the Helios vote verification system. Ingenious used of advanced cryptography!Although I'm quite optimistic about the advantages of encrypted electronic voting, I'm still worried about the opportunities this represents for hacking by unscrupulous individuals & organizations, domestic or foreign. Even Helios, in their FAQ, recognizes the concerns:"Online elections are appropriate when one does not expect a large attempt at defrauding or coercing voters. For some elections, notably US Federal and State elections, the stakes are too high, and we recommend against capturing votes over the Internet. This has nothing to do with Helios itself: we just dont trust that peoples home computers are secure enough to withstand significant attacks. If youd like to use a truly verifiable voting system for your public-office election, we recommend an in-person election. Helios could be adapted to the in-person, precinct voting setting, but we have not done this work yet, and we intend to focus on online elections first."

make_sure_your_voice_was_heard..title: Make sure your voice was heard.

mobilevoting_bring_the_ballot_box_to_you.description: What if we could bring the ballot box to the voter with a mobile polling station to reach communities that have limited mobility or historically have less access to the polls?
mobilevoting_bring_the_ballot_box_to_you.creator: ff518cfc0901904ba759195f3195c537

comments.text: Congratulations Ally - this is an excellent suggestion.You make some excellent points about low technology and resources already existing.The general problem seems to be chicken and egg - is it worth visiting an area if we don't know how many people will want to vote. I am merely making this observation as an outsider (Australian) . In 1967 one of the few referendums to be passed gave Australian aboriginals the right to vote - so there is an obligation on the Australian government to provide voting opportunities to these remote communities.Can I please ask a few questions?Was the organisation you worked for a part of 'government'? If not do you know why the government (federal or state) does not sponsor such work?I gather the work was voluntary - would there be more people willing to do the job you were doing if it was paid? The remote work for the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) is done mainly by paid employees of the AEC.Similarly would working on pooling stations be more attractive if it was paid at a reasonable rate?Finally (for now) in addition to visiting bus and train stations did you do any 'door-to-door' work and would doing it help to identify people who would like to vote but may be house-bound?

Thanks Paul for your feedback!  I would love to hear more about your perspective on the Australian system since my outsider perspective is a bit limited.In response to your questions, the work I did in voter registration was government funded as a 501c3 (the non profit tax code in the states) but the organization I worked for was distinctly not governmental to remain non partisan.I actually was paid a small amount, nothing extraordinary but a small stipend, as it was a full time job. However, most voter registration staff are volunteers and there are many people willing to do the work paid or unpaid. While I think individuals should be recompensed for their work, there is something to be said for the value of a volunteer to build community and foster support among disenfranchised communities.  In terms of door-to-door work, I did go door to door but that work was more of community organizing than voter registration.  As community organizing can become politically motivated very easily, we did not do voter registration during those visits. However, the most productive door to door work for voter registration is in apartment buildings or other high density housing complexes (though I didn't directly work in those spaces). You're absolutely right though that door-to-door work is the best way to identify the homebound, and while we separated voter registration from organizing, the field notes from those organizing visits were valuable sources of information regarding reaching the home bound and connecting those who needed services with services provided in their community.

Thanks for the comprehensive replies Ally.Your comment about the organisation being non-governmental to remain non-partisan reflects a fundamental difference between your system and ours. Our Electoral Commissions are public service departments which in themselves are traditionally non-partisan. They work under the Electoral Act which, except for minor changes has had bi-partisan support for many years.Greg Baker has given an excellent summary of the Australian voting process - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-we-ve-learned-from-a-century-of-better-than-99-turnout-in-australia/although where he mentions manual marking of the rolls, this has been replaced by computer rolls and by next election may be updated in real-time which will further discourage multiple voting.I don't know if you have looked at my inspirations - I have been rather more verbose in describing aspects of the Australian system.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/employ-people-to-overcome-the-obstacles/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/flat-pack-polling-booths/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/compulsory-voting-the-ultimate-freedom-of-choice/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/build-trust-in-the-system-and-achieve-confidence-in-the-outcome/I am happy to answer any questions you might have.

Another innovation. Well done.

comments.text: Hey, Sasha. I'm from Portugal and that is a common practice in here. While you were mesmerized, I on the other hand thought it was a widespread practice everywhere. I know they have it in Spain as well.They often stop the vans at one point and gather small crowds around the van for "tiny-rallies" with the locals.

Thanks for sharing Ana.  It was somewhat new to me over seven years ago as someone who had been less traveled prior to that trip. It happens a bit differently in the Caribbean as well but I hadn't experienced it in the way that I did in Japan.I also understand that reactions to it are very mixed but its a process that with some refinement, has some potential to work in more remote areas, with a greater bend toward non-partisan delivery and learning around the election process.

braille_burgers..description: My sister-in-law recently shared this video from Wimpy burgers in South Africa. I found it to be such an inspirational and amazingly well-crafted way of showing compassion for the visually impaired.
braille_burgers..creator: 3235e3e7b5e215043e3d5105fef47950

comments.text: yes, it is lovely, and such a poetic message. So nice I hate to add a "but" into it. ButThe video message on YouTube cannot be enjoyed by people who are blind as it does not include a text version nor audio description, so the audience for this is clearly people with sight. It is not as difficult to create an audio description as it must have been to create the braille buns, since all that is required is an audio description to narrate both the visual text and the events that cannot be seen, like how the seeds are placed on the buns. A few hours to read and a few hours to edit, at most, easier if added into the production schedule at the start. Much more difficult is the culture change required in an organisation so that these issues are obvious when creating the film telling people how wonderful they are. Perhaps they could have thought of all the blind people who would enjoy this message, not just the carefully selected ten who got the burgers and all the people without disabilities who shared the film.I'm surprised the blind organisations they worked with weren't included in helping with the video. I see someone has provided an excellent audio description version, but they had to do so with a deteriorated, blurry version of the vid. I have also seen, but I do not know as I am not an expert on this, that the braille logo image doesn't spell Wimpy" but spells " ])-#* "Good start though!
This really cheered me up this morning and made me smile - thanks!
Heartwarming story, imagine voting experiences like this for everybody!
labor of love...
so little yet so much :')
Love, love, love this one!!

Moving and powerfulsuch a lovely display of empathy (and fantastic marketing move). If you took a concept like this, creating true delight with a creative gesture, in combination with inspirations likehttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/goodgrips-what-s-good-for-arthritics-can-be-good-for-all./andhttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/when-the-solutions-for-disabled-becomes-the-new-standard/you could remove so many of the existing barriers to a streamlined, pleasant, even enjoyable election and voting process.

Hi Katie,I saw this video for the first time a couple days ago and was happy to see it again here. After seeing my fellow commenters' reactions, I think the most powerful part of the video is the reception it gets among sighted viewers. Though it's primarily an advertisement, the video's focus on this special experience for blind customers elicits one of our noblest emotions: empathy. Could a similar human-oriented focus on highlighting accessibility measures in the election process change everyone's perspective on the experience? After all, providing braille menus is just about equivalent to making more user friendly voting machines and setting up mobile voting operations. Documenting these features at work would not only spread the word (as it was in the video), but perhaps change all of our attitudes toward voting and our civic duties.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Way to go, Katie. For me this inspires *creative approaches* to accessibility and inclusiveness. Looking forward to what it might inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase.
Definitely inspiration...wonderful video and project!

Beautiful intersection of design, communication and humanity. I love that 15 people ended up reaching 800,000. Improvements to election accessibility doesn't have to come from major changes. Sometimes small acts and efforts are enough to create big movements.
Very nice! thanks for sharing! I love how the faces of the people in the second part of the video just lit up as they "saw" the burger...
This is really clever and fun. But more than that, its shows how a new channel of communication can be designed into almost anything if we just think to do it. I also love the way it reaches out.
Awesome! For some reason, the next thing that jumped into my mind: Braille Marriage Proposal, a twist on the classic proposals during dining.

I really like these 2 lines in the video clip!!"This was the 1st time they could do more than just taste their food" "They could see it"No wonder the 15 people who touched and tasted the burgers were motivated to speak about it!!

missed_call_for_voting_.creator: 687c01fdf352327da897a9fa5b4e0256

comments.text: Interesting analogy, Kiran. As we move into the Concepting phase this week you might consider developing your ideas further and posting there. The issue of security has been discussed throughout our Inspiration phase so it we'll be keen to see what you and others can come with around these concerns.
Sure Meena !! I will definitely put few ideas considering security concern in concepting phase.
Its indeed interesting. How do administrators know the candidate being voted for or does it just work with referenda?

Every contestant has been designated with an unique number. All viewer has to do is dial that number and after one ring, the call gets disconnected automatically. The viewer gets an acknowledgement message that his vote for the particular contestant has been registered. In one week, a viewer can vote for a particular contestant only once. However he can vote for multiple contestants in the same week. The best part is you can call to vote your favorite contestant even if you have zero balance in your prepaid account.
That is really good practice especially as voters do not have to pay anything.

using_technology_to_help_those_who_are_d.creator: a610669548f25670fbed4f6cfcfc288e

comments.text: Hi there  interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the right hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

using_technology_to_help_those_who_are_d.title: Using technology to help those who are disabled

brainwave_controlled_interface.description: Brain scanning controlled interface devices can adapt to the user by initial tasks, combined with alternative feedbacks to the user; visual, audio and brail, it could be quite accessible even for people with severe disability.
brainwave_controlled_interface.creator: 04e53dae2f54dc421469f3b54994d2d1

comments.text: Excellent idea
If set up proper I believe you manage with:1 brain + 1 eye =ok1 brain + 1 ear =okI think that is quite as far you can push the accessibility.

Wow, imagine voting (and so much more) just with your thoughts! So cool, Jakob. Thanks for sharing =)One thing I won't enjoy as the brainwave reading technology/interface/people's experience is being perfected (considering the current state of automated voice systems): "I think you voted for Option A. Think 'Yes' or Smile if this is correct. Think 'No' or Frown if I made a mistake...I'm sorry, I couldn't detect your thinking. Think 'Yes' or Smile if this is correct. Think 'No' or Frown if I made a mistake............................................"=P
Ha ha! Vincent I agree with you, Its a wow possibility, but as well most possibly troublesome at a unperfected state.

brainwave_controlled_interface.title: Brainwave controlled interface

voting_with_a_touch.description: Traditionally surveys are paper-based during an event. Even an electronic-based system represents a challenge for the organizer. NFC (Near Field Communication) technology allows to establish communication with a "touch" for smart-phones and alike.
voting_with_a_touch.creator: 0bc0dbb5b1792d2dfd3537516c92529b

comments.text: Great concept Patricio!  People with dexterity issues may prefer to vote with an object rather than their finger on a touch screen. I wonder if you can build off some of the ideas from this concept -- http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/voting-objects/ -- which explores the idea of making votes more significant by making them more tangible.
Voting with a touch via www.poken.com (object) NFC enabled makes it a reality instantly as much as the "voting objects" concept. Building the fusion of both is the ideal

Current touch screen systems are out of favor all across the country.   We should be moving toward systems that are safe & secure & auditable & offer a paper trail.  And even if this system offered a paper printout, what assurance does the voter have that the software recorded the ballot as the voter intended?

Your comment does seem to echo some of the current requirements for auditability - this is why I thought that a two step process of creating a completed ballot and lodging it was the best option http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/bus-ticket-ballot/ the NFC device could be used to generate a bus ticket sized ballot with just the voters choices which then would be read into the voting machine where it would be like any other ballot countable and auditable - the voter would then receive a receipt showing the voting choices.
Well articulated Paul

I like your concept Patricio it would allow people to do their voting before hand and just use the NFC for casting (or as I indicated in Jason's thread perhaps a 2 step process).NFC could also be incorporated in Ting-Han's Kioskshttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/year-round-voting-center-stores-equipped-with-voting-kiosks/ or the portable kiosks associated with Andrew Baranak's Ipad ideahttp://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/ipad-absentee-voting/ or the other technologies proposed for Voting Vans/Trucks etc.This would be complementary to using removable media as the source of voter choices.

Hi Paul, thanks for posting the wonderful references above - all actionable in a second. Having witnessed how Poken (nfc provider) worked in a sponsored trade show in Switzerland the voting is executed in that touch, instantly

If you know how to read, you have a complete education about life, then you know how to vote within a democracy. But if you dont know how to read, you dont know how to decide. Ray Bradbury via @explorerDeveloping the empathy, the tangible experience of Democracy: Voting by focusing on the usability (user interaction) versus the product function (design) makes this challenge epic.

voting_with_a_touch.title: Voting with a Touch (w/ Poken devise)

mark_anywhere.description: Make it easy for voters to mark their ballot anywhere, then bring them to the polling place to cast them. Why not make it easy to get a copy of the ballot and mark it anywhere (in any method), then come to the polling place to cast the ballot
mark_anywhere.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: Whitney, I think you have remarkably addressed: Speed, Tempo, and Accuracy building your concept. Congratulations!
I like this idea a lot but wouldn't this make it easier to make counterfeit ballots? Registering online poses many risks. But this is a great idea nonetheless I also hope this goes through.
I thought the same thing, but I think she is referring to just casting your vote to print, then turning it in to a registered voting area.  That way there is really no way to counterfeit.

Correct Michael - how, when and where the ballot is prepared doesn't really matter as long as it becomes acceptable (machine readable) to cast once you have established your entitlement to cast it. It basically shifts the voter validation process to after you have prepared your ballot.But it does more than this too. If preparation of the ballot is made virtual (rather than on paper) the printed ballot for casting only requires the voters actual choices. I proposed a bus ticket size ballot for casting (which was a bit extreme) but the potential is there to cut the printed ballot down to perhaps half letter size with something like a machine readable QR code of the voters choices and a human readable version on the same sheet.Then the casting machine would only have to display the choices and allow the voter to confirm and cast the vote.The Mark Anywhere concept opens up a great variety of possibilities.Vote 1 - Mark Anywhere
What a great way to take advantage of the technology we have now to improve the way we vote on a massive scale!
Convenient and simple. Hope this goes through.

Congrats on this post joining our Top 20 shortlist! We were excited to see how this concept brings new flexibility and adaptability to the voting experience.During this Refinement phase, let's think about the initial steps we'd need to take to bring this idea to life  for instance, what would we want to do first, second or third to start implementing it? What partners might we need to get things moving, and how might we get them onboard? For more information on specific ways to iterate and update your concept, check http://bit.ly/oi_voterefine and www.bit.ly/oi_refine.

Love this creative process redesign concept Whitney! Provides the benefits of marking your ballot whenever, wherever, & however you want, while maintaining the physical voter identification & paper trail of the current polling place system.This provides some of the benefits of Online/Mobile/Absentee voting ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-mobile-voting-increase-accessibility-for-all/ ), while remaining a more incremental system change that may be more quickly palatable & immediately implementable.You might also want to check out Rachel Happen's related "DIY Absentee Ballots" concept, which separates the voting & verification/identification process to increase accessibility, and also proposes expanding voting & verification locations: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/diy-absentee-ballots/
Vincent, I agree, and have added these to the collaboration map. I should have taken the time to make those connections.

I'm just excited with all the great inspirations, ideas, & insights you're posting Whitney! No biggie, about missing a connection here or there. It'd take a superhuman effort to keep tabs on everything.On that note, have now linked to this concept from my online voting concept as well.And thought you might be interested in Amanda's related "Online Balloting" concept, which she recently posted: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/online-balloting/

Thanks for the mention, Vincent.  I like that we are all at least on the same page here.  It indicates this concept might be a winning one.  I think the idea of accessible balloting, combined with accessible drop offs and multi-device support will help tie together a solution for voting for people with disabilities.

Very well thought through Whitney - in my now abandoned concept I had sought to separate the casting and review/counting steps (until you kindly explained the review requirement).I noticed in another of your posts that you said new generation voting machines are being developed all the time so, as Vincent says, your proposal might be very quickly implementable.I was using the technology currently adopted by NY State as a point of reference. They utilise a special marking pen for the ballots.and require that there be no stray marks on the ballot - this sounds like technology from about 15 years ago. It should be relatively simple to reprogram the machines to accept hand marked ballots and QR codes and probably fewer errors. It would be a good intermediate step on the way to electronic voting, an ongoing alternative for those who prefer and a fall-back position for electronic failure.

Paul, when I think about how most paper ballots work currently, they are like the whole menu at a restaurant - showing all the choices. But it occurs to me that there is no reason why the ballot as cast has to show the whole menu. It could just show the voter's selections, just as your bill from a restaurant only shows what you actually ordered. I think this leads to several advantages:- It's easier to review your choices, because there is no ambiguity. The candidates you chose are on the list. No hoping that the scanners will count your ballot as you intend.- No special printer requirements - just be able to print the selected names or answers to ballot questions.- It makes it possible to use digital/OCR scan instead of optical scan (using timing marks and measuring the position of the marks) to count the ballots on a tabulator.  - If laid out well, it would also make auditing or hand-counting the cast ballots easier, too. No arguments about stray marks or deciding what to do if a voter (for example) circles the name instead of filling in an oval.- Smaller papers to store (most countries have requirements for how long after an election the ballot papers are stored)

Thanks Whitney I am getting a better picture of the process detail.As usual this means I have some more questions - one of which re-raises some aspects of my abandoned concept.When you lodge an absentee or postal ballot there is no review step and no feedback - what you lodge is what is counted (or not as the case may be) - therefore is the review mainly to see that the machine can interpret what is lodged, as opposed to just a chance to change your mind?In your latest discussion you say -"If laid out well, it would also make auditing or hand-counting the cast ballots easier, too. No arguments about stray marks or deciding what to do if a voter (for example) circles the name instead of filling in an oval. "If a ballot had a name circled what would be the outcome if it was counted manually? Under present circumstances this constitutes a stray mark and the ballot would be rejected.If digital/OCR scanning was adopted how, if at all, would this alter?As I said before the basis of my abandoned concept was to separate the casting and counting steps - basically I was thinking that casting the ballot would be a simple matter of feeding a machine that would result in a secure stack awaiting counting. That way several machines could accept ballots but only 2 scanning engines would be required (one for redundancy). Counting could then proceed at a relatively constant rate independent of voter traffic, unless volumes are very low.
Quick reply about ambiguous marking on a paper ballot. Although specifics vary by jurisdiction, there is an attempt to determine the voter's intent and count the ballot accordingly.

Whitney, I like your comment above regarding outputs that only show the voter's choices rather than the whole menu. But doesn't that system then necessitate that votes are being recorded electronically (a whole new world of considerations) rather than everyone's votes being captured in a standardized, machine-countable ballot? Or am I being old-fashioned in thinking that all the paper records need to appear as the same, standard ballot?

Hi Drew,I don't think it would matter if only the voters choices are recorded provided the ballot is both machine and human readable. Hence my suggestion for bus ticket size ballots that are both human and machine readable.http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/bus-ticket-ballot I was thinking bus/rail tickets mainly for some fairly robust medium together with magnetic encoding but even credit card size would be ok to accommodate referenda type choices.
Great concept Whitney! I love how inclusive it is.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

At the ITIF workshop an example of something similar to this idea was highlighted in the discussion for illustrative purposes.  The concept is similar in nature to the units available at Drug Stores where you can print and order copies of digital photos.  The customer (i.e. voter) can provide the input in a variety of ways (USB, Memory Card, eMail, etc.) and the input is separate from the common platform (and, in the case of voting, the security) for the output (receipt and tabulation).

As Whitney suggests, in further discussion, the output could be far smaller than the equivalent paper ballot. If the voter was prepared to accept the 1-1 correspondence between an encoded ballot and the printed receipt then when they attend the polling place to cast their vote they could be given the choice of casting it at the desk where they are marked off the roll (like presenting a bus or train ticket at an automatic turnstile) or queuing to use a similar machine that will 'read' the encoded ballot and present with a review/reject option before casting. In either case the equipment used to scan the ballot would be the same relatively small device with the former set to automatically accept and have no review device attached. I bet by the third election using such a process that the percentage of voters wanting to go through the review process reduces significantly.

I thought there where rules against filling in the ballots outside the polling station? It must be so that no "organised tampering" could take place... i.e. someone filling out several thousands of ballots and handing them to voters against a bribe...

Like coercion, there are always concerns about vote buying. But more and more states allow absentee ballots, and two use postal voting entirely. The problem is that some voters can't use these paper ballots independently. So why not offer alternatives outside of the polling place. It's a change, but perhaps not such a large one. The difference is that voters could still come to the polling place to cast their ballots, which gives them an opportunity to vote freely.Maybe our focus should be on enabling all voters, rather than restricting access in the hopes of reducing fraud and abuse.

Johan, I think you are right that in some places there would be restrictions on this, depending on how it is implemented. But there would likely be ways to get around it by treating this as an absentee ballot.One way to reduce coercion would be to allow the voter to change their ballot at the poll place before casting the ballot or allow them to vote multiple times but only count the last ballot.

I totally agree, but I just had to ask, in case this violated any federal or local legislation.The swedish system allows distance voting by mail, and also to vote again at the polling station on election day : Only the last vote is counted, and any earlier submitted is cancelled from the records.and of course we also have totally different ballot cards here, which I think is much simpler to understand for people with disabilities or little less grasp of logics and understanding complex graphic forms:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/ballot-cards/
Great build from the accessible election design workshop  advantages abound!

Dear Whitney, while trying to understand the challenge brief, i did follow the link and saw this concept. I think it is great idea-it allows for flexibility, ballot readers can mark on their own or with the help of their relatives, it would reduce the time one stands in a queue and would be very easy on the pole workers as well. However just a small concern- one is never sure that the ballot was marked by that  individual only. For example would their be situation when people in the family know who voted for whom, in the neighborhoods would people show each others ballots ? The good thing about people marking at voting places is no one is watching you ( one might be influenced ) but there is no way other person knows who voted for whom.  In this concept maintaining ones ballot is left onto an individual , i am assuming it should not be an issue to keep it discreet in the American context. In India (rural context) it would mean all the husbands marking for their wives !

Mamta, Great point. You are right that the election system has to help protect voters from coercion. That's why it's important that there is always an option to receive your ballot and mark it at the polling place.

mark_anywhere.title: Mark anywhere

py/tuple: How well does this concept address the needs of voters who might be excluded from elections today because of a disability, difficulty with languages or reading, limited mobility or other conditions?
Really well: this concept clearly addresses the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Pretty well: this concept addresses some of the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.
Not well: this concept doesn't at all address the needs of voters with different abilities or limitations.

Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible is this concept for your community? (Hint: resources might be money, time, partnerships, or other inputs needed for implementation)
This concept is definitely feasible for my community to implement; the resources needed wouldn't be an issue.
This concept might be feasible for my community to implement, as long as we could find assistance with some of our resource constraints.
This concept is not feasible for my community to implement; it's just too resource-intensive.
How much of an impact would this concept make on you or your community?
This concept would clearly have a positive impact on me or my community.
This concept might have a positive impact on me or my community, but it's not clear exactly how.
This concept would not have a positive impact on me or my community.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

use_for_profit_best_practices_to_develop.description: It's time to take the continually evolving best practices being implemented throughout the commercial, for-profit world of interactive on-screen experiences and apply that thinking to electronic voting to make a more accesible experience.
use_for_profit_best_practices_to_develop.creator: 517d5bd97565af43ddfd57d045d406be

comments.text: I agree with you, even though variety is the spice of life.

Accompanying this should be an acknowledgement that the use of public funds in best practice for the public good is a worthwhile investment. For an example look to Tim Noonan's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/

I should note that I included the primary images above as examples of how most current electronic voting options are woefully behind the times, compared to examples of consumer-oriented interfaces we all encounter on a daily basis.

use_for_profit_best_practices_to_develop.title: Use for-profit best practices to develop a more usable / accessible electronic ballot

streamlined_absentee_voting.description: Absentee voting is often a huge hassle, this is a simple concept for a web-based system that may ease some of the confusion related to absentee voting.
streamlined_absentee_voting.creator: b53e27dc0a9b381d0838cf7b2a3bd517

comments.text: Great illustration of the process, Andrew. You might also want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.

streamlined_absentee_voting.title: Streamlined Absentee Voting

climbing_vail_mountain.description: While the video is somewhat outside the scope of the challenge, Mr. Horton faced his handicap with an incredible amount of creative design and a desire to make the difficulties of his condition obsolete in his everyday life.
climbing_vail_mountain.creator: 54843eb4b913cad8ebd5d7df9f12012f

comments.text: A highly inspiring 5 minutes indeed!

I hope you did enjoy it!  WIth our limited resources, especially in the social sector, I think it's so important to be informed, not only about innovative ideas and solutions, but also creative leaders, so as to be able collaborate, transfer and tweek ideas across markets/industries/entrepreneurs/businesses.  Vail shows us the creative solutions and determined individuals allow almost anyone to do accomplish almost anything.

Thanks Kate! This is indeed inspiring and I agree it is important to keep in mind the human component in mind: people who can inspire, people who can innovate and come up with ideas or create links between fields.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
I like how he adapted the razor for his own needs and abilities.  With only things you can buy at the supermarket.Every one who is not standard size has to be creative once in a while I guess.

Kate, I'm so glad you shared Vail's story! I was also in the audience at the Net Impact Conference and found Vail's keynote inspiring, motivating and eye-opening. He's truly a leader we can all learn from.

climbing_vail_mountain.title: Conquering "Vail" Mountain

atms_are_quite_accessible.description: I immediately thought of ATMs: they're secure, they guide you through whatever you're doing, they're often equipped with braille and a hole to plug in your earphones, they're almost omnipresent (at least in the western world) …
atms_are_quite_accessible.creator: 73c4c49a943edf62af75354a7a21fc80

comments.text: This is great. It reminds me of the idea of using the coca-cola distribution network to deliver mosquito nets to areas where Malaria is an issue. Both are great ideas because they essentially piggy-back on current infrastructure to bring needed services, with comparatively little additional cost, to a population in need. Excellent!I hesitate to tie the banks to the government anymore, but it seems your bank account information could provide enough of a unique identification to enable sufficient tracking.I wonder if it would induce more crime though? It would potentially be one more reason for someone to try to steal your bank card.
Interesting anecdote about the mosquito net distribution- and what a perverse picture it paints of western priorities and attitudes.

I agree that the Coca-Cola idea is an interesting one. But I'm not sure it describes a Western attitude, as much as a universal one. After all, if Coca-Cola really does have a functioning (profitable) distribution network in places that doesn't have traditional postal services (even to deliver life-saving equipment), there are customers making some interesting choices. ;-) Either way, it's a nice illustration of how there are opportunities everywhere  and a lot of them are human-made.

Yes you are right! In talking about Western attitudes I was commenting merely on the irony of having a distribution network arising from activity that intrinsically contributes little to social good in place ahead of supporting the basic health needs of communities.

I understand. But am not sure that Coke's net contribution to social good is small. (Especially compared to the *other* Western attitudes that shaped the world's infrastructure.) Doesn't really matter, though, because in any case, it raises the important issue of who owns and operates the infrastructure. Would I trust Coca-Cola, a bank or the local internet service provider with my vote? I'm not quite sure especially not in younger democracies. Then again, somebody has to collect and count the votes. Who can be trusted?

Great analogy! I think ATMs benefits are their quick and easy locations, but it can be difficult to navigate.  Here's an example of a redesign IDEO did with BBVA on the ATM to incorporate visuals, privacy and accessibility: http://www.fastcodesign.com/1662281/a-radical-atm-redesign-thats-sexy-ipad-enabled

That's awesome! Just what an ATM should look like a smooth experience all the way from the easily understandable digital interaction, down to the low-tech but friendly countertop it's embedded in. :-)

Christian, great idea for using already available infrastructure. Could this be taken further to produce a secure smart phone app that would have all the neccesary authentication- making it even easier?
Definitely. There are some valid concerns about how to ensure that the voter has the necessary privacy when voting, but I'm sure there's a way to do that even on a smart phone.

Vincent, love the idea. Perhaps the parallel between voting and ATMs can be expanded to include some bank tellers (i reckon not everybody is physically able to use ATMs or have an individual preference for human interaction) and even mobile banking. The general thrust of making voting something as accessible as a private sector service (ATMs, Food Trucks, Ipads)  is brilliant. Thank you!
this is a great comparison to an ubiquitous service tool that we've come to take for granted, I hope that one day voting will be as facilitated!
Agreed, nice analogous thinking Christian!
Great analogous thinking, Christian  we're big fans: http://bit.ly/oi_analogous

atms_are_quite_accessible.title: ATMs are quite accessible

digital_and_global_plataform_like_openid.description: Why not create an official website to all political parties in the world? It is an opportunity to democratize the speeches.
digital_and_global_plataform_like_openid.creator: 0b15daa205be7c0ee7ce3ab28b58e928

comments.text: Great thoughts Carlos! I'm looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post this again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

digital_and_global_plataform_like_openid.title: Digital and global plataform, like OpenIDEO !!!

_out_of_the_box_mobile_phone_packaging.description: Sometimes it is not the technology that is the barrier, it is learning how to use the technology that is the challenge.
_out_of_the_box_mobile_phone_packaging.creator: 59ce4f71e16c7f4f27abffcca4d3d39c

comments.text: Thanks for the inspiration! I like the idea to spot "what people is looking for when dealing with" and the way the elder woman (in the first video) is handling the box, for some reasons, reminded me an article I read.The article is about the attempt in helping Alzheimer's Patients while escaping from hospitals.Alzheimer's Patients commonly feel disoriented from their surroundings with a need to "just get home"; for this reason they often escape.An hospital in Dusseldorf, Germany found an alternative solution: the staff realized that most of the escaped patient looked for public transports so, they built a fake bus stop just in front of the hospitalhttp://www.fastcompany.com/1598472/uncommon-act-of-design-fake-bus-stop-helps-alzheimers-patients

Great inspiration. East-of-use with mobile is key and there are many similar examples for making it easy to understand how to interact with one's mobile devices. These devices are sophisticated computers and secure transaction machines that should be evaluated as part of any future election concepts for those with disabilities.

This is fantastic!  Well done! I especially love the simple, bright cards worded with specific actions. I know from years of teaching my parents and grandparents how to use a phone (or computer or dvd player) about the barrier with terminology: I say "open the calculator app"and the word "open" doesn't make sense to them. Your cards say "Tap the picture of the calculator." This attention to detail is fantastic. You picked up on the importance of barriers set by lexicon, true for many design issues.

Terrific analogous inspiration Daniel  I particularly like that they've created a guided, user-friendly yet still sophisticated journey for new cell phone users. And like Matt mentioned, the keepsake hardcover book elevates the product and its experience to something more than a quick tutorial for a new phone.

Very cool! I resonate with the "hardcover book" manual that is simple, effective, and conversational in tone.  The use of infographics keeps it playful and easy to understand.I guess I wonder whether the whole process could be digital?  Cutting down on printed materials / extra packaging would be a great next step.  Maybe the phone explains itself digitally as you turn it on for the first time?

_out_of_the_box_mobile_phone_packaging.title: "Out of the box" mobile phone packaging

don_t_just_grab_a_coffee_get_other_chore.description: Similar to systems at amusement parks, voters could sign up for time slots for voting. However, in addition to voting, provide other services such as tax preparation, parent-teacher talks, grocery shopping (at dedicated computer stations) etc
don_t_just_grab_a_coffee_get_other_chore.creator: 51d133637a5ecad9bdf9ac40c800abfd
don_t_just_grab_a_coffee_get_other_chore.title: Don't just grab a coffee, get other chores done.

limited_space._lots_of_people.description: My experience accompanying my dad to vote during the last elections in Metro Manila, Philippines in 2010 and the difficulties of trying to find information amidst the mass people.
limited_space._lots_of_people.creator: bf183546af21a5b49853afe9240e21a7

comments.text: Birdie, you make a very relevant observation, since space varies between Polling Stations, and of course the smaller the station, the larger the challenge to permit an accessible election experience for everyone. This makes me think about defining certain physical standards for all polling stations, which might have to vary depending on the volume of voters each station is expecting or other factors.

This is fascinating. Voting in the Philippines sounds very stressful. I can't imagine how a first-time voter or a disabled voter would be able to navigate the crowds and megaphones. But I guess it's better to have the problem of too many voters instead of too few...
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Birdie, I just love this story - it's fantastic. Really personal and insightful. It makes me think of other inspiring examples of queue management - such as how Apple Stores will take your order whilst you're in line. Also you hint towards ways of making the line an opportunity to help educate. That's brilliant - save that thought for the Concepting phase in a couple of weeks.

Really good relating of personal experience Birdie.By contrast our polling places are set up in schools, scout halls, community halls, libraries and other publicly accessible places. These facilities tend to be distributed roughly according to population density. Polling booths will have between 1 and about 6 queues, depending on the building size. In more than 40 years (probably 20 elections) I don't recall  spending more than 15 minutes in a queueOften families living at the one address will vote together making the marking of the vote registration quite efficient.
Welcome Birdie! Great first post, providing personal insights which may spark a number of ideas amongst our community of global collaborators.  Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.

limited_space._lots_of_people.title: Limited space. Lots of people

non_traditional_views_from_voter.description: Since I started to interview some citizen, I found that not all the people are willing to vote, and some of them are unsatisfied with the election for years. This made me worry about the situation of the election process.
non_traditional_views_from_voter.creator: 2ed42562c28e8f500f50f18642a80c51

comments.text: Thanks for sharing, Jiangxuan!
Thank you Jiangxuan for sharing the results of your interviews. It is always good to hear opinions direct from the source.

Indeed it's great to have you going and interviewing people. I guess in the case of Charlie W, there is a general questioning about the democratic process which reminded that inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-a-task-or-an-opportunityThis influences his motivation, or creates his lack of motivation... As Whitney pointed out - http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/think-a-wheelchair-user-s-daily-struggle/- , what kind of motivation do you need when you are also facing challenges due to accessibility? Last, I can see the question of having access to the right information to help you in your decision process:http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/confusion-and-empowerment-/http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-art-of-choosing/thanks again for sharing your findings!

This means that we need to integrate the use of technology and have a secure way of having polling come to the user, rather than the user come to the polling place.
Nice, these videos really help in understanding some of the challenges and how to address them, rather than just a set of written guidelines.
Great way to engage officials towards empathy!

comments.text: Paul, have you looked at the mobility and orientation resources at VisionAustralia? http://www.visionaustralia.orghttp://www.visionaustralia.org.au/info.aspx?page=2038The also have a link to a radio panel yesterday on orientation and mobility that you might find useful: http://www.visionaustralia.org.au/info.aspx?page=823&news=2503And their policy on access to voting:http://www.visionaustralia.org.au/info.aspx?page=2508

Tactile maps are used more frequently today then in the past and embossers exist that can create tactile maps on paper rather than expensive plastic. However there are few commerciql printers that can produce tactile maps. For areas where voting takes place in centralized locations, the provision of a tactile map of the polling place to blind voters may be practical. However, in areas where citizens vote at their local polling place, producing tactile maps of each polling place would probably not be practical. In this instance, the information that a map would contain can be conveyed verbally to the blind voter by a poll worker, friend, or family member. Then, using a cane or guide dog the blind voter can move independently to the voting machine.
Thanks for the input and links I lost my updates about 2am this morning and decided to sleep on it before trying to update again -this will actually become tatile and Narrative Maps shortly

Thanks for the insights too Lou Ann - im hoping that someone may be inspired to find an inexpensive and practical way to produce something like portable tactile maps supported by audio. I am going to link to a few websites that have been active in this area such as these related sites http://www.intouchgraphics.com/ and http://www.clickandgomaps.com/ Thanks too WhitneyI have now had the chance to listen to the radio program and review some of the http://www.visionaustralia.org information

customised_election_practices_in_develop.description: Due to lack of resources, low levels of democracy or high corruption levels, electoral practices in the developing world are usually customized: to meet local conditions in rural areas, to involve vulnerable people of all categories and all processes
customised_election_practices_in_develop.creator: e43734c2a8eed0c20a8150795b2343a3

comments.text: Hey Takang,i like the idea of customisation . It would be helpful if we could dig out some simple and effective examples of the same.like i would like to know if the solutions vary completely or people re organise the same solution to meet different constraints ! any clue on that ?

Hi Tony,Great contribution and like you rightly said, I strongly agree with you that  United Nation troops should be sent to nations that intimidate voters especially on voting days. I further point out that the bigger problem is with pre-election day violence which registers the highest electoral violence in developing nations including corruption, intimidation, information lag, discrimination, exclusion etc. Therefore an additional big issue is whether united Nations troops should be sent to these nations to help  prevent election violence before election day and for what length of time if they must produce results.

The USA had its own history of voter intimidation.  When African-Americans were granted the right to vote in 1870, white supremacist intimidated them by threatening violence unless they turn around and abort their intentions to cast a vote.  In other areas,  polling stations charged a fee  to cast a vote if you're black, or men threatening violence will dictate how a black voter should vote.   The government sent federal troops to protect  black voters and preserve their right to vote.  Perhaps this is what is needed where voter intimidation is prevalent.  United Nation troops should be mobilized to protect the safety of voters on election day.

customised_election_practices_in_develop.title: Customised election practices in developing countries:

voting_is_private_but_elections_are_soci.description: We're more likely to vote if/when we know that our friends and neighbors are also voting. What if sharing the experience can also help communities extend their support for disabled members into and around Election Day?
voting_is_private_but_elections_are_soci.creator: 94da4376f0d738db16804f11001b0284

comments.text: When I read this I couldnt stop thinking in ideas about election sharing, I strongly agree of what you say that "voting is private but elections are social", I can say from my own experience that sharing the experience of voting from one of my friends have encouraged others to do the same. Thanks for the inspiration Kathryn!

Kathryn, to me your comment is definitely an inspiration. With out a doubt the learning we've gotten form all social media networks is that we like to be in the trends, in the know, up to date, etc. So yes, I believe there is a large potential to build over your observation and take advantage of these networks on real time to promote a larger assistance, to communicate wait time, to inform bets times to vote for handicapped people, etc, etc.
While I see the positive effect of flocking, it can also have the negative effect when paired with areas of apathy. This may discourage people from standing out for good or bad.Great post :)

Some very interesting points here Kathryn.Door to door canvassing is very common in Australian state and federal elections and many candidates make a point of offering assistance to people who may find it difficult to attend polling places by arranging transport (taxis etc,) - naturally they see potential for support from the voter too but largely they are fulfilling the established ethos of enabling all eligible electors to vote.

Great insight.The social aspect reminded me the inspiration about elections as festive: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/elections-a-kind-of-festive-season-in-indiaIt also reminded me a post in the vibrant city challenge on the power of visualizing data in influencing behaviors: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/inspiration/tidy-street-changing-neighbors-behaviors-through-voluntary-monitoring-and-public-infographics/

Two of the main reasons why people do not vote is because they don't think their vote matters or they just don't care enough about politics. Social channels have the power to address both issues. By illustrating votes with a graph or image such as this, people are given a badge of honor and may feel more empowered to vote. Regular social media users clearly care about what their friends are doing. Seeing their friends' votes pop up on the chart will remind and encourage them to vote. In addition, social channels can provide information on issues and enable voters to learn in a quick and effective way, making them more confident to go out to the polls.

Kathryn, great insight here. Nothing works better than a bit of indirect peer pressure whe you see your friends have voted. I wonder if a social media platform added a nudged, i.e something on your page that shows you havent voted, would work? Calling out people who havent voted in a public arena?

James, Kathryn: like a FourSquare for elections! i.e. send out messages like: "James voted from the John Smith electoral constituency area." to friends and followers. (We might not be able to make someone a mayor of a place just on that basis though :))It could then automatically put up a counter on your twitter/FB showing how many of your friends voted or didn't.

I definitely applaud leveraging (and celebrating) the social aspect of elections, creating a dynamic exchange (virtual, or analog, like a number of other inspirations posted) for people to share in the election 'buzz'. As a means to encourage more voters, I think the peer pressure concept is brilliantif friends haven't checked in via social media that they have voted, a prompt for you to nudge them to go vote could be pretty powerful. Often people will be more responsive to friends than the media at large. Taking that model  to the weeks and months leading up to election day (inviting friends to a Facebook event, or the like; voter registration street parties) could help build more of a sense of community into the process, and help balance out the unending political commentary were subjected to.

Mei Hsieh proposed "rivalry!" for the revitalizing cities challenge. Similarly, cities or colleges could compete on a platform like this to be the most "politically responsible" city-college-state-whatever. Winners could win visits from victorious candidates and or candidates for future elections. Imagine Duke competing against North Carolina for greater voter participation.
Here's the link to Mei's winning Rivalry concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/concepting/rivalry-a-competitive-challenge-network-to-spark-business-growth-and-city-spirit/
Incorporating a social aspect to voting is a great idea! Even getting a sticker that says "I voted" is quite powerful too and something that I look forward to getting.

"the act of voting is contagious" is definetly a way to promote people to vote, social webpages are experiencing lots of insights about the process. I think promote young people more than others, because we need to vote for good leaders for our countries.

comments.text: Hey Ollie , i like this inspiration , and its true some of the suggestive solutions are simple and effective.I also agree when u mention how can we make it wordless and yet universally accessible. I had similar thoughts when i posted my inspiration from emoticons.Here is the link to same . http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/-emoticons-the-universal-vocabulary-of-expressions-for-chatting-/

There's some nice out-of-the-box thinking in the mockups in this competition. Our ballots can be really challenging for anyone, but especially for people who don't read well, or have any cognitive disability that affects focus and concentration. Nice ideas for how we can do better.
Yes, lots of great creative ideas here!

@WhitneyThanks for the feedback! In particular I wonder if the idea could be taken further to include the functionally illiterate and non-English speaking populations by making ballots entirely wordless?

Interesting idea. I've been thinking about being able to combine audio and visual text in a really seamless way. Instead of audio being just something for people who can't see, it becomes a second channel of information, reinforcing the visual.One challenge in US elections is that ballots often include questions that voters decide directly. They don't just have words... they have a lot of words! Plain language summaries, and explanations of what it means to say Yes or No are really important for every voter.

Some are disgruntled for various reasons to the extent they decide to be left out as a means of  retaliation of how they feel about the system.

Very inspiring to see the different persons interviewed being so motivated by voting. The "who" indeed was mentioned and I think mattered. I guess these persons who inspired them are also those who helped them and made the process as smooth as possible.
Thanks, Anne-Laure. Yes, these people, I think, have very very important roles not only in "helping", as you say, but also in empowering them.

Thanks Ana for the clarification. I did not mean to stress only the helping part, but the inspirational part... empowering encompasses the 2 to a certain extent. Clearly something to keep in mind when it comes to the concepting phase.

I really appreciated your insight that the 'who' influences people to vote just as much as the 'what'. The act of voting is essentially staking a claim in your community and empowering the people who help empower others is a fantastic idea.
Hey, Andre. Thanks for you comment. That was exactly the idea behind this inspiration - that was in fact THE inspiration. Empowerment is a very important and useful word.

comments.text: Interesting point, Jakob, about how most of us can't read the chart you've posted. It makes me wonder how we might display voting materials more visually for people who have trouble reading or who don't speak the local language. We've seen some inspirations about using pictures/images in voting, but what other examples might we learn from as we head into Concepting?

Good point! Somthing that comes up is a Ted talk I remember that might inspire:"In Rajasthan, India, an extraordinary school teaches rural women and men -- many of them illiterate -- to become solar engineers, artisans, dentists and doctors in their own villages. It's called the Barefoot College, and its founder, Bunker Roy, explains how it works."
The link: http://www.ted.com/talks/bunker_roy.html

Simple visual tools such as these are particularly valuable if they link users directly and easily to the sources of the data that was used to generate them. This way, they may act as a good starting point for getting informed, but don't run the risk of promoting only superficial engagement with the issues.
Love it! We're actually working on a DemDash feature that will let us generate reports like this as well, coming pretty soon.
Way to go Dan! Think easy accessable track records will push democracy in a god way!

Interesting thoughts Prita  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Social media is powerful. I've noticed that a lot of election departments are using Twitter for announcements.How else can we use YouTube, Twitter and other social media?

Perhaps we can create mock elections during certain debates where one needs to tweet their votes or opinions? We can also essentially monitor the debate with our own opinions and believes through comments if YouTube does a live stream!
