voting_a_labyrinth_of_obstacles_and_rule.description: Voting in New York City can be more complex and frustrating than doing a Rubik's cube one-handed. Cumbersome ballots w/ four languages, confusing old machines, cramped poll sites w/ only certain stations for certain voters, paper-based registries...
voting_a_labyrinth_of_obstacles_and_rule.creator: cbd44f8b5b48a51f7dab98abcdf45d4e

comments.text: very helpful insight, thanks for this contribution really helps to focus in on the touchpoint problems

If it's this difficult for an English speaker who lives near a poll site and is interested in voting to cast their ballot, I can only imagine the difficulty others must have with the system. This list reminds me that sometimes, before we can make the system work better for some people, we simply have to make the system work better for everyone.

Thanks for your comment Alex.  I'm reminded of this other inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/when-the-solutions-for-disabled-becomes-the-new-standard/Let's design a voting process that works for everyone rather than making countless amendments to one that deliberately excluded most people.

Brian - I had forgotten how complex the rules in NY were.  I registered to vote there my Freshman year of college.My sophomore year of college I went to vote and discovered I was no longer registered.At the time, if any of the election materials sent to you were returned as undeliverable, you would be removed from the voter roles.  Since I was not living in the dorms over the summer (and voter materials could not be forwarded), a notice about a primary got returned and I was de-listed.I understood why they had implemented that rule (NYC is a transient city with many people coming and going and it's hard to keep track of who is still in residence and who should be eligible to vote); however, in their attempt to make sure that only eligible people could vote, they ended up disenfranchising quite a few eligible people that didn't realize we'd need to re-register each year if we'd left for the summer.It's a good reminder to watch out for unintended consequences when reviewing our own proposals!

Thanks for your anecdote Jessica!  I wasn't even aware of this particular rule.  I know voting for students generally around the country is problematic, and given the nature of New York it seems that things get extra complicated.  I remember when I was a student, there were lots of rumors about how registering to vote at your school address instead of your permanent address in another state could ruin your financial aid.  This made many very hesitant to register, and students did not vote in their home state or at school.Bottom line is that too many complicated rules creates yet another barrier to voting.
Brian, this is such a terrific rundown of some of the issues facing polling places and voters. Thanks so much for sharing your personal insights with us.

voting_a_labyrinth_of_obstacles_and_rule.title: VOTING: A Labyrinth of Obstacles and Rules

wounded_warrior_designing_homes_for_the_.description: Most injured U.S. service men and women returning from war must adapt to a home, even if it complies with Americans with Disabilities Act guidelines. This approach to designing new homes started with their needs from the ground up.
wounded_warrior_designing_homes_for_the_.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: As an architect, this is truly an inspiring story. I am really impressed with IDEO taking on such challenge. This just shows how small design moves can make large differences; and that every design must stem from a comprehensive understanding of the challenges, not just cosmetic. As designers, I think we have the potential to design outcomes that surpass the user's expectations, and this is a case that proves just that. Thank you for this project!

In the video I was particularly struck by Shannon's experiences getting her hair done at home because she didn't want to deal with the stress and self-consciousness she felt going to a salon. I wonder how many people don't cast their ballots for similar reasons?

So glad you posted this! I was very interested in this project when I first saw it on ideo's website. Dignity certainly deserves to be emboldened in this challenge. I posted a comment regarding it on "Portland Used iPads for Accessible Voting Before It Was Cool" from a quote I read in metropolis magazine's article about ideo's project--"Wounded veterans dont want to be coddled, they want to be challenged. They need homes that help them reclaim control, that dont make them feel different from their wives and children." dignity is so crucial to enthusiastic participation, I'm glad you focused in on that I hope many are inspired by this great contribution!

wounded_warrior_designing_homes_for_the_.title: Wounded Warrior - Designing Homes for the Disabled

why_won_t_you_vote.description: For a vibrant democracy, it's of vital importance to get as many people to vote as possible. The first step to improving the percentage of people voting lies in understanding why those who don’t vote, don’t vote.
why_won_t_you_vote.creator: 298c9f3fc51afb5aae8d9407a3e76027

comments.text: Thank you Ashley and Mamta. I was trying to get a hold on the subject myself and ended up writing what I was trying to understand.
This is a really nice holistic view of voting, and I like how you've noted that each issue is interconnected. Nice work Vinu!
Thanks Vinu, for a graphical representation of the same !
Thank you Paul. I was trying to help myself understand the different reasons why one might not vote. I hope we can keep adding to the list to get as clear an idea of the various barriers to voting.

I can see what your point about voter apathy. In fact it is one of the aspects that a good voting system needs to take into account. However, when I was talking about taking the ballot box to the voter, I did not mean it in a literal sense. I was wondering if it could be made more accessible to people who find it difficult to get to polling booths to cast their votes.
Vinu, a great summary of many barriers to voting.It complements a number of other inspirations.

In my humble opinion, governments and the international community should not seek to promote democracy by funding initiatives to combat voter apathy. For me this is because if populations refuse to register and vote, they have a reason for it. In my country Cameroon for instance, there is no need to register to vote for someone who has been in power for thirty years and still clings to power with little to show for it. Instead the international community should fund surveys to document why people don't want to register and vote. This done incumbents should be stripped of power and proper elections conducted for the miserable people.

Unfortunately the path to democracy is long and painful, often involving revolution, civil war and even when established requires constant evolution.The very fact that there is a need for this challenge even in an established democracy like the US shows there is a long way to go before true majority representation. Even then there are flavours of democracy depending on economic philosophy.

Taking the ballot box to the population like you said is one way of combating voter apathy. In Africa this would mean trekking in deep mud by the supervisory authorities to conduct elections which would have double constraint because it would be difficult to bring back ballot boxes to the central location. This system would facilitate data falsification as the team would have to traverse bushes to convey ballot documents which would  enable them falsify figures and signatures.

why_won_t_you_vote.title: Why Won't you Vote?

just_like_a_food_truck...meeting_voters_.description: What if we could create a voting system that functioned like the food trucks that roam the streets of so many cities? We could improve access, reduce wait times at the polls and cut the amount of travel time required of voters (less CO2).
just_like_a_food_truck...meeting_voters_.creator: 6ca53c38aff4f2024f8442bd320a8ea2

comments.text: Another great post Josh! It reminded me of Joyce's inspiration too http://bit.ly/zw2siN.Here's a quick tip: you might want to connect Joyce's submission to your post using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like 'social media' and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!
Thanks for the tip, Ashley. It's really nice to get helpful feedback about the features of the openIDEO platform. I'm fairly new to it so I'm still trying to figure out some of the finer points.

Paul R., if you're not familiar with the USA voting system, it's not as liberal in other countries where you simply show up and cast your vote.   You have to be at least 18 years old, be an American (or naturalized) citizen, and be a registered voter.  Each state has more requirements.  Here's a website to give more info to cast a vote in USA.http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0781452.htmlFurthermore, each state has passed laws to add more constraints to the USA voting system.  For example, in the 2000 Presidential election between George Bush (republican) and Al Gore (Democrat), the governor of Florida (Jeb Bush, a republican) passed voting restrictions and enforced them on areas that are majority Democrat registered voters.  Although Gore won the popular (people) vote, Bush won the electoral vote.   Historically,  American voters have always been vulnerable to rhetoric and deception by political candidates.  IMO deception is an integral part of the election campaign of every candidate.  A portion of the American population believe mud slinging (disparaging remarks) is a sign of strength in a candidate.  If candidate_A says "I can lower taxes & balance the (budget) books without cutbacks on any programs (spending)" and candidate_B says "there is no way we can balance the books without either cutting back on spending or increasing taxes..."   the American voters will select candidate_A.   This is why the USA has a serious deficit & cannot solve its domestic problems; the vast majority of registered American voters are not realistic in analyzing the situation.  They want instant gratification, so they select candidate_A without analyzing his statement.   Candidate_B is too realistic of the situation, which is why this candidate will loose the election.  Candidate_A is making promises he's not likely going to keep, but his statement appeals to various voters.  The middle and upper middle-class voters will focus on his promise to lower taxes, while the working class (blue collar) will focus on his promise not to cut spending on social programs to help people on the lower end of the socio-economic ladder.  To summarize, the failure of American government lies in the voters.   In the end, they often vote the wrong candidate into office because the American voters wants instant gratification.  Its an issue with the psyche of the American people.

This analogy makes me think of the mobile library (Bookmobile in the US?) that used to visit my town when I was younger. That kind of vehicle would be perfect. I love the idea of it playing ice cream van chimes as well, and everyone streaming out of their houses like excited children to vote. It makes the idea of voting a lot more playful.
I definitely feel you on the playful nature of the ice-cream chimes. Better yet, maybe there could actually be ice cream. Who said that voting had to be such a chore?

I vote for ice-cream every time!However the bookmobile is another excellent analogy.Regarding the chimes - maybe there could be an election musical theme used in all advertising associated with elections and then used to alert voters to the proximity of the mobile voting stations.

The food trucks are a business profit venture, which is why you see so many of them.  Setting up polling locations and staffing them are all taxpayers' expense.  Creating a mobile polling vehicle would have the added cost of renting or leasing these vehicles, or paying polling staff additional compensation for using their personal vehicles as mobile polling stations.  If polling staff are hurt by a mentally unstable voter who becomes violent when voters with opposing views verbally express their feelings, then it raises the question of the added cost of security to protect the safety of polling staff.  IMO the cheapest way to make it easier to cast their vote is online voting.  We can pay our bills and make  retail purchases online, so why not expand internet use to online voting as well ??   People would enter their social security number as their user_names, their date of birth as the password, and their zip code as another layer of security.  On another related topic to your food truck idea, I live near Riverside and San Bernardino Counties.  The restaurants lobbied (and passed) a law making it a criminal violation for lunch trucks (with cooking grills) to do business in these counties.  The only lunch trucks allowed are ones who sell cold sandwiches or pre-made hot sandwiches.  This law was intended to increase restaurants' lunch-time revenue.  This is why voting and showing up at town hall meetings is important.  You don't want special-interest lobby groups dictate how you should spend your lunch money.

Tony, I think the analogy is a good one, there is no suggestion that the food trucks become mobile voting stations only that if mobile polling stations were set up they could visit voters like food trucks do.As for competing with restaurants the mobile booths would compete with no one - just offer the service to voters.By the way does everyone have a social security number?Once again I am ignorant of the complicated American system and still trying to understand it.

just_like_a_food_truck...meeting_voters_.title: Just Like a Food Truck...Meeting Voters on Their Turf

the_importance_of_properly_trained_poll_.description: Poll workers in the United States who are not properly trained on how to setup and operate the accessible voting machine may prevent voters with disabilities from exercising their right to vote privately and independently.
the_importance_of_properly_trained_poll_.creator: 52ccec73edeaf4de1a4b377644cdef1c

comments.text: Maybe poll workers could be trained with a serious game. IJsfontein build several serious games, also to train bank employees. This could be carried over to poll workers I think.http://www.ijsfontein.nl/diensten/serious-games/serious-gaming-financiele-sector/

Thanks for sharing this inspiration Lou Ann.  It is important to realize that while we have at least (voluntary) standards for accessible voting systems, we do not have similar standards for poll worker training. It is often the human element that is the biggest barrier.
Agreed, accessible technology is limited, if the broader systems/human elements around it don't properly support.

I posted a link to some training material for poll workers http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/sensitivity-to-voters-with-disabilities/ since you seem to agree that training is important I wanted to share it here. But from Ann's story I understand training is not always enough. What I like about this video however is that it puts you in the voters shoos. In that way I think it helps people to understand that everyone want s to be able to vote independently and privately.

Thank you Lou-Ann your points are well made.Training of and payment to poll workers are two issues I feel very strongly about. In Australia all elections are deemed sufficiently important for the state to publicly fund both training and payment of poll workers to provide the service necessary for smooth operation.If I may ask three questions of you -Do you own and use a mobile phone or landline?Is the voter card used to operate the machine exclusive to you?When you respond to the audio ballot do you use voice or keypad?Sorry to ask these but as an Australian I am trying to understand the US system.to which I have no direct access.

Hi Paul, I can help with two of the questions:The voter card on the system I think Lou Ann is describing is just an activation card. It does not contain personal information, and is reused throughout the day. There are several different activation systems - a card, a code, etc. - used in different voting systems.In this case, the card can also be used to indicate the party (for primary elections), or enable audio ballot. More ideally, a voter could choose to use the audio without any assistance or special set up.As far as I know, none of the audio ballot systems include voice response, for privacy. There are a few experimental systems that allow any sound to act as a "click" as a way to allow voice activation without using any speech that could be matched to a selection being made.

Hi Paul and Whitney, I do own an iPhone. In fact, it is the only phone I use now that I have disconnected my landline. Many of my blind friends and I are looking forward to the day when we will be able to cast our vote using an iPhone.Whitney is correct about the voter card. The primary purpose of the card is to tell the machine which ballot to display. The card also activates the audio ballot when it is properly loaded by the poll worker. As Whitnery states, the ideal design would not require action by the poll worker to enable the audio ballot. Rather, the audio ballot function would always be on and the voter would simply have to plug in headphones to hear it.I am not aware of any voting machines currently in use in actual elections in the U.S. that have voice response capability.
I think you are right, ideally accessibility features should always be ready to use without human intervention.

Thanks Lou-Ann and Whitney.I am gradually understanding some of the details of US voting.My enquiry regarding phone was related to the fact that I should like to explore possibilities of using telephone for voting. Not everyone will have a smart phone but I am imagining that most visually impaired will have access to a telephone of some sort.Could you imagine some variation to the audio voting process that would allow responses by using the keypad of any telephone?Here I use a pre-paid phone that I reload by purchasing a numbered voucher. I can choose to use the voucher at any time up to the expiry date. When I dial to reload I am asked a series of questions (including the voucher number) that I respond to using the keypad. I am envisioning something similar for voting.

There is one voting system that uses a phone keypad as the tactile input.There is another system in which the actual voting happens on a phone line.  In current implementations, it is used from a polling place, rather than from any phone, so the voter signs in just as they do now, but this is available as an accessible, non-visual option. Also, although we sometimes talk about poll workers as volunteers, they are paid, and are also given training both initially and every year or every major election cycle.

Thanks so much for the reply Whitney.I am trying to work up a concept where using the phone keypad would be the most basic form of input so for presidential/vice-presidential elections, for example, the audio prompts would be "To vote for A and B press 1, to hear the next candidates press 2, to start over press 3 etc." If the voter has keypad input options then that part of the voting process could be done on any phone from anywhere at any time. Nice as smart phones are not everyone can afford them and if people could use landline as well it could include payphones too.

Thanks for sharing your personal experience Lou Ann. We've seen the question of proper poll worker training come up in other inspirations, and your story underscores that. I'll be eager to see what solutions we might develop together in our upcoming Concepting phase.

the_importance_of_properly_trained_poll_.title: The Importance of Properly Trained Poll Workers

an_interview_with_my_grandpa.description: I used the Voting Challenge’s Inspiration Interview Kit to interview my grandfather in California about his voting experiences. Here’s what I learned.
an_interview_with_my_grandpa.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: I also like talking to parents and grandparents to get their views and feelings - I think that we should build on this and involve them in what we do. We can certainly use the support!And as see in your example, online research and "all this other new online stuff" was adopted and integrated by them. I really value that openness.

Ashley - Wonderful research!  This is such a telling sentiment regarding your Grandpa's perception of changing party affiliations : its too much of a hassle to go through the paperwork.  It does seem like a hassle to change.  The interesting thing I noticed is your Grandfather generates his political knowledge online.  I'm impressed that a 99-year old is so tech savvy!  Seems like an on-line method may span generations more that I had thought.  Your grandfather (and many more in his generation) could much more easily access and update their voting affiliation / preferences / address, etc.  Is there a method for changing party affiliation on-line?  Or is it only by mail-in?

Thanks Matt! I'm glad you enjoyed this inspiration. To be honest, I'm not sure how to go about changing party affiliation - my hunch is that it actually is a paper-based process at least in California where I live. I think I chose my party affiliation when I got my driver's license at the dept of motor vehicles (which never quite made sense to me). But since you can vote however you want (regardless of your party affiliation), I'd bet that only the most motivated folks really ever bother with changing their party. So embedded in this question isn't just the issue of process, but also of mindset and attitude: if I can vote however I want, does the designation even matter?

Thanks, Ashley, for this heart-warming story about your grandfather. (And I thank others who have given us personal stories. The people in these stories are the people whom this challenge is all about.)The work that Dana Chisnell and I did a few years ago for AARP showed how diverse the people we call "older adults" are. To make that diversity visually obvious -- and to help developers think about all the people they are designing for, we developed a multifaceted model. The 4As model shows that we have to consider not only age, but also ability, aptitude, and attitude. I've just put up an inspiration showing and explaining that model. I called the inspiration: Older adults are not all alike.
Terrific Ginny  I can't wait to check out your inspiration!

Thank you for sharing, it's a very inspiring story. It makes me realize how serious the election problem is, since it becomes more and more obvious that it was never designed for people and to accommodate users, instead it is oriented to treat humans as numbers and votes.

Thanks for the very informative piece Ashley.Again from experience here (in Australia) it is difficult to understand why there is a need to register for any particular affiliation.Our registration is simply to place us on the roll of voters - nothing to do with who we might "follow" (in twitter terms).Maybe this is another reason voting here seems so much easier.

an_interview_with_my_grandpa.title: An Interview with My Grandpa

the_technological_distance.description: People with disabilities face different challanges every day. At  the beginning one should explore the different needs of each disability to find a solution which fits best to everyone.
the_technological_distance.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: Helena I agree with you for the most part although I think finding a single solution may be too difficult but would suggest that perhaps 2 or 3 options might be sufficient. I think telephone is the most likely candidate for the majority and I think even most elderly can cope with a Touch phone (one with numbered keys rather than a rotary dial.You might like to look at Tom Noonan's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/the-voice-of-decomcray-if-you-can-use-a-phone-you-can-vote/

Hello Paul, thank you for your interest. Perhaps you misunderstood me a little. Perhaps I didn`t convey it clearly enough. The telephone was only meant symbolically, as example for a common stereotype. Like the ordinary phone icon. I actually wanted to point out that we should look for such stereotyps in form, color and usability which are easy to handle by everyone because of their long lasting practise and their worldwide connotation.

Thanks for clarifying this Helena. I don't consider myself elderly but I am 61 years old and I completely agree that being familiar with some things makes them very suitable for all. When I was young, in England, some telephones didn't even have dials you had to ring the exchange and tell them who you wanted to call. In some ways it is easier to expect the young to adapt to older technology than to expect the elderly to adapt to new things.

the_technological_distance.title: The  technological distance

voting_using_marbles.description: This method was used in the Gambia in 2011 presidential elections. it involves the use of marbles and metal containers for every candidate.
voting_using_marbles.creator: e5369c90f7f603c7ce2ca54e932d6251

comments.text: This is an innovative one for me. Bravo.
Thanx, Tankang :)

Thanks Abdelrahman!Great inspiration illustrating an actual voting process using physical objects. Also some very creative thinking on avoiding multiple voting, determining when casting a vote is completed and rapid counting.The article doesn't mention precautions taken to avoid someone rejoining the queue but probably the local level of trust is sufficient.Using such a simple process also means the counting can be public.A truly imaginative approach.
Thanks Paul,

Agreed with Paul, this is a great inspiration Abdelrahman! Certainly opens up our eyes outside of Gambia to new possibilities.Noticed that the article mentioned that election officials listen to the bell to ensure no one votes multiple times when entering the voting area. Just wondering, how would officials be able to cancel an illegitimate multi-vote, in case they hear more than one bell sound from a voter?

Hi Vincent, i suppose in a country like Gambia, a suspect would be captured and made to confess. But i think this is a mistake in their design which could have been prevented if the system was electronic which is easy to program to report violations in a smarter way.

Abdelrahman - I have been thinking about variations on this and the controls that might be applied. The two things that I really like about this are: the simple technology involved and the possibility of rapid public counting so the community that has voted can see and know the true results of their efforts.This is a great way to build trust in the process for remote communities all over the developing world.

Simple way to address illiteracy issues.  Abdelrahman, do you know how much privacy people have to vote with this system?  I suspect the photos may be showcasing the drums, rather than demonstrating the typical voting set-up.

Thanx Carla, the picture above shows the drums sealed with red plastic straps after the polls closed. Unfortunately, all the articles i have read focused mostly on the unique design but never mentioned whether or not the voters went behind a curtain for privacy. I think believe it is a very necessary for voters to have some privacy of some sort like going behind a wall or curtain where the drums would be placed.

Thanks Abdelrahan for sharing this inspiration with us. I use a similar system during some of the design projects I coordinate on the University. At the end of a project we always like to select a winner of the best design project of the semester. We use public voting among the students. It is remarkable simple and it empowers the public.

voting_using_marbles.title: Voting using Marbles

online_platform_for_home_bound_voters.description: The rapid advances in technology and security on the internet have created a huge opportunity to reach home-bound or disabled members of our society.  Creating an online and a contact based program would significantly increase voter turnout.
online_platform_for_home_bound_voters.creator: 1e1417769e57b1ae84542f52b8b45a0c

comments.text: The contrasts you draw between our current voting system and existing online transactions (like banking) are pretty distinct, underscoring how archaic and vulnerable the process is at the moment. Especially in light of the fact that there are assistance programs already in place to provide disabled customers equal accessibility, online voting seems like a no-brainer, and has huge potential to increase election participation.

Terrific insights Ember, especially your work interviewing two people with very interesting perspectives. Any chance you could find an image to go along with your post? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.
Thank you for the advice, Ashley.  I was able to successfully update the photo, so for future posts, I will definitely make sure to include that.
Great point about security, perceived vs. reality, of voting.

parkingfee_machines.description: I thought it could be interesting to watch different types of Parking-fee- and vending machines. They are more and more designed with big colourful buttons and graphic symbols easily recognizable. And with lots of smart functions.
parkingfee_machines.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Nice work drawing on analogies here Johan! I'll be eager to see how this conversation continues...

This inspiration made me think about all of the different kinds of public kiosks. These parking fee machines have big buttons that are probably easy to press - for people wearing gloves, or with dexterity disabilities. Another similar example is the the Amtrak ticket machine, which uses the EZ Access keypad. There are photos, and a description of why the keys are designed the way they are at the Trace Center web site: http://trace.wisc.edu/handouts/ez-intro/ and http://trace.wisc.edu/faqs/ezfaq/index.html

Also a good idea, there would have to be some kind of concessions for deaf voters, as well as a way to keep noise down for those who may not need audio help but drive through voting would definitely streamline the process and make it more accessible.

Thank you for commenting.I guess that almost all deaf voters have their vision and can read. Please elaborate on what you are meaning?If people have several severe disabilities they would probably have personal assistent or a relative accompanying them to vote. Or by postal vote, from home.

Correct there may be voters with both visual and auditory impairments, who might be otherwise independent. Most ATMs near me are completely touch screen which is what I first thought of but like you said this could be altered by having physical buttons and not just touch screen so those who have visual impairments could still feel the buttons and know where to press.

parkingfee_machines.title: Parkingfee machines

fund_and_implement_u.s._law.description: The United States government is not properly implementing the Help America Vote Act.  For instance, it needs to appoint election assistance commissioners.  Let’s give it push in that direction!
fund_and_implement_u.s._law.creator: 4092c3521e4fcad2d401ba8f0cfe3885

comments.text: Thanks for sharing your provocative thoughts, David. We're keen to think about how we can innovate under constraints rather than taking up issues surrounding regulations and enforcement for particular countries. Instead of focusing on what's not working, we're keen for OpenIDEO collaborators to help us think about examples where transparency, equality and fairness *are* working  let's learn from inspiring analogies and examples to fuel our thinking as we gear up for Concepting. You can check out more on the challenge Guiding Principles: http://bit.ly/vote_guide Looking forward to seeing more from you in this challenge!

Hi Meena, the chief elections officer of LA County says he is using this challenge as a way to collect inspirations/ideas for better voting in general, guided by the LA Voting Systems Assessment Project (VSAP) principles linked on the ITIS/OPENideo site.  The LA official is very pleased to have the ability to piggyback on the crowdsourcing platform here.  His remarks can be heard/viewed at http://livestre.am/1fUVv . The LA official sees this website as a timely way to fulfill the VSAP advisory committee's desire for crowdsourcing in general.  For LA, then, use of this website's challenge is not limited to accessibility -- accessibility is really only part of 2 or 3 of the many LA VSAP principles.  For LA, it is also not limited to things that *are* working -- it includes things that *could* work or *did* work!  Thanks to ITIS/OPENideo for letting my county use the ongoing challenge for its purposes too!  Those purposes include addressing constraints related to "regulations and enforcement."  By taking LA County as a co-sponsor, and by posting LA's principles, links, logo and videos, OPENideo and ITIS have evidently consented to expand the challenge beyond its nominal scope.   So OPENideo really should not be suggesting that posts be limited when they might in any way help LA get a new voting system that meets the LA VSAP principles -- especially since OPENideo has posted those principles as part of this challenge.  OPENideo should be open!Now, WITH REGARD TO THIS INSPIRATION:  The U.S. Election Assistance Commission (EAC) *did* work when it had commissioners.  In fact, under current US law, any system inspired or developed by this challenge must be certified by the EAC to be used in U.S. Government elections.  So acting on the inspiration I proposed (or something similar) is a prerequisite to the success of the challenge here!

fund_and_implement_u.s._law.title: Fund and implement U.S. law!

comments.text: Excellent Deepak!Very commonsense approach and some interesting ideas to flesh out here. Do you have any idea of how extensive the AADHAR card is at the moment.?

I like the way that you can simply vote through other mediums other than going to a polling station which can a) be quite time consuming and b) put people off of voting as many people have to vote once they have finished work and it is the last place they want to be at the end of their day. This would ensure stress free voting and give everyone an equal oppurtunity to make thier votes count. As you said in todays society younger people pay bills online instead of paying them in a post office etc. This insight allows us to look at the future and how is best convienient for the younger generation to not only encourage them to vote but also allow their voice to be heard by taking into consideration thier every day routines.
I like the Base of the Pyramid analogy and the idea that helping people at the base -- whether through education, poverty, distance or disability-- helps all.Nice brainstorming sessions, too.

i really like this idea, deepak.  i think variety of methods according to demographics is great approach to encourage participation. i would add that while younger generations lean toward electronic tools, older populations and those with limited access to technology may be more amenable to more traditional or different (non-e) mediums.  i think you're absolutely right that the 1-size fits all approach is not the way to go.  good work!

Hi Katie. Thanks for your appreciation. You are right about the  various approaches and also we will have to explore more on traditional ways of voting medium, because we can not depends too much on technology. Still there is very large section of the society who still prefers doing things in traditional manner. We can look into this opportunity. I am sure we will figure out the various mediums where people are muchmore  comfortable.

using_internet_banking_as_a_portal_to_vo.description: Online voting offers myriad advantages but the authentication of the voter is a hurdle. This proposal suggests that online banking, used by many in the Western world, offers a convenient portal to an online voting website.
using_internet_banking_as_a_portal_to_vo.creator: 165f07a46a57ca122317ea58425e4214

comments.text: Interesting thoughts, James! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add the posts you mention in your Virtual Team field to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get email notifications and are likely to come and join the provocative conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)
Done! :)

I like where you are going with this, however, I have a few more issues that I can foresee. Hypothetically, anyone can access anyone else's online bank account and vote for them. For instance, my father has access to my online account and he could easily go in and vote for me and my actual vote be excluded. There is no way to know if the person behind the screen is actually the actual account owner. In the public voting booth method, there is someone there to verify that you are who you say you are by confirming it with your ID. Here that certification is lost. In addition, banks are privately owned corporations. The banks wouldn't be fond of the government coming in to their online accounts and monitoring the system like you describe. There would need to be an extensive amount of programming and security measures used to successfully separate the government from the online banking accounts. I would think the individual would also feel a bit wary about allowing the government such control, even if the government officials were not interested in the bank accounts of the online voting populace. There is a high level of suspicion when speaking about anyone associated with the government and to seemingly allow them access to some of your most private and personal information would make some people cringe. There is also the question of whether or not the fact that the banking industry is a private industry would in any way inhibit the execution of this idea. What I mean to say is that the government and the private industries have always been relatively separate in their operations (with some clear exceptions). If you propose mixing them in something so personal as voting, the implications could be disastrous. At best, it would receive insane amounts of criticism and garner heavy skepticism, adding fuel to the political fire and starting up heated debate about whether or not your vote was counted. While I understand that you tried to solve this with the video camera, there unfortunately will still be skeptics who espouse ideas of discrimination and voter fraud.

The identification verification for this method is equivalent to a vote by mail ballot (no photo ID is checked, no one is "really" sure who cast the vote in the envelope.) We have decided however that that fraud threats are relatively minor in comparison to the convenience gained, as evidenced by the fact that a few states have moved to all voting by mail. (And frankly, voting doesn't reward anyone strongly enough to be worth committing the fraud. In other words, if someone with a slightly devious side has access to your bank account online it is a safe assumption that the contents of the bank account will be more interesting than the person's ballot.) The pass through of information from bank to government isn't all that sophisticated, it's no more complex than what is already done now when the bank reports interest earnings to the IRS. I have thought about the suspicions involved with the intertwining of banking and elections. A lot of people don't trust their banks, a lot of people don't trust the government and the mix together is ugly. We already see this with the deep distrust of voting machine companies. I guess that the solution is paper ballots cast in person or via mail for the untrusting. (This is offered here in Ohio--people can always cast a paper ballot and avoid the voting machine. In fact boards of elections spend huge amounts of money printing up paper ballots that almost no voter chooses to use.)

While it's a very good point that online banking requires several authentication procedures, making it one of the more secure activities we perform online, many individuals do not have any sort of bank account at all. (This is why check cashing businesses exist. If everyone had a bank account then they could just go to their bank to cash a check or deposit it.) A report by the FDIC a few years ago concluded that 7.7% of households do not have any bank accounts whatsoever! And minorities are represented disproportionately among those households. (In fact, this topic might be a good topic for a future OpenIDEO challenge.) http://www.fdic.gov/householdsurvey/executive_summary.pdf

I have had this thought and I admit that this particular proposal misses out on the unbanked. Then again, there are a lot of people who have bank accounts who decline or unable to use internet banking.

The Pokemon image refers to the choosing/electing of the preferred Pokemon for that particular scenario.Truthfully I don't like the cartoon. I never could get into cartoons which were based around violence, regardless of the cuteness of the characters. But...is Pokemon a child's first introduction to the idea of an election? Can Pokemon be used as a way of teaching children about political elections? Would candidates/parties benefit from campaigning using Pokemon metaphors as a way of getting in touch with younger voters who grew up on Pokemon? Discuss.

using_internet_banking_as_a_portal_to_vo.title: Using internet banking as a portal to voting online

comments.text: Thanks for this particular insight.Sounds like 'wild' is a very good word to describe the US system.There are many areas in which differences occur between states in Australia but regular meetings of politicians from each state sees more and more agreement on issues. For elections, while some differences remain, the process is sufficiently similar for people to be able to work in any jurisdiction. Clear, consistent and reliable advice and educational materials are available directly from state and federal departments.

Thanks for your comments, Paul! Since you compare Australian & the US systems,  I'm curious to hear your insight on Australia's compulsory voting. Do you think this affects politicians willingness agree since they know nearly all of their constituents will head to the polls? It's hard to imagine compulsory voting in the US, though I assume it would bring a different climate to Capitol Hill given this increased voter engagement. What do you think?

election_protection_volunteer_based_poll.title: Voter Empowerment & Poll Monitoring to Protect Voters' Rights

comments.text: Dan, after reading your post, I just realized that I never have to decide where to vote! In Taiwan, voters have their designated polling station - they can only go to that station to mark their votes.
Why isn't this happening already?  It's very straight forward and should be easy to execute and integrate into any idea for voting.

I guess that things are changing fast in terms of the channels through which people seek and receive information. It used to be via more broadcast channels (tv + radio + newspapers) and perhaps directly via one's local community. Now many of us go to a variety of places to get info  from social media to the internet, etc. A great prompt for the upcoming Concepting phase to explore multiple channels for dissemination of election information.

It is happening in some places - when i visit the Australian Electoral Office site I can search for polling places near to my home or work. They provide a google map of polling places, their addresses, how far away they are and whether they have wheelchair access http://www.ehoundplatform.com/Services/Map/AEC these are updated in good time before every election.

comments.text: Thank you for sharing this concept -- I can tell a lot of energy went into these ideas. You might want to think about what parts of this idea election officials can use right now to make elections better given their very limited budgets and resources. For example, is there something here that can be implemented by the November 2012 elections?

@Daniel Thanks for your feedback , I can understand the amount of energy that has gone into some of these ideas for the past 3-5 yrs through a quick glance at the papers in the ITIF website. If the objective is to look for quick wins for Nov 2012 elections , then we need to look at those ideas that are easier to implement and also solve top priority issues of different stakeholders. Given this short time frame my perspective is to prioritize the stake holders first (Citizens, Govt, Elections officials .. ) and then to prioritize their issues and then to map the ideas to these issues and analyse to identify/filter the low hanging fruits by setting criteria based on the available budget and resources, impact magnitude, Complexity to implement etc . Post this, action plan starts on roll-out planning.  If any of these ideas are already implemented but failed, then quick analysis on the reasons of failure can be done if they are repairable given the multi-dimensional constraints then they are the immediate wins ... e-voting in India is a good case study, when they first announced e-voting i just didn't believe this will work but it worked.

easy_button_feedback_for_polling_station.creator: 40e1dfdf10b0366612f767976bdd277d

comments.text: I like this concept as well. I do have a few questions.1.) If a particular voting station did well in the survey system, how would they be rewarded, i.e. what is their incentive to do well? or rather, what is their incentive to not do poorly? 2.) Since voting only takes place every 4 years, there would be no way to immediately reward a successful voting station.3.) For voting stations which get a lot of traffic, the survey results would report more average, normally distributed data about the experience, because there is a larger population, whereas the opposite might be true for voting stations without a large influx of people. 4.) Because of the brevity of the voting time period, there would be no appreciable way to tabulate the results, inform the voting stations of the results, AND correct any problems with voting stations. Voting stations are set up to facilitate the submission of opinions on various governmental matters and elect politicians. These have to be meticulously counted. By adding more opinion-based submissions, i.e. the surveys, the government would need to fund the hiring of more workers to sort through them as well. While this idea seems like a good one, it unfortunately does not appear very cost-effective.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Laura - this sort of approach is used extremely successfully in many organisations to drive changes in behaviors and may powerful in this challenge. As you build on this you may want to think about:1) As well as the real-time element, how could this data be used effectively after the election, e.g., high performing stations could be identified to figure out what they did particularly well (as could the less well performing to determine what was not so great)2) Care needs to be taken in how this is designed as there is always a risk that you can drive the wrong type of behaviors (e.g., people staffing the polling stations that are not doing well at any stage may feel demoralised and less confindent)

Great stuff, Lara! You might also want to update your concept to give your thoughts on the optional fields about resources, adaptability, etc. within the Concepting form. This will also provide a way for you to add the MIT brainstormers to your virtual team ;^) It's great to let others know about your group by filling out this field.

Laura, I love the competition aspect of this. The successful adoption of electronic health records in some European countries was similarly driven by a competition-based model where doctors shared how "digital" their offices were and competed against each other.I like the idea of creating a real-time feedback system so that voters can share their problems and election officials can take action. I'd like to see how this can encourage not only competition, but also accountability. How do you know who is "in charge" of a poll site?  I'm thinking of something like the photo with the "Hi, I'm the manager." that you see at some fast food restaurants.I'd encourage you to think about the costs involved in this and how to maximize benefit/minimize cost for election officials.I look forward to seeing where you take your concept.

I agree with Daniel. I think having real-time feedback will be very useful. It would be great to provide polling places with information from votes on how improve things like the overall experience and accessibility!

Ha, this would be great for certain other governmental functions/agencies, such as the DMV (Department of Motor Vehicles). Make it a friendly competition, with bonus recognition & prizes.My one recommendation would be to keep this real-time feedback short and sweet to make it easy to give, interpret, and act on. I.E., a general satisfaction/net promoter question (e.g."Would you recommend this polling place to a friend?" on a scale of 1 to 5), followed by a qualitative Why/Why Not?).

easy_button_feedback_for_polling_station.title: Easy button feedback for polling stations

web_surfing_reading_documents_with_blind.description: What's it like to use a computer if you're impaired by blindness? Screen readers are often used to facilitate activities like reading and web surfing. Learn how it feels to use a screen reader by watching this video.
web_surfing_reading_documents_with_blind.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Thanks Vincent! Very thought provoking video!Reminds me of providing computer support to one of our blind clerks in the Australian Taxation Office about 25 years ago. Of course that was before the web was in common use but the challenges of using screen readers with word processors seem substantially the same now as then. The reliability of the text to speech has improved and I don't remember the capacity to describe formatting features in the early version of Kurzweil Reader we were using.The anecdote regarding forms and the placement of instructions illustrates the importance of involving people with a range of disabilities in the design process. Although empathetic thinking can go a long way there is no real substitute for feedback from disadvantaged users.
Great that you've chosen to feature this as a dedicated Inspiration post, Vincent  and tease out some of highlights.
Vincent- Thanks for this contribution. This is new tech to me and it interestingly tackles some core components. In general, I agree with Ramanand that we have a ways-to-go!

After I read this, I looked at how blind voters are currently treated in India. Turns out that by default, disabled voters are allowed to take in a companion with them who can carry out the actual voting on their behalf. But it seems the Election Commission of India is also trying a system with new electronic voting machines which are Braille-enabled, by simply putting a Braille strip next to each candidate name, thus allowing a blind voter to participate on his own. From what I see, the actual system is still a little clunky, but I thought that was a start.

stop_fraud._make_sure_absentee_ballots_g.description: According to the award-winning blog, Eye on Miami, theft of absentee ballots is a huge problem. Because many people who need accessible voting use absentee ballots, this may disproportionately affect these voters.
stop_fraud._make_sure_absentee_ballots_g.creator: a43aee6b398af0c5dd808ea1e975f9de

comments.text: It is common practice back home to see thos in power producing voters cards for those in villages and relatives, then  getting people to vote for them.

Yes fraud and vote buying is common practice in countries where fundamental controls over the voting process are difficult to either put in place or oversight. It is not easy to think of solutions to this that dont involve some sort of popular uprising or revolution.

Very interesting story.I suspect theft of absentee ballots happens here in Australia too but the laws are quite specific here. In these circumstances she would have had automatic right to a provisional ballot and in fact polling staff would have been entirely familiar with her rights. To avoid just this type of problem absentee ballots will not be opened until cross-matching with provisional ballots has been completed and conflicts resolved. Theft of ballot papers is of course a criminal offence (felony) although prosecutions are rare.Sometimes, of course, absentee, postal and provisional votes will be insufficient to alter the outcome

This brings up the importance of security, as well as backup procedures in place if it's compromised, as Paul gave the Australia example of. Thanks for this inspiration Ginny! Ensuring a fair vote and that people aren't disenfranchised must be a priority.

stop_fraud._make_sure_absentee_ballots_g.title: Stop fraud. Make sure absentee ballots get to voters.

comments.text: Definitely, showing good examples to inspire more disabled to believe they will be able to vote seems a good way forward!
Great point, Alex  awareness is a significant part of the mix!

This is such an important point. People can't use things they don't know about! As William Gibson said "The future is already here, it's just not evenly distributed."We all adopt technology and try new things at different paces. It's easy to think that because the iPhone is accessible, everyone who is blind will have one. But of course, there are people who don't want one, or can't afford one, or don't want to have to learn how to interact with a new type of technology. Some of the other inspirations talks about the value of social networks in supporting all sorts of activities. There are already some good projects... looking forward to thinking about building on them to be even more effective in including everyone in elections.

comments.text: Nice one, Gabrielle! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add the concepts that influenced you to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get email notifications and are likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

Gabriella, When I read this, I saw it as an interesting build on my Ballot Navigator concept. I like the way it breaks the ballot into explorable chunks, and the way is blends voter ed/info with making choices. I'd love to see this developed a little more, and am especially intrigued by being able to use a tool that already exists.Could you add a link to the CAST book builder?

Yes, it certainly would! All of your concepts are wonderful. Even better than book builder, this new (still in development) UDL site goes a bit beyond book builder but has all the concepts of it wrapped in.  You can still make a book builder book and much more from it: http://udlstudio.cast.org/

hi, I'm not an expert but went to check CAST book builder and it seems that this could be a great resource to build the book. I just wanted to ask you a question (as I'm still a paper book reader): can this ebook be read on various platforms / devices? I am not familiar with the American election process and I'm still unclear why the voting process seems to be so complicated, but based on this assumption, it seems, Gabrielle, that your concept is extremely useful and relevant.

Agreed AL and the fit between this potential teaching tool and Whitney's Ballot Navigator is a natural. Looking at the companion BookBuilder ( http://bookbuilder.cast.org/ ) it seems it will be possible to create a book that can be read using a browser offline. However having downloaded one book consisting of a large number of files I failed to satisfactorily read it offline but could read the original online I will persevere however as I think there is potential for this as a collaborative tool in the broader OpenIDEO context too.As for understanding US election processes I think some of the fresh ideas emerging here, such as Whitney's Mark Anywhere concept http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/mark-anywhere/ represent a sensible and fundamental rethink of the process. The sticking point in all of this seems to be limited capacity for collaboration and consensus.
Also AL you might find this UDL link of interest http://www.udlcenter.org/implementation/postsecondary

Book Builder and other UDL tools are super helpful in the arena of representation, but the ballot E-book would need something like Whitney's 'Mark Anywhere' to make sure it is also universally accessible.

Hi Gabrielle, thanks for sharing this great concept! I especially like how you've emphasized the importance of universal design. As we wrap up the Concepting phase, you might want to check out our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be designed to meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve. You can make updates to your entry at any time using the Update Entry button up there on the right.

comments.text: This a great, simple story that pinpoints a serious problem.  In particular it makes me cautious of the potential in using online or  electronic forms of voting.  What does your own story tell you about voting with a printed/manufactured ballot versus an electronic one?

Thanks Campbell. Agreed about the importance of security, and thus the caution that must be employed when exploring new solutions (and in evaluating current implementations). But, an electric ballot isn't necessarily less secure than a physical one (which as my story demonstrates, has its own security issues). Yes, if a digital system is implemented improperly, there's certainly potential for widespread fraud at a level unlikely to occur for a more granular physical system. However, I think smart design can close up many of the loopholes, perhaps including such measures as a backup physical paper trail audit. Certainly something to explore for the concepting phase of this challenge.
Via your personal story, you've raised this issue of trust very engagingly here. Nice one, Vincent.
Really great insights here  thanks for sharing your personal experience!

use_your_bank_or_doctors.description: Local banks and healthcare centres are places that most people are familiar with and which have to deal with accessibility issues in their daily business already.  They also know how to handle personal information securely.
use_your_bank_or_doctors.creator: 892697246445cbe553182766b6ef4653

comments.text: This is a really good idea. I completely agree that the disabled would really need to be focused on during  the voting process. Having them be able to vote at their local clinic or banks will really increase the conviency for these people. I suggest expanding the places to everywhere that may have a large amount of people such as community centers and evn recreational centers.

I especially like the idea of using healthcare centres as voting and voter education locations. Building on the providers of healthcare angle, It might be helpful to look at the locations where flu shots (or flu jabs, as they're called in the UK) are offered during flu season. In addition to healthcare centres, they're offered in schools, banks, pharmacies, workplaces, community centres, libraries, etc -- places meant to be accessible and convenient for a large number of people. Bryant, some really good points about the benefits of movie theaters, particularly for capacity and accessibility. Plus, popcorn! There's still time to add it as a separate concept -- it has legs, I think.

On a similar note, what about movie theaters as information centers and polling places?  Although they aren't normally used for dealing with sensitive information like banks and health centers, theater settings would provide existing infrastructure for visual dissemination of voting information, accessibility, and high volume traffic (for both cars and people).  One of the key challenges in creating a successful election experience is ensuring that the public is making well-informed decisions.  Movie theaters would be able to provide high-level, visual information about major issues like policies, candidates and their platforms, and the voting process itself.  Instead of movies, these different categories of information could be shown in different theater rooms within the same building. Voters would be able to freely choose the type of information to get a better understanding of, with showtimes listed for easy scheduling.  These showings could help improve large-scale public knowledge and also cater to citizens whose first language is not English with subtitles or translated videos.Movie theaters also already incorporate other aspects of accessibility that can be taken advantage of.  For example, wheelchair accessibility is common.  Handicapped individuals would be able to park close to the location and enter any of the informational viewings previously discussed.  Those with hearing disabilities could utilize videos with English subtitles, while those with visual disabilities could be escorted to and from viewings, listening to the information presented.  Theaters also have public restrooms and food amenities that can be provided to allow voters to stay in the same location and spend as much time as necessary to understand the election information.  Once comfortable with details of the elections, voters could return to a lobby converted into a polling place, allowing a continuous flow of learning and voting.The ability to accommodate a large volume of people within a movie theater would improve convenience and also strengthen citizens as a community.  Many voters would be able to create their own schedules to learn political issues that they did not have the time or resources to evaluate on their own.  Since many major theater buildings also have ample space, benefits of this project could reach many more voters without disturbing the important functions of institutions like banks or hospitals.  It also is possible a theater could become a hub for discussion and create a sense of community.  Groups of voters could attend informational showings together and motivate their families/friends to join them.  As a result, interest, participation, and overall success of the election process could improve.

Hello everyone!  Thank you very much for for the encouraging words.  I'm brand new to this and thought I might get notified of comments... so I'm glad I came back to have a look!  Gwaenelle, I also really like your idea about using these trusted locations as an opportunity for education.  Restating the importance of voting and making participants feel truly valued is an element that shouldn't be lost sight of, especially for those who may see themselves as more generally disenfranchised by society in other areas.Will keep a better eye on this and hopefully many more conversations to come :)

Hi Sienna, I just came across your message  it sounds like you're not receiving your email notifications? You should receive notifications, assuming your profile settings are set correctly. Check your preferences (via your profile page), and if you're still not receiving email notifications of new comments even after verifying your settings, send us an email via the 'support' tab at the left. We're happy to take a look!

I see the potential of this concept as it relies on trusted organisations that people are familiar with and they visit frequently - healthcare centres especially if they need medical support and have regular visits-.However, I still see a problem on the lack of engagement. Just by offering the facility to vote from local areas doesn't necessarily mean they will consider doing it. This should be complemented with an emphasis on the social compromise of voting and creating a space for people to think, e.g. emphasising the new voting facilities in healthcare waiting rooms and little reminders that prompt people to evaluate their thinking towards candidates. Overall setting the basis for an education towards the voting system.

I agree that education is an important issue, particularly emphasising the importance of civic duty, but that is a general issue aside from accessibility, even before accessibility in fact.In the context of those with special needs, the worry that those needs would not be met is probably a major barrier and that is what this concept seeks to address primarily, although some benefits spill over to the wider community.Addressing voter apathy by making use of 'spaces to think' is a very interesting point that you make. **Perhaps there is a comms design issue that could be investigated here...?**Perhaps like little posters, stickers or tokens in select places with something short (like 5 points or an acronym maybe) that could sink into people's minds for them to contemplate.
By the way, Ana, Gwenaelle makes a similar point in her comment below - perhaps you both may have a shared interest in that area?

I like how you really thought about the voter and how they might have needs that need to be met in order for them to vote. In the UK especially there is a problem for people who are in hospital at the time of a vote or election for them to vote appropriately and also for their votes to beable to get to the place they need to be on time in order for them to be counted. This idea really embraces the users needs and will ensure they are able to vote if they wish to.The idea of allowing people to vote in a place which they visit on a regular basis and  close to where they live allows the user to easily access thier voting stations and will hopefully cut down the amount of traffic and foot fall which especially in the past uk election angered people as they were unable to vote as there were simply too many people and not enough voting stations, but by using this method it would create more places for people to register and vote.The only down side to this idea is data protection, I know that it is a funny topic and in some cases might stop people from being able to share or access their information at banks or doctors.Also another place which would be good to look at is the post office, many people access this every day and it is already used to pay bills  etc so would be an ideal location for people to vote at, there is also alot of post offices about so people wouldnt have to look to far for their nearest polling station and it would also cut down the footfall allowing everyones votes to be considered.

Hi Martine.  I initially was going to include the Post Office as I very much agree with you - and am from the UK - but wanted to describe a more general idea that could be applied around the world.  Of course each country is different, but banking and healthcare seemed like universal issues accessed in the same ways. Data protection is also a universal issue.  What I had in mind, however, is something like the Swedish system where one identity number is enough to access a range of services by relying on a pooled source of personal data which is shared across those services.  We are fairly anti personal ID cards or numbers in the UK - and in the developing world many may not have the use of such systems - but I really think that putting data in one place so it doesn't have to be repeatedly supplied, which creates more hassle and admin for everyone, could be a way to increase engagement in civic activities and make life easier for those with disabilities.  Questions: Is this idea possible in the context of voting without a pre-existing system..?  How can admin be cut down for everyone's sake?

Nice one guys! Takes me back to this great post from the Inspiration phase: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/atms-are-quite-accessible/ Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add that post to your Build Upon feature. That way the person who wrote it will get an email notification and is likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

I like how you thought about location but also the practices associated to it. Two other concepts you might want to check: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/vote-anywhere/and http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/polling-day-s-every-day.-vote-when-you-can-when-you-want-during-any-period-of-an-election-term./
Thanks for that, Anne-Laure :)
Excuse me, it seems I got excited and typed before reading around the site to see that my idea was already suggested.

No problem Shaun: The more, the merrier on OpenIDEO! Be sure to check out the conversations and concepts in our challenge, and of course you're always welcome to build on the ideas of others and add your own concept too. You may also want to check out the New User Forums too: http://bit.ly/new_users to learn a bit more about how we work together on our challenges for social good. Hope to see more of you on OpenIDEO!
sounds good I've started reading, thanks for your advice.

I love the concept of establishing voting systems in places that people already visit on a routine basis. Not only would this benefit those with accessibility issues but the institutions themselves would benefit from the added traffic. If a business has a polling station they then might also be incited to run promotions during that time, maybe increasing voter turnout overall? What do people think about expanding to less secure locations like gas stations and corner stores and compensating with higher security polling technology? In my mind right now (totally getting ahead of myself) is a secured disability-friendly polling unit at your local Starbucks with the gas attendant additionally required to go a process like what a notary public goes through.
I like the way you are thinking about what makes a location suitable for use as a polling place.

Hmm...I think you're definitely onto something here Sienna, particularly in regards to banks providing one of the more secure forms of online identity (especially when compared to the weak identity verification of most social networks).

I think that being able to vote in locations such as these is potentially very valuable. Maybe cash points could be used, people are naturally given space at these locations which is conducive to placing your vote. Banks could provide additional covers to shield them during an election. You have the benefit of voting in a secure way, withdrawing cash, and maintaining transparency over your actions.

I like this a lot - I think you can go beyond accessibility and also educate people in these places as you build the trust that already exists (at lease for the healthcare centre) I think you could also use schools to vote and educate the voting communities.

comments.text: Hi Avi, you may want to think about how your idea would address issues such as voter privacy.  Also, you may want to consider the needs of election officials. How can this system enable them to be sure that a person is eligible to vote in a particular election (e.g. where they live, citizenship, etc.)?  How can this system enable an efficient post-election audit to verify the results?

Thanks for the insightful feedback Daniel! Of course, this concept would only work in a (relatively) non-corrupt democracy which is why the voting occurs only through a secure website run by the election commission. Existing online governmental services provided to the citizen could be leveraged to establish and protect voter identity. Maybe a special private section of youtube could be allocated to handle the massive video upload bandwidth requirements on election day.The system will work only if every uploaded video can be accessed if needed by authorized election officials to determine absence of fraud. The recorded video is itself the deterrent against misuse.
Agree with Daniel, there is potential in the technology but the privacy might be a problem, how to ensure privacy and voters are not under pressure when voting?

Cardboard to the rescue! How about an individual privacy screen made out of cardboard with the candidates, parties and voting video confirmation instructions printed on it with user-friendly icons? You use it even if you are alone as a symbolic act of privacy while voting.

I wonder if a similar recognition tool could be implemented for blind voters. Perhaps a recording of the candidate stating their name or stating their platform would be a helpful aural memory trigger, just like a symbol or picture is for sighted people.

Hi Rachel,Tying in with what you said, I was also thinking about videos with sign language. In Europe, many channels (including QVC, hahaha) have a small screen in the corner with someone doing sign language.These are just some examples, or rather, inspirations to add to a more inclusive voting experience to all. a_primer_on_3d_printing.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: this will blow your mind, but there is discussion about how such a technology can "print" buildings (using concrete etc.). i have used 3d printers before... they are more addictive than [insert your favorite vice here]. in terms of elections, it is nice to get a 3D view of each candidate; not just the branded version that we see on commercials, but the real deal. social networking seems to have the power to render this missing 3rd dimension.
What if we could print more accessible polling stations?! :) I like where you're going with your comments Kirk  we might just have a concept on our hands!

Hmmmm, I like crazy ideas! I saw 3D printers used at the SIGGRAPH conference last year in a fun way; visitors to this booth (I forget the name of the company) could edit a 3D model of a dog tag with either their name or a message on it, then have it sent to the machine where you could watch it print out. It was a cool twist on conference swag by giving visitors something really unique.Playing off that application of the technology, what if 3D printers were used to give people a physical token after their ballot is scanned - like a personalized receipt along the lines of the classic "I Voted" sticker? Following the classic rule of feedback in human-computer interaction (that essentially says a user should get some kind of response after making an input or any kind), the personalized token could reassure people that yes - their vote was indeed counted and here's a little something to commemorate it.
Very cool thinking here, Mike! I like the direction you're heading in :)

as much as I like those crazy ideas, I am equally thrilled about the amazing video images I remember from Iraq's first democratic election, when people, senior citizens came out from polling stations and proudly held up their purple-coloured index finger, in victory sign, as proof that they been casting their vote for the very first time in their life.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1wP_s-asMKQ
So true Johan, those images are incredibly powerful and inspiring.
Great post! Why does voting how to be flat and 2D experience? Definitely got me thinking about the how physical layout, booths and voting devices could be improved upon in a unique way.
I'm so happy to hear this inspired your thinking!

mobile_phones_tablets_2013_the_voting_ma.creator: aa7f3ef276d58c7ab6d87bc3bb2dc40e

comments.text: What about poor people like me on a fixed income?  I'm on SSI disability and can't afford to upgrade.  Even if I get a used 3G or 4G phone off Ebay, I'd still have to pay more $$ to my cellphone service provider to use this technology.  I've been with Sprint for almost a decade.  I've shopped around and my old-school voice-only service is the cheapest in my region area (without incurring increased dropped calls or poor reception).  Your idea has merit, but it should be incorporated with my idea of allowing online voting.  A registered voter would access the internet using their cellphone, then enter their SS number as their user_names,  their date of birth as the password, then their zip code and registered full name as additional layers of security.

The people at Mobile Voices (see my inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/accessitiblity-through-community-story-sharing-mobile-voices/) have developed their project to run on regular cell phones rather than smart phones.

Tony, you've raised some great questions for us to think about, especially as we move into Concepting and think about various constraints that might impact our ideas. For now, while we're still in Inspiration, let's stay broad and open to any stories, existing technologies or innovations that might help spark our thinking. Clearly mobile technology is a common theme in our conversation, but as you say, it might not be the only way to make elections accessible. I'm looking forward to seeing how this conversation develops!

Mobile devices can be supplied at voting and polling locaitons too. It is not mandated that they be "owned' by those with accessiblity issues, although most with disabilities rely on their mobile devices and have upgraded phones. That said, there are solutions that can also be enabled on feature phones but not an optimal experience. Lots of innovation and technologies to be explored and much is possible. Mobile is our future, becase it can be made much more secure then the desktop internet frought with problems we all know too well regarding security.

You might be surprised to know how many polling places there are in a typical US county. LA County, for example, has over 4,300. But, even in my small town, with just one polling place and three districts, there can be lines first thing in the morning, at lunchtime, and around dinner time.
