comments.text: Dear Partner,Greetings!Those who accept colonialism do not believe in justice for all!Now that we know that the political parties will not solve this problem, I invite you to join the non-violent protest to demand that the United States (US) decolonize Puerto Rico (PR) immediately.  It will be on Monday, June 17, 2013 from 8 AM to 5 PM outside the United Nations (UN) visitors entrance located on 46th Street and First Avenue in New York City.The UN has determined that colonialism is a crime against humanity in 1960 under Resolution 1514 (XV).  Thats why the UN celebrates every year a hearing about Puerto Rico decolonization.  Every year the UN puts forth a resolution asking the US to decolonize PR.  Despite 30 of these resolutions, PR is still the oldest and most populated colony in the world!  It is obvious by now that the US is not going to decolonize PR just because the UN asks. Through education, we must create a domestic and international solidarity with this cause to pressure the US to do what historically she has refused to do.  This is why we need everyone who also believes that colonialism is a crime against humanity to join the protest to demand compliance to international law!Puerto Rico has been a colony of the US for 114 years.  The US intention is to keep PR a colony forever unless we do something about it.  It is important to note that: democracy isnt what a government does.  Democracy is what people do!  President John F. Kennedy said, Those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable.  Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said, Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice anywhere.  These ideas, of course, are the reasons why the United Nations was created after World War II.It is up to us to defend the fundamental human rights that promote world peace.  The tragedy of doing nothing is that we will have the kind of government that we deserve! Sincerely,Jos M. Lpez SierraFor more information:   www.TodosUnidosDescolonizarPR.blogspot.comCompaeros Unidos para la Descolonizacin de Puerto Rico
Clearly they're doing something right with that level of voter registration and turnout! I love it!

turning_colors_into_sounds_and_vice_vers.description: Neil Harbisson is an artist who suffers achromatopsia, a condition that only allows him to see in black and white. But with his ‘eyeborg’ he translates colors into sounds, and vice versa. Why not use sounds and colors to develop another voting?
turning_colors_into_sounds_and_vice_vers.creator: 48d6d8aa667f1b277685a45e31683b98

comments.text: Your interesting inspiration made me think of a neurological phenomena called synesthesia that improves metaphorical thinking: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SynesthesiaA found a great explanation in this video: Synesthesia: A film by Jonathan Fowler http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a3DbScY8AisI also recommend anyone to have a look at the Ted talk about the brain: he talks about synesthesia from 17:30 down the talk.http://www.ted.com/talks/vilayanur_ramachandran_on_your_mind.htmlThink this is inspiring and maybe it can inspire to present voting information and communication in a more understanding way.

Hi Jakob. This is really interesting, it made me look with different eyes (or ears hehe) my senses and wonder about things like for example why do we experience flavours only with food.  In the TED talk, the speaker says that actually we are all synesthesics because we 'see sounds', or we attribute shapes to sounds. That's interesting because it suggests me that synesthesia can be boosted in ourselves by opening our minds, trying to not be influenced for what we know as established (I don't know if this is true scientifically, but that's the impression I got).Another thing I found inspring about synesthesia is that it makes me realize how different perceptions can be. I always thought and tried to discuss with people, about how do we see colors. For example, how do I know that what I call red is not your green? But that's very difficult to discover by talking. Now I see that it is proved that there are completely different perceptions in people, and I think that this can help us to put ourselves in other people's skin.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Thanks!

Hi Laura. Nice reminder of the importance of colours!Your inspiration reminded me of a project by a Portuguese designer called "ColorADD". It's a visual code designed for people who are colour blind. The project's website is in Portuguese (http://www.coloradd.net/index.asp), but you can download some information in English about the project in here: http://include11.kinetixevents.co.uk/4dcgi/prog?operation=author&id=1632
Oops! I forgot to say the designer's name: Miguel Neiva.
Hi Ana. Thanks for the information, interesting project and really makes us see how important are colors in our daily life. What happened with it? Is it going to be implemented in Portugal?

Hey, Laura. I don't know if the Government is thinking about implementing it, but I know some sectors in industry or healthcare have already adopted it. Miguel Neiva is putting a lot of effort into it becoming a widely spread code.

Nice inspiration reminding us how what we take for granted "colors" is not always so obvious. I also like the idea of translating colors in sounds and the possibilities it suggests for designing using several modes.

turning_colors_into_sounds_and_vice_vers.title: Turning colors into sounds, and vice versa

accessible_voting_experiences.description: Since 2004, Noel Runyan has kept notes on his experiences as a blind voter. Sometimes the system isn't set up; it has taken him over an hour to vote. He agreed to let me to post these notes as an example of how frustrating it can be.
accessible_voting_experiences.creator: 6bf4be9492d606d715c40af44de254e3

comments.text: It's amazing the seemingly small things that can actually be a big deal as far as accessibility.I've been in cold polling places before and, while I wasn't comfortable, it didn't affect my ability to vote.Noel, on the other hand, had to keep his 'braille fingers' in his pocket in order to maintain their sensitivity so they could read the ballot.  In other words, his ability to vote was directly affected by temperature!It's also eye-opening that his poll workers had to ask for special training to make sure they knew how to use the accessibility equipment since they knew he would be voting there.  It's great that they were willing to ask, but what if he moves to a new area or if he were a blind person that decided to vote at his local polling place for the first time?  It seems like the standard training should include training on all accessibility equipment to ensure that the poll workers are ready to go no matter who comes through the door!
Dear Jessica, very true,you have made a very good point here about training the staff for same.cheers.
Very informative inspiration Whitney. Really shows how frustrating the accessible voting experience can be without adequate poll worker training, as well as the limitations of the current machines.

This goes to the heart of the matter.A couple of years ago I was working in a Police and Citizens Youth Centre where they were running a program for 'at risk youth' automobile driving awareness. To allow the kids to gain a better understanding of the risks they engaged the services of a very brave 16 year old quadriplegic girl who could relate from personal experience the possible consequences dangerous driving habits.As Whitney points out elsewhere bringing disabled people into the process not only as voters but also as team members and trainers would greatly enhance accessibility. Setting up a polling place takes time and effort generally but employing someone like Noel to both test the equipment to ensure it is working properly and then assist others to use it seems a really good investment.I am not familiar with the specifics of US polling but I imagine that the process of identifying voters and the actual casting of the vote are well separated. Having someone like Noel 'on hand' to assist others would therefore in no way compromise the confidentiality of voting.Ironically over the six years covered in Noel's notes a comprehensive program of training and consistent assistance could have been developed for adoption around the country.

thanks for these insightful notes. As Jessica noted, it is incredible how things might be uncomfortable (like cold) can become a real issue. Back to another conversation about motivation it is incredible to see the motivation of Noel who keeps going to vote despite the lines and all the problems he encounters. It reminded me a conversation we started in another inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/voting-a-task-or-an-opportunity/as well as the inspiration with the video of everyday shopping trip in a wheelchair: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/think-a-wheelchair-user-s-daily-struggle/

accessible_voting_experiences.title: Accessible voting experiences

I like that there's a static and dynamic component to it - some of the information is there for basic background and details, and some of it changes over time (wait times, ratings for polling places etc). Speaking of ratings, your concept made me think a bit of Lucy's http://bit.ly/zTHFPe - perhaps you'd like to build upon her idea to connect the two?

Thanks Ashley.Lucy's concept popped up while I was developing this (as did her crowd sourcing concept). I will certainly build upon her concepts. I notice u have used bit.ly to shorten concept links - are there short forms of all concepts? I like being able to incorporate bb code in developing concepts and would find it useful for comments and replies too.

Great point Paul. I usually just use the bit.ly shortener as it helps to keep the comment field clean and tidy. But we were actually just talking as a team about enabling a link shortener in the rich text editor so that all links appear that way. It's definitely on our ever-growing list of new features :)

Great thinking, Paul. One thing you might want to check out is our Personas for Concepts tip sheet. It's a helpful outline of the kinds of accessibility needs we're designing for in this challenge: http://bit.ly/vote_personas. Perhaps you'll be inspired by one or more of the personas and have a think about how your concept could be further extended meet their needs? We're looking forward to seeing discussions flourish here and your ideas evolve.

Thanks Meena I already have some thoughts about using the personas but am in two minds whether to build further on this concept or build associated concepts. I am mindful of the way we read and access information these days where long articles can turn off participants. However I shall certainly attempt to incorporate elements related to some of the personas.My experiment of using Google docs as a collaborative tool has had limited success and while I think having OpenIDEO host a CMap Tools server would be a fantastic resource (a la social impact challenge) to complement the Collaboration Map I can at the moment only set them up, reference them and see if other IDEATORs respond.

mapping_accessability_rating_and_traffic.title: Mapping, Accessibility Rating and Traffic Reports.

elections_a_community_celebration.description: Let's experience elections as a public celebration in every community, just like New Years Eve!
elections_a_community_celebration.creator: aef124e5213d69dc35733683ab0e10e9

comments.text: So would this be similar to Straw Polls found in Iowa?
Hi Rondelle, the names of the candidates do not appear even if the number of votes are counted up. Is that what you were wondering?

This idea is brilliant. It changes the voting experience completely. Not only does it make the voting experience more enjoyable, the real time voting count will inspire people to get others to vote as well. It will be a more positive environment and also competitive, similar to watch a football game in a bar. This voting fair can last a few days until the actual voting day, so more people will be able to attend.

I'm really enjoying seeing the energy around this concept! Have you thought about how to incorporate the votes of people who must vote absentee, such as those who have difficulty leaving the home, may be out of town, live overseas or find crowds intimidating?  In particular, I'm wondering how you would incorporate this into your vote totals.  At the beginning?  At the end?You may also want to consider reporting turnout rather than election results.  Some countries prohibit reporting results (and even exit polling) until polls are closed. The concern is that there will be media-induced voter suppression where people don't vote because of what they hear on TV. For example, voter's might decide not to vote because they think their candidate will win (or that their candidate is definitely going to lose).

I agree with you Daniel. It's nice to see the lively conversation and energy around this concept. Thanks also for the clarification regarding reporting results. For Cansu's purposes, reporting the turnout rather than election will work. However, I was wondering is it possible to start counting if you don't report them officially. That could help bottle necks and reducing chances of errors - see the conversation on another concept http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/the-election-festival/ and Louise's comment. Yet I can see why it cannot be officially reported. thanks.

Very nice concept and a lively conversation around it. I can see it nicely integrated with the election festival concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/the-election-festival/The election festival is focusing on offering more time to people to vote, and thus making voting more accessible (more time for individual voting, more options, reducing lines and bottle necks) but it could be reinforced or accompanied with community events.

This is fantastic!  I'd love to see this as an annual celebration of neighborhood, taking place even when there is no election being held.  In the US we have a holiday right around election time, Veteran's Day.  How great would it be if every year, people took a day off to celebrate their communities, and then every other year took ownership by voting?!
Completely agree with transparency! http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/use-colour-and-transparency/(and I love your illustration!)
Thanks a lot! Great inspiration there.

Hey Cansu, i like the idea of having a children corner, is  a simple and effective idea. I don't know if its such a issue in American context , in India it would be very effective and moms can vote hassle free. The same was brought up by one of my interviewee Manjula  .http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/interview-with-my-cheerful-maid-manjula-/ .So what could we provide for kids, small dedicated corner for all the kids to get together and make friends, but young kids would need a caretaker !

Great, that the idea is supported by your inspiration:) Inside the corner, the best would be to have a small 'children's voting' section where they also practice voting for the head of their class, cheerleader, football team captain, etc. I was also a bit worried about the American context, but if this is held within the neighborhood and teachers take care of the kids, then should be fine. We can also be inspired by some completely isolated safe children's playgrounds, usually places in shopping malls: http://bit.ly/Aqrbs6

Seeing people in your community all together taking the time to vote, when it is truly a physical community event and celebration makes the value and importance of voting more personal and less abstract. An understanding that your vote could impact you and all the people around you. That's a powerful concept to understand. A New Years eve type party might be intimidating to certain citizens of varying disabilities, the hard of hearing don't like all the noise for example. Parents might need to bring their kids along. What if the concept of a celebration included it being a day where of picnics and state fair like events with various activities that allow for community interaction. Community theater does a play, local artists do a show, Representatives of local public service agencies are available to meet and greet and answer questions ie. fire truck and firefighters, water service providers, local grange representatives etc... Social media can come into play as well.

Hello Jaime, great point! Picnic is a great idea, and yes, it should appeal to all people.When I think of some city celebrations or parties, at least in my city, it makes some young people move from their neighborhood to the main square and create a big crowd. However, the voting event can encourage people to stay in their own neighborhood, vote there and interact with their neighbors. This kind of a local event can be accessible by people with obstacles, old and young people.

Great build Jaime! Here's another thought: what if this community celebration and togetherness could be nurtured throughout the election process, not just around the results? For instance, we saw some inspirations about people carpooling to their polling station. Might there be ways to help connect community members of different abilities and needs so that *everyone* can participate in the entire election experience?
In fact, I just realized that Ramanand has had a similar idea http://bit.ly/y0Cz9i  perhaps you'll want to build on his for your next concept! :)

Ashley, Jaime: good points. I especially like the idea about turning it into a community interaction day. In India, the authorities have tried things such as giving people a holiday the day of the elections, but sometimes find people leaving town for vacation :) So on most occasions, we have these on working days, thus making it harder for people to spend too much time around elections. However, there is immense interest during the day, which gets reflected in water-cooler talk, social networks, and neighbourly chat. Someway to harness this, to involve families and perhaps even help teach kids what elections are about would be immensely beneficial.

Hello! I am becoming more and more convinced about creating a fun celebrating event to attract people to participate and vote at the same time! I am a bit worried about leaving out people who really have to stay home:S May be we can not solve all the problems with a single solution:)

If the election is a celebration of public life, then why not use public resources to bring people out?  Police and FIrefighters could pick people up, school buses could run special routes (especially if it is a holiday or weekend), and regular public transit could be free.

Hi Darren thank you for the input! I was thinking that the events would ve at a walking distance. Since I do not live in USA, I do not know if such community events, state fairs are usually far.. are they?

Most community events in the US are usually driving affairs, I live in California, the state fair is about 2 hours away, by car.  Even the county fair is about 45 mins away by car.  The most accessible public space for most people is a school, which is usually walkable, unless people live in a very rural area.

How about the voting places? Are they held more locally? I guess it is better to have a couple of fairs in the state, rather than everyone living in the state gathering in a single fair. The voting event could be similar to a state fair, but it would be much smaller in each community.

Cansu: In India, instant counting is disallowed to avoid early trends from influencing voter choice. That said, I think it would be a great idea if at least count the no. of votes cast so far, and provide an effective way to broadcast that. In India, we only get the %age vote cast at the end of the day. Having that during the day may help push people to step out.
Love the idea of tallying the number of votes cast! That deals with one of the challenges of bringing a sense of unity to what is usually in the USA, a very politically divided day.

Ramanand I was also worried about instant counting of each party, but the party names do not have to be displayed. Imagine if you see that two parties are close, and you know that your vote can change things, then you would go there and vote! Showing the %is also a good idea..Then we can say '68% of the city voted already, how about you?' Thanks Jaime, creative ways to visualize these votes would really help voters understand how they have an impact on the overall process.
Yup - anonymous trends could probably work. And totally agree about creative visualizations to amplify individual impact.
Loving the bouncing off of each other's thoughts to develop these visualization ideas. Like where this is heading ;)

A lot of psychology research backs up the idea that discovering that many other people are doing something is a great persuader towards action. I think this is a great application of that. I wonder about showing percentages versus absolute numbers, though. If percentages tend to be low in elections, then seeing that 4,000 people already voted in your community might be more persuasive than seeing 40%.
That makes a lot of sense, Patrick.
Yes Partick, so it is for sure not good to display the percentage! How about '283910' people are left? May be that's also a bad idea?

I think displaying the number of people who have already voted is probably best - seeing that 1,000 people have voted sounds like a lot, even if the municipality has a population of 10,000. Kind of like how the government spending a billion dollars on something sounds like an enormous amount of money, even if it's really only a small fraction of the overall budget. As long as the absolute number feels high, people will probably feel social pressure to vote themselves.

comments.text: This concept touches on elements in several of the principles adopted by the L.A. County Voting Systems Assessment Advisory Committee.  In particular it appeals to flexibility, offering a variety of options (customized preferences), scalability and ease of use.  I think much of what you have outlined could be looked at in concert with other ideas for separating the voter/ballot interface from the ballot casting and tabulation process.  Thanks!

Hi Joshua, welcome to OpenIDEO and cheers for your concept! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you can go in and add Whitney's posts or anyone else's using the Build Upon feature. That way the people who inspired your concept will get an email notification and they're likely to come and join the conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :)

In order to enhance the voting experience it will be critical to increase these.
build_trust_in_the_system_and_achieve_co.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Great ideas.Trust is an extremely positive virtue we should all aim for.
Great highlight on trust via your personal insights, Paul!

color_coded_voting.description: With the use of community shuttle buses and color coding, there is less confusion in the voting process in terms of where to go and how to get there.
color_coded_voting.creator: f91f9c5f8d927116d939fe1c610870ef

comments.text: Great collaborative thinking guys! Just wondering  were you brainstorming as part of a student group?
thank you, yes we were.

Nice one! What university/class are you guys from? Was the brainstorm done in class or in an after class session? Always great for us to know how our community are participating in our challenges ;^) Hope to see more of y'all on OpenIDEO!
Would different colours of corn work?
no
Could you be more specific? Using corn you could accomplish the same results while using a renewable resource.
I'm not sure I understand what you want to use corn for.  Can you please explain further?
Hey guys - some good thinking here - see if you can hitch this to Accessibility Maps V2  http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/concepting/accessibility-map-v.2/ from Stefan Ritter

you_are...where.description: Shouldn't simple wayfinding be one of the most integral parts of voting? If you build it, no one will come if they can't find it.
you_are...where.creator: 3235e3e7b5e215043e3d5105fef47950

comments.text: You'd think they'd have an app for that =P
Nicely played.

I live in Clarendon Vale in Tasmania - in addition to publishing locations of polling places in newspapers all electoral authorities local state and federal maintain search pages such as this one http://www.ehoundplatform.com/Services/Map/AEC to help electors find the nearest polling places. When I put in my suburb I get a map with about 10 polling places and a list with their addresses, approximately how far away each is, and whether or not they have wheelchair access, Feel free to try Clarendon Vale Tasmania as search criteria to see what is provided.
Are voters not obliged to go to a specified location instead of one of choice or proximity? That's how it was for me in Canada and the UK.

Hi Joe,Although this challenge is finished - just to reply to you.Things are pretty much as you say in USA by all accounts but here in Australia we often have a choice of several voting stations depending on where we happen to be on voting day. Many of the voting stations will have a full copy of the electoral roll for the electorate, state or even the whole country so voters can be marked off and given the appropriate ballot. The rolls are maintained by the states which agree to reciprocal access for other states and the federal electoral office. It is well co-ordinated and works well.RegardsPaul

Hi Paul and Joe! Thanks so much for your comments. You are both correct that they are required to keep voting in the same location and/or update voters with the location. However, my polling station is on a university campus (my neighborhood happens to be next to a major university) and they constantly move the voting location on the campus due to construction, time of year, etc. So even with the "correct" directions I'm often led to a building that is closed with no signs pointing toward the correct location. As someone with a disability, walking is not always an easy task for me  so I wonder how frustrating it must be for someone with a truly debilitating condition.Cheers,+Katie

Thanks PaulI live in Australia to, but not a citizen yet (applying this year) so hope to be voting soon, although in the present circumstances, it may happen sooner than I'd prefer!The system you mention is great, and it should be in other places. where you get a choice rather than being forced to be at the one nearest home.

Great to hear Joe - and Welcome to OpenIDEOI'm not a citizen either just a long term permanent resident although I shall probably take on citizenship before I retire.The voting does vary a bit from state to state - I live in Tassie where we have moved to digital rolls on laptop for marking off voters - NSW may still be using paper rolls but I expect digital is only a whisker away.You might find this description from Greg Baker instructive it was an inspiration for this challenge ( http://www.openideo.com/open/voting/inspiration/what-we-ve-learned-from-a-century-of-better-than-99-turnout-in-australia/ )

Hi Katie! I can understand your frustration and, as you say, the greater frustration of those with disabilities - hopefully the outcomes of this challenge will make a difference to everyone's experience in the future. Sorry for conducting a bit if private banter here - I know there are other places for exchanging information but I'm averse to being treated as a marketing product. I have actually developed a prototype resources site for OpenIDEO with some social networking aspects, but its really just a response to some of the non-winning concepts. It's not exactly popular (to my knowledge only 2 ideators have looked at it at the moment) but you would be welcome to visit ( http://www.experiment.vacau.com )Love your latest (employment) inspiration too.
Thanks for taking a look.
It's great! Thanks for the feedback too!

too_elderly_to_vote.description: Many elderly citizens residing in nursing homes may not have the opportunity to vote due to lack of transportation, information, and support. Some individuals are even denied the right to vote as their facilities deem them incompetent.
too_elderly_to_vote.creator: 5a40e80a9499c04b55954e1f93ba8dfa

comments.text: Caitlin, this is a very informative video that shows the barriers of people in institutional settings. I hope this helps us think about how to design solutions that considers the realities of institutional care while respecting people's desire for independence.

dialogue_in_the_dark_empathy_through_exp.description: In Hamburg, Germany, there is a museum called Dialogue in The dark where you can experience the daily life of blind people.
dialogue_in_the_dark_empathy_through_exp.creator: 88a24f49777f8f698cfbd64b8a6d6da4

comments.text: Here you can see Andreas Heinecke speak about his project "Dialogue in the dark" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ApLYJ3sHxWA
Nice, and here's where you can experience it around the world: http://www.dialogue-in-the-dark.com/venues-worldwide/
Thanks for sharing I'll be in Milan in one week...hope I'll have the time to try, I might gather usefull insights! :)
You should go! It's unforgettable!

It is indeed an incredible experience. I went to the one in Paris more than 15 years ago and I still remember it. It is truly a way to put yourself in the others' shoes. What is nice is that more than highlighting what being blind means in terms of limitation, it makes you realize all the other senses you don't rely on.

Very positive idea. I know the restaurant in Paris, Dans le Noir (in the dark) where you experience your meal (along with being seated, paying the check etc...) in absolute darkness. It teaches you that very simple things we take for granted (like the position of the mouth) rely on our eyesight. This makes you reflect on each movement and action usually done automatically making you apreciate every second, every gesture etc..In the case of this challenge this experience could teach us how important voting is, making each voter meditate in the darkness on the importance of his decision/his vote.
It's unforgettable!

I went to the one in Atlanta, GA, USA about a half year ago. It was an unforgettable experience.  When you cannot see your other senses become better in use. The forest smells fresher, and the sounds of nature were louder and sensitive to ears.
I think they will open a new one in Barcelona too. This project is in expansion and it's good because it causes lot of changes in people's attitude.
Its nice to know about this Alex! Thanks for sharing!

dialogue_in_the_dark_empathy_through_exp.title: Dialogue In the Dark, Empathy through experience.

partner_with_home_delivery_meal_services.description: Partner with home delivery meal services, such as Meals on Wheels, which provide daily hot meals to low income and mobility impaired individuals. Set up a process where voting ballots are delivered and picked up with meal delivery.

Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section in this post as a way to think about how you might build on this with even more relevant inspiration: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO!
